<h1 align="center">Course 10: Chemical Engineering<br>Spring
2014</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://web.mit.edu/cheme/"><i>Course 10 Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course10.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=++10&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>10.00-10.899</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m10b.html">10.90-10.999 plus THG, THU, UROP, UPOP</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<a name="10.01"></a>
<p><h3>10.01 Ethics for Engineers
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Begins with a survey of case studies that illustrate ethical problems in engineering. Case studies include written analyses and films that address engineering disasters, biotechnology, court cases, ethical codes, and the ultimate scope and aims of engineering. Second part of the term focuses on fundamental readings taken from Aeschylus, Sophocles, Aristotle, Plato, Machiavelli, Bacon, Descartes, Franklin, Jefferson, Madison, Tocqueville, Kass, the Bible, and others. Includes short, weekly analyses of readings, oral assignments, and discussions in and out of class.
<br><I>D. Doneson, B. L. Trout</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.03"></a>
<p><h3>10.03 Advances in Biomanufacturing
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); second half of term
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m10a.html#10.53">10.53</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 1-0-2 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30 (BEGINS MARCH 31)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-156</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar examines how biopharmaceuticals, an increasingly important class of pharmaceuticals, are manufactured. Topics range from fundamental bioprocesses to new technologies to the economics of biomanufacturing. Also covers the impact of globalization on regulation and quality approaches as well as supply chain integrity. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>J. C. Love, A. Sinskey, S. Springs</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.04"></a>
<p><h3>10.04J A Philosophical History of Energy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m24a.html#24.114">24.114J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Philosophic and historical approach to conceptions of energy through the 19th century. Relation of long standing scientific and philosophic problems in the field of energy to 21st-century debates. Topics include the development of thermodynamics and kinetic theories, the foundation of the scientific project, the classical view of energy, and the harnessing of nature. Authors include Bacon, Boltzmann, Carnot, Compte, Descartes, Gibbs, Plato, Aristotle, Leibniz, Kant, Hegel, Mill, Peirce, Whitehead, and Maxwell. Key texts and controversies form topics of weekly writing assignments and term papers.
<br><I>B. L. Trout, A. Schulman</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.10"></a>
<p><h3>10.10 Introduction to Chemical Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-110</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>T11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-110</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>The diverse applications of chemical engineering are explored through example problems. Solutions require application of fundamental concepts of mass and energy conservation to batch and continuous systems, involving chemical and biological processes. Computer skills and the elements of engineering design are taught in the context of these example problems. The objective is to acquaint the student with the field of chemical engineering and to enable use of computer methods to solve chemical and biological engineering problems.
<br><I>B. D. Olsen, J. W. Swan</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=10.10');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.213"></a>
<p><h3>10.213 Chemical and Biological Engineering Thermodynamics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5b.html#5.60">5.60</a>, <a href="m10a.html#10.10">10.10</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-110</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-154</a>) or <i>W12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-154</a>) or <i>W1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-168</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Thermodynamics of multicomponent, multiphase chemical and biological systems. Applications of first, second, and third laws of thermodynamics to open and closed systems. Properties of mixtures, including colligative properties, chemical reaction equilibrium, and phase equilibrium; non-ideal solutions; power cycles; refrigeration; separation systems.
<br><I>K. K. Gleason, H. D. Sikes</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=10.213');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.22"></a>
<p><h3>10.22 Molecular Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5b.html#5.60">5.60</a>, <a href="m10a.html#10.213">10.213</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces molecular concepts in relation to engineering thermodynamics. Includes topics in statistical mechanics, molecular description of gases and liquids, property estimation, description of equilibrium and dynamic properties of fluids from molecular principles, and kinetics of activated processes. Also covers some basic aspects of molecular simulation and applications in systems of engineering interest.
<br><I>G. C. Rutledge, P. S. Doyle</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.25"></a>
<p><h3>10.25 Industrial Chemistry and Chemical Process Pathways
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>, <a href="m10a.html#10.213">10.213</a>, <a href="m10a.html#10.37">10.37</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Chemical and engineering principles involved in creation and operation of viable industrial processes. Topics: analysis of process chemistry by p-pathways (i.e., radical, ionic, and pericyclic reactions of organic syntheses) and d-pathways (i.e., catalysis by transition-metal complexes). Use of reaction mechanisms for inference of co-product formation, kinetics, and equilibria: process synthesis logic related to reaction selectivity, recycle, separations. Illustrations drawn from current and contemplated commercial practice.
<br><I>P. S. Virk</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.26"></a>
<p><h3>10.26 Chemical Engineering Projects Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m10a.html#10.27">10.27</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.29">10.29</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2b.html#2.671">2.671</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.014">3.014</a>, <a href="m5a.html#5.310">5.310</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.02">7.02</a>, <a href="m12a.html#12.335">12.335</a>, or <a href="m1a.html#1.106">1.106</a> and <a href="m1a.html#1.107">1.107</a>; <a href="m10a.html#10.302">10.302</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-8-4
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/10.26/www/">http://web.mit.edu/10.26/www/</a>
<br><b>Lab:</b> <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=76">76-653</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=76">76-653</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E18">E18-566</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0064</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0064</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0064</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0064</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Projects in applied chemical engineering research. Students work in teams on one project for the term. Projects often suggested by local industry. Includes training in research planning and project management, execution of experimental work, data analysis, oral presentation skills and individual report writing, and team-building.
<br><I>C. K. Colton, B. S. Johnston, B. D. Burrell, G. C. Rutledge, W. H. Dalzell</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.27"></a>
<p><h3>10.27 Energy Engineering Projects Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m10a.html#10.26">10.26</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.29">10.29</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2b.html#2.671">2.671</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.014">3.014</a>, <a href="m5a.html#5.310">5.310</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.02">7.02</a>, <a href="m12a.html#12.335">12.335</a>, or <a href="m1a.html#1.106">1.106</a> and <a href="m1a.html#1.107">1.107</a>; <a href="m10a.html#10.302">10.302</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-8-4
<br><b>Lab:</b> <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=76">76-653</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=76">76-653</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E18">E18-566</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0064</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0064</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0064</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0064</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Projects in applied energy engineering research. Students work in teams on one project for the term. Projects often suggested by local industry. Includes training in research planning and project management, execution of experimental work, data analysis, oral presentation skills and technical report writing, and team-building. Projects consider social science issues in addition to technical issues. Intended for students with diverse technical backgrounds. Preference to Energy Studies minors.
<br><I>C. K. Colton, M. S. Strano, W. A. Tisdale, W. H. Green</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.28"></a>
<p><h3>10.28 Chemical-Biological Engineering Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.310">5.310</a> or <a href="m10a.html#10.702">10.702</a>; <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a> or <a href="m5a.html#5.07">5.07</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-8-5
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/10.28/www">http://web.mit.edu/10.28/www</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the complete design of the bioprocess: from vector selection to production, separation, and characterization of recombinant products. Utilize concepts from many fields, such as, chemical and electrical engineering, and biology. Student teams work through parallel modules spanning microbial fermentation and animal cell culture. With the bioreactor at the core of the experiments, students study cell metabolism and biological pathways, kinetics of cell growth and product formation, oxygen mass transport, scale-up and techniques for the design of process control loops. Introduces novel bioreactors and powerful analytical instrumentation. Downstream processing and recombinant product purification also included. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>J.-F. Hamel and K. J. Prather</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.29"></a>
<p><h3>10.29 Biological Engineering Projects Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m10a.html#10.26">10.26</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.27">10.27</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2b.html#2.671">2.671</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.014">3.014</a>, <a href="m5a.html#5.310">5.310</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.02">7.02</a>, <a href="m12a.html#12.335">12.335</a>, or <a href="m1a.html#1.106">1.106</a> and <a href="m1a.html#1.107">1.107</a>; <a href="m10a.html#10.302">10.302</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-8-4
<br><b>Lab:</b> <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=76">76-653</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=76">76-653</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E18">E18-566</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0064</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0064</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0064</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0064</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Projects in applied biological engineering research. Students work in teams on one project for the term. Projects often suggested by local industry. Includes training in research planning and project management, execution of experimental work, data analysis, oral presentation skills and report writing, and team-building.
<br><I>C. K. Colton, J. F. Hamel, D. G. Anderson, J. C. Love</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.291"></a>
<p><h3>10.291J Introduction to Sustainable Energy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.650">2.650J</A>, <A HREF="m22a.html#22.081">22.081J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m1c.html#1.818">1.818J</A>, <A HREF="m2b.html#2.65">2.65J</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.391">10.391J</A>, <A HREF="m11c.html#11.371">11.371J</A>, <A HREF="m22c.html#22.811">22.811J</A>, <A HREF="mESDa.html#ESD.166">ESD.166J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-1-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Assessment of current and potential future energy systems. Covers resources, extraction, conversion, and end-use technologies, with emphasis on meeting 21st-century regional and global energy needs in a sustainable manner. Examines various renewable and conventional energy production technologies, energy end-use practices and alternatives, and consumption practices in different countries. Investigates their attributes within a quantitative analytical framework for evaluation of energy technology system proposals. Emphasizes analysis of energy propositions within an engineering, economic and social context. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to juniors and seniors.
<br><I>M. W. Golay</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.301"></a>
<p><h3>10.301 Fluid Mechanics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>, <a href="m10a.html#10.10">10.10</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/10.301/www/welcome.html">http://web.mit.edu/10.301/www/welcome.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR12-1.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-110</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>M11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-160</a>) or <i>M12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-160</a>) or <i>M11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-154</a>) or <i>M12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-154</a>) or <i>M11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-169</a>) or <i>M12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-169</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the mechanical principles governing fluid flow. Stress in a fluid. Conservation of mass and momentum, using differential and integral balances. Elementary constitutive equations. Hydrostatics. Exact solutions of the Navier-Stokes equations. Approximate solutions using control volume analysis. Mechanical energy balances and Bernoulli's equation. Dimensional analysis and dynamic similarity. Introduces boundary-layer theory and turbulence.
<br><I>P. S. Doyle, F. R. Brushett, P. S. Virk</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=10.301');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.302"></a>
<p><h3>10.302 Transport Processes
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5b.html#5.60">5.60</a>, <a href="m10a.html#10.301">10.301</a>, <a href="m10a.html#10.213">10.213</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Principles of heat and mass transfer. Steady and transient conduction and diffusion. Radiative heat transfer. Convective transport of heat and mass in both laminar and turbulent flows.  Emphasis on the development of a physical understanding of the underlying phenomena and upon the ability to solve real heat and mass transfer problems of engineering significance.
<br><I>T. A. Hatton, W. A. Tisdale</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.32"></a>
<p><h3>10.32 Separation Processes
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m10a.html#10.213">10.213</a>, <a href="m10a.html#10.302">10.302</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-110</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>General principles of separation by equilibrium and rate processes. Staged cascades. Applications to distillation, absorption, adsorption, and membrane processes. Use of material balances, phase equilibria, and diffusion to understand and design separation processes.
<br><I>W. H. Dalzell, A. S. Myerson</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=10.32');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.333"></a>
<p><h3>10.333 Introduction to Modeling and Simulation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Engineering School-Wide Elective Subject. <br>(Offered under: <A HREF="m1a.html#1.021">1.021</A>, <A HREF="m3a.html#3.021">3.021</A>, <A HREF="m22a.html#22.00">22.00</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.016">3.016</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Basic concepts of computer modeling and simulation in science and engineering. Uses techniques and software for simulation, data analysis and visualization. Continuum, mesoscale, atomistic and quantum methods used to study fundamental and applied problems in physics, chemistry, materials science, mechanics, engineering, and biology. Examples drawn from the disciplines above are used to understand or characterize complex structures and materials, and complement experimental observations.
<br><I>M. Buehler, J. Grossman</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.34"></a>
<p><h3>10.34 Numerical Methods Applied to Chemical Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/10.34/www/">http://web.mit.edu/10.34/www/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Numerical methods for solving problems arising in heat and mass transfer, fluid mechanics, chemical reaction engineering, and molecular simulation. Topics: numerical linear algebra, solution of nonlinear algebraic equations and ordinary differential equations, solution of partial differential equations (e.g. Navier-Stokes), numerical methods in molecular simulation (dynamics, geometry optimization). All methods are presented within the context of chemical engineering problems. Familiarity with structured programming is assumed.
<br><I>R. D. Braatz, J. W. Swan</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.37"></a>
<p><h3>10.37 Chemical Kinetics and Reactor Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5b.html#5.60">5.60</a>, <a href="m10a.html#10.301">10.301</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/10.37/www/">http://web.mit.edu/10.37/www/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>WF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-110</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>M11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-110</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Applies the concepts of reaction rate, stoichiometry and equilibrium to the analysis of chemical and biological reacting systems. Derivation of rate expressions from reaction mechanisms and equilibrium or steady state assumptions. Design of chemical and biochemical reactors via synthesis of chemical kinetics, transport phenomena, and mass and energy balances. Topics: chemical/biochemical pathways; enzymatic, pathway and cell growth kinetics; batch, plug flow and well-stirred reactors for chemical reactions and cultivations of microorganisms and mammalian cells; heterogeneous and enzymatic catalysis; heat and mass transport in reactors, including diffusion to and within catalyst particles and cells or immoblized enzymes.
<br><I>K. D. Wittrup, A. Mehra</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=10.37');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.390"></a>
<p><h3>10.390J Fundamentals of Advanced Energy Conversion
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.60">2.60J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.006">2.006</a>, or <a href="m2a.html#2.051">2.051</a> and <a href="m2a.html#2.06">2.06</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m2b.html#2.62">2.62</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.392">10.392</A>, <A HREF="m22b.html#22.40">22.40</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW12.30-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-370</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Fundamentals of thermodynamics, chemistry, and transport applied to energy systems. Analysis of energy conversion and storage in thermal, mechanical, chemical, and electrochemical processes in power and transportation systems, with emphasis on efficiency, performance, and environmental impact. Applications to fuel reforming and alternative fuels, hydrogen, fuel cells and batteries, combustion, catalysis, combined and hybrid power cycles using fossil, nuclear and renewable resources. CO<SUB>2</SUB> separation and capture. Biomass energy. Meets with 2.62 when offered concurrently; students taking the graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>A. F. Ghoniem, W. Green, M. Kazimi</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.391"></a>
<p><h3>10.391J Sustainable Energy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1c.html#1.818">1.818J</A>, <A HREF="m2b.html#2.65">2.65J</A>, <A HREF="m11c.html#11.371">11.371J</A>, <A HREF="m22c.html#22.811">22.811J</A>, <A HREF="mESDa.html#ESD.166">ESD.166J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m2b.html#2.650">2.650J</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.291">10.291J</A>, <A HREF="m22a.html#22.081">22.081J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-1-8
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/10.391J/www/">http://web.mit.edu/10.391J/www/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Assessment of current and potential future energy systems. Covers resources, extraction, conversion, and end-use technologies, with emphasis on meeting 21st-century regional and global energy needs in a sustainable manner. Examines various energy technologies in each fuel cycle stage for fossil (oil, gas, synthetic), nuclear (fission and fusion) and renewable (solar, biomass, wind, hydro, and geothermal) energy types, along with storage, transmission, and conservation issues. Emphasizes analysis of energy propositions within an engineering, economic and social context. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>M. W. Golay</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.392"></a>
<p><h3>10.392J Fundamentals of Advanced Energy Conversion
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.62">2.62J</A>, <A HREF="m22b.html#22.40">22.40J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.006">2.006</a>, or <a href="m2a.html#2.051">2.051</a> and <a href="m2a.html#2.06">2.06</a>, or permission of instructor

<a name="10.40"></a>
<p><h3>10.40 Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m10a.html#10.213">10.213</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Basic postulates of classical thermodynamics. Application to transient open and closed systems. Criteria of stability and equilibria. Constitutive property models of pure materials and mixtures emphasizing molecular-level effects using the formalism of statistical mechanics. Phase and chemical equilibria of multicomponent systems. Applications emphasized through extensive problem work relating to practical cases.
<br><I>B. D. Olsen, A. Chakraborty</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.424"></a>
<p><h3>10.424 Pharmaceutical Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m10a.html#10.524">10.524</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m10a.html#10.213">10.213</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents engineering principles and unit operations involved in the manufacture of small molecules pharmaceuticals, from the isolation of purified active pharmaceutical ingredients (API) to the final production of drug product. Regulatory issues include quality by design and process analytical technologies of unit operations, such as crystallization, filtration, drying, milling, blending, granulation, tableting and coating. Also covers principles of formulation for solid dosage forms and parenteral drugs. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 50.
<br><I>A. S. Myerson</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.426"></a>
<p><h3>10.426 Electrochemical Energy Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m10a.html#10.626">10.626</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m10a.html#10.302">10.302</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-144</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces principles and mathematical models of electrochemical energy conversion and storage. Studies equivalent circuits, thermodynamics, reaction kinetics, transport phenomena, electrostatics, porous media, and phase transformations. Includes applications to batteries, fuel cells, supercapacitors, and electrokinetics. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>M. Z. Bazant</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.43"></a>
<p><h3>10.43 Introduction to Interfacial Phenomena
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m10a.html#10.213">10.213</a> or introductory subject in thermodynamics or physical chemistry
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces fundamental and applied aspects of interfacial systems. Theory of capillarity. Experimental determination of surface and interfacial tensions. Thermodynamics of interfaces. The Gibbs adsorption equation. Charged interfaces. Surfactant adsorption at interfaces. Insoluble monolayers. Curvature effects on the equilibrium state of fluids. Nucleation and growth. Fundamentals of wetting and contact angle. Adhesion, cohesion, and spreading. Wetting of textured surfaces. Super-hydrophilic and super-hydrophobic surfaces. Self-cleaning surfaces.
<br><I>D. Blankschtein</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.441"></a>
<p><h3>10.441J Molecular and Engineering Aspects of Biotechnology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m7a.html#7.37">7.37J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.361">20.361J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.005">2.005</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.012">3.012</a>, <a href="m5b.html#5.60">5.60</a>, <a href="m20a.html#20.110">20.110</a>, or <a href="m20a.html#20.111">20.111</a>; <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/7.37j/">http://web.mit.edu/7.37j/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW3-5</i> (Whitehead-7TH)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers biological and bioengineering principles underlying the development and therapeutic use of recombinant proteins and stem cells; glycoengineering of recombinant proteins; normal and pathological signaling by growth factors and their receptors; receptor trafficking; monoclonal antibodies as therapeutics; protein pharmacology and delivery; stem cell-derived tissues as therapeutics; RNA therapeutics; combinatorial protein engineering; and new antitumor drugs.
<br><I>H. Lodish, L. Griffith</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=10.441');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.444"></a>
<p><h3>10.444 Frontiers in Therapeutics and Drug Delivery
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m10a.html#10.644">10.644J</A>, <A HREF="mHSTb.html#HST.914">HST.914J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to pharmaceutics and conventional oral, injected, transdermal and inhaled drug delivery systems. Includes studies of drug delivery devices and systems, e.g., stents, pumps, depo systems, responsive drug delivery systems, and biological/cell based therapies. Covers nano- and micro drug delivery systems, including polymer-drug conjugates, modified proteins, liposomes and polymer nanoparticles, viral and non-viral genetic therapy, and microencapsulated vaccines. Discusses reviews and current technology. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 40.
<br><I>D. G. Anderson</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.450"></a>
<p><h3>10.450 Process Dynamics, Operations, and Control
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m10a.html#10.302">10.302</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-154</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to dynamic processes and the engineering tasks of process operations and control. Subject covers modeling the static and dynamic behavior of processes; control strategies; design of feedback, feedforward, and other control structures; model-based control; applications to process equipment.
<br><I>Geo. Stephanopoulos</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.466"></a>
<p><h3>10.466 Structure of Soft Matter
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m10a.html#10.566">10.566</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5b.html#5.60">5.60</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to the basic thermodynamic language used for describing the structure of materials, followed by a survey of the scattering, microscopy and spectroscopic techniques for structure and morphology characterization. Applies these concepts to a series of case studies illustrating the diverse structures formed in soft materials and the common length, time and energy scales that unify this field. For students interested in studying polymer science, colloid science, nanotechnology, biomaterials, and liquid crystals. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>B. D. Olsen</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.467"></a>
<p><h3>10.467 Polymer Science Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.12">5.12</a>, <a href="m5a.html#5.310">5.310</a>
<br>Units: 2-7-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Experiments broadly aimed at acquainting students with the range of properties of polymers, methods of synthesis, and physical chemistry. Examples: solution polymerization of acrylamide, bead polymerization of divinylbenzene, interfacial polymerization of nylon 6,10. Evaluation of networks by tensile and swelling experiments. Rheology of polymer solutions and suspensions. Physical properties of natural and silicone rubber. Preference to Course 10 seniors and juniors.
<br><I>C. Love</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.489"></a>
<p><h3>10.489 Concepts in Modern Heterogeneous Catalysis
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m10a.html#10.689">10.689</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m10a.html#10.37">10.37</a>, <a href="m10a.html#10.302">10.302</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-168</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores topics in the design and implementation of heterogeneous catalysts for chemical transformations. Emphasizes use of catalysis for environmentally benign and sustainable chemical processes. Lectures address concepts in catalyst preparation, catalyst characterization, quantum chemical calculations, and microkinetic analysis of catalytic processes. Shows how experimental and theoretical approaches can illustrate important reactive intermediates and transition states involved in chemical reaction pathways, and uses that information to help identify possible new catalysts that may facilitate reactions of interest. Draws examples from current relevant topics in catalysis. Includes a group project in which students investigate a specific topic in greater depth. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>Y. Roman</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>

<a name="10.491"></a>
<h3>10.491 Integrated Chemical Engineering II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); first half of term

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents and solves chemical engineering problems in an industrial context, with applications varying by term. Emphasis on the integration of fundamental concepts with approaches of process design.  Emphasis on problems that demand synthesis, economic analysis, and process design.

<a name="10.492"></a>
