<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Textbooks arranged individually
<a name="12.URG"></a>
<h3>12.URG Undergraduate Research
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Undergraduate research opportunities in Earth, Atmospheric, and Planetary Sciences.
<br><I>EAPS Faculty</I><br>Textbooks arranged individually
</p><!--end-->
<a name="12.IND"></a>
<p><h3>12.IND Independent Study
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m12a.html#12.TIP">12.TIP</a>
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Independent reading, laboratory, or fieldwork in Earth, Atmospheric, and Planetary Sciences. Requires written report. To be arranged by student and an appropriate MIT faculty member.
<br><I>EAPS Faculty</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="12.TIP"></a>
<p><h3>12.TIP Thesis and Independent Study Preparation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Definition of and early-stage work on thesis project or independent study. Students develop a written research proposal and begin writing the supporting text of the thesis concurrent with conducting research for the thesis project or independent study. Supervision of the writing continues into the Spring term which concludes with an oral presentation of the research results.
<br><I>EAPS Staff</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="12.THU"></a>

<br>Prereq: <a href="m12a.html#12.TIP">12.TIP</a>
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Program of research leading to the writing of a thesis; to be arranged by the student and an appropriate MIT faculty member.
<br><I>EAPS Faculty</I><br>Textbooks arranged individually
</p><!--end-->
</td></tr></table>

<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Course 14: Economics<br>Spring
2014</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://econ-www.mit.edu/"><i>Course 14 Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course14.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=++14&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>14.00-14.399 plus UROP</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m14b.html">14.40-14.999 and UROP and Thesis</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<h2>General Economics and Theory</h2>
<a name="14.003"></a>
<p><h3>14.003 Microeconomic Theory and Public Policy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m14a.html#14.03">14.03</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9-10.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=54">54-100</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=24">24-115</a>) or <i>F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=24">24-115</a>) or <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=24">24-115</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Applies microeconomic theory to analysis of public policy. Builds from microeconomic model of consumer behavior; extends to operation of single and multiple markets and analysis of why markets sometimes fail. Empirical examples to evaluate theory, focusing on the casual effects of policy interventions on economic outcomes. Topics include minimum wages and employment, food stamps and consumer welfare, economics of risk and safety regulation, the value of education, and gains from international trade.  Graduate students are expected to complete additional assignments.
<br>Fall: <I>D. Paserman</I><br>Spring: <I>P. Somaini</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.01"></a>
<p><h3>14.01 Principles of Microeconomics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=54">54-100</a>) or <i>NO LECTURE FOR RECS 07-11</i> <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-135</a>) or <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-135</a>) or <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-135</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-135</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=6">6-120</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-135</a>) or <i>MWF9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=12">12-142</a>) or <i>MWF10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=12">12-142</a>) or <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=12">12-142</a>) or <i>MWF12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=12">12-142</a>) or <i>MWF2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=12">12-142</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces microeconomic concepts and analysis, supply and demand analysis, theories of the firm and individual behavior, competition and monopoly, and welfare economics. Applications to problems of current economic policy.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Gruber</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Harris</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=14.01');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.02"></a>
<p><h3>14.02 Principles of Macroeconomics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=54">54-100</a>) or <i>NO LECTURE FOR RECS 03-05</i> <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-442</a>) or <i>F3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-442</a>) or <i>MWF10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-159</a>) or <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-159</a>) or <i>MWF1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=12">12-142</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an overview of macroeconomic issues: the determination of output, employment, unemployment, interest rates, and inflation. Monetary and fiscal policies are discussed. Important current policy debates such as the sub-prime crisis, social security, the public debt, and international economic issues are critically explored. Introduces basic models of macroeconomics and illustrates principles with the experience of the US and foreign economies.
<br>Fall: <I>P. Willen</I><br>Spring: <I>F. Giavazzi</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=14.02');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.03"></a>
<p><h3>14.03 Microeconomic Theory and Public Policy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m14a.html#14.003">14.003</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9-10.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=54">54-100</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=24">24-115</a>) or <i>F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=24">24-115</a>) or <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=24">24-115</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Applies microeconomic theory to analysis of public policy. Builds from microeconomic model of consumer behavior; extends to operation of single and multiple markets and analysis of why markets sometimes fail. Empirical examples to evaluate theory, focusing on the casual effects of policy interventions on economic outcomes. Topics include minimum wages and employment, food stamps and consumer welfare, economics of risk and safety regulation, the value of education, and gains from international trade.
<br>Fall: <I>D. Paserman</I><br>Spring: <I>P. Somaini</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.04"></a>
<p><h3>14.04 Intermediate Microeconomic Theory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analysis of consumer and producer decisions including analysis of competitive and monopolistic markets. Price-based partial and general equilibrium analysis. Introduction to game theory as a foundation for the strategic analysis of economic situations. Imperfect competition, dynamic games among firms. Failures of general equilibrium theory and their resolutions: externalities, public goods, incomplete information settings, signaling, screening, insurance, alternative market mechanisms, auctions, design of markets.
<br><I>J. Toikka</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.05"></a>
<p><h3>14.05 Intermediate Macroeconomics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a>, <a href="m14a.html#14.02">14.02</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10.30-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E25">E25-117</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E25">E25-117</a>) or <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E25">E25-117</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-061</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Uses the tools of macroeconomics to study various macroeconomic policy problems in depth. The problems range from economic growth in the long run to government finances in the intermediate run and economic stability in the short run. Many economic models used today are surveyed.  Requires a substantial research paper on the economics of long-run economic growth.
<br><I>A. Simsek</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=14.05');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.08"></a>

<p><h3>14.11 Topics in Economics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<br>Considers issues of current research interest in economics.
<br><I>M. Hoffman, E. Yoeli</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.12"></a>
<p><h3>14.12 Economic Applications of Game Theory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a>; <a href="m14a.html#14.03">14.03</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.041">6.041</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analysis of strategic behavior in multi-person economic settings. Introduction to solution concepts, such as rationalizability, backwards induction, Nash equilibrium, subgame-perfect equilibrium, and sequential equilibrium, with a strong emphasis on the assumptions behind these solution concepts. Issues of incomplete information, such as signaling and reputation formation. Applications drawn from microeconomics and political economy.
<br><I>M. Yildiz</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.121"></a>
<p><h3>14.121 Microeconomic Theory I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">; first half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.04">14.04</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers consumer and producer theory, markets and competition, and general equilibrium. Covers the tools of identification in price and general equilibrium theory, the fundamental welfare theorems, aggregation, and applications. Enrollment limited; preference to PhD students.
<br><I>R. Townsend</I><br>
<a name="14.122"></a>
<p><h3>14.122 Microeconomic Theory II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">; second half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.121">14.121</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to game theory. Topics include normal form and extensive form games, and games with incomplete information. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>G. Ellison</I><br>
<a name="14.123"></a>
<p><h3>14.123 Microeconomic Theory III
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.121">14.121</a>, <a href="m14a.html#14.122">14.122</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30 (ENDS MARCH 21)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-136</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-151</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Models of individual decision-making under certainty and uncertainty. Additional topics in game theory. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>M. Yildiz</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=14.123');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
<a name="14.124"></a>
<p><h3>14.124 Microeconomic Theory IV
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.123">14.123</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30 (BEGINS MARCH 31)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-136</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-151</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Decision-making under uncertainty, information economics, incentive and contract theory. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>B. Holmstrom</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=14.124');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.125"></a>
<p><h3>14.125 Market Design
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.124">14.124</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T EVE (4-7 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-129</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Theory and practice of market design, building on ideas from microeconomics, game theory and mechanism design.  Prominent case studies include auctions, labor markets, school choice, prediction markets, financial markets, and organ exchange clearinghouses.
<br><I>P. Pathak</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.126"></a>
<p><h3>14.126 Game Theory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.122">14.122</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E25">E25-117</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-136</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Rigorous investigation of the evolutionary and epistemic foundations of solution concepts, such as rationalizability and Nash equilibrium. Covers classical topics, such as repeated games, bargaining, and supermodular games as well as new topics such as global games, heterogeneous priors, psychological games, and games without expected utility maximization. Applications provided when available.
<br><I>M. Yildiz</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=14.126');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.129"></a>
<p><h3>14.129 Advanced Contract Theory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">; second half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.121">14.121</a>, <a href="m14a.html#14.281">14.281</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30 (BEGINS MARCH 31)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-361</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-372</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Recent developments in contract theory. Includes advanced models of moral hazard, adverse selection, mechanism design and incomplete contracts with applications to theory of the firm, organizational design, and financial structure.
<br><I>R. Townsend</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.137"></a>
<p><h3>14.137J Psychology and Economics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m9b.html#9.822">9.822J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines "psychology appreciation" for economics students. Aims to enhance knowledge and intuition about psychological processes in areas relevant to economics. Increases understanding of psychology as an experimental discipline, with its own distinct rules and style of argument. Topics include self-knowledge, cognitive dissonance, self-deception, emotions, social norms, self-control, learning, mental accounting, memory, individual and group behavior, and some personality and psycho-analytic models. Within each of these topics, we showcase effective and central experiments and discuss their role in the development of psychological theory. Term paper required.
<br>Consult D. Prelec<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.147"></a>
<p><h3>14.147 Topics in Game Theory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">

</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.15"></a>
<p><h3>14.15J Networks
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6a.html#6.207">6.207J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.041">6.041</a> or <a href="m14a.html#14.30">14.30</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-155</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-156</a>) or <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-144</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Highlights common principles that permeate the functioning of diverse technological, economic and social networks. Utilizes three sets of tools for analyzing networks--random graph models, optimization, and game theory--to study informational and learning cascades; economic and financial networks; social influence networks; formation of social groups; communication networks and the Internet; consensus and gossiping; spread and control of epidemics; control and use of energy networks; and biological networks.
<br>Consult D. Acemoglu, M. Dahleh<br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=14.15');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.16"></a>
<p><h3>14.16 Strategy and Information
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.12">14.12</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-136</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-139</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Begins with a rigorous overview of the main equilbrium concepts for non-cooperative games in normal and extensive form, with complete or incomplete information. Defines and explores properties of iterated dominance, rationalizability, Nash equilibrium, subgame perfection, perfect Bayesian equilibrium, and sequential, perfect and proper equilibria. Introduces solution concepts for cooperative games and studies non-cooperative implementations. Other topics include matching and allocation problems, auctions and mechanism design, and reputation. Bargaining and networks are recurring themes.
<br><I>M. Manea</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.19"></a>
<p><h3>14.19 Market Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.04">14.04</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers the design and operation of organized markets, building on ideas from microeconomic and game theory.  Topics may include mechanism design, auctions, matching markets, and other resource allocation problems.
<br>Consult P. Pathak<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.191"></a>

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">

<br><I>M. Greenstone</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->

<h2>Industrial Organization</h2>
<a name="14.20"></a>
<p><h3>14.20 Industrial Organization and Competitive Strategy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-395</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-361</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analyzes the behavior and performance of firms in markets, with a particular focus on strategic interactions.  Topics include monopoly power, behavior of firms in oligopoly markets, static and dynamic measurement of market performance, pricing and product choice decisions, advertising, research and development, and theory of the firm. Requires attendance and team participation in a Competitive Strategy Game.
<br><I>N. Rose</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.21"></a>
<p><h3>14.21 Health Economics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/14.21j/www/">http://web.mit.edu/14.21j/www/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E25">E25-117</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Applies theoretical and empirical tools of economics to problems of health and medical care delivery. Concentrates on selected topics such as decision-making under uncertainty, cost-benefit analysis, health insurance, physician remuneration, government regulation, health care systems of developing countries, and the economics of AIDS.
<br><I>J. E. Harris</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.26"></a>
<p><h3>14.26 Economics of Incentives: Theory and Applications
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.04">14.04</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Rigorous introduction to the economic theory of incentives in conjunction with a wide range of applications. These include, among others, the optimal design of sales and CEO compensation schemes; the impact of incentives on risk-taking and innovation; the analysis of venture capital and other forms of financing; and the implications of informational asymmetries among participants for the functioning of markets.
<br><I>H. Rantakari</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.27"></a>
<p><h3>14.27 Economics and E-Commerce
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a>; <a href="m6a.html#6.041">6.041</a> or <a href="m14a.html#14.30">14.30</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/14.27/www">http://web.mit.edu/14.27/www</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Uses theoretical economic models and empirical evidence to help understand the growth and future of e-commerce.  Economic models help frame class discussions of, among other topics, content provision, privacy, piracy, sales taxation, group purchasing, price search, and advertising on the internet.  Empirical project and paper required.
<br>Consult S. Ellison<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.271"></a>
<p><h3>14.271 Industrial Organization I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.04">14.04</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers theoretical and empirical work dealing with the structure, behavior, and performance of firms and markets and core issues in antitrust. Topics include: the organization of the firm, monopoly, price discrimination, oligopoly, and auctions. Theoretical and empirical work are integrated in each area.
<br><I>G. Ellison</I><br>
<a name="14.272"></a>
<p><h3>14.272 Industrial Organization II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.271">14.271</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9-10.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-217</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F9-10.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-217</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A continuation of 14.271.  Topics covered include horizontal mergers and demand estimation, vertical integration and vertical restraints, natural monopoly and its regulation, public enterprise, political economy of regulation, network access pricing, deregulation of telecommunications, electric power, cable television, transportation sectors, and risk and environmental regulation.
<br><I>N. Rose</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=14.272');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.273"></a>
<p><h3>14.273 Advanced Topics in Industrial Organization
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">

</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.281"></a>
<p><h3>14.281 Contract Economics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.124">14.124</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers theoretical research on contracts in static as well as dynamic settings. Emphasis is on canonical models in contracting (agency theory, mechanism design, incomplete contracting) illustrated by major areas of application (e.g. compensation, labor and capital markets, property rights, organizational design, corporate finance).
<br><I>J. Toikka</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.282"></a>
<p><h3>14.282 Introduction to Organizational Economics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.124">14.124</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Begins with survey of contract theory for organizational economists, then introduces the main areas of the field, including the boundary of the firm; decision-making, employment, structures and processes in organizations;  and organizations other than firms.
<br><I>M. Whinston</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.283"></a>

<h2>Statistics and Econometrics</h2>
<a name="14.30"></a>
<p><h3>14.30 Introduction to Statistical Method in Economics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Self-contained introduction to probability and statistics with some economic applications.  Elements of probability theory, sampling theory, statistical estimation, and hypothesis testing.  May not count toward HASS  requirement.
<br><I>S. Ellison</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.32"></a>
<p><h3>14.32 Econometrics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.30">14.30</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9-10.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E25">E25-117</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E25">E25-117</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to econometric models and techniques, simultaneous equations, program evaluation, emphasizing regression. Advanced topics include instrumental variables, panel data methods, measurement error, and limited dependent variable models. Includes problem sets. May not count toward HASS requirement.
<br>Fall: <I>Y. Dong</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Angrist</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=14.32');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.33"></a>
<p><h3>14.33 Research and Communication in Economics:  Topics, Methods, and Implementation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.04">14.04</a>, <a href="m14a.html#14.05">14.05</a>, <a href="m14a.html#14.32">14.32</a>
<br>Units: 3-4-5
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9-10.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-122</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Exposes students to the process of conducting independent research in empirical economics and effectively communicating the results of the research. Emphasizes econometric analysis of an assigned economic question and culminates in each student choosing an original topic, performing appropriate analysis, and delivering oral and written project reports.
<br>Fall: <I>S. Ellison</I><br>Spring: <I>M. Greenstone</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=14.33');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.36"></a>
<p><h3>14.36 Advanced Econometrics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.30">14.30</a>, <a href="m14a.html#14.32">14.32</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M12-2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-372</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-129</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers a range of topics including duration models, discrete choice models, differentiated product models, count models and other advanced models that are used in a wide variety of applications in applied microeconomics, financial economics, and business economics. Mastery of one or more techniques taught in class demonstrated through the completion of an econometrics paper.
<br><I>J. Hausman</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=14.36');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.381"></a>
<p><h3>14.381 Statistical Method in Economics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to probability and statistics as background for advanced econometrics and introduction to the linear regression model. Covers elements of probability theory; sampling theory; asymptotic approximations; decision-theory approach to statistical estimation focusing on regression, hypothesis testing; and maximum-likelihood methods. Includes simple and multiple regression, estimation and hypothesis testing. Illustrations from economics and application of these concepts to economic problems. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>K. Evdokimov, A. Mikusheva</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.382"></a>
<p><h3>14.382 Econometrics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.381">14.381</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-372</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-372</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Regression analysis, focusing on departures from the standard Gauss-Markov assumptions, and simultaneous equations. Regression topics include heteroskedasticity, serial correlation, and errors in variables, generalized least squares, nonlinear regression, and limited dependent variable models. Covers identification and estimation of linear and nonlinear simultaneous equations models. Economic applications are discussed. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>J. Hausman</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=14.382');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.384"></a>
<p><h3>14.384 Time Series Analysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.382">14.382</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies theory and application of time series methods in econometrics, including spectral analysis, estimation with stationary and non-stationary processes, VARs, factor models, unit roots, cointegration, estimation of DSGE models, and Bayesian methods. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>A. Mikusheva</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.385"></a>
<p><h3>14.385 Nonlinear Econometric Analysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.382">14.382</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies micro-econometric models, including large sample theory for estimation and hypothesis testing, generalized method of moments, estimation of censored and truncated specifications, quantile regression, structural estimation, nonparametric and semiparametric estimation, panel data, bootstrapping, and simulation methods. Methods illustrated with economic applications. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>K. Evdokimov, W. Newey</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.386"></a>
<p><h3>14.386 New Econometric Methods
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.382">14.382</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T EVE (4-6 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-372</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-057</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on recent developments in econometrics, especially structural estimation.  Topics include nonseparable models, models of imperfect competition, auction models, duration models, and nonlinear panel data.  Results illustrated with economic applications.
<br>Consult Department Headquarters<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.387"></a>
<p><h3>14.387 Topics in Applied Econometrics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.382">14.382</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW10.30-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-151</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers core econometric ideas and widely used empirical modeling strategies. Topics vary from year to year, but course typically begins with instrumental variables, concepts, and methods; then moves on to discussion of differences-in-differences and regression discontinuity methods.  Concludes with discussion of standard errors, focusing on issues such as clustering and serial correlation.
<br><I>J. Angrist</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=14.387');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.389"></a>
<p><h3>14.389 Econometrics Paper
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.382">14.382</a> or <a href="m14a.html#14.32">14.32</a>
<br>Units: 0-0-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Paper in econometrics required of all PhD candidates. Paper due at the end of IAP.
<br><I>J. Hausman</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.391"></a>
<p><h3>14.391 Workshop in Economic Research
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.124">14.124</a>, <a href="m14b.html#14.454">14.454</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-10 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>
<a name="14.392"></a>
<h3>14.392 Workshop in Economic Research
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.124">14.124</a>, <a href="m14b.html#14.454">14.454</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-10 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Recitation:</b> <i>M2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-450</a>) or <i>M4-5.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-650</a>) or <i>M EVE (5.30-7 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E19">E19-758</a>) or <i>T2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-650</a>) or <i>T EVE (4-6 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E18">E18-202</a>) or <i>W2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-376</a>) or <i>R EVE (4.30-6 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E18">E18-202</a>) or <i>R EVE (4-6 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-372</a>) or <i>M EVE (4-6 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E18">E18-202</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops research ability of students through intensive discussion of dissertation research as it proceeds, individual or group research projects, and critical appraisal of current reported research. Workshops divided into various fields, depending on interest and size.
<br>Consult M. Greenstone<br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<p>For additional related subjects in Statistics, see:
<p>Civil and Environmental Engineering: <a href="m1b.html#1.151">1.151</a>, <a href="m1b.html#1.155">1.155</a>, <a href="m1b.html#1.202">1.202J</a>, <a href="m1b.html#1.203">1.203J</a>, <a href="m1b.html#1.205">1.205J</a>
<p>Electrical Engineering and Computer Science: <a href="m6a.html#6.041">6.041</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.231">6.231</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.245">6.245</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.262">6.262</a>, <a href="m6b.html#6.431">6.431</a>, <a href="m6b.html#6.432">6.432</a>, and <a href="m6b.html#6.435">6.435</a>
<p>Management: <a href="m15a.html#15.034">15.034</a>, <a href="m15a.html#15.061">15.061</a>, <a href="m15a.html#15.065">15.065</a>, <a href="m15a.html#15.070">15.070</a>, <a href="m15a.html#15.075">15.075</a>, <a href="m15a.html#15.076">15.076</a>, <a href="m15a.html#15.098">15.098</a>, and <a href="m15b.html#15.306">15.306</a>
<p>Mathematics: <a href="m18a.html#18.05">18.05</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.175">18.175</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.177">18.177</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.440">18.440</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.441">18.441</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.443">18.443</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.445">18.445</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.458">18.458</a>, and <a href="m18a.html#18.465">18.465</a>
<p>See also: <a href="m2a.html#2.061">2.061</a>, <a href="m2c.html#2.830">2.830</a>, <a href="m5b.html#5.70">5.70</a>, <a href="m5b.html#5.72">5.72</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.02">7.02</a>, <a href="m8a.html#8.044">8.044</a>, <a href="m8a.html#8.08">8.08</a>, <a href="m10a.html#10.816">10.816</a>, <a href="m11b.html#11.220">11.220</a>, <a href="m11b.html#11.221">11.221</a>, <a href="m16a.html#16.322">16.322</a>, <a href="m17b.html#17.872">17.872</a>, <a href="m17b.html#17.874">17.874</a>, <a href="m22b.html#22.38">22.38</a>, <a href="mHSTa.html#HST.191">HST.191</a>, and <a href="mMASa.html#MAS.622">MAS.622J</a>.
</td></tr></table>

<h1 align="center">Course 15: Management<br>Spring
2014</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://mitsloan.mit.edu/"><i>Course 15 Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course15.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=++15&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>15.00-15.299</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m15b.html">15.30-15.699</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m15c.html">15.70-15.999 plus UROP and Thesis</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>

<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<h2>Managerial Economics</h2>
<a name="15.002"></a>
<p><h3>15.002 Sloan Innovation Period Requirement
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Units assigned to MBA students upon completion of the Sloan Innovation Period requirement. MBAs only.
<br><I>T. Walor</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.010"></a>
<p><h3>15.010 Economic Analysis for Business Decisions
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-5
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>
<a name="15.011"></a>
<h3>15.011 Economic Analysis for Business Decisions
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m15a.html#15.016">15.016</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-5
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces principles of microeconomic analysis as a framework for making more informed managerial decisions. Includes the analysis of competitive markets with supply and demand, sources of market power, pricing, anti-trust policy, as well as an overview of game theory and its application to competitive strategy. Students use the tools presented to analyze business and public policies. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Intended primarily for non-Sloan School students.
<br><I>J. Doyle</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.012"></a>
<p><h3>15.012 Applied Macro- and International Economics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW8.30-10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-149</a>) or <i>MW10-11.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-149</a>) or <i>MW2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-145</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Uses case studies to investigate the macroeconomic environment in which firms operate. First half of subject develops the basic tools of macroeconomic management: monetary, fiscal, and exchange rate policy. Discusses recent emerging market and financial crises, examining their causes, how best to address them, and how to prevent them from recurring in the future. Second half evaluates different strategies of economic development. Topics include growth, the role of debt and foreign aid, and the reliance on natural resources.
<br><I>Staff</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=15.012');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.013"></a>
<p><h3>15.013 Industrial Economics for Strategic Decisions
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15a.html#15.010">15.010</a> or <a href="m15a.html#15.011">15.011</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Applies principles of industrial economics most relevant for corporate strategy to analysis of particular industries. Topics include market structure and its determinants; rational strategic behavior in small numbers situations; strategies for price and nonprice competition; dynamic pricing, output, and advertising decisions; entry and entry deterrence; competition with network externalities; investments under uncertainty; R&D and patent licensing; and the growth and evolution of industries.
<br><I>R. Pindyck</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.014"></a>
<p><h3>15.014 Applied Macro- and International Economics II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">; second half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15a.html#15.012">15.012</a> or <a href="m15a.html#15.015">15.015</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Builds on 15.012 to establish an understanding of the development processes of societies and economies, the role of social entrepreneurship, and consequences for sustainability. Discusses current challenges that face emerging markets: health and the HIV epidemic, education and poverty, the emergence of financial and other markets, inflation and the role of commodity prices, macroeconomic management and the implications for policy. Across all dimensions, considers the roles of private and social entrepreneurs, as well as the public sector.
<br><I>R. Rigobon</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.015"></a>
<p><h3>15.015 Macro and International Economics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">; first half of term
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on the policy and economic environment of firms. Subject divided in three parts: study of the closed economy and how monetary and fiscal policy interacts with employment, GNP, inflation, and interest rates; examination of national economic strategies for development and growth, and study of the recent financial and currency crises in emerging markets; study of the problems faced by transition economies and the role of institutions both as the engine of growth, and as the constraints for policy. Restricted to Sloan Fellows in Innovation and Global Leadership.
<br><I>R. Rigobon</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.016"></a>
<p><h3>15.016 Economic Analysis for Business Decisions
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m15a.html#15.011">15.011</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-5
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces principles of microeconomic analysis as a framework for making more informed managerial decisions. Includes the analysis of competitive markets with supply and demand, sources of market power, pricing, anti-trust policy, as well as an overview of game theory and its application to competitive strategy. Students use the tools presented to analyze business and public policies. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>J. Doyle</I><br>

<a name="15.021"></a>
<p><h3>15.021J Real Estate Economics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11c.html#11.433">11.433J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a>, <a href="m15a.html#15.010">15.010</a>, or <a href="m15a.html#15.011">15.011</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops an understanding of the economic factors that shape and influence the markets for real property. Includes an analysis of housing as well as commercial real estate, and covers demographic analysis, regional growth, construction cycles, urban land markets and location theory. Exercises and modeling techniques for measuring and predicting property demand, supply, vacancy and prices.
<br><I>W. C. Wheaton</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.023"></a>
<p><h3>15.023J Global Climate Change: Economics, Science, and Policy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m12c.html#12.848">12.848J</A>, <A HREF="mESDa.html#ESD.128">ESD.128J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m12a.html#12.348">12.348J</A>, <A HREF="m15a.html#15.026">15.026J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m5b.html#5.60">5.60</a>; <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a> or <a href="m15a.html#15.010">15.010</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces scientific, economic, and ecological issues underlying the threat of global climate change, and the institutions engaged in negotiating an international response. Develops an integrated approach to analysis of climate change processes, and assessment of proposed policy measures, drawing on research and model development within the MIT Joint Program on the Science and Policy of Global Change. Graduate students are expected to explore the topic in greater depth through reading and individual research.
<br><I>R. G. Prinn</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.024"></a>
<p><h3>15.024 Applied Economics for Managers
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m15c.html#15.722">15.722</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops facility with concepts, language, and analytical tools of economics. Primary focus on microeconomics, analysis of markets and strategic interactions among firms.  Emphasizes integration of theory, data, and judgment in the analysis of corporate decisions, and in the assessment of the changing global business environment. Restricted to MIT Sloan Fellows in Innovation and Global Leadership.
<br><I>T. Stoker</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.025"></a>
<p><h3>15.025 Game Theory for Strategic Advantage
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15a.html#15.010">15.010</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10-11.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-223</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops and applies principles of game theory relevant to managers' strategic decisions. Topics include how to reason about strategies and opponents; strategic commitment, reputation, and "irrational" actions; brinkmanship and negotiation; auctions; and the design of markets and contests. Applications to a variety of business decisions that arise in different industries, both within and outside the firm.
<br><I>A. Bonatti</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.026"></a>
<p><h3>15.026J Global Climate Change: Economics, Science, and Policy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m12a.html#12.348">12.348J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m12c.html#12.848">12.848J</A>, <A HREF="m15a.html#15.023">15.023J</A>, <A HREF="mESDa.html#ESD.128">ESD.128J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m5b.html#5.60">5.60</a>; <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a> or <a href="m15a.html#15.010">15.010</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces scientific, economic, and ecological issues underlying the threat of global climate change, and the institutions engaged in negotiating an international response. Develops an integrated approach to analysis of climate change processes, and assessment of proposed policy measures, drawing on research and model development within the MIT Joint Program on the Science and Policy of Global Change. Graduate students are expected to explore the topic in greater depth through reading and individual research. 12.340 recommended.
<br><I>R. G. Prinn, M. D. Webster</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.031"></a>
<p><h3>15.031J Energy Decisions, Markets, and Policies
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11a.html#11.161">11.161J</A>, <A HREF="m14b.html#14.43">14.43J</A>, <A HREF="m17a.html#17.397">17.397J</A>, <A HREF="m21Aa.html#21A.415">21A.415J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Structured around choices and constraints regarding sources and uses of energy by households, firms, and governments, introduces managerial, economic, political, social and cultural frameworks for describing and explaining behavior at various levels of aggregation. Includes examples of cost-benefit, organizational and institutional analyses of energy generation, distribution, and consumption. Topics include the role of markets and prices; financial analysis of energy-related investments; institutional path dependence; economic and political determinants of government regulation and the impact of regulation on decisions; and other forms of government action and social norms regarding desired behavior and opportunities for businesses and consumers, including feedback into the political/regulatory system. Examples drawn from a wide range of countries and settings.
<br><I>D. Lessard, R. Schmalensee, S. Silbey, C. Warshaw</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.032"></a>
<p><h3>15.032J Engineering, Economics and Regulation of the Electric Power Sector
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6b.html#6.695">6.695J</A>, <A HREF="mESDa.html#ESD.162">ESD.162J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-2-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW10.30-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-376</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F10.30-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-149</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an in-depth and interdisciplinary look at electric power systems, focusing on regulation as the link among engineering, economic, legal and environmental viewpoints. Explores a range of topics, such as generation mix and dispatch, demand response, optimal network flows, wholesale and retail electricity supply, renewable generation, risk allocation, reliability of service, tariff design, transmission policy, distributed generation, rural electrification, and environmental sustainability issues, all under both traditional and competitive regulatory frameworks. Background in policy, microeconomics, or engineering required.
<br><I>I. Perez-Arriaga, R. Schmalensee</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=15.032');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.034"></a>
<p><h3>15.034 'Metrics for Managers:  Big Data and Better Answers
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Enables students to understand and conduct careful empirical work using regression analysis as used in business fields such as finance, marketing and strategy, as well as in general business planning and forecasting. Emphasizes model formulation, intuition, and critical evaluation of results.  Learning is primarily through empirical work done by student groups; delivered through problem sets, short write-ups, presentations and debates.
<br><I>R. Rigobon, T. Stoker</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.037"></a>
<p><h3>15.037J Energy Economics and Policy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m14b.html#14.44">14.44J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m14b.html#14.444">14.444</A>, <A HREF="m15a.html#15.038">15.038</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-145</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-376</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Theoretical and empirical perspectives on individual and industrial demand for energy, energy supply, energy markets, and public policies affecting energy markets. Discusses aspects of the oil, natural gas, electricity, and nuclear  power sectors. Examines energy tax, price regulation, deregulation, energy efficiency and policies for controlling pollution and CO<SUB>2</SUB> emissions. Students taking the graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 60.
<br><I>C. Knittel</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.038"></a>
<h3>15.038J Energy Economics and Policy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">

Discusses aspects of the oil, natural gas, electricity, and nuclear  power sectors. Examines energy tax, price regulation, deregulation, energy efficiency and policies for controlling pollution and CO<SUB>2</SUB> emissions.
