<a name="15.040"></a>
<p><h3>15.040 Seminar in Managerial Economics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<h2>Operations Research/Statistics</h2>
<a name="15.053"></a>
<p><h3>15.053 Optimization Methods in Management Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m15a.html#15.058">15.058</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10-11.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-335</a>) or <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-315</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-085</a>) or <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-085</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces students to the theory, algorithms, and applications of optimization. The optimization methodologies include linear programming, network optimization, integer programming, and decision trees. Applications to logistics, manufacturing, transportation, marketing, project management, and finance. Includes a team project in which students select and solve a problem in practice.
<br><I>J. B. Orlin</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.054"></a>
<p><h3>15.054J The Airline Industry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1b.html#1.232">1.232J</A>, <A HREF="m16b.html#16.71">16.71J</A>, <A HREF="mESDa.html#ESD.217">ESD.217J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Overview of the global airline industry, focusing on recent industry performance, current issues and challenges for the future. Fundamentals of airline industry structure, airline economics, operations planning, safety, labor relations, airports and air traffic control, marketing, and competitive strategies, with an emphasis on the interrelationships among major industry stakeholders. Recent research findings of the MIT Global Airline Industry Program are showcased, including the impacts of congestion and delays, evolution of information technologies, changing human resource management practices, and competitive effects of new entrant airlines. Taught by faculty participants of the Global Airline Industry Program.
<br><I>P. P. Belobaba, A. I. Barnett, C. Barnhart, R. J. Hansman, T. A. Kochan, A. R. Odoni</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.058"></a>
<p><h3>15.058 Optimization Methods in Operations Research
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m15a.html#15.053">15.053</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10-11.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-335</a>) or <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-315</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-057</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces students to the theory, algorithms, and applications of optimization. Methodologies include linear programming, network optimization, integer programming, and decision trees. Applications to logistics, manufacturing, transportation, marketing, project management, and finance.  Includes a team project in which students select and solve a problem in practice. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>J. Orlin</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.060"></a>
<p><h3>15.060 Data, Models, and Decisions
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m15c.html#15.730">15.730</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces students to the basic tools in using data to make informed management decisions. Covers introductory probability, decision analysis, basic statistics, regression, simulation, linear and nonlinear optimization, and discrete optimization. Computer spreadsheet exercises, cases, and examples drawn from marketing, finance, operations management, and other management functions. Restricted to first-year Sloan master's students.
<br><I>D. Bertsimas, R. Freund, G. Perakis, A. S. Schulz</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.062"></a>
<p><h3>15.062J Data Mining: Finding the Data and Models that Create Value
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">; second half of term
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mESDa.html#ESD.754">ESD.754J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15a.html#15.060">15.060</a> or <a href="m15a.html#15.075">15.075</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to data mining and  machine learning, a class of methods that assist in recognizing patterns and making intelligent use of massive amounts of data collected via the internet, e-commerce, electronic banking, point-of-sale devices, bar-code readers, medical databases, search engines, and social networks. Topics selected from logistic regression, association rules, tree-structured classification and regression, cluster analysis, discriminant analysis, and neural network methods. Presents examples of successful applications in areas such as credit ratings, fraud detection, marketing, customer relationship management, and investments. Introduces data-mining software. Term project required.
<br><I>R. E. Welsch</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.063"></a>
<p><h3>15.063 Communicating with Data
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces statistical tools and communication skills for using data to influence management decisions. In real-life decisions, decision-makers use both analytical and intuitive approaches to understand problems and to persuade others to act. Statistical tools are important, but statistical arguments are often met with skepticism. Covers decision analysis, communication principles, probability, testing theories, statistical sampling and regression, and misuses of statistics, with exercises and examples drawn from marketing, finance, operations management, strategy, and law. Restricted to MIT Sloan Fellows in Innovation and Global Leadership.
<br><I>A. Barnett</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.064"></a>
<p><h3>15.064J Engineering Probability and Statistics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mESDa.html#ESD.751">ESD.751J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Modeling and analysis of uncertainty and variation. Covers probability models and distributions, regression, and basic statistical procedures pertinent to manufacturing and operations. Introduces experimental and robust design, statistical process control, forecasting, and data-mining. Students use a data analysis package, such as JMP, Minitab, or MATLAB. Primarily for Leaders for Global Operations students.
<br><I>A. I. Barnett, R. E. Welsch</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.066"></a>
<p><h3>15.066J System Optimization and Analysis for Operations
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2c.html#2.851">2.851J</A>, <A HREF="mESDa.html#ESD.750">ESD.750J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to mathematical modeling, optimization, and simulation, as applied to manufacturing. Specific methods include linear programming, network flow problems, integer and nonlinear programming, discrete-event simulation, heuristics and computer applications for manufacturing processes and systems. Restricted to Leaders for Global Operations students.
<br><I>V. Farias</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.068"></a>
<p><h3>15.068 Statistical Consulting
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15a.html#15.060">15.060</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-151</a>) or <i>MW2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-151</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Addresses statistical issues as a consultant would face them: deciphering the client's question; finding appropriate data; performing a viable analysis; and presenting the results in compelling ways. Real-life cases and examples.
<br><I>A. I. Barnett</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.070"></a>
<p><h3>15.070J Advanced Stochastic Processes
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6a.html#6.265">6.265J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6b.html#6.431">6.431</a>, <a href="m15a.html#15.085">15.085J</a>, or <a href="m18a.html#18.100">18.100</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analysis and modeling of stochastic processes. Topics include measure theoretic probability, martingales, filtration, and stopping theorems; elements of large deviations theory; Brownian motion and reflected Brownian motion; stochastic integration and Ito calculus; functional limit theorems. Applications to finance theory, insurance, queueing and inventory models.
<br><I>D. Gamarnik, D. Shah</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.071"></a>
<p><h3>15.071 The Analytics Edge
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15a.html#15.053">15.053</a> or <a href="m15a.html#15.060">15.060</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M EVE (4-7 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-262</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-345</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents real-world examples in which quantitative methods provide a significant competitive edge that has led to a first order impact on some of today's most important companies. Examples include finance (quantitative asset management and options pricing), sports, health care, revenue management, supply chains, and the Internet. Outlines the competitive landscape. Presents the key quantitative methods that created the edge (data-mining, dynamic optimization, simulation), and discusses their impact. Includes team projects.
<br><I>D. Bertsimas</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.072"></a>
<p><h3>15.072J Queues: Theory and Applications
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6a.html#6.264">6.264J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.262">6.262</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Modeling and analysis of queueing systems, with applications in communications, manufacturing, computers, call centers, service industries and transportation. Topics include birth-death processes and simple Markovian queues, networks of queues and product form networks, single and multi-server queues, multi-class queueing networks, fluid models, adversarial queueing networks, heavy-traffic theory and diffusion approximations. Covers state of the art results which lead to research opportunities.
<br><I>D. Bertsimas, D. Gamarnik, J. N. Tsitsiklis</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.073"></a>
<p><h3>15.073J Logistical and Transportation Planning Methods
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1b.html#1.203">1.203J</A>, <A HREF="m6a.html#6.281">6.281J</A>, <A HREF="m16b.html#16.76">16.76J</A>, <A HREF="mESDa.html#ESD.216">ESD.216J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.041">6.041</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Quantitative techniques of operations research with emphasis on applications in transportation systems analysis (urban, air, ocean, highway, and pickup and delivery systems) and in the planning and design of logistically oriented urban service systems (e.g., fire and police departments, emergency medical services, and emergency repair services). Unified study of functions of random variables, geometrical probability, multi-server queuing theory, spatial location theory, network analysis and graph theory, and relevant methods of simulation. Computer exercises and discussions of implementation difficulties.
<br><I>R. C. Larson, A. R. Odoni, A. I. Barnett</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.074"></a>
<p><h3>15.074J Predictive Data Analytics and Statistical Modeling
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mESDa.html#ESD.755">ESD.755J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6b.html#6.431">6.431</a>, <a href="m15a.html#15.060">15.060</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-5
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Designed for students who have some acquaintance with probability and/or statistics and want exposure to a broader range of topics and examples. Begins with a brief review of statistics and regression by addressing advanced topics, such as bootstrap resampling, variable selection, data and regression diagnostics, visualization, and Bayesian and robust methods. Goes on to cover data-mining and machine learning, including classification, logistic regression, and clustering. Culminates with time series analysis and forecasting, design of experiments, analysis of variance, and process control. Students use statistical computing systems based on Excel add-ins and stand-alone packages. Includes case studies involving finance, management science, consulting, risk management, and engineering systems. Term project required.
<br><I>R. E. Welsch</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.075"></a>
<p><h3>15.075J Statistical Thinking and Data Analysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mESDa.html#ESD.07">ESD.07J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.041">6.041</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-376</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>R4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-085</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces statistical data analysis. Topics chosen from applied probability, sampling, estimation, hypothesis testing, linear regression, analysis of variance, categorical data analysis, and nonparametric statistics.
<br><I>R. Welsch</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=15.075');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.077"></a>
<p><h3>15.077J Statistical Learning and Data Mining
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mESDa.html#ESD.753">ESD.753J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6b.html#6.431">6.431</a>, <a href="m15a.html#15.085">15.085</a>, or <a href="m18a.html#18.440">18.440</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a> or <a href="m18b.html#18.700">18.700</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW4-5.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-345</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>T4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-085</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Advanced introduction to the theory and application of statistics, data-mining, and machine learning, concentrating on techniques used in management science, finance, consulting, engineering systems, and bioinformatics. First half builds the statistical foundation for the second half, with topics selected from sampling, including the bootstrap, theory of estimation, testing, nonparametric statistics, analysis of variance, categorical data analysis, regression analysis, MCMC, EM, Gibbs sampling, and Bayesian methods. Second half focuses on data mining, supervised learning, and multivariate analysis. Topics selected from logistic regression; principal components and dimension reduction; discrimination and classification analysis, including trees (CART), partial least squares, nearest neighbor and regularized methods, support vector machines, boosting and bagging, clustering, independent component analysis, and nonparametric regression. Uses statistics software packages, such as R and MATLAB for data analysis and data mining.  Term project required.
<br><I>R. E. Welsch</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=15.077');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.078"></a>
<p><h3>15.078J Models, Data and Inference for Socio-Technical Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mESDa.html#ESD.86">ESD.86J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mESDa.html#ESD.83">ESD.83</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.041">6.041</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW10.30-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-372</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F10.30-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-385</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Use data and systems knowledge to build models of complex socio-technical systems for improved system design and decision-making. Enhance model-building skills, including: review and extension of functions of random variables, Poisson processes, and Markov processes. Move from applied probability to statistics via Chi-squared t and f tests, derived as functions of random variables. Review classical statistics, hypothesis tests, regression, correlation and causation, simple data mining techniques, and Bayesian vs. classical statistics. Class project.
<br><I>R. Larson, R. Welsch</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.081"></a>
<p><h3>15.081J Introduction to Mathematical Programming
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6a.html#6.251">6.251J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to linear optimization and its extensions emphasizing both methodology and the underlying mathematical structures and geometrical ideas. Covers classical theory of linear programming as well as some recent advances in the field. Topics: simplex method; duality theory; sensitivity analysis; network flow problems; decomposition; integer programming; interior point algorithms for linear programming; and introduction to combinatorial optimization and NP-completeness.
<br><I>J. N. Tsitsiklis, A. Schulz</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.082"></a>
<p><h3>15.082J Network Optimization
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mESDa.html#ESD.78">ESD.78J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15a.html#15.081">15.081</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Doctoral seminar on network models and algorithms. Emphasis on the design and analysis of efficient algorithms for network flow models. Topics may vary from year to year.
<br><I>J. Orlin</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.083"></a>
<p><h3>15.083J Integer Programming and Combinatorial Optimization
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6c.html#6.859">6.859J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15a.html#15.081">15.081J</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-276</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F3-4.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-376</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>In-depth treatment of the modern theory of integer programming and combinatorial optimization, emphasizing geometry, duality, and algorithms. Topics include formulating problems in integer variables, enhancement of formulations, ideal formulations, integer programming duality, linear and semidefinite relaxations, lattices and their applications, the geometry of integer programming, primal methods, cutting plane methods, connections with algebraic geometry, computational complexity, approximation algorithms, heuristic and enumerative algorithms, mixed integer programming and solutions of large-scale problems.
<br><I>D. J. Bertsimas, A. S. Schulz</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=15.083');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.084"></a>
<p><h3>15.084J Nonlinear Programming
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6a.html#6.252">6.252J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.100">18.100</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-361</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F10.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-390</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A unified analytical and computational approach to nonlinear optimization problems. Unconstrained optimization methods include gradient, conjugate direction, Newton, and quasi-Newton methods. Constrained optimization methods include feasible directions, projection, interior point, and Lagrange multiplier methods. Convex analysis, Lagrangian relaxation, nondifferentiable optimization, and applications in integer programming. Comprehensive treatment of optimality conditions, Lagrange multiplier theory, and duality theory. Applications drawn from control, communications, power systems, and resource allocation problems.
<br><I>R. M. Freund, D. P. Bertsekas, G. Perakis</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=15.084');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.085"></a>
<p><h3>15.085J Fundamentals of Probability
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6b.html#6.436">6.436J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to probability theory. Probability spaces and measures. Discrete and continuous random variables. Conditioning and independence. Multivariate normal distribution. Abstract integration, expectation, and related convergence results. Moment generating and  characteristic functions. Bernoulli and Poisson process. Finite-state  Markov chains. Convergence notions and their relations. Limit theorems. Familiarity with elementary notions in probability and real analysis is desirable.
<br><I>J. N. Tsitsiklis, D. Gamarnik</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.093"></a>
<p><h3>15.093J Optimization Methods
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6a.html#6.255">6.255J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the principal algorithms for linear, network, discrete, robust, nonlinear, dynamic optimization and optimal control. Emphasizes methodology and the underlying mathematical structures. Topics include the simplex method, network flow methods, branch and bound and cutting plane methods for discrete optimization, optimality conditions for nonlinear optimization, interior point methods for convex optimization, Newton's method, heuristic methods, and dynamic programming and optimal control methods.
<br><I>D. Bertsimas, P. Parrilo</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.094"></a>
<p><h3>15.094J Robust Modeling, Optimization, and Computation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1a.html#1.142">1.142J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W EVE (4-7 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-372</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>M12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-057</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces modern robust optimization, including theory, applications, and computation. Presents formulations and their connection to probability, information and risk theory for conic optimization (linear, second-order, and semidefinite cones) and integer optimization. Application domains include analysis and optimization of stochastic networks, optimal mechanism design, network information theory, transportation, pattern classification, structural and engineering design, and financial engineering. Students formulate and solve a problem aligned with their interests in a final project.
<br><I>D. Bertsimas, R. M. Freund</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.096"></a>
<p><h3>15.096 Prediction: Machine Learning and Statistics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Gives a practical background and theoretical foundation to machine learning algorithms and Bayesian analysis. Includes an overview of the top ten algorithms in data mining. Covers frameworks for knowledge discovery, a unified view of support vector machines, AdaBoost and regression based on regularized risk minimization; generalization bounds from statistical learning theory based on covering numbers, VC dimension, and the margin theory; as well as basic Bayesian analysis and notes on the history of machine learning and statistics.
<br><I>C. Rudin</I><br>
</p><!--end-->

<br>Doctoral student seminar covering current topics related to operations research.
<br><I>D. Bertsimas, R. Freund, T. L. Magnanti, J. B. Orlin, G. Perakis, A. S. Schulz</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<p>For additional related subjects in Statistics, see:

<p>Management: <a href="m15a.html#15.034">15.034</a>, <a href="m15a.html#15.070">15.070</a>, <a href="m15a.html#15.075">15.075</a>, and <a href="m15a.html#15.098">15.098</a>
<p>Mathematics: <a href="m18a.html#18.05">18.05</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.175">18.175</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.177">18.177</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.440">18.440</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.443">18.443</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.445">18.445</a>, and <a href="m18a.html#18.465">18.465</a>

<h2>Health Care Management</h2>
<a name="15.121"></a>
<p><h3>15.121J Clinical Trials in Biomedical Enterprise
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mHSTb.html#HST.975">HST.975J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Clinical trials have become one of the leading barriers to sucess in the introduction of new products and services for the healthcare industry. Subject enables healthcare managers to ask the important questions surrounding a decision to pursue a clinical trial. Deciding to participate in a clinical trial can sometimes result in expensive, long-term corporate commitments, which can have a significant impact on the company's success or failure, particularly in the case of smaller companies. Subject explores issues related to determing whether a clinical trial is needed to significantly further the important goals of the company. Topics include the design, implementation, analysis and presentation of clinical trials. Case scenarios are presented by professionals in the field, and students are asked to develop their own outline plan and clinical trial study plan from the sample cases provided. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>H. Golub</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.122"></a>
<p><h3>15.122J Critical Reading and Technical Assessment of Biomedical Information
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">; first half of term
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mHSTb.html#HST.977">HST.977J</A>)
<br>Prereq: SB degree in Biological Science or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 1-0-2
<br>Begins Feb 10. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>M EVE (6.30-8.30 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E25">E25-101</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Gain experience in critical reading of scientific literature,  including patents, journal articles and FDA labels, with an emphasis on analyzing clinical controversies and emerging technologies in subject areas that have been or could become sources of entrepreneurial activity. Students required to analyze a variety of topics in the scientific literature, including screening for and cost-effectiveness of early detection of cancer, therapeutic opportunities in oncology, evaluation of immunotoxins and antibody therapies, and new prospects for the treatment of autoimmune disorders. To support the discussion of these topics, outside experts may be invited to participate as facilitators.
<br><I>S. Lapidus, J. Karp</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.123"></a>
<p><h3>15.123J Dynamics of Biomedical Technologies
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mHSTb.html#HST.979">HST.979J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T EVE (4-6.30 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E25">E25-119</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents a systematic approach to developing a biomedical product and launching a startup company to successfully commercialize that product. Faculty and outside experts discuss assigned readings and lecture on a range of relevant topics. Students work in project teams dedicated to finding a commercial solution to an important clinical need, and interact with clinicians, potential customers, other stakeholders, potential competitors and expert consultants. Students present their analyses and solutions regarding each of the critical issues their business would face in addressing the identified clinical need. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>R. Anders, J. Tolkoff, C. Berke, R. J. Cohen</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=15.123');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.124"></a>
<p><h3>15.124J Evaluating a Biomedical Business Concept
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mHSTb.html#HST.973">HST.973J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Involves critical analysis of new biomedical business ideas. Inventors or principals of early stage companies present their ideas to the class and provide background material including scientific papers and patents. A team of students is assigned to evaluate each business idea. Students interact with the companies, potential customers, other stakeholders and experts to develop a series of analyses concerning the critical issues that each business idea would face. Company and student presentations supplemented by topic-specific lectures and presentations by biomedical entrepreneurs. Enrollment limited. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>C. Berke, R. Anders, R. J. Cohen</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.127"></a>
<p><h3>15.127J Designing and Sustaining Technology Innovation for Global Health Practice
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mHSTb.html#HST.939">HST.939J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T EVE (3.30-6.30 PM)</i> (HMS MEC 250)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Course trains students to think and act like global health leaders and entrepreneurs. Looks at the business of running a social venture and how to plan and provide access to life-saving medicines and essential services in international and domestic settings.  Considers specific case studies for influential and leading edge technologies for health services delivery, as well as human resources, and pharmaceutical and diagnostic design in resource-poor settings. Features lectures and skills-based tutorial sessions led by industry, foundation, and academic leaders.  Lectures provide the foundation for a design project that may involve creation of a market or business plan, product design specification, or research study. Limited to 24.
<br><I>U. Demirci, J. Blander</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.128"></a>
<p><h3>15.128J Neurotechnology Ventures
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m9a.html#9.455">9.455J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.454">20.454J</A>, <A HREF="mMASa.html#MAS.883">MAS.883J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-7
<br>URL: <a href="http://neuro.media.mit.edu/classes/neuroven/">http://neuro.media.mit.edu/classes/neuroven/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Special seminar focusing on envisioning, launching, and building start-ups that are commercializing innovations from neuroscience and neuroengineering.  Topics include neuroimaging, diagnostics, motor rehabilitation, affective computing, novel scientific tools, and novel therapeutics including neuropharmaceuticals, neuromodulation, neuroprosthetics, regenerative medicine, and more.  Each class is devoted to a specific topic area, exploring issues from the deeply technical through the market opportunity.  Working in small groups students prepare a business plan executive summary for a new neurotechnology start-up.
<br><I>E. S. Boyden, R. Ellis-Behnke, J. Bonsen</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.136"></a>
<p><h3>15.136J Principles and Practice of Drug Development
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m7a.html#7.547">7.547J</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.547">10.547J</A>, <A HREF="mESDa.html#ESD.691">ESD.691J</A>, <A HREF="mHSTb.html#HST.920">HST.920J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br>URL: <a href="http://hst-hu-mit.mit.edu/courses/HST920.shtml">http://hst-hu-mit.mit.edu/courses/HST920.shtml</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Description and critical assessment of the major issues and stages of developing a pharmaceutical or biopharmaceutical. Drug discovery, preclinical development, clinical investigation, manufacturing and regulatory issues considered for small and large molecules. Economic and financial considerations of the drug development process. Multidisciplinary perspective from faculty in clinical; life; and management sciences; as well as industry guests.
<br><I>T. J. Allen, C. L. Cooney, S. N. Finkelstein, A. J. Sinskey, G. K. Raju</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.137"></a>
<p><h3>15.137J Case Studies and Strategies in Drug Discovery and Development
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m7a.html#7.549">7.549J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.486">20.486J</A>, <A HREF="mHSTb.html#HST.916">HST.916J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M EVE (4-6 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-614</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>The stages in drug discovery and development begin with target identification and end with the submission of preclinical and clinical data to the regulatory authorities. Following identification of a lead compound, there is optimization of structures for pharmaceutical properties, bioavailability, and safety. Subject relies on actual cases presented by the scientist(s) involved in discovery and drug development. A major goal is to analyze the cases and determine how the discovery and development process might be influenced by new and future technologies.
<br><I>S. R. Tannenbaum, A. J. Sinskey, A. Wood</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.141"></a>
<p><h3>15.141J Economics of the Health Care Industries
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mHSTb.html#HST.918">HST.918J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W EVE (4-7 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-262</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on economic issues in various health care and allied industries, such as the pharmaceutical, biotechnology, medical device, vaccine and diagnostic sectors. Addresses differences between health care and other industries; regulatory issues, in the US and globally, that involve establishment of the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of treatments; managing those who manage research and development; policies to incentivize research and development for neglected tropical diseases; strategic issues in global pricing and marketing; use of e-commerce and information technology; personalized/stratified medicines and diagnostic biomarkers; and formation and management of various alliances. Visiting speakers from academia, government, NGOs, and industry. Assignments include 4 to 6 essays.
<br><I>E. R. Berndt</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<h2>Global Economics & Management</h2>
<a name="15.218"></a>
<p><h3>15.218 Global Economic Challenges and Opportunities
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR8.30-10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-276</a>) or <i>TR10-11.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-276</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analyzes the causes, effects and policy responses to major global economic issues. Focuses on financial crises, beginning with historical examples in emerging markets and building up to recent crises. Also focuses on current economic debates and challenges facing countries around the world. Possible topics include unsustainable debt, European union, aging populations, global warming, inequality and poverty, oil and commodity markets, international institutions, and the implications of rapid growth in the BRICs (Brazil, Russia, India, and China) and "frontier" economies. Some background in international economics recommended.
<br><I>K. Forbes</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=15.218');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.220"></a>
<p><h3>15.220 Global Strategy and Organization
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); partial term
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30 (BEGINS MARCH 31)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-223</a>) or <i>TR2.30-4 (BEGINS MARCH 31)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-223</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on the international dimensions of strategy and organization, and provides a framework for formulating strategies in an increasingly complex world economy, and for making those strategies work effectively. Topics include the globalization of industries, the continuing role of country factors in competition, organization of multinational enterprises, building global networks, and the changing managerial tasks under conditions of globalization.
<br><I>Staff</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=15.220');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.221"></a>
<p><h3>15.221 Global Strategy and Organization
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); first half of term
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>R8.30-11.30 (ENDS MARCH 14)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-233</a>) or <i>R1-4 (ENDS MARCH 14)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-233</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on the international dimensions of strategy and organization, and provides a framework for formulating strategies in an increasingly complex world economy, and for making those strategies work effectively. Topics include the globalization of industries, the continuing role of country factors in competition, organization of multinational enterprises, building global networks, and the changing managerial tasks under conditions of globalization. Restricted to Sloan Fellows in Innovation and Global Leadership.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.223"></a>
<p><h3>15.223 Global Markets, National Policies and the Competitive Advantages of Firms
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">); first half of term
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW10-11.30 (ENDS MARCH 14)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-250</a>) or <i>MW2.30-4 (ENDS MARCH 14)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-262</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines opportunities and risks firms face in today's global market. Provides conceptual tools for analyzing how governments and social institutions influence economic competition among firms embedded in different national settings. Public policies and institutions that shape competitive outcomes are examined through cases and analytical readings on different companies and industries operating in both developed and emerging markets.
<br><I>S. Johnson, E. Obukhova</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.225"></a>
<p><h3>15.225 Economy and Business in Modern China and India: China Lab and India Lab
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR4-5.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-315</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an integrated approach to analyze the economies of China and India  through action learning. The classroom portion covers macro issues of China and India, project-related issues and personal and learning reflections. The onsite portion involves working with a host company in China or in India. Students work in teams to  tackle a real world business problem with an entrepreneurial Chinese or Indian company and produce a final deliverable for the host company. Students are required to take a mid semester trip during SIP and Spring Break to China or India to work onsite with the host company. Past lab projects have included creating a business plan for fundraising, developing a new market strategy, and crafting financial models; the projects have included both for-profit and NGO projects. Limited to graduate students who participate in China Lab or India Lab.
<br><I>J. Grant, Y. Huang, M. Jester</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.227"></a><a name="15.228"></a><a name="15.229"></a>
<p><h3>15.227 - 15.229 Seminar in International Management
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged
<br><b>15.228:</b> Ends March 14. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>M EVE (6-9 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-372</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-376</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Group study of current topics related to international business.
<br><I>Staff</I><br><b>15.228:</b> No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.231"></a>
<p><h3>15.231J Enabling Energy Efficiency: Practice and Innovation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11c.html#11.379">11.379J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m11a.html#11.168">11.168</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the ways in which energy efficiency is enabled by innovations in technology, business models, and public initiatives, and its potential to create societal, economic and carbon benefits. Supported by guest interviews with government and industry efficiency leaders, students critically examine current practice methods and issues. Develops skills in areas such as building energy analysis, economic resource planning, energy information and behavioral analysis, and business/program strategy development and evaluation. Assignments challenge students to discover, analyze, and articulate strategic approaches to scaling transformative ideas. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 25.
<br><I>H. Michaels</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.232"></a>
<p><h3>15.232 Business Model Innovation: Global Health in Frontier Markets
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">); first half of term
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines how new approaches to operations, revenue, marketing, finance, and strategy enable improved health care in resource-limited settings across Africa, Latin America, and Asia. Draws on system dynamics, design thinking, and strategic analysis. Explores success and failure in innovative healthcare delivery. Analysis of novel business models draws on case studies, videos, industry reports, research, and guest speakers. Students present their assessments of innovative base-of-the-pyramid health enterprises that aim to do more with less. Students who have not taken at least three management or business classes must apply to the instructor for permission to enroll before the first day of class.
<br><I>A. Sastry</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.233"></a>
<p><h3>15.233 Global Health Lab
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-335</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Pairs faculty-mentored student teams with enterprises on the front lines of health care delivery in sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia. Custom-designed projects in strategy, business model innovation, operations, marketing, and technology designed to tackle specific barriers identified by each partnering organization. Interactive cases, practical exercises, and conversations with experts, all designed to support project work before, during, and after an intensive two-week onsite collaboration with entrepreneurs, leaders, staff, and stakeholders. Assignments include a portfolio of host deliverables, a foundational toolkit designed to support each project, and a distillation of learning from the field. Enrolled students must be available to work on site in Africa or South Asia for the entire weeks of SIP and Spring Break. Admission by application and interview in the prior November and December. Preference to students who have taken 15.232. Graduate students only.
<br><I>A. Sastry</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.249"></a>
<p><h3>15.249 Institutions, Society, and International Business
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Advanced seminar in the study of international management. Covers major theoretical work and approaches to empirical research in the fields of national business systems and globalization, linking them to the core frameworks of strategy and organization theory. Restricted to doctoral students.
<br><I>E. Obukhova</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<h2>History, Environment and Ethics</h2>
<a name="15.268"></a>
<p><h3>15.268 Choice Points: Readings on the Exercise of Power and Responsibility
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-6 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>F10-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-250</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Managerial power and responsibility. Examines conflicts between power and moral responsibility and the contexts for choice in dealing with a number of such problems. Readings are principally "classics" used to illustrate several enduring issues. Restricted to Sloan Fellows in Innovation and Global Leadership.
<br>Consult S. Sacca<br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=15.268');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.269"></a>
<p><h3>15.269 Leadership Stories:  Literature, Ethics, and Authority
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores how we use story to articulate ethical norms.  The syllabus consists of short fiction, novels, plays, feature films and some non-fiction. Major topics include leadership and authority, professionalism, the nature of ethical standards, social enterprise, and questions of gender, cultural and individual identity, and work/life balance. Materials vary from year to year, but past readings have included work by Robert Bolt, Michael Frayn, Timothy Mo, Wole Soyinka, H.D. Thoreau, and others; films have included <i>Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, Hotel Rwanda, The Descendants, Motorcycle Diaries, Three Kings</i>, and others. Draws on various professions and national cultures, and is run as a series of moderated discussions, with students centrally engaged in the teaching process.
<br><I>L. Hafrey</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<h2>Communication</h2>
<a name="15.270"></a>
<p><h3>15.270 Ethical Practice:  Leading Through Professionalism, Social Responsibility, and System Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); partial term
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW2.30-4 (BEGINS MARCH 31)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-262</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to ethics in business, with a focus on business management. Students explore theoretical concepts in business ethics, and cases representing the challenges they will likely face as managers. Opportunity to work with guest faculty as well as business and other professional practitioners. Individual sessions take the form of moderated discussion, with occasional short lectures from instructor.
<br><I>L. Hafrey</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=15.270');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.277"></a>
<p><h3>15.277 Seminar in Communications
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>
<a name="15.278"></a>
<h3>15.278 Seminar in Communications
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Group study of current topics related to communication.
<br><I>J. Yates</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.279"></a>
<p><h3>15.279 Management Communication for Undergraduates
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11.30-1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-376</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-217</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops writing, speaking, teamwork, interpersonal, and cross-cultural communication skills necessary for management professionals. Assignments include creating persuasive memos, writing in response to cases, and giving presentations. Major project involves the production of a team report and presentation on a topic of interest to a professional audience. Instruction in written and oral communication provided.
<br><I>L. Breslow</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=15.279');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.280"></a>
<p><h3>15.280 Communication for Leaders
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-1-5
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m15c.html#15.710">15.710</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students develop and polish communication strategies and methods through discussion, examples, and practice. Emphasizes writing and speaking skills necessary for effective leaders. Includes several oral and written assignments which are integrated with other subjects, and with career development activities, when possible. Schedule and curriculum coordinated with Organizational Processes.  Mandatory one hour recitation in small groups. Restricted to first-year Sloan graduate students.
<br><I>N. Hartman, C. Kelly, R. Pittore, V. Healy-Tangney, K. Blackburn, M. Kazakoff, J.Yates</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.281"></a>
<p><h3>15.281 Advanced Leadership Communication
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15a.html#15.279">15.279</a>, <a href="m15a.html#15.280">15.280</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-250</a>) or <i>MW2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-250</a>) or <i>TR8.30-10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-221</a>) or <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-221</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces interactive oral and interpersonal communication skills critical to leaders, including strategies for presenting to a hostile audience, running effective and productive meetings, active listening, and contributing to group decision-making. Includes team-run classes on chosen communication topics, and an individual analysis of leadership qualities and characteristics. Students deliver an oral presentation and an executive summary, both aimed at a business audience.
<br><I>N. Hartman</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.289"></a>
<p><h3>15.289 Doctoral Seminar: Communication Skills for Academics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">; partial term
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W8.30-10.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-350</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on the communication skills needed for a career in academia. Topics include writing for academic journals, preparing and delivering conference papers and job talks, peer reviewing for journals and conferences, and teaching. Participants are expected to work on a written project and deliver an oral presentation based on their current research. Restricted to doctoral students who have completed their first year. Limited to 20; priority to Sloan students.
<br><I>J. Yates, L. Breslow</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=15.289');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->

<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Course 16: Aeronautics and Astronautics<br>Spring
2014</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://web.mit.edu/aeroastro/www/"><i>Course 16 Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course16.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=++16&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>16.00-16.599 plus UROP and EP</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m16b.html">16.60-16.999 plus ThG</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<a name="16.00A"></a>
<p><h3>16.00AJ Fundamentals of Engineering Design: Explore Space, Sea and Earth
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2a.html#2.00A">2.00AJ</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-3-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Student teams formulate and complete space/earth/ocean exploration-based design projects with weekly milestones. Introduces core engineering themes, principles, and modes of thinking. Specialized learning modules enable teams to focus on the knowledge required to complete their projects, such as machine elements, electronics, design process, visualization and communication. Includes exercises in written and oral communication and team building. Examples of projects include surveying a lake for millfoil, from a remote controlled aircraft, and then sending out robotic harvesters to clear the invasive growth; and exploration to search for the evidence of life on a moon of Jupiter, with scientists participating through teleoperation and supervisory control of robots. Enrollment limited; preference to freshmen.
<br><I>A. H. Techet, D. Newman</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.00"></a>
<p><h3>16.00 Introduction to Aerospace and Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-1-5
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/16.00/">http://web.mit.edu/16.00/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-141</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>The fundamental concepts and approaches of aerospace engineering are highlighted through lectures on aeronautics, astronautics, and design. Active learning aerospace modules make use of information technology. Student teams are immersed in a hands-on, lighter-than-air (LTA) vehicle design project where they design, build, and fly radio-controlled LTA vehicles. The connections between theory and practice are realized in the design exercises. Required design reviews precede the LTA race competition. The performance, weight, and principle characteristics of the LTA vehicles are estimated and illustrated using physics, mathematics, and chemistry known to freshmen, the emphasis being on the application of this knowledge to aerospace engineering and design rather than on exposure to new science and mathematics. Includes exercises in written and oral communication and team building.
<br><I>J. A. Hoffman</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.001"></a>
<p><h3>16.001 Unified Engineering I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>; <I>Coreq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.034">18.034</a>; <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a></I>
<br>Units: 5-1-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>16.001 and 16.002 require simultaneous registration. Presents fundamental principles and methods of aerospace engineering, as well as their interrelationship and applications, through lectures, recitations, design problems, and labs. Materials and structures, including statics, analysis of trusses, the analysis of statically determinate and indeterminate systems, and the stress-strain behavior of materials. Fluid mechanics, including conservation laws for fluid flows, the integral momentum theorem and applications, potential flow, vorticity and circulation, and the characterization of airfoil performance. Thermodynamics, including the thermodynamic state of a system, work, heat and various forms of energy, the first law of thermodynamics, heat engines, reversible and irreversible processes, entropy, and the second law of thermodynamics. Signals and systems, including linear and time invariant systems, convolution, and transform analysis.
<br><I>Z. S. Spakovszky, H. Balakrishnan, O. de Weck, P. Lozano, R. Radovitzky</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.002"></a>
<p><h3>16.002 Unified Engineering II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>; <I>Coreq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.034">18.034</a>; <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a></I>
<br>Units: 5-1-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>16.001 and 16.002 require simultaneous registration. Presents fundamental principles and methods of aerospace engineering, as well as their interrelationship and applications, through lectures, recitations, design problems, and labs. Materials and structures, including statics, analysis of trusses, the analysis of statically determinate and indeterminate systems, and the stress-strain behavior of materials. Fluid mechanics, including conservation laws for fluid flows, the integral momentum theorem and applications, potential flow, vorticity and circulation, and the characterization of airfoil performance. Thermodynamics, including the thermodynamic state of a system, work, heat and various forms of energy, the first law of thermodynamics, heat engines, reversible and irreversible processes, entropy, and the second law of thermodynamics. Signals and systems, including linear and time invariant systems, convolution, and transform analysis.
<br><I>Z. S. Spakovszky, H. Balakrishnan, O. de Weck, P. Lozano, R. Radovitzky</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.003"></a>
<p><h3>16.003 Unified Engineering III
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m16a.html#16.001">16.001</a>, <a href="m16a.html#16.002">16.002</a>
<br>Units: 5-1-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-141</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=33">33-419</a>) or <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=33">33-419</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>16.003 and 16.004 require simultaneous registration.
