<h1 align="center">Course 18: Mathematics<br>Spring
2014</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://www-math.mit.edu/"><i>Course 18 Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course18.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=++18&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>18.01-18.499</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m18b.html">18.50-18.THG</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<h2>General Mathematics</h2>
<a name="18.01"></a>
<p><h3>18.01 Calculus
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/calc1.gif" alt="Calculus I" title="Calculus I" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.014">18.014</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.01A">18.01A</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.181A">CC.181A</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.1801">ES.1801</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.181A">ES.181A</A>
<br>URL: <a href="http://www-math.mit.edu/18.01/">http://www-math.mit.edu/18.01/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11,F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-139</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>MW2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-139</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Differentiation and integration of functions of one variable, with applications.  Informal treatment of limits and continuity.  Differentiation: definition, rules, application to graphing, rates, approximations, and extremum problems. Indefinite integration; separable first-order differential equations.  Definite integral; fundamental theorem of calculus. Applications of integration to geometry and science.  Elementary functions.  Techniques of integration.  Polar coordinates. L'Hopital's rule.  Improper integrals.  Infinite series: geometric, p-harmonic, simple comparison tests, power series for some elementary functions.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Speck</I><br>Spring: Information: G. Staffilani<br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014JA&Subject=18.01');" >Textbooks (IAP 2014)</a></font>; <a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=18.01');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.01A"></a>
<p><h3>18.01A Calculus
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/calc1.gif" alt="Calculus I" title="Calculus I" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">; first half of term
<br>Prereq: Knowledge of differentiation and elementary integration
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.01">18.01</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.014">18.014</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.181A">CC.181A</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.1801">ES.1801</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.181A">ES.181A</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Six-week review of one-variable calculus, emphasizing material not on the high-school AB syllabus: integration techniques and applications, improper integrals, infinite series, applications to other topics, such as probability and statistics, as time permits. Prerequisites: one year of high-school calculus or the equivalent, with a score of 4 or 5 on the AB Calculus test (or the AB portion of the BC test, or an equivalent score on a standard international exam), or equivalent college transfer credit, or a passing grade on the first half of the 18.01 advanced standing exam.
<br><I>J. W. Bush</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.014"></a>
<p><h3>18.014 Calculus with Theory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/calc1.gif" alt="Calculus I" title="Calculus I" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.01">18.01</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.01A">18.01A</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.181A">CC.181A</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.1801">ES.1801</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.181A">ES.181A</A>
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.014">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.014</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers the same material as 18.01, but at a deeper and more rigorous level. Emphasizes careful reasoning and understanding of proofs. Assumes knowledge of elementary calculus. Topics: axioms for the real numbers; the Riemann integral; limits, theorems on continuous functions; derivatives of functions of one variable; the fundamental theorems of calculus; Taylor's theorem; infinite series, power series, rigorous treatment of the elementary functions.
<br><I>C. Barwick</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.02"></a>
<p><h3>18.02 Calculus
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/calc2.gif" alt="Calculus II" title="Calculus II" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.022">18.022</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.023">18.023</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.024">18.024</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.02A">18.02A</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.1802">CC.1802</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.182A">CC.182A</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.1802">ES.1802</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.182A">ES.182A</A>
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.02">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.02</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11,F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=54">54-100</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>MW10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-308</a>) or <i>MW11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-308</a>) or <i>MW12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-308</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-310</a>) or <i>MW1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-308</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-162</a>) or <i>MW2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-308</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Calculus of several variables. Vector algebra in 3-space, determinants, matrices. Vector-valued functions of one variable, space motion. Scalar functions of several variables: partial differentiation, gradient, optimization techniques. Double integrals and line integrals in the plane; exact differentials and conservative fields; Green's theorem and applications, triple integrals, line and surface integrals in space, Divergence theorem, Stokes' theorem; applications.
<br>Fall: <I>W. Minicozzi</I><br>Spring: <I>A. Postnikov</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=18.02');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.02A"></a>
<p><h3>18.02A Calculus
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/calc2.gif" alt="Calculus II" title="Calculus II" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.02">18.02</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.022">18.022</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.023">18.023</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.024">18.024</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.1802">CC.1802</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.182A">CC.182A</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.1802">ES.1802</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.182A">ES.182A</A>
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.02A">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.02A</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11,F2 (ENDS MARCH 21)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-129</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>MW2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-129</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>First half is taught during the last six weeks of the  Fall term; covers material in the first half of 18.02 (through double integrals). Second half of 18.02A can be taken either during IAP (daily lectures) or during the first half of the Spring term; it covers the remaining material in 18.02.
<br>Fall: <I>J. W. Bush</I><br>Spring: Information: G. Staffilani<br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014JA&Subject=18.02A');" >Textbooks (IAP 2014)</a></font>; <a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=18.02A');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.022"></a>
<p><h3>18.022 Calculus
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/calc2.gif" alt="Calculus II" title="Calculus II" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.02">18.02</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.023">18.023</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.024">18.024</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.02A">18.02A</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.1802">CC.1802</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.182A">CC.182A</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.1802">ES.1802</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.182A">ES.182A</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Calculus of several variables. Topics as in 18.02 but with more focus on mathematical concepts. Vector algebra, dot product, matrices, determinant. Functions of several variables, continuity, differentiability, derivative. Parametrized curves, arc length, curvature, torsion. Vector fields, gradient, curl, divergence. Multiple integrals, change of variables, line integrals, surface integrals. Stokes' theorem in one, two, and three dimensions.
<br><I>A. Borodin</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.023"></a>
<p><h3>18.023 Calculus with Applications
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/calc2.gif" alt="Calculus II" title="Calculus II" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.02">18.02</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.022">18.022</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.024">18.024</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.02A">18.02A</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.1802">CC.1802</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.182A">CC.182A</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.1802">ES.1802</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.182A">ES.182A</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Calculus of several variables, emphasizing applications. Vector algebra, partial differentiation, multiple integrals, and vector calculus. Asymptotic and numerical methods.
<br>Information: M. X. Goemans<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.024"></a>
<p><h3>18.024 Calculus with Theory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/calc2.gif" alt="Calculus II" title="Calculus II" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">

<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.02">18.02</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.022">18.022</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.023">18.023</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.02A">18.02A</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.1802">CC.1802</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.182A">CC.182A</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.1802">ES.1802</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.182A">ES.182A</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11,F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-122</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>MW3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-122</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Continues 18.014. Parallel to 18.02, but at a deeper level, emphasizing careful reasoning and understanding of proofs. Considerable emphasis on linear algebra and vector integral calculus.

<a name="18.03"></a>
<p><h3>18.03 Differential Equations
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a></I>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.034">18.034</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.036">18.036</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.1803">CC.1803</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.1803">ES.1803</A>
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.03">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.03</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=10">10-250</a>) or <i>MWF2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=10">10-250</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-153</a>) or <i>TR10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-153</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-156</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=24">24-307</a>) or <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-153</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-156</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=24">24-307</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=24">24-112</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-168</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-314</a>) or <i>TR12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-153</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-156</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=24">24-307</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=24">24-112</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-168</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-314</a>) or <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-156</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=24">24-307</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=24">24-112</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-145</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-314</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-322</a>) or <i>TR2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-156</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=24">24-112</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-145</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-314</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-322</a>) or <i>TR3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-112</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-156</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Study of differential equations, including modeling physical systems. Solution of first-order ODEs by analytical, graphical, and numerical methods. Linear ODEs with constant coefficients. Complex numbers and exponentials. Inhomogeneous equations: polynomial, sinusoidal, and exponential inputs. Oscillations, damping, resonance. Fourier series. Matrices, eigenvalues, eigenvectors, diagonalization. First order linear systems: normal modes, matrix exponentials, variation of parameters. Heat equation, wave equation. Nonlinear autonomous systems: critical point analysis, phase plane diagrams.
<br>Fall: <I>D. Jerison, H. R. Miller</I><br>Spring: <I>B. Poonen</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=18.03');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.034"></a>
<p><h3>18.034 Differential Equations
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a></I>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.036">18.036</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.1803">CC.1803</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.1803">ES.1803</A>
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.034">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.034</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-159</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-168</a>) or <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-168</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers much of the same material as 18.03 with more emphasis on theory. The point of view is rigorous and results are proven.  Local existence and uniqueness of solutions.
<br><I>J. Lauer</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=18.034');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.036"></a>
<p><h3>18.036 Differential Equations
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a></I>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.034">18.034</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.1803">CC.1803</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.1803">ES.1803</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Study of ordinary differential equations (ODEs), including modeling physical systems. Solution of first-order ODEs by analytical, graphical, and numerical methods.  Linear ODEs, primarily second order with constant coefficients. Complex numbers and exponentials. Inhomogeneous equations: polynomial, sinusoidal, and exponential inputs. Oscillations, damping, resonance. Fourier series inputs; resonant terms. Matrix methods: eigenvalues and eigenvectors, matrix powers and exponentials. Applications to linear systems. Nonlinear autonomous systems: critical point analysis, phase plane diagrams, applications to modeling. Enrollment limited.
<br>Information: H. R. Miller<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.04"></a>
<p><h3>18.04 Complex Variables with Applications
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.034">18.034</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.075">18.075</A>
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/18.04/">http://math.mit.edu/18.04/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-163</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-310</a>) or <i>W3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-310</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Complex algebra and functions; analyticity; contour integration, Cauchy's theorem; singularities, Taylor and Laurent series; residues, evaluation of integrals; multivalued functions, potential theory in two dimensions; Fourier analysis, Laplace transforms, and partial differential equations.
<br><I>H. Cheng</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=18.04');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.05"></a>
<p><h3>18.05 Introduction to Probability and Statistics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.05">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.05</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TRF1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-082</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Elementary introduction with applications. Basic probability models. Combinatorics. Random variables. Discrete and continuous probability distributions. Statistical estimation and testing. Confidence intervals. Introduction to linear regression.
<br><I>J. Orloff</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.06"></a>
<p><h3>18.06 Linear Algebra
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18b.html#18.700">18.700</A>
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/18.06/www/">http://web.mit.edu/18.06/www/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=10">10-250</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>T10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-144</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-310</a>) or <i>T11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-144</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-149</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-136</a>) or <i>T12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-144</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-149</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-112</a>) or <i>T1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-144</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-153</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-155</a>) or <i>T2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-144</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-155</a>) or <i>T3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-144</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Basic subject on matrix theory and linear algebra, emphasizing topics useful in other disciplines, including systems of equations, vector spaces, determinants, eigenvalues, singular value decomposition, and positive definite matrices. Applications to least-squares approximations, stability of differential equations, networks, Fourier transforms, and Markov processes. Uses MATLAB. Compared with 18.700, more emphasis on matrix algorithms and many applications.
<br>Fall: <I>A. Edelman</I><br>Spring: <I>G. Strang</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=18.06');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.062"></a>
<p><h3>18.062J Mathematics for Computer Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6a.html#6.042">6.042J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>URL: <a href="http://theory.csail.mit.edu/classes/6.042">http://theory.csail.mit.edu/classes/6.042</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-044</a>) or <i>MWF2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-044</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Elementary discrete mathematics for computer science and engineering. Emphasis on mathematical definitions and proofs as well as on applicable methods.  Topics: formal logic notation, proof methods; induction, well-ordering; sets, relations; elementary graph theory; integer congruences; asymptotic notation and growth of functions; permutations and combinations, counting principles; discrete probability.  Further selected topics such as: recursive definition and structural induction; state machines and invariants; recurrences; generating functions.
<br><I>A. R. Meyer, T. Leighton</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.075"></a>
<p><h3>18.075 Methods for Scientists and Engineers
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> (H except 2, 6, 8, 12, 16, 18, 22)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.04">18.04</A>
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.075">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.075</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=24">24-115</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers functions of a complex variable; calculus of residues. Includes ordinary differential equations; Bessel and Legendre functions; Sturm-Liouville theory; partial differential equations; heat equation; and wave equations.
<br><I>H. Cheng</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=18.075');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.085"></a>
<p><h3>18.085 Computational Science and Engineering I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> (H except 18)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.034">18.034</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.085">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.085</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-163</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Review of linear algebra, applications to networks, structures, and estimation, finite difference and finite element solution of differential equations, Laplace's equation and potential flow, boundary-value problems, Fourier series, discrete Fourier transform, convolution. Frequent use of MATLAB in a wide range of scientific and engineering applications.
<br>Fall: <I>G. Strang</I><br>Spring: <I>L. Demanet</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=18.085');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.086"></a>
<p><h3>18.086 Computational Science and Engineering II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> (H except 18)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.034">18.034</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/18086/">http://math.mit.edu/18086/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-136</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Initial value problems: finite difference methods, accuracy and stability, heat equation, wave equations, conservation laws and shocks, level sets, Navier-Stokes.  Solving large systems: elimination with reordering, iterative methods, preconditioning, multigrid, Krylov subspaces, conjugate gradients. Optimization and minimum principles: weighted least squares, constraints, inverse problems, calculus of variations, saddle point problems, linear programming, duality, adjoint methods.
<br>Information: G. Strang<br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=18.086');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.089"></a>
<p><h3>18.089 Review of Mathematics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>One-week review of one-variable calculus (18.01), followed by concentrated study covering multivariable calculus (18.02), two hours per day for five weeks. Primarily for graduate students in Course 2N. Degree credit allowed only in special circumstances.
<br>Information: G. Staffilani<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.094"></a>
<p><h3>18.094J Teaching College-Level Science and Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1c.html#1.95">1.95J</A>, <A HREF="m5b.html#5.95">5.95J</A>, <A HREF="m6c.html#6.982">6.982J</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.59">7.59J</A>, <A HREF="m8b.html#8.395">8.395J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m2c.html#2.978">2.978</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-2 [P/D/F]
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Participatory seminar focuses on the knowledge and skills necessary for teaching science and engineering in higher education. Topics include theories of adult learning; course development; promoting active learning, problemsolving, and critical thinking in students; communicating with a diverse student body; using educational technology to further learning; lecturing; creating effective tests and assignments; and assessment and evaluation. Students research and present a relevant topic of particular interest. Appropriate for both novices and those with teaching experience.
<br><I>J. Rankin</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.095"></a>
<p><h3>18.095 Mathematics Lecture Series
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.095/">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.095/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Ten lectures by mathematics faculty members on interesting topics from both classical and modern mathematics. All lectures accessible to students with calculus background and an interest in mathematics. At each lecture, reading and exercises are assigned. Students prepare these for discussion in a weekly problem session.
<br>Information: G. Staffilani<br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->

<h2>Analysis</h2>
<a name="18.100A"></a>
<p><h3>18.100A Real Analysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> (H except 18)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>; or <a href="m18a.html#18.014">18.014</a> and <I>Coreq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.100B">18.100B</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.100C">18.100C</A>
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.100a">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.100a</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-163</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=18.100A');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
<a name="18.100B"></a>
<h3>18.100B Real Analysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> (H except 18)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>; or <a href="m18a.html#18.014">18.014</a> and <I>Coreq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.100A">18.100A</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.100C">18.100C</A>
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/~datchev/18.100B/18.100B.html">http://math.mit.edu/~datchev/18.100B/18.100B.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-163</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=18.100B');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
<a name="18.100C"></a>
<h3>18.100C Real Analysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>; or <a href="m18a.html#18.014">18.014</a> and <I>Coreq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a></I>
<br>Units: 4-0-11
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.100A">18.100A</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.100B">18.100B</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-163</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>R12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-129</a>) or <i>R3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-136</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Three options offered, each covering fundamentals of mathematical analysis: convergence of sequences and series, continuity, differentiability, Riemann integral, sequences and series of functions, uniformity, interchange of limit operations. Each option shows the utility of abstract concepts and teaches understanding and construction of proofs. <i>Option A:</i> Proofs and definitions are less abstract. Gives applications where possible. Concerned primarily with the real line. <i>Option B:</i> More demanding; for students with more mathematical maturity. Places more emphasis on point-set topology and n-space. <i>Option C:</i> 15-unit (4-0-11) variant of Option B, with further instruction and practice in written communication. Enrollment limited in Option C. Enrollment limited.
<br>Fall: <I>18.100A: A. P. Mattuck<br>18.100B: P. Etingof <br>18.100C:  Information: R.B. Melrose</I><br>Spring: <I>18.100A: M. Behrens <br>18.100B: T. Colding<br>18.100C: J. McGibbon</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=18.100C');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.101"></a>
<p><h3>18.101 Analysis and Manifolds
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> (H except 18)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.100">18.100</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>, <a href="m18b.html#18.700">18.700</a>, or <a href="m18b.html#18.701">18.701</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.101/">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.101/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the theory of manifolds: vector fields and densities on manifolds, integral calculus in the manifold setting and the manifold version of the divergence theorem. 18.901 helpful but not required.
<br><I>V. W. Guillemin</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.102"></a>
<p><h3>18.102 Introduction to Functional Analysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> (H except 18)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.100">18.100</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>, <a href="m18b.html#18.700">18.700</a>, or <a href="m18b.html#18.701">18.701</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.102">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.102</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-163</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Normed spaces, completeness, functionals, Hahn-Banach theorem, duality, operators. Lebesgue measure, measurable functions, integrability, completeness of L-p spaces. Hilbert space. Compact, Hilbert-Schmidt and trace class operators. Spectral theorem.
<br><I>R. B. Melrose</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.103"></a>
<p><h3>18.103 Fourier Analysis: Theory and Applications
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> (H except 18)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.100">18.100</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>, <a href="m18b.html#18.700">18.700</a>, or <a href="m18b.html#18.701">18.701</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.103">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.103</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Roughly half the subject devoted to the theory of the Lebesgue integral with applications to probability, and half to Fourier series and Fourier integrals.
<br><I>D. Jerison</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.104"></a>
<p><h3>18.104 Seminar in Analysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.100">18.100</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/~datchev/18.104/18.104.html">http://math.mit.edu/~datchev/18.104/18.104.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-129</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students present and discuss material from books or journals. Several items will be based on the classic work: Polya and Szego's "Problems and Theorems from Analysis." More recent work will also be used depending on each individual's background. Instruction and practice in written and oral communication provided. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>G. Staffilani</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=18.104');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.112"></a>
<p><h3>18.112 Functions of a Complex Variable
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> (H except 18)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.100">18.100</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>, <a href="m18b.html#18.700">18.700</a>, or <a href="m18b.html#18.701">18.701</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.112">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.112</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies the basic properties of analytic functions of one complex variable. Conformal mappings and the Poincare model of non-Euclidean geometry.  Cauchy-Goursat theorem and Cauchy integral formula. Taylor and Laurent decompositions. Singularities, residues and computation of integrals. Harmonic functions and Dirichlet's problem for the Laplace equation.  The partial fractions decomposition. Infinite series and infinite product expansions. The Gamma function.  The Riemann mapping theorem. Elliptic functions.
<br><I>C. Smart</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.116"></a>
<p><h3>18.116 Riemann Surfaces
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.112">18.112</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Riemann surfaces, uniformization, Riemann-Roch Theorem. Theory of elliptic functions and modular forms. Some applications, such as to number theory.
<br><I>T. S. Mrowka</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.117"></a>
<p><h3>18.117 Topics in Several Complex Variables
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.112">18.112</a>, <a href="m18b.html#18.965">18.965</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-128</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Harmonic theory on complex manifolds, Hodge decomposition theorem, Hard Lefschetz theorem. Vanishing theorems. Theory of Stein manifolds. As time permits students also study holomorphic vector bundles on Kahler manifolds.
<br><I>V. W. Guillemin</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.125"></a>
<p><h3>18.125 Real and Functional Analysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.100">18.100</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.125/">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.125/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-160</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introductions to set theory and general topology as needed in analysis. Lebesgue's integration theory. Introduction to functional analysis, Banach and Hilbert spaces.
<br><I>D. W. Stroock</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=18.125');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.135"></a>
<p><h3>18.135 Geometric Analysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18b.html#18.745">18.745</a> or <a href="m18b.html#18.755">18.755</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A quick description of Riemannian symmetric spaces.  Spherical functions and Harish-Chandra's c-function.  Fourier transforms and Radon transforms on Riemannian symmetric spaces X. Applications to invariant differential equations, in particular the multitemporal wave equation on X.  Eigenspace representations.
<br>Information: S. Helgason<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.137"></a>

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<a name="18.152"></a>
<p><h3>18.152 Introduction to Partial Differential Equations
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> (H except 18)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.100">18.100</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>, <a href="m18b.html#18.700">18.700</a>, or <a href="m18b.html#18.701">18.701</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.152">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.152</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-129</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces three main types of partial differential equations: diffusion, elliptic, and hyperbolic. Includes mathematical tools, real-world examples and applications, such as the Black-Scholes equation, the European options problem, water waves, scalar conservation laws, first order equations and traffic problems.
<br><I>W. Minicozzi</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=18.152');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.155"></a>
<p><h3>18.155 Differential Analysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.102">18.102</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.103">18.103</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.155">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.155</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>
<a name="18.156"></a>
<h3>18.156 Differential Analysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.155">18.155</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.156">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.156</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-129</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Fall: Review of Lebesgue integration.  L<SUP>p</SUP> spaces.  Distributions.  Fourier transform.  Sobolev spaces.  Spectral theorem, discrete and continuous spectrum.  Homogeneous distributions.  Fundamental solutions for elliptic, hyperbolic and parabolic differential operators.  Spring:  Variable coefficient elliptic, parabolic and hyperbolic partial differential equations. 18.112 recommended for 18.155.
<br>Fall: <I>R. B. Melrose</I><br>Spring: <I>L. Guth</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.157"></a>
<p><h3>18.157 Introduction to Microlocal Analysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.155">18.155</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.157">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.157</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-133</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>The semi-classical theory of partial differential equations. Discussion of Pseudodifferential operators, Fourier integral operators, asymptotic solutions of partial differential equations, and the spectral theory of Schroedinger operators from the semi-classical perspective. Heavy emphasis placed on the symplectic geometric underpinnings of this subject.
<br><I>R. B. Melrose</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.158"></a>
<p><h3>18.158 Topics in Differential Equations
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<a name="18.175"></a>
<p><h3>18.175 Theory of Probability
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.125">18.125</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.175">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.175</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-168</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Sums of independent random variables, central limit  phenomena, infinitely divisible laws, Levy processes,  Brownian motion, conditioning, and martingales.
<br><I>S. Sheffield</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.176"></a>
<p><h3>18.176 Stochastic Calculus
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.175">18.175</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A rigorous introduction to stochastic calculus.  Topics include Brownian motion and continuous martingales, diffusions and Levy processes, Ito calculus, martingale representation and quadratic variation, Girsanov's theorem, Bessel processes,  general existence and uniqueness theory for stochastic differential equations, applications to partial differential equations, and a brief overview of applications to finance and statistical physics.
<br><I>A. Guionnet</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.177"></a>
<p><h3>18.177 Topics in Stochastic Processes
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>

<a name="18.199"></a>
<p><h3>18.199 Graduate Analysis Seminar
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<a name="18.238"></a>
<p><h3>18.238 Geometry and Quantum Field Theory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A rigorous introduction designed for mathematicians into perturbative quantum field theory, using the language of functional integrals. Basics of classical field theory. Free quantum theories. Feynman diagrams. Renormalization theory. Local operators. Operator product expansion. Renormalization group equation. The goal is to discuss, using mathematical language, a number of basic notions and results of QFT that are necessary to understand talks and papers in QFT and string theory.
<br>Information: P. I. Etingof<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.276"></a>
<p><h3>18.276 Mathematical Methods in Physics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18b.html#18.745">18.745</a> or some familiarity with Lie theory
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Content varies from year to year. Recent developments in quantum field theory require mathematical techniques not usually covered in standard graduate subjects.
<br><I>V. W. Guillemin</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<h2>Applied Mathematics</h2>
<a name="18.303"></a>
<p><h3>18.303 Linear Partial Differential Equations: Analysis and Numerics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a> or <a href="m18b.html#18.700">18.700</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.303">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.303</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides students with the basic analytical and computational tools of linear partial differential equations (PDEs) for practical applications in science and engineering, including heat/diffusion, wave, and Poisson equations. Analytics emphasize the viewpoint of linear algebra and the analogy with finite matrix problems. Studies operator adjoints and eigenproblems, series solutions, Green's functions, and separation of variables. Numerics focus on finite-difference and finite-element techniques to reduce PDEs to matrix problems, including stability and convergence analysis and implicit/explicit timestepping. MATLAB is introduced and used in homework for simple examples.
<br><I>S. G. Johnson</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.304"></a>
<p><h3>18.304 Undergraduate Seminar in Discrete Mathematics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.310">18.310</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.062">18.062</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>, <a href="m18b.html#18.700">18.700</a>, or <a href="m18b.html#18.701">18.701</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.316">18.316</A>
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.304">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.304</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-133</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=8">8-205</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=13">13-4101</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar in combinatorics, graph theory, and discrete mathematics in general. Participants read and present papers from recent mathematics literature. Instruction and practice in written and oral communication provided.  Enrollment limited.
<br>Fall: Information: M. X. Goemans<br>Spring: <I>J. Fox, C. Lee</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=18.304');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.305"></a>
<p><h3>18.305 Advanced Analytic Methods in Science and Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.04">18.04</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.075">18.075</a>, or <a href="m18a.html#18.112">18.112</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/18.305/">http://math.mit.edu/18.305/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers expansion around singular points: the WKB method on ordinary and partial differential equations; the method of stationary phase and the saddle point method; the two-scale method and the method of renormalized perturbation; singular perturbation and boundary-layer techniques; WKB method on partial differential equations.
<br><I>H. Cheng</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.306"></a>
<p><h3>18.306 Advanced Partial Differential Equations with Applications
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.034">18.034</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.04">18.04</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.075">18.075</a>, or <a href="m18a.html#18.112">18.112</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.306">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.306</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-133</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Concepts and techniques for partial differential equations, especially nonlinear. Diffusion, dispersion and other phenomena. Initial and boundary value problems. Normal mode analysis, Green's functions, and transforms. Conservation laws, kinematic waves, hyperbolic equations, characteristics shocks, simple waves. Geometrical optics, caustics. Free-boundary problems. Dimensional analysis. Singular perturbation, boundary layers, homogenization. Variational methods. Solitons. Applications from fluid dynamics, materials science, optics, traffic flow, etc.
<br><I>R. R. Rosales</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=18.306');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.310"></a>
<p><h3>18.310 Principles of Discrete Applied Mathematics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-11
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.310A">18.310A</A>
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.310">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.310</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Study of illustrative topics in discrete applied mathematics, including sorting algorithms, probability theory, information theory, coding theory, secret codes, generating functions, and linear programming. Instruction and practice in written communication provided. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>M. X. Goemans</I><br>
<a name="18.310A"></a>
<p><h3>18.310A Principles of Discrete Applied Mathematics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.310">18.310</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-149</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Study of illustrative topics in discrete applied mathematics, including sorting algorithms, probability theory, information theory, coding theory, secret codes, generating functions, and linear programming.
<br><I>P. W. Shor</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.311"></a>
<p><h3>18.311 Principles of Continuum Applied Mathematics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.034">18.034</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.311">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.311</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-133</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers fundamental concepts in continuous applied mathematics. Applications from traffic flow, fluids, elasticity, granular flows, etc. Also covers continuum limit; conservation laws, quasi-equillibrium; kinematic waves; characteristics, simple waves, shocks; diffusion (linear and nonlinear); numerical solution of wave equations; finite differences, consistency, stability; discrete and fast Fourier transforms; spectral methods; transforms and series (Fourier, Laplace). Additional topics may include sonic booms, Mach cone, caustics, lattices, dispersion and group velocity. Uses MATLAB computing environment.
<br><I>R. R. Rosales</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=18.311');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.312"></a>
<p><h3>18.312 Algebraic Combinatorics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18b.html#18.701">18.701</a> or <a href="m18b.html#18.703">18.703</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.312">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.312</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-159</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Applications of algebra to combinatorics.  Topics include walks in graphs, the Radon transform, groups acting on posets, Young tableaux, electrical networks.
<br><I>J. Novak</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=18.312');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.314"></a>
<p><h3>18.314 Combinatorial Analysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>, <a href="m18b.html#18.700">18.700</a>, or <a href="m18b.html#18.701">18.701</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.314">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.314</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Combinatorial problems and methods for their solution.   Enumeration, generating functions, recurrence relations, construction of bijections. Introduction to graph theory.  Prior experience with abstraction and proofs is helpful.
<br><I>V. Venkateswaran</I><br>
</p><!--end-->

<a name="18.325"></a>

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
