<a name="18.330"></a>
<p><h3>18.330 Introduction to Numerical Analysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.034">18.034</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.330/">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.330/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-139</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Basic techniques for the efficient numerical solution of problems in science and engineering. Root finding, interpolation, approximation of functions, integration, differential equations, direct and iterative methods in linear algebra. Knowledge of programming in Fortran, C, or MATLAB helpful.
<br><I>H. Reid</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.335"></a>
<p><h3>18.335J Introduction to Numerical Methods
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6b.html#6.337">6.337J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.034">18.034</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>, <a href="m18b.html#18.700">18.700</a>, or <a href="m18b.html#18.701">18.701</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.335">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.335</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Advanced introduction to numerical linear algebra and related numerical methods. Topics include direct and iterative methods for linear systems, eigenvalue and QR/SVD factorizations, stability and accuracy, floating-point arithmetic, sparse matrices, preconditioning, and the memory considerations underlying modern linear algebra software. Starting from iterative methods for linear systems, explores more general techniques for local and global nonlinear optimization, including quasi-Newton methods, trust regions, branch-and-bound, and multistart algorithms. Also addresses Chebyshev approximation and FFTs. MATLAB is introduced for problem sets.
<br><I>S. G. Johnson</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.336"></a>
<p><h3>18.336J Fast Methods for Partial Differential and Integral Equations
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6b.html#6.335">6.335J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6b.html#6.336">6.336</a>, <a href="m16b.html#16.920">16.920</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.085">18.085</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.335">18.335</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.336">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.336</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-159</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Unified introduction to the theory and practice of modern, near linear-time, numerical methods for large-scale partial-differential and integral equations. Topics include preconditioned iterative methods; generalized Fast Fourier Transform and other butterfly-based methods; multiresolution approaches, such as multigrid algorithms and hierarchical low-rank matrix decompositions; and low and high frequency Fast Multipole Methods. Example applications include aircraft design, cardiovascular system modeling, electronic structure computation, and tomographic imaging.
<br><I>L. Demanet</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.337"></a>
<p><h3>18.337J Parallel Computing
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6b.html#6.338">6.338J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>, <a href="m18b.html#18.700">18.700</a>, or <a href="m18b.html#18.701">18.701</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://beowulf.csail.mit.edu/18.337/index.html">http://beowulf.csail.mit.edu/18.337/index.html</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Interdisciplinary introduction to parallel computing and modern big data analysis using Julia. Covers scientific computing topics such as dense and sparse linear algebra, N-body problems, and Fourier transforms, and geometric computing topics such as mesh generation and mesh partitioning. Focuses on application of these techniques to machine learning algorithms in big data applications. Provides direct experience with programming traditional-style supercomputing as well as working with modern cloud computing stacks. Designed to separate the realities and myths about the kinds of problems that can be solved on the world's fastest machines.
<br><I>A. Edelman</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.338"></a>
<p><h3>18.338 Eigenvalues of Random Matrices
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18b.html#18.701">18.701</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://www.mit.edu/~18.338/">http://www.mit.edu/~18.338/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers the modern main results of random matrix theory as it is currently applied in engineering and science. Topics include matrix calculus for finite and infinite matrices (e.g., Wigner's  semi-circle and Marcenko-Pastur laws), free probability, random graphs, combinatorial methods, matrix statistics, stochastic operators, passage to the continuum limit, moment methods, and compressed sensing. Knowledge of MATLAB hepful, but not required.
<br><I>A. Edelman</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.352"></a>
<p><h3>18.352J Theoretical Environmental Analysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m12a.html#12.009">12.009J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>; <I>Coreq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-160</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analyzes cooperative processes that shape the natural environment, now and in the geologic past. Emphasizes the development of theoretical models that relate the physical and biological worlds, the comparison of theory to observational data, and associated mathematical methods. Topics include carbon cycle dynamics; ecosystem structure, stability and complexity; mass extinctions; biosphere-geosphere coevolution; and climate change. Employs techniques such as stability analysis; scaling; null model construction; time series and network analysis.
<br><I>D. H. Rothman</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.353"></a>
<p><h3>18.353J Nonlinear Dynamics: Chaos
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as 2.050J, <A HREF="m12a.html#12.006">12.006J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.034">18.034</a>; <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to nonlinear dynamics and chaos in dissipative systems. Forced and parametric oscillators. Phase space. Periodic, quasiperiodic, and aperiodic flows. Sensitivity to initial conditions and strange attractors. Lorenz attractor. Period doubling, intermittency, and quasiperiodicity. Scaling and universality. Analysis of experimental data: Fourier transforms, Poincare sections, fractal dimension, and Lyapunov exponents. Applications to mechanical systems, fluid dynamics, physics, geophysics, and chemistry. See 12.207J/18.354J for Nonlinear Dynamics: Continuum Systems.
<br><I>R. Lagrange</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.354"></a>
<p><h3>18.354J Nonlinear Dynamics: Continuum Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> (H except 18)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m12a.html#12.207">12.207J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.034">18.034</a>; <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.354/">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.354/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW3-4.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-128</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>General mathematical principles of continuum systems. From microscopic to macroscopic descriptions in the form of linear or nonlinear (partial) differential equations. Exact solutions, dimensional analysis, calculus of variations and singular perturbation methods. Stability, waves and pattern formation in continuum systems. Subject matter illustrated using natural fluid and solid systems found, for example, in geophysics and biology.
<br><I>J. Dunkel</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.355"></a>
<p><h3>18.355 Fluid Mechanics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.354">18.354</a>, <a href="m2b.html#2.25">2.25</a>, or <a href="m12c.html#12.800">12.800</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Topics include the development of Navier-Stokes equations, inviscid flows, boundary layers, lubrication theory, Stokes flows, and surface tension. Fundamental concepts illustrated through problems drawn from a variety of areas, including geophysics, biology, and the dynamics of sport. Particular emphasis on the interplay between dimensional analysis, scaling arguments, and theory. Includes classroom and laboratory demonstrations.
<br><I>J. W. Bush</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.357"></a>
<p><h3>18.357 Interfacial Phenomena
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.354">18.354</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.355">18.355</a>, <a href="m12c.html#12.800">12.800</a>, <a href="m2b.html#2.25">2.25</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Fluid systems dominated by the influence of interfacial tension. Elucidates the roles of curvature pressure and Marangoni stress in a variety of hydrodynamic settings. Particular attention to drops and bubbles, soap films and minimal surfaces, wetting phenomena, water-repellency, surfactants, Marangoni flows, capillary origami and contact line dynamics. Theoretical developments are accompanied by classroom demonstrations. Highlights the role of surface tension in biology.
<br><I>J. W. Bush</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.369"></a>
<p><h3>18.369 Mathematical Methods in Nanophotonics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.305">18.305</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.369">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.369</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-128</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>High-level approaches to understanding complex optical media, structured on the scale of the wavelength, that are not generally analytically soluable. The basis for understanding optical phenomena such as photonic crystals and band gaps, anomalous diffraction, mechanisms for optical confinement, optical fibers (new and old), nonlinearities, and integrated optical devices. Methods covered include linear algebra and eigensystems for Maxwell's equations, symmetry groups and representation theory, Bloch's theorem, numerical eigensolver methods, time and frequency-domain computation, perturbation theory, and coupled-mode theories.
<br><I>S. G. Johnson</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=18.369');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.376"></a>
<p><h3>18.376J Wave Propagation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1a.html#1.138">1.138J</A>, <A HREF="m2a.html#2.062">2.062J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.003">2.003</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.075">18.075</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.376/">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.376/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-133</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Theoretical concepts and analysis of wave problems in science and engineering with examples chosen from elasticity, acoustics, geophysics, hydrodynamics, blood flow, nondestructive evaluation, and other applications.  Progressive waves, group velocity and dispersion, energy density and transport. Reflection, refraction and transmission of plane waves by an interface. Mode conversion in elastic waves. Rayleigh waves. Waves due to a moving load. Scattering by a two-dimensional obstacle.  Reciprocity theorems. Parabolic approximation. Waves on the sea surface. Capillary-gravity waves. Wave resistance. Radiation of surface waves. Internal waves in stratified fluids.  Waves in rotating media.  Waves in random media.
<br><I>T. R. Akylas, R. R. Rosales</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=18.376');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.377"></a>
<p><h3>18.377J Nonlinear Dynamics and Waves
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1c.html#1.685">1.685J</A>, <A HREF="m2a.html#2.034">2.034J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A unified treatment of nonlinear oscillations and wave phenomena with applications to mechanical, optical, geophysical, fluid, electrical and flow-structure interaction problems. Nonlinear free and forced vibrations; nonlinear resonances; self-excited oscillations; lock-in phenomena.  Nonlinear dispersive and nondispersive waves; resonant wave interactions; propagation of wave pulses and nonlinear Schrodinger equation.  Nonlinear long waves and breaking; theory of characteristics; the Korteweg-de Vries equation; solitons and solitary wave interactions.  Stability of shear flows.  Some topics and applications may vary from year to year.
<br><I>T. R. Akylas, R. R. Rosales</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.384"></a>
<p><h3>18.384 Undergraduate Seminar in Physical Mathematics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.311">18.311</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.353">18.353</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.354">18.354</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.384">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.384</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-129</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers the mathematical modeling of physical systems, with emphasis on the reading and presentation of papers. Addresses a broad range of topics, with particular focus on macroscopic physics and continuum systems: fluid dynamics, solid mechanics, and biophysics. Instruction and practice in written and oral communication provided. Enrollment limited.
<br>Information: J. W. Bush<br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.385"></a>
<p><h3>18.385J Nonlinear Dynamics and Chaos
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2a.html#2.036">2.036J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.034">18.034</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.385">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.385</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the theory of nonlinear dynamical systems with applications from science and engineering. Local and global existence of solutions, dependence on initial data and parameters. Elementary bifurcations, normal forms. Phase plane, limit cycles, relaxation oscillations, Poincare-Bendixson theory. Floquet theory. Poincare maps. Averaging. Near-equilibrium dynamics. Synchronization.  Introduction to chaos. Universality. Strange attractors. Lorenz and Rossler systems. Hamiltonian dynamics and KAM theory. Uses MATLAB computing environment.
<br><I>R. R. Rosales</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.386"></a>
<p><h3>18.386 Advanced Nonlinear Dynamics and Chaos
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.385">18.385</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/2.037j/www/">http://web.mit.edu/2.037j/www/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Advanced subject on the modern theory of nonlinear dynamical systems with an emphasis on applications in science and engineering. Invariant manifolds, homoclinic orbits, global bifurcations. Hamiltonian systems, completely integrable systems, KAM theory. Different mechanisms for chaotic dynamics, Shilnikov-type orbits, attractors, horseshoes, symbolic dynamics. Geometric singular perturbation theory. Physical applications.
<br>Information: R. R. Rosales<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.395"></a>
<p><h3>18.395 Group Theory with Applications to Physics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8b.html#8.321">8.321</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Selection of topics from the theory of finite groups, Lie groups, and group representations, motivated by quantum mechanics and particle physics. 8.322 and 8.323 helpful.
<br><I>D. Z. Freedman</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.396"></a>
<p><h3>18.396J Supersymmetric Quantum Field Theories
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m8b.html#8.831">8.831J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Topics selected from the following: SUSY algebras and their particle representations; Weyl and Majorana spinors; Lagrangians of basic four-dimensional SUSY theories, both rigid SUSY and supergravity; supermultiplets of fields and superspace methods; renormalization properties, and the non-renormalization theorem; spontaneous breakdown of SUSY; and phenomenological SUSY theories. Some prior knowledge of Noether's theorem, derivation and use of Feynman rules, l-loop renormalization, and gauge theories is essential.
<br><I>D. Z. Freedman</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.398"></a>
<p><h3>18.398 Quantum Field Theories
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>For students who want to have a clear understanding of quantum field theories. Appropriate for students who have not taken such a subject as well as students who have but are not entirely comfortable with the basic concepts and techniques. The topics begin with classical mechanics and end with gauge field theories and the renormalization of the standard model.
<br>Information: H. Cheng<br>
</p><!--end-->
<h2>Theoretical Computer Science</h2>
<a name="18.400"></a>
<p><h3>18.400J Automata, Computability, and Complexity
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6a.html#6.045">6.045J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.042">6.042</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.400">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.400</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-141</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-303</a>) or <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-303</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to some of the central ideas of theoretical computer science, including circuits, finite automata, Turing machines and computability, efficient algorithms and reducibility, the P versus NP problem, NP-completeness, the power of randomness, cryptography, computational learning theory, and quantum computing. Examines the classes of problems that can and cannot be solved in various computational models.
<br><I>S. Aaronson</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=18.400');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.404"></a>
<p><h3>18.404J Theory of Computation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> (H except 18)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6c.html#6.840">6.840J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.310">18.310</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.062">18.062J</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.404">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.404</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A more extensive and theoretical treatment of the material in 6.045J/18.400J, emphasizing computability and computational complexity theory. Regular and context-free languages. Decidable and undecidable problems, reducibility, recursive function theory. Time and space measures on computation, completeness, hierarchy theorems, inherently complex problems, oracles, probabilistic computation, and interactive proof systems.
<br><I>M. Sipser</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.405"></a>
<p><h3>18.405J Advanced Complexity Theory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6c.html#6.841">6.841J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.404">18.404</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Current research topics in computational complexity theory. Nondeterministic, alternating, probabilistic, and parallel computation models. Boolean circuits. Complexity classes and complete sets. The polynomial-time hierarchy. Interactive proof systems. Relativization. Definitions of randomness. Pseudo-randomness and derandomizations. Interactive proof systems and probabilistically checkable proofs.
<br><I>D. Moshkovitz</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.409"></a>
<p><h3>18.409 Topics in Theoretical Computer Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.409">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.409</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=37">37-212</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Study of areas of current interest in theoretical computer science. Topics vary from term to term.
<br><I>J. A. Kelner</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.410"></a>
<p><h3>18.410J Design and Analysis of Algorithms
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6a.html#6.046">6.046J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.006">6.006</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.410">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.410</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-101</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-112</a>) or <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-112</a>) or <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-112</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-112</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-112</a>) or <i>F3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-112</a>) or <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-144</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Techniques for the design and analysis of efficient algorithms, emphasizing methods useful in practice. Topics include sorting; search trees, heaps, and hashing; divide-and-conquer; dynamic programming; greedy algorithms; amortized analysis; graph algorithms; and shortest paths. Advanced topics may include network flow; computational geometry; number-theoretic algorithms; polynomial and matrix calculations; caching; and parallel computing.
<br><I>C. E. Leiserson, M. Goemans</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=18.410');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.415"></a>
<p><h3>18.415J Advanced Algorithms
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6c.html#6.854">6.854J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.041">6.041</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.042">6.042</a>, or <a href="m18a.html#18.440">18.440</a>; <a href="m6a.html#6.046">6.046</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>URL: <a href="http://theory.lcs.mit.edu/classes/6.854/">http://theory.lcs.mit.edu/classes/6.854/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>First-year graduate subject in algorithms. Emphasizes fundamental algorithms and advanced methods of algorithmic design, analysis, and implementation. Surveys a variety of computational models and the algorithms for them. Data structures, network flows, linear programming, computational geometry, approximation algorithms, online algorithms, parallel algorithms, external memory, streaming algorithms.
<br><I>D. R. Karger</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.416"></a>
<p><h3>18.416J Randomized Algorithms
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6c.html#6.856">6.856J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6c.html#6.854">6.854J</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.041">6.041</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.042">6.042J</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies how randomization can be used to make algorithms simpler and more efficient via random sampling, random selection of witnesses, symmetry breaking, and Markov chains. Models of randomized computation. Data structures: hash tables, and skip lists. Graph algorithms: minimum spanning trees, shortest paths, and minimum cuts. Geometric algorithms: convex hulls, linear programming in fixed or arbitrary dimension. Approximate counting; parallel algorithms; online algorithms; derandomization techniques; and tools for probabilistic analysis of algorithms.
<br><I>D. R. Karger</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.417"></a>
<p><h3>18.417 Introduction to Computational Molecular Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.01">6.01</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.006">6.006</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://www-math.mit.edu/18.417/">http://www-math.mit.edu/18.417/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the basic computational methods used to model and predict the structure of biomolecules (proteins, DNA, RNA). Covers classical techniques in the field (molecular dynamics, Monte Carlo, dynamic programming) to more recent advances in analyzing and predicting RNA and protein structure, ranging from Hidden Markov Models and 3-D lattice models to attribute Grammars and tree Grammars.
<br>Information: B. Berger<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.418"></a>
<p><h3>18.418 Topics in Computational Molecular Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.417">18.417</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.047">6.047</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.418">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.418</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers current research topics in computational molecular biology.  Recent research papers presented from leading conferences such as the SIGACT International Conference on Computational Molecular Biology (RECOMB). Topics include original research (both theoretical and experimental) in comparative genomics, sequence and structure analysis, molecular evolution, proteomics, gene expression, transcriptional regulation, and biological networks. Recent research by course participants also covered. Participants will be expected to present either group or individual projects to the class.
<br><I>B. Berger</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.424"></a>
<p><h3>18.424 Seminar in Information Theory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.05">18.05</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.440">18.440</a>, or <a href="m6a.html#6.041">6.041</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>, <a href="m18b.html#18.700">18.700</a>, or <a href="m18b.html#18.701">18.701</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-129</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Considers various topics in information theory, including data compression, Shannon's Theorems, and error-correcting codes. Students present and discuss the subject matter.  Instruction and practice in written and oral communication provided. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>P. W. Shor</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=18.424');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.425"></a>
<p><h3>18.425J Cryptography and Cryptanalysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6c.html#6.875">6.875J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.046">6.046J</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-144</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A rigorous introduction to modern cryptography. Emphasis on the fundamental cryptographic primitives of public-key encryption, digital signatures, pseudo-random number generation, and basic protocols and their computational complexity requirements.
<br><I>S. Goldwasser, S. Micali</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.426"></a>
<p><h3>18.426J Advanced Topics in Cryptography
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6c.html#6.876">6.876J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6c.html#6.875">6.875</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Recent results in cryptography, interactive proofs, and cryptographic game theory. Lectures by instructor, invited speakers, and students.
<br><I>S. Goldwasser, S. Micali</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.433"></a>
<p><h3>18.433 Combinatorial Optimization
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> (H except 18)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>, <a href="m18b.html#18.700">18.700</a>, or <a href="m18b.html#18.701">18.701</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.433">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.433</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Thorough treatment of linear programming and combinatorial optimization.  Topics include matching theory, network flow, matroid optimization, and how to deal with NP-hard optimization problems. Prior exposure to discrete mathematics (such as 18.310) helpful.
<br><I>M. X. Goemans</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.434"></a>
<p><h3>18.434 Seminar in Theoretical Computer Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.404">18.404</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.410">18.410</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href=" http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.434"> http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.434</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-129</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-128</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Topics vary from year to year. Students present and discuss the subject matter. Instruction and practice in written and oral communication provided. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>L. Orecchia, A. Moitra</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=18.434');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.435"></a>
<p><h3>18.435J Quantum Computation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2a.html#2.111">2.111J</A>, <A HREF="m8b.html#8.370">8.370J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to the theory and practice of quantum  computation. Topics covered: physics of information processing; quantum algorithms including the factoring algorithm and Grover's search algorithm; quantum error correction; quantum communication and cryptography. Knowledge of quantum mechanics helpful but not required.
<br><I>I. Chuang, E. Farhi, S. Lloyd, P. Shor</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.436"></a>
<p><h3>18.436J Quantum Information Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6b.html#6.443">6.443J</A>, <A HREF="m8b.html#8.371">8.371J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.435">18.435</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines quantum computation and quantum information. Topics include quantum circuits, quantum Fourier transform and search algorithms, the quantum operations formalism, quantum error correction, stabilizer and Calderbank-Shor-Steans codes, fault tolerant quantum computation, quantum data compression, entanglement, capacity of quantum channels, and proof of the security of quantum cryptography. Prior knowledge of quantum mechanics required.
<br>Information: I. Chuang<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.437"></a>
<p><h3>18.437J Distributed Algorithms
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6c.html#6.852">6.852J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.046">6.046</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://theory.csail.mit.edu/classes/6.852/">http://theory.csail.mit.edu/classes/6.852/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Design and analysis of concurrent algorithms, emphasizing those suitable for use in distributed networks. Process synchronization, allocation of computational resources, distributed consensus, distributed graph algorithms, election of a leader in a network, distributed termination, deadlock detection, concurrency control, communication, and clock synchronization. Special consideration given to issues of efficiency and fault tolerance. Formal models and proof methods for distributed computation.
<br><I>N. A. Lynch</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.438"></a>
<p><h3>18.438 Advanced Combinatorial Optimization
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.433">18.433</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-122</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Advanced treatment of combinatorial optimization with an emphasis on combinatorial aspects. Non-bipartite matchings, submodular functions, matroid intersection/union, matroid matching, submodular flows, multicommodity flows, packing and connectivity problems, and other recent developments.
<br><I>M. X. Goemans</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<h2>Probability and Statistics</h2>
<a name="18.440"></a>
<p><h3>18.440 Probability and Random Variables
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m6a.html#6.041">6.041</A>, <A HREF="m6b.html#6.431">6.431</A>
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.440">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.440</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=54">54-100</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Probability spaces, random variables, distribution functions. Binomial, geometric, hypergeometric, Poisson distributions. Uniform, exponential, normal, gamma and beta distributions. Conditional probability, Bayes theorem, joint distributions. Chebyshev inequality, law of large numbers, and central limit theorem.
<br>Fall: <I>J. A. Kelner</I><br>Spring: <I>S. Sheffield</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=18.440');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.443"></a>
<p><h3>18.443 Statistics for Applications
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> (H except 18)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.440">18.440</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.041">6.041</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.443">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.443</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-163</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A broad treatment of statistics, concentrating on specific statistical techniques used in science and industry. Topics: hypothesis testing and estimation. Confidence intervals, chi-square tests, nonparametric statistics, analysis of variance, regression, correlation, decision theory, and Bayesian statistics.
<br>Fall: <I>L. Wang</I><br>Spring: <I>R. M. Dudley</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=18.443');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.445"></a>
<p><h3>18.445 Introduction to Stochastic Processes
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.440">18.440</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.041">6.041</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E25">E25-111</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Basics of stochastic processes.  Markov chains, Poisson processes, random walks, birth and death processes, Brownian motion.
<br><I>A. Guionnet</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=18.445');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.465"></a>
<p><h3>18.465 Topics in Statistics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<a name="18.466"></a>
<p><h3>18.466 Mathematical Statistics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-139</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Decision theory, estimation, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing. Introduces large sample theory. Asymptotic efficiency of estimates. Exponential families. Sequential analysis.
<br><I>L. Wang</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=18.466');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<p>For additional related subjects in Statistics, see:
<p>Civil and Environmental Engineering: <a href="m1b.html#1.151">1.151</a>, <a href="m1b.html#1.155">1.155</a>,<a href="m1b.html#1.202">1.202J</a>, <a href="m1b.html#1.203">1.203J</a>, <a href="m1b.html#1.205">1.205J</a>
<p>Electrical Engineering and Computer Science: <a href="m6a.html#6.041">6.041</a>,<a href="m6a.html#6.231">6.231</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.245">6.245</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.262">6.262</a>, <a href="m6b.html#6.431">6.431</a>, <a href="m6b.html#6.432">6.432</a>, and <a href="m6b.html#6.435">6.435</a>
<p>Management: <a href="m15a.html#15.034">15.034</a>, <a href="m15a.html#15.061">15.061</a>, <a href="m15a.html#15.065">15.065</a>, <a href="m15a.html#15.070">15.070</a>, <a href="m15a.html#15.075">15.075</a>, <a href="m15a.html#15.076">15.076</a>, <a href="m15a.html#15.098">15.098</a>, and <a href="m15b.html#15.306">15.306</a>
<p>Mathematics: <a href="m18a.html#18.05">18.05</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.175">18.175</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.176">18.176</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.177">18.177</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.440">18.440</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.441">18.441</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.443">18.443</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.445">18.445</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.458">18.458</a>, and <a href="m18a.html#18.465">18.465</a>
<p>See also: <a href="m2a.html#2.061">2.061</a>, <a href="m2c.html#2.830">2.830</a>, <a href="m5b.html#5.70">5.70</a>, <a href="m5b.html#5.72">5.72</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.02">7.02</a>, <a href="m8a.html#8.044">8.044</a>, <a href="m8a.html#8.08">8.08</a>,<a href="m10a.html#10.816">10.816</a>, <a href="m11b.html#11.220">11.220</a>, <a href="m11b.html#11.221">11.221</a>, <a href="m16a.html#16.322">16.322</a>, <a href="m17b.html#17.872">17.872</a>, <a href="m17b.html#17.874">17.874</a>, <a href="m22b.html#22.38">22.38</a>, <a href="mHSTa.html#HST.191">HST.191</a>, and <a href="mMASa.html#MAS.622">MAS.622J</a>.
</td></tr></table>
