<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Course 1: Civil and Environmental Engineering<br>Spring
2014</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://cee.mit.edu/"><i>Course 1 Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course1.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=+++1&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>1.00-1.149</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m1b.html">1.150-1.499</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m1c.html">1.50-1.999 plus UROP and Thesis</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<h2>Fundamentals</h2>
<a name="1.00"></a>
<p><h3>1.00 Introduction to Computers and Engineering Problem Solving
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m1a.html#1.001">1.001</A>, <A HREF="m1a.html#1.002">1.002</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 5-1-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF3-4.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=10">10-250</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TBA</i> <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>No required or recommended textbooks
<a name="1.001"></a>
<h3>1.001 Introduction to Computers and Engineering Problem Solving
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m1a.html#1.00">1.00</A>, <A HREF="m1a.html#1.002">1.002</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 5-1-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF3-4.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=10">10-250</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TBA</i> <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>No required or recommended textbooks
<a name="1.002"></a>
<h3>1.002 Introduction to Computers and Engineering Problem Solving
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m1a.html#1.00">1.00</A>, <A HREF="m1a.html#1.001">1.001</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 5-1-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF3-4.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=10">10-250</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TBA</i> <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents the fundamentals of object-oriented software design and development, computational methods and sensing for engineering, and scientific and managerial applications. Covers design of classes, inheritance, graphical user interfaces, numerical methods, streams, threads, sensors, and data structures. Students use Java programming language to complete weekly software assignments. Laptop computers available on loan. Students taking graduate version 1.002 complete additional assignments.
<br>Fall: <I>G. Kocur</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Williams</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.007"></a>
<p><h3>1.007 EES-Lab: Engineering for Environment and Sustainability
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 1-2-6
<br><img align="bottom" width=16 height=16 alt="Subject Cancelled" title="Subject Cancelled" src="/icns/buttonx.gif"> <i><b>Subject Cancelled</b></i> <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides a practical introduction to key topics, current research and state-of-the-art tools in engineering for sustainability. Addresses engineering problems associated with the built and natural environments, with a focus on design of novel solutions to grand challenges related to energy, the environment, and sustainable societal growth. Organized around three themes: sustainable cities, energy and climate, and air, water, and health. Each week involves a lab or field trip related to a specific topic; examples include assessing the viability of sequestration, monitoring urban air pollution, collecting and observing the microorganisms that drive oceans' vital cycles, measuring the energy efficiency of buildings, and taking a boat on the Charles River for water quality measurements. Culminates in a field trip to Cape Cod.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.010"></a>
<p><h3>1.010 Uncertainty in Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-2-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to probability and statistics with emphasis on    engineering applications. Events and their probability, Total Probability and Bayes' Theorems, discrete and continuous random variables and vectors, univariate and multivariate distributions,   Bernoulli Trial Sequence and Poisson point process, uncertainty    propagation and conditional analysis. Second-moment representation of uncertainty and second-moment uncertainty propagation and conditional analysis. Random sampling, estimation of distribution parameters (method of moments, maximum likelihood, Bayesian estimation), and simple and multiple linear regression. Concepts illustrated with examples from various areas of engineering and everyday life.
<br><I>D. Veneziano</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.011"></a>
<p><h3>1.011 Project Evaluation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-1-5
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-134</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-217</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Methodologies for evaluating civil engineering projects, which typically are large-scale and long-lived, involving many economic, financial, social and environmental factors. Emphasis on dealing with uncertainty. Presents basic techniques of engineering economics, including net present value analysis, life-cycle costing, benefit-cost analysis, and other approaches to project evaluation. Examples drawn from both contemporary and historical projects in various fields, including transportation systems, urban development, energy and environmental projects, water resource management, telecommunications systems, and other elements of the public and private projects and programs. Term project required.
<br><I>J. Sussman</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.013"></a>
<p><h3>1.013 Senior Civil and Environmental Engineering Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-4-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=BEAVERWORKS">BEAVERWORKS</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>TR2-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=BEAVERWORKS">BEAVERWORKS</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Synthesizes prior design education through a semester-long design project, concurrent implementation project, lectures and related assignments. Students who have specialized in structural, geotechnical, engineering systems, and environmental areas form mixed teams to work on the projects. For the semester-long project, which must be planned and designed for a specific location, students demonstrate creativity in applying theories and methodologies from their design and analysis subjects while considering the project's technical, environmental and social feasibility. Parallel to the design project is a related project involving actual implementation and analysis. Lectures on a variety of related civil and environmental engineering concepts, and engineering practice and ethics, are also part of the subject. Instruction and practice in oral and written communication are an integral part of the multiple design stages.
<br><I>C. Heald, J. Kroll</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=1.013');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.015"></a>
<p><h3>1.015J Design of Electromechanical Robotic Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/HalfLab.gif" alt="1/2 Institute Lab" title="1/2 Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2a.html#2.017">2.017J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.003">2.003</a> or <a href="m2a.html#2.03">2.03</a>; <I>Coreq: <a href="m2a.html#2.005">2.005</a>, <a href="m2a.html#2.05">2.05</a> and <a href="m2a.html#2.051">2.051</a>, or <a href="m2a.html#2.016">2.016</a>; <a href="m2b.html#2.671">2.671</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-4-5
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-132</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>W2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-007</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Design, construction, and testing of field robotic systems, through team projects with each student responsible for a specific subsystem. Projects focus on electronics, instrumentation, and machine elements. Design for operation in uncertain conditions is a focus point, with ocean waves and marine structures as a central theme. Basic statistics, linear systems, Fourier transforms, random processes, spectra and extreme events with applications in design.  Lectures on ethics in engineering practice included. Enrollment may be limited due to laboratory capacity.
<br><I>F. S. Hover, J. J. Leonard</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.016"></a>
<p><h3>1.016 Design for Complex Environmental Issues: Building Solutions and Communicating Ideas
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m12a.html#12.000">12.000</a>
<br>Units: 3-1-5
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW3-4.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-168</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-168</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students work in small groups, under the guidance of researchers from MIT, to pursue specific aspects of the  year's Terrascope problem. Teams design and build prototypes, graphic displays and other tools to communicate their findings and display them in a Bazaar of Ideas open to the MIT community.  Some teams develop particular solutions, others work to provide deeper understanding of the issues, and others focus on ways to communicate these ideas with the general public. Students' work is evaluated by independent experts. Offers students an opportunity to develop ideas from the fall semester and to work in labs across MIT. Limited to Terrascope students.
<br><I>C. Harvey, A. Epstein</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.018"></a>
<p><h3>1.018J Ecology I: The Earth System
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m7a.html#7.30">7.30J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-1-8
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/7.30j">http://web.mit.edu/7.30j</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Fundamentals of ecology, considering Earth as an integrated dynamic living system. Coevolution of the biosphere, geosphere, atmosphere and oceans. Introduction to biological energy transfer and thermodynamics. The Earth's energy budget. Photosynthesis and respiration. The hydrologic, carbon, phosphorus, and nitrogen cycles. Flow of energy and materials through ecosystems, regulation of the distribution and abundance of organisms, structure and function of ecosystems. Metabolic diversity; productivity. Trophic dynamics; models of population growth, competition, mutualism and predation. Instruction and practice in oral and written communication provided. 7.012-7.014 recommended.
<br><I>E. DeLong, A. Mueller</I><br>
<a name="1.020"></a>
<p><h3>1.020 Ecology II: Engineering for Sustainability
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>; <I>Coreq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or permission of instructor</I>
<br>Units: 3-2-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=48">48-316</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F9-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=48">48-316</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Review of physical, chemical, ecological, and economic principles used to examine interactions between humans and the natural environment. Applications of mass balance concepts in ecology, chemical kinetics, and hydrology; energy balance concepts in building design, ecology, and climate change; economic and life-cycle concepts in resource evaluation and engineering design. Uses numerical models to integrate concepts and to assess environmental impacts of human activities. Problem sets involve development of MATLAB models for particular engineering applications. Some experience with computer programming is helpful but not essential.
<br><I>S. Amin</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=1.020');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.021"></a>
<p><h3>1.021 Introduction to Modeling and Simulation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Engineering School-Wide Elective Subject. <br>(Offered under: <A HREF="m3a.html#3.021">3.021</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.333">10.333</A>, <A HREF="m22a.html#22.00">22.00</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.016">3.016</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Basic concepts of computer modeling and simulation in science and engineering. Uses techniques and software for simulation, data analysis and visualization. Continuum, mesoscale, atomistic and quantum methods used to study fundamental and applied problems in physics, chemistry, materials science, mechanics, engineering, and biology. Examples drawn from the disciplines above are used to understand or characterize complex structures and materials, and complement experimental observations.
<br><I>M. Buehler, J. Grossman</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.032"></a>
<p><h3>1.032 Geomaterials and Geomechanics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m1b.html#1.361">1.361</A>, <A HREF="m1b.html#1.366">1.366</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m1a.html#1.010">1.010</a>, <a href="m1a.html#1.011">1.011</a>, <a href="m1a.html#1.036">1.036</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presentation and application of principles of soil mechanics. Considers topics: the origin and nature of soils; soil classification; the effective stress principle; hydraulic conductivity and seepage; stress-strain-strength behavior of cohesionless and cohesive soils and application to lateral earth stresses, bearing capacity and slope stability; consolidation theory and settlement analyses; laboratory and field methods for evaluation of soil properties in design practice. Same lectures as 1.361.
<br><I>L. C. Jen</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.035"></a>
<p><h3>1.035 Mechanics of Structures and Soils
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m1a.html#1.050">1.050</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>
<br>Units: 5-3-10
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analysis of determinate and indeterminate structures including beams, plates, cables and arches. Introduction to matrix methods of structural analysis. Mechanical properties of construction materials, including steel, concrete and soils. Behavior of steel and concrete structural systems. Sources of stress concentrations and nonlinearities in steel and concrete structures; composite behavior of reinforced concrete elements, prestressing of concrete. Groundwater seepage, effective stress and consolidation of soils, principles of slope stability. Interaction of structures and soils in foundations and earth retaining systems. Integrated laboratory sessions introduce concepts and techniques to measure properties of materials and to understand structural behavior.
<br><I>E. Kausel, R. Juanes, J. T. Germaine</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.036"></a>
<p><h3>1.036 Structural and Geotechnical Engineering Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m1a.html#1.035">1.035</a>
<br>Units: 3-1-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-150</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>T1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-242</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Basic philosophy of planning and design of structures. Loading conditions, design criteria and factors of safety. Application of principles of structural mechanics and soil mechanics in design. Structural system design concepts.  Design of reinforced concrete structural elements using the ultimate strength design method. Load factor design of structural steel members and connections.  Selection of soil parameters from laboratory and in situ tests.  Stability and ground deformations in geotechnical design.  Design with soil-structure interaction. Emphasis on problem-based learning through team design projects.
<br><I>O. Buyukozturk, L. C. Jen</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.040"></a>
<p><h3>1.040 Project Management
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m1b.html#1.401">1.401J</A>, <A HREF="mESDa.html#ESD.018">ESD.018J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="mESDa.html#ESD.052">ESD.052</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-217</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>M2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-233</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to project management with emphasis on finance, evaluation, and organization.  Topics include project financing; public-private partnership; cost-benefit analysis, resource and cost estimation; project organization; and project control and delivery.  Case studies used to demonstrate relevant issues.  Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>R. Schuhmann</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.041"></a>
<p><h3>1.041J Transportation Systems Modeling
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mESDa.html#ESD.01">ESD.01J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m1a.html#1.00">1.00</a>, <a href="m1a.html#1.010">1.010</a>
<br>Units: 3-1-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M11-1,W11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-134</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-134</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces basic concepts of transportation systems modeling, data analysis and visualization techniques. Covers fundamental analytical and simulation-based methodologies. Topics include time-space diagrams, cumulative plots, queueing theory, network science, data analysis, and their applications. Provides students with an understanding of the current challenges and opportunities in different areas of transportation.
<br><I>C. Osorio, M. Gonzalez</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.044"></a>
<p><h3>1.044J Fundamentals of Energy in Buildings
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.66">2.66J</A>, <A HREF="m4d.html#4.42">4.42J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-2-7
<br>URL: <a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/fall-2013-442">http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/fall-2013-442</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Design-based introduction to energy and thermo-sciences, with applications to sustainable, energy-efficient architecture and building technology. Covers introductory thermodynamics, air/water/vapor mixtures, and heat transfer. Studies leading order factors in building energy use. Includes several building design projects in which students creatively employ energy fundamentals and building energy use.
<br><I>L. R. Glicksman</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.050"></a>
<p><h3>1.050 Engineering Mechanics I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>; <I>Coreq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-2-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Basic principles of mechanics to describe the behavior of materials, structures and fluids. Dimensional analysis, conservation of momentum, static equilibrium, stress and stress states, hydrostatics, moments and forces. Material and structural strength criteria. Deformation and strain. Conservation of energy in solid mechanics, elasticity and elasticity bounds. Energy dissipation, plasticity and fracture. Open-ended geotechnical and structural engineering studio exercises and experiments with natural and man-made physical systems.
<br><I>F. J. Ulm, M. J. Buehler</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.053"></a>
<p><h3>1.053J Dynamics and Control I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2a.html#2.003">2.003J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>, or permission of instructor; <I>Coreq: <a href="m2a.html#2.086">2.086</a> or <a href="m1a.html#1.020">1.020</a></I>
<br>Units: 4-1-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-270</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>R2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-375</a>) or <i>R4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-375</a>) or <i>F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-375</a>) or <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-375</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the dynamics and vibrations of lumped-parameter models of mechanical systems. Kinematics. Force-momentum formulation for systems of particles and rigid bodies in planar motion. Work-energy concepts.  Virtual displacements and virtual work. Lagrange's equations for systems of particles and rigid bodies in planar motion. Linearization of equations of motion. Linear stability analysis of mechanical systems. Free and forced vibration of linear multi-degree of freedom models of mechanical systems; matrix eigenvalue problems.
<br><I>J. K. Vandiver, N. C. Makris, N. M. Patrikalakis, T. Peacock, D. Gossard, K. Turitsyn</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=1.053');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.054"></a>
<p><h3>1.054 Mechanics and Design of Concrete Structures
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m1c.html#1.541">1.541</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m1a.html#1.035">1.035</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies strength and deformation of concrete under various states of stress; failure criteria; concrete plasticity; and fracture mechanics concepts. Topics include fundamental behavior of reinforced concrete structural systems and their members; basis for design and code constraints; high-performance concrete materials and their use in innovative design solutions; and yield line theory for slabs. Uses behavior models and nonlinear analysis. Covers complex systems, including bridge structures, concrete shells, and containments. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>O. Buyukozturk</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.055"></a>
<p><h3>1.055 Steel Bridge Competition
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m1c.html#1.58">1.58</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 0-4-0
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TBA</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-050</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students participate in the ASCE / AISC Student Steel Bridge Competition, gaining practical experience in structural design, steel fabrication processes, construction planning, organization, and teamwork. Provides an opportunity to compete against, and network with, students from other colleges and universities from around the country.
<br><I>P. Ghisbain</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.056"></a>
<p><h3>1.056J Building Structural Systems I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m4d.html#4.440">4.440J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4d.html#4.462">4.462</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m4d.html#4.401">4.401</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br>URL: <a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2014-4440">http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2014-4440</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-154</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>F9.30-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=9">9-250</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the design and behavior of large-scale structures and structural materials. Emphasizes the development of structural form and the principles of structural design. Presents design methods for timber, masonry, concrete and steel applied to long-span roof systems, bridges, and high-rise buildings. Includes environmental assessment of structural systems and materials. In laboratory sessions, students solve structural problems by building and testing simple models. Graduate and undergraduate students have separate lab sections.
<br><I>J. Ochsendorf</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=1.056');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.058"></a>
<p><h3>1.058 Structural Dynamics & Vibrations
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m1c.html#1.581">1.581J</A>, <A HREF="m2a.html#2.060">2.060J</A>, <A HREF="m16a.html#16.221">16.221J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-1-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Single- and multiple-degree-of-freedom vibration problems, using matrix formulation and normal mode superposition methods. Time and frequency domain solution techniques including convolution and Fourier transforms. Applications to vibration isolation, damping treatment, and dynamic absorbers. Analysis of continuous systems by exact and approximate methods. Applications to buildings, ships, aircraft and offshore structures. Vibration measurement and analysis techniques. Students should possess basic knowledge in structural mechanics and in linear algebra. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>E. Kausel</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.060"></a>
<p><h3>1.060 Engineering Mechanics II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor or <I>Coreq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-2-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=48">48-316</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>T11-1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=48">48-308</a>) or <i>F2.30-4.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=48">48-316</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Mechanics principles for incompressible fluids and their interactions with solid materials. Review of hydrostatics. Conservation of mass, momentum and energy in fluid mechanics. Flow nets, velocity distributions in laminar and turbulent flows, groundwater flows. Momentum and energy principles in hydraulics, with emphasis on open channel flow and hydraulic structures. Drag and lift forces. Analysis of pipe systems, pumps and turbines. Gradually varied flow in open channels, significance of the Froude number, backwater curves. Application of principles through open-ended studio exercises. Engineering Mechanics I is not required for this subject.
<br><I>M. Ghisalberti</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=1.060');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.061"></a>
<p><h3>1.061 Transport Processes in the Environment
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m1c.html#1.61">1.61</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m1a.html#1.060">1.060</a>; <I>Coreq: <a href="m1a.html#1.106">1.106</a>, <a href="m1a.html#1.070">1.070</a>; or permission of instructor</I>
<br>Units: 3-1-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces mass transport in environmental flows, with emphasis on river and lake systems. Covers derivation and solutions to the differential form of mass conservation equations. Topics include molecular and turbulent diffusion, boundary layers, dissolution, bed-water exchange, air-water exchange, and particle transport.
<br><I>H. M. Nepf</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.064"></a>
<p><h3>1.064 Physical Limnology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m1c.html#1.64">1.64</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m1a.html#1.061">1.061</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=48">48-316</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to physical processes occurring in lakes and shallow surface water systems with emphasis on mechanisms affecting fate and transport. Topics include internal waves, differential heating and cooling, boundary mixing, turbulent mixing, and influence of vegetation. Begins with a review of Navier-Stokes equation. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>H. M. Nepf</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.070"></a>
<p><h3>1.070J Introduction to Hydrology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m12a.html#12.320">12.320J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m1a.html#1.060">1.060</a>; <I>Coreq: <a href="m1a.html#1.061">1.061</a>, <a href="m1a.html#1.106">1.106</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the global water and energy cycles and the Earth system, including the atmosphere, oceans, land, and biosphere. Fundamentals of hydrologic science and its applications. Covers bases for the characterization of hydrologic processes such as precipitation, evaporation, transpiration by vegetation, infiltration, and storm runoff. Understanding and modeling of groundwater flow, hydraulics of wells, and subsurface transport of pollutants. Probabilistic analysis and risk estimation for hydrologic variables.
<br><I>D. Entekhabi</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.071"></a>
<p><h3>1.071J Global Change Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m12a.html#12.300">12.300J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the basic relevant principles and concepts in atmospheric physics, climate dynamics, biogeochemistry, and water and energy balance at the land-atmosphere boundary, through an examination of two current problems in the global environment: carbon dioxide and global warming; and tropical deforestation and regional climate. An introduction to global environmental problems for students in basic sciences and engineering.
<br><I>E. A. B. Eltahir</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.072"></a>
<p><h3>1.072 Groundwater Hydrology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m1c.html#1.72">1.72</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m1a.html#1.061">1.061</a>
<br>Units: 3-1-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents the fundamentals of subsurface flow and transport, emphasizing the role of groundwater in the hydrologic cycle, the relation of groundwater flow to geologic structure, and the management of contaminated groundwater. Topics include Darcy equation, flow nets, mass conservation, the aquifer flow equation, heterogeneity and anisotropy, storage properties, regional circulation, unsaturated flow, recharge, stream-aquifer interaction, well hydraulics, flow through fractured rock, numerical models, groundwater quality, contaminant transport processes, dispersion, decay, and adsorption. Includes laboratory and computer demonstrations. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>C. Harvey, R. Juanes</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.080"></a>
<p><h3>1.080 Environmental Chemistry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MF1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=48">48-308</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=48">48-316</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers basic environmental chemistry with a focus on understanding the principles governing the function of both natural systems and systems perturbed or engineered by humans. Emphasizes the key processes that act on chemical species in the atmosphere, natural waters, soils and sediments, allowing for the prediction of chemical concentrations and fates. Topics include acid-base chemistry, metal complexation, mineral dissolution and precipitation, oxidation/reduction reactions, photolysis, phase partitioning including bioaccumulation, and radiochemistry. Concurrent enrollment in 1.083 and 1.107 recommended.
<br><I>P. M. Gschwend</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=1.080');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.081"></a>
<p><h3>1.081J Environmental Cancer Risks, Prevention, and Therapy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m20a.html#20.104">20.104J</A>, <A HREF="mESDa.html#ESD.053">ESD.053J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-220</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analysis of the history of cancer and vascular disease mortality rates in predominantly European- and African-American US cohorts, 1895-2006, to discover specific historical shifts. Shifts identified are explored in terms of contemporaneously changing environmental risk factors: air-, food- and water-borne chemicals; subclinical infections; diet and lifestyles. Interaction of environmental and inherited risks. Considers the hypotheses that environmental factors affect metakaryotic stem cell  mutation rates in fetuses and juveniles and/or the growth rates of preneoplastic stem cells in adults. Interaction of environmental and inherited risks. Introduces the use of metakaryocidal drugs to treat cancer in clinical trials.
<br><I>W. Thilly, R. McCunney</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=1.081');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.083"></a>
<p><h3>1.083 Environmental Health Engineering and Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, <a href="m1a.html#1.061">1.061</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=48">48-308</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TBA</i> <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Considers human health issues associated with environmental engineering for air, land, and water. Topics include the fundamental and applied aspects of biological and microbial processes in natural and engineered systems, including microbial metabolisms, water quality, ecological assessment, and wastewater treatment; the interaction between humans and chemicals in the environment including toxicology, exposure pathways, and risk assessment; treatment technologies; and the basis for environmental regulation of chemical exposure. Case studies illustrate concepts and issues. Concurrent enrollment in 1.080 and 1.107 recommended.
<br><I>J. Thompson</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.084"></a>
<p><h3>1.084J Systems Microbiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m20a.html#20.106">20.106J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introductory microbiology from a systems perspective - considers microbial diversity and the integration of data from a molecular, cellular, organismal, and ecological context to understand the interaction of microbial organisms with their environment. Special emphasis on specific viral, bacterial, and eukaryotic microorganisms and their interaction with animal hosts with focus on contemporary problems in areas such as vaccination, emerging disease, antimicrobial drug resistance, and toxicology.
<br><I>E. DeLong, J. Runstadler</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.085"></a>
<p><h3>1.085J Air Pollution
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m12a.html#12.336">12.336J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides a working knowledge of basic air quality issues, with emphasis on a multidisciplinary approach to investigating the sources and effects of pollution.  Topics include emission sources; atmospheric chemistry and removal processes; meteorological phenomena and their impact on pollution transport at local to global scales; air pollution control technologies; health effects; and regulatory standards. Discusses regional and global issues, such as acid rain, ozone depletion and air quality connections to climate change.
<br><I>C. Heald</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.089"></a>
<p><h3>1.089 Environmental Microbiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m1c.html#1.89">1.89</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides a general introduction to the diverse roles of microorganisms in natural and artificial environments. Topics include cellular architecture, energetics, and growth; evolution and gene flow; population and community dynamics; water and soil microbiology; biogeochemical cycling; and microorganisms in biodeterioration and bioremediation. 7.014 recommended as prerequisite; students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>J. R. Thompson</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.092"></a>
<p><h3>1.092 Traveling Research Environmental Experience (TREX)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides students with the opportunity to gain direct fieldwork and research experience in a global context. Subject spans three weeks, including two weeks of fieldwork in a remote location, such as Hawaii or Florida, and one week of lectures on campus. Expedition focuses on one or more environmental issues in three dimensions: scientific, political, and economic. Group presentations or equivalent required. Limited to Course 1 students.
<br><I>J. Kroll, S. Frankel</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.093"></a>
<p><h3>1.093 Introduction to Computer-Aided Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-2
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces concepts of computer-aided design (CAD) though the use of modeling software. Provides the basic skills applicable to various CAD programs. Students create 2-D wireframe geometry, 3-D solid models, and produce dimensioned drawings. Licensed software provided for class use. Limited to 20; preference to Course 1 students.
<br><I>J. Germaine, S. Rudolph</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.095"></a>

<h2>Undergraduate Laboratory Subjects</h2>
<a name="1.101"></a>
<p><h3>1.101 Introduction to Civil and Environmental Engineering Design I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/HalfLab.gif" alt="1/2 Institute Lab" title="1/2 Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="m1a.html#1.018">1.018</a>, <a href="m1a.html#1.050">1.050</a></I>
<br>Units: 0-3-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Project-oriented introduction to the principles and practice of civil and environmental engineering design. First half of the term, students work in teams to apply the design process to an open-ended design/planning problem involving civil and environmental engineering aspects.  In the second half, teams design and build a working model researching, in detail, an aspect of the planning/design project.  Each team then presents the model and the results to the class. Regular written and oral presentations. Students also start on their design portfolio. Enrollment limited; preference to Course 1 majors and minors.
<br><I>H. H. Einstein, P. Reis, A. Epstein, S. Rudolph</I><br>
<a name="1.102"></a>
<p><h3>1.102 Introduction to Civil and Environmental Engineering Design II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/HalfLab.gif" alt="1/2 Institute Lab" title="1/2 Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>; or <I>Coreq: <a href="m1a.html#1.060">1.060</a></I> and permission of instructor
<br>Units: 1-3-2
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-217</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>R9-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-050</a>) or <i>R1-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-050</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Project-oriented subject focused on the principles and practice of engineering design. Emphasis on construction and deployment of designs, plus performance testing used to determine if designs behave  as expected. Includes a major team project involving use and application of sensors, as well as environmentally-friendly, and energy-effective or energy-producing designs. Develops practical, teamwork and communication skills. Enrollment limited; preference to Course 1 majors and minors.
<br><I>J. T. Germaine, A. Mueller</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.106"></a>
<p><h3>1.106 Environmental Fluid Transport Processes and Hydrology Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/HalfLab.gif" alt="1/2 Institute Lab" title="1/2 Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="m1a.html#1.061">1.061</a>, <a href="m1a.html#1.070">1.070</a></I>
<br>Units: 0-4-2
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Builds on the lecture subjects 1.061 and 1.070. Fundamentals of mass and flow measurements in field and laboratory settings, and application of these measurement techniques to analyze real and model environmental systems. Enrollment limited; preference to 1-E and 1-A students.
<br><I>H. M. Nepf</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.107"></a>
<p><h3>1.107 Environmental Chemistry and Biology Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/HalfLab.gif" alt="1/2 Institute Lab" title="1/2 Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="m1a.html#1.080">1.080</a></I>
<br>Units: 0-4-2
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=48">48-308</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>W2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=48">48-109</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Laboratory and field techniques in biogeochemistry and environmental engineering and their application to the understanding of natural and engineered ecosystems. Exercises demonstrate data acquisition and modeling suited to identifying and quantifying physical, chemical, and biological processes that govern the effects of human activity on the functioning of natural systems and/or the efficacy of engineered approaches to environmental problems. Applications include chemical and biological remediation, measurement of contaminants, and detection of biogeochemical activity in natural environments. An independently designed final project is required. 1.018 and 1.061 strongly recommended. Enrollment limited; preference to 1-E students.
<br><I>P. Gschwend</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<h2>Engineering Information Systems and Computation</h2>
<a name="1.124"></a>
<p><h3>1.124J Software and Computation for Simulation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2a.html#2.091">2.091J</A>, <A HREF="mESDa.html#ESD.51">ESD.51J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m1a.html#1.00">1.00</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/1.124/www/">http://web.mit.edu/1.124/www/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Modern software development techniques and algorithms for engineering computation. Hands-on investigation of computational and software techniques for simulating engineering systems, such as sensor networks, traffic networks, and discrete simulation of materials using atomistic and particle methods. Covers data structures and algorithms for modeling, analysis, and visualization in the setting of multi-core and distributed computing. Treatment of basic topics, such as queuing, sorting and search algorithms, and more advanced numerical techniques based on state machines and distributed agents. Foundation for in-depth exploration of image processing, optimization, finite element and particle methods, computational materials, discrete element methods, and network methods. Knowledge of an object-oriented language required.
<br><I>J. R. Williams</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.125"></a>
<p><h3>1.125J Architecting & Engineering Software Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mESDa.html#ESD.341">ESD.341J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m1a.html#1.00">1.00</a>, <a href="m1a.html#1.124">1.124J</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Software architecting and design of  software-intensive systems. Targeted at future CTOs who must understand both the business and technical issues involved in architecting enterprise-scale systems. Student teams confront technically challenging problems. Lectures and readings cover core database, XML, web server components and browser issues in a distributed web service environment. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>J. Williams, A. Sanchez</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.126"></a>
<p><h3>1.126J Pattern Recognition and Analysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mMASa.html#MAS.622">MAS.622J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Fundamentals of characterizing and recognizing patterns and features of interest in numerical data. Basic tools and theory for signal understanding problems with applications to user modeling, affect recognition, speech recognition and understanding, computer vision, physiological analysis, and more. Decision theory, statistical classification, maximum likelihood and Bayesian estimation, nonparametric methods, unsupervised learning and clustering. Additional topics on machine and human learning from active research. Knowledge of probability theory and linear algebra required. Limited to 20.
<br><I>R. W. Picard</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.128"></a>
<p><h3>1.128J Computational Geometry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as 2.089J)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Topics in surface modeling: b-splines, non-uniform rational b-splines, physically based deformable surfaces, sweeps and generalized cylinders, offsets, blending and filleting surfaces. Non-linear solvers and intersection problems. Solid modeling: constructive solid geometry, boundary representation, non-manifold and mixed-dimension boundary representation models, octrees. Robustness of geometric computations. Interval methods. Finite and boundary element discretization methods for continuum mechanics problems. Scientific visualization. Variational geometry. Tolerances. Inspection methods. Feature representation and recognition. Shape interrogation for design, analysis, and manufacturing. Involves analytical and programming assignments.
<br><I>N. M. Patrikalakis, D. C. Gossard</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<h2>Engineering Analysis Methods</h2>
<a name="1.133"></a>
<p><h3>1.133 MEng Concepts of Engineering Practice
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Core requirement for the M.Eng. program designed to teach students about the roles of today's professional engineer and expose them to team-building skills through lectures, team workshops, and seminars. Topics include: written and oral communication, job placement skills, trends in the engineering and construction industry, risk analysis and risk management, managing public information, proposal preparation, project evaluation, project management, liability, professional ethics, and negotiation. Draws on relevant large-scale projects to illustrate each component of the subject. Grading is based on both individual and team exercises involving written and oral presentations. Limited to Course 1 MEng students.
<br><I>E. E. Adams</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.138"></a>
<p><h3>1.138J Wave Propagation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2a.html#2.062">2.062J</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.376">18.376J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.003">2.003</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.075">18.075</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.376/">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.376/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-133</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Theoretical concepts and analysis of wave problems in science and engineering with examples chosen from elasticity, acoustics, geophysics, hydrodynamics, blood flow, nondestructive evaluation, and other applications.  Progressive waves, group velocity and dispersion, energy density and transport. Reflection, refraction and transmission of plane waves by an interface. Mode conversion in elastic waves. Rayleigh waves. Waves due to a moving load. Scattering by a two-dimensional obstacle.  Reciprocity theorems. Parabolic approximation. Waves on the sea surface. Capillary-gravity waves. Wave resistance. Radiation of surface waves. Internal waves in stratified fluids.  Waves in rotating media.  Waves in random media.
<br><I>T. R. Akylas, R. R. Rosales</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=1.138');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<p>See also <a href="m1b.html#1.351">1.351</a>, <a href="m1c.html#1.541">1.541</a>, <a href="m1c.html#1.56">1.56J</a>, <a href="m1c.html#1.63">1.63</a>, <a href="m1c.html#1.691">1.691</a>.
<h2>Engineering Systems, Economics, and Optimization</h2>
<a name="1.142"></a>
<p><h3>1.142J Robust Modeling, Optimization, and Computation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m15a.html#15.094">15.094J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W EVE (4-7 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-372</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>M12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-057</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces modern robust optimization, including theory, applications, and computation. Presents formulations and their connection to probability, information and risk theory for conic optimization (linear, second-order, and semidefinite cones) and integer optimization. Application domains include analysis and optimization of stochastic networks, optimal mechanism design, network information theory, transportation, pattern classification, structural and engineering design, and financial engineering. Students formulate and solve a problem aligned with their interests in a final project.
<br><I>D. Bertsimas, R. M. Freund</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.145"></a>
<p><h3>1.145J Engineering Economy Module
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">); partial term
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mESDa.html#ESD.70">ESD.70J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 1-0-2 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presentation of the spreadsheet mechanics for the efficient calculation of discounted cash flows and related metrics of project worth; the use of data tables as means of exploring sensitivity analysis; and of simulation to develop the value of options. Intensive module designed for students who are not familiar with the efficient use of Excel. Presented intensively over first week of term.
<br><I>R. de Neufville</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="1.146"></a>
<p><h3>1.146 Engineering Systems Analysis for Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Engineering School-Wide Elective Subject. <br>(Offered under: <A HREF="m16b.html#16.861">16.861</A>, <A HREF="mESDa.html#ESD.71">ESD.71</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mESDa.html#ESD.710">ESD.710</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m1a.html#1.145">1.145</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://msl1.mit.edu/mib/dsp/curricula.mit.edu/~dsplan/">http://msl1.mit.edu/mib/dsp/curricula.mit.edu/~dsplan/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers theory and methods to identify, value, and implement flexibility in design, also known as "real options." Topics include definition of uncertainties, simulation of performance for scenarios, screening models to identify desirable flexibility, decision and lattice analysis, and multidimensional economic evaluation. Students demonstrate proficiency through an extended application to a systems design of their choice. Provides a complement to research or thesis projects. Meets with ESD.710 first half of term.
<br><I>R. de Neufville</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<p>See also <a href="m1b.html#1.202">1.202J</a>, <a href="m1b.html#1.203">1.203J</a>, <a href="m1b.html#1.283">1.283J</a>, <a href="m1c.html#1.731">1.731.</a> For management of engineering systems, see also <a href="m1a.html#1.040">1.040</a>, <a href="m1b.html#1.401">1.401J</a>-<a href="m1b.html#1.482">1.482</a>.
</td></tr></table>
