<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Course 20: Biological Engineering<br>Spring
2014</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://web.mit.edu/be/"><i>Course 20 Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course20.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=++20&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>20.00-20.ZZZZ</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<a name="20.002"></a>
<p><h3>20.002 Metakaryotic Biology and Epidemiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces non-eukaryotic metakaryotic cells that serve as the stem cells of human fetal/juvenile growth and development. Considers their peculiar modes of genome organization in chromosomal rings, replication via dsRNA/DNA intermediates and amitotic segregation. Explores the hypothesis that high mutation rates in these cells lead to cancers and atherosclerotic plaques and account for the increasing death rates observed with human age.
<br><I>W. Thilly</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.020"></a>
<p><h3>20.020 Introduction to Biological Engineering Design Using Synthetic Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m20a.html#20.385">20.385</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-3-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Project-based introduction to the engineering of synthetic biological systems. Throughout the term, students develop projects that are responsive to real-world problems of their choosing, and whose solutions depend on biological technologies. Lectures, discussions, and studio exercises will introduce components and control of prokaryotic and eukaryotic behavior; DNA synthesis, standards, and abstraction in biological engineering; and issues of human practice, including biological safety, security, ethics, and ownership, sharing, and innovation. Preference to freshmen.
<br><I>N. Kuldell</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.102"></a>
<p><h3>20.102 Stem Cells in Organogenesis, Carcinogenesis, and Atherogenesis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m20a.html#20.215">20.215</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Study of the amitotic metakaryotic stem cells in fetal/juvenile organogenesis and wound healing. Explores their roles as stem cells in clonal diseases such as cancers and atherosclerosis. Application of a hypermutable/mutator stem cell model to the analysis of age-specific mortality from clonal diseases. Students taking 20.215 do additional research and computer modeling.
<br><I>E. V. Gostjeva, W. G. Thilly</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.104"></a>
<p><h3>20.104J Environmental Cancer Risks, Prevention, and Therapy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1a.html#1.081">1.081J</A>, <A HREF="mESDa.html#ESD.053">ESD.053J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-220</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analysis of the history of cancer and vascular disease mortality rates in predominantly European- and African-American US cohorts, 1895-2006, to discover specific historical shifts. Shifts identified are explored in terms of contemporaneously changing environmental risk factors: air-, food- and water-borne chemicals; subclinical infections; diet and lifestyles. Interaction of environmental and inherited risks. Considers the hypotheses that environmental factors affect metakaryotic stem cell  mutation rates in fetuses and juveniles and/or the growth rates of preneoplastic stem cells in adults. Interaction of environmental and inherited risks. Introduces the use of metakaryocidal drugs to treat cancer in clinical trials.
<br><I>W. Thilly, R. McCunney</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.106"></a>
<p><h3>20.106J Systems Microbiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1a.html#1.084">1.084J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introductory microbiology from a systems perspective - considers microbial diversity and the integration of data from a molecular, cellular, organismal, and ecological context to understand the interaction of microbial organisms with their environment. Special emphasis on specific viral, bacterial, and eukaryotic microorganisms and their interaction with animal hosts with focus on contemporary problems in areas such as vaccination, emerging disease, antimicrobial drug resistance, and toxicology.
<br><I>E. DeLong, J. Runstadler</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.109"></a>
<p><h3>20.109 Laboratory Fundamentals in Biological Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m20a.html#20.S109">20.S109</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.00">6.00</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>; <a href="m20a.html#20.110">20.110</a> or <a href="m20a.html#20.111">20.111</a>
<br>Units: 2-8-5
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-220</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-322</a>) or <i>WF1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-322</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces experimental biochemical and molecular techniques from a quantitative engineering perspective. Experimental design, data analysis, and scientific communication form the underpinnings of this subject. Examples of discovery-based experimental modules include DNA engineering in which students design, construct, and use genetic material; parts engineering, which emphasizes protein design and quantitative assessment of protein performance; systems engineering, in which students consider genome-wide consequences of genetic perturbations; and biomaterials engineering, in which students use biologically-encoded devices to design and build materials. Enrollment limited; priority to Course 20 majors.
<br>Fall: <I>A. Belcher, B. Engelward, S. Hughes-Alford, A. Stachowiak</I><br>Spring: <I>S. Hughes, A. Ramaswamy, J. Runstadler, L. Samson, A. StachowiaK</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
<a name="20.S109"></a>
<h3>20.S109 Special Subject: Laboratory Fundamentals in Biological Engineering
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m20a.html#20.109">20.109</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.00">6.00</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>; <a href="m20a.html#20.110">20.110</a> or <a href="m20a.html#20.111">20.111</a>
<br>Units: 2-7-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-220</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>WF9-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-322</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Experimental version of 20.109, which offers an online component as part of the laboratory experience. See description of 20.109. Licensed for Spring 2014 by the Committee on Curricula as an acceptable alternative to 20.109. Enrollment limited; priority to Course 20 majors.
<br>Fall: <I>A. Belcher, B. Engelward, S. Hughes, N. Kuldell, A. Stachowiak</I><br>Spring: <I>A. Jasanoff, J. Runstadler, A. Stachowiak, S. Hughes</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.110"></a>
<p><h3>20.110J Thermodynamics of Biomolecular Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.772">2.772J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m7a.html#7.10">7.10</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.111">20.111</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Equilibrium properties of macroscopic and microscopic systems. Basic thermodynamics: state of a system, state variables. Work, heat, first law of thermodynamics, thermochemistry. Second and third law of thermodynamics: entropy and its statistical basis, Gibbs function. Chemical equilibrium of reactions in gas and solution phase. Macromolecular structure and interactions in solution. Driving forces for molecular self-assembly. Binding cooperativity, solvation, titration of macromolecules.
<br><I>L. Griffith, C. Voigt</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.111"></a>
<p><h3>20.111J Physical Chemistry of Biomolecular Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m7a.html#7.10">7.10J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>; <I>Coreq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a></I>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m2b.html#2.772">2.772</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.110">20.110</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-370</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>M2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-145</a>) or <i>T1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=8">8-205</a>) or <i>R1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=8">8-205</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides a quantitative approach to understanding the physical and chemical laws that govern the behavior of biological macromolecules.  Basic thermodynamics, state of a system, state variables. Work, heat, first, second, and third laws of thermodynamics.  Entropy and its statistical basis, free energy representations, Legendre transforms, Maxwell relations, Gibbs function, Boltzmann distribution and partition functions.  Equilibrium properties of macroscopic and microscopic systems; macromolecular structure and interactions in solution. Driving forces for molecular self-assembly. Binding, cooperativity, solvation, and titration of macromolecules. Meets with 5.60 first half of term.
<br><I>E. Alm, C. Voigt</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=20.111');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.129"></a>
<p><h3>20.129J Biological Circuit Engineering Laboratory
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6a.html#6.129">6.129J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 2-8-2
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-121</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>MW1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-077</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students assemble individual genes and regulatory elements into larger-scale circuits; they characterize these circuits using quantitative techniques, including flow cytometry, and model their results computationally. Emphasizes concepts and techniques to perform independent synthetic biology research. Discusses current literature and ongoing research in the field of synthetic biology. Instruction and practice in oral and written communication provided. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>T. Lu</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.200"></a>
<p><h3>20.200 Biological Engineering Seminar
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Open only to BE graduate students, or by permission of instructor
<br>Units: 1-0-2 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-370</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Weekly one-hour seminars covering graduate student research and presentations by invited speakers.
<br><I>J. S. Wishnok</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.201"></a>
<p><h3>20.201 Fundamentals of Drug Development
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Addresses the scientific basis for the development of new drugs. First half of term begins with an overview of the drug discovery process, followed by fundamental principles of pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, metabolism, and the mechanisms by which drugs cause therapeutic and toxic responses. Second half applies principles to case studies and literature discussions of current problems with specific drugs, drug classes, and therapeutic targets.
<br><I>P. C. Dedon, M. A. Murcko, S. R. Tannenbaum</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.202"></a>
<p><h3>20.202 In vivo Models: Principles and Practices
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">; first half of term
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 1-1-4
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30 (ENDS MARCH 21)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-802</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Selected aspects of anatomy, histology, immuno-cytochemistry, in situ hybridization, physiology, and cell biology of mammalian organisms and their pathogens. Subject material integrated with principles of toxicology, in vivo genetic engineering, and molecular biology. A lab/demonstration period each week involves experiments in anatomy (in vivo), physiology, and microscopy to augment the lectures. Offered first half of spring term.
<br><I>J. G. Fox, B. Marini, M. Whary</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.205"></a>
<p><h3>20.205J Principles and Applications of Genetic Engineering for Biotechnology and Neuroscience
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m9a.html#9.26">9.26J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.28">7.28</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.32">7.32</a>, or <a href="m20a.html#20.020">20.020</a>; <a href="m9a.html#9.01">9.01</a> or <a href="m9a.html#9.09">9.09</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-3015</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers principles underlying current and future genetic engineering approaches, ranging from single cellular organisms to whole animals. Focuses on development and invention of technologies for engineering biological systems at the genomic level, and applications of engineered biological systems for medical and biotechnological needs, with particular emphasis on genetic manipulation of the nervous system. Design projects by students.
<br><I>F. Zhang</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.213"></a>
<p><h3>20.213 DNA Damage and Genomic Instability
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">; second half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.07">5.07</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW10-12 (BEGINS MARCH 31)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-614</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on the biochemistry and molecular mechanisms of DNA replication and DNA repair. Analyzes the chemistry of DNA damaging events, and continues with analysis of the mutagenic and toxic consequences of modifications to DNA structure. Also presents the contrasting perspective that normal DNA processing leads to mutations. Moves from analysis and discussion of key DNA repair pathways to connections between DNA repair and human diseases. Discussion of current literature and in-depth discussions of the chemistry and biochemistry of DNA metabolism form the foundation of the subject.
<br><I>B. P. Engelward, L. Samson</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.215"></a>
<p><h3>20.215 Macroepidemiology, Population Genetics, and Stem Cell Biology of Human Clonal Diseases
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m20a.html#20.102">20.102</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>, <a href="m1a.html#1.00">1.00</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-15
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies the logic and technology needed to discover genetic and environmental risks for common human cancers and vascular diseases. Includes an introduction to metakaryotic stem cell biology. Analyzes large, organized historical public health databases using quantitative cascade computer models that include population stratification of stem cell mutation rates in fetal/juvenile tissues  and  growth rates in preneoplastic colonies and atherosclerotic plaques. Means to test hypotheses (CAST) that certain genes carry mutations conferring risk for common cancers via genetic analyses in large human cohorts.
<br><I>W. G. Thilly</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.219"></a>
<p><h3>20.219 Selected Topics in Toxicology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: Permission of Instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Detailed discussion of selected topics of current interest. Classwork in various areas not covered by regular subjects.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.260"></a>
<p><h3>20.260 Analysis and Presentation of Complex Biological Data
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m20a.html#20.560">20.560</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-2 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Illustrates best practices in the statistical analysis of complex biological datasets and the graphical representation of such analyses. Covers fundamental concepts in probability and statistical theory as well as principles of information design.  Provides mathematical concepts and tools that enable students to make sound judgments about the application of statistical methods and to present statistical results in clear and compelling visual formats. Assignments focus on key concepts and their application to practical examples. Assumes basic knowledge of calculus and programming in MATLAB or R. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>P. Blainey</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.300"></a>
<p><h3>20.300 Advanced Workshop in Biological Engineering Communication: Professors Share Their Practices
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-0 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Working scientists and engineers discuss best practices for written, visual, and oral communication in the classroom, the lab, and the workplace. In a series of lectures, successful academics and industry professionals share how they prepare papers, talks, and graphics. Recitations allow deeper exploration of the lecture topics. With faculty guidance, students develop their own projects during workshops. Emphasizes systematic approaches and transferable skills such as effective drafting and revision. Topics include creating compelling visuals to represent data and concepts; formal/informal writing, from research papers to cover letters; and developing memorable talks and presentations. Examples drawn from biological engineering research. Enrollment limited; preference to Course 20 majors.
<br><I>E. Alm, J. Goldstein, A. Stachowiak</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.305"></a>
<p><h3>20.305J Principles of Synthetic Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6b.html#6.580">6.580J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6b.html#6.589">6.589J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.405">20.405J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the basics of synthetic biology, including quantitative cellular network characterization and modeling. Considers the discovery and genetic factoring of useful cellular activities into reusable functions for design. Emphasizes the principles of biomolecular system design and diagnosis of designed systems. Illustrates cutting-edge applications in synthetic biology and enhances skills in analysis and design of synthetic biological applications. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>R. Weiss</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.309"></a>
<p><h3>20.309J Instrumentation and Measurement for Biological Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.673">2.673J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m20a.html#20.409">20.409</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.00">6.00</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>, <a href="m20a.html#20.330">20.330</a>; <a href="m2a.html#2.001">2.001</a>, <a href="m20a.html#20.310">20.310</a>, or <a href="m6a.html#6.02">6.02</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-6-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-237</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>TBA</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-336</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-154</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Sensing and measurement aimed at quantitative molecular/cell/tissue analysis in terms of genetic, biochemical, and biophysical properties. Methods include light and fluorescence microscopies, electronic circuits, and electro-mechanical probes (atomic force microscopy, optical traps, MEMS devices). Application of statistics, probability, signal and noise analysis, and Fourier techniques to experimental data. Preference to juniors and seniors.
<br>Fall: <I>P. Blainey, A. Jasanoff, S. Manalis, S. Nagle, S. Wasserman</I><br>Spring: <I>E. Boyden, M. Jonas, S. Nagle, P. So, S. Wasserman</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=20.309');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.310"></a>
<p><h3>20.310J Molecular, Cellular, and Tissue Biomechanics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.797">2.797J</A>, <A HREF="m3a.html#3.053">3.053J</A>, <A HREF="m6a.html#6.024">6.024J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2b.html#2.370">2.370</a> or <a href="m2b.html#2.772">2.772J</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m3a.html#3.016">3.016</a>; <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-270</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>M4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-304</a>) or <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-303</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops and applies scaling laws and the methods of continuum mechanics to biomechanical phenomena over a range of length scales. Topics include structure of tissues and the molecular basis for macroscopic properties; chemical and electrical effects on mechanical behavior; cell mechanics, motility and adhesion; biomembranes; biomolecular mechanics and molecular motors. Experimental methods for probing structures at the tissue, cellular, and molecular levels.
<br><I>R. D. Kamm, A. J. Grodzinsky</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=20.310');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.320"></a>
<p><h3>20.320 Analysis of Biomolecular and Cellular Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m20a.html#20.110">20.110</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.00">6.00</a>; <I>Coreq: <a href="m5a.html#5.07">5.07</a></I>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analysis of molecular and cellular processes across a hierarchy of scales, including genetic, molecular, cellular, and cell population levels. Topics include gene sequence analysis, molecular modeling, metabolic and gene regulation networks, signal transduction pathways and cell populations in tissues. Emphasis on experimental methods, quantitative analysis, and computational modeling.
<br><I>F. White, E. Fraenkel</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.330"></a>
<p><h3>20.330J Fields, Forces and Flows in Biological Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.793">2.793J</A>, <A HREF="m6a.html#6.023">6.023J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m2a.html#2.005">2.005</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.021">6.021</a>, <a href="m20a.html#20.320">20.320</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-237</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>T10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-180</a>) or <i>T12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-180</a>) or <i>T4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-144</a>) or <i>W4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-144</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to electric fields, fluid flows, transport phenomena and their application to biological systems. Flux and continuity laws, Maxwell's equations, electro-quasistatics, electro-chemical-mechanical driving forces, conservation of mass and momentum, Navier-Stokes flows, and electrokinetics. Applications include biomolecular transport in tissues, electrophoresis, and microfluidics.
<br><I>J. Han, S. Manalis</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.340"></a>
<p><h3>20.340J Materials for Biomedical Applications
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m3a.html#3.051">3.051J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.034">3.034</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.012">3.012</a> or <a href="m3a.html#3.046">3.046</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the interactions between cells and surfaces of biomaterials. Surface chemistry and physics of selected metals, polymers, and ceramics. Surface characterization methodology. Modification of biomaterials surfaces. Quantitative assays of cell behavior in culture. Biosensors and microarrays. Bulk properties of implants. Acute and chronic response to implanted biomaterials. Topics in biomimetics, drug delivery, and tissue engineering.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.345"></a>
<p><h3>20.345J Bioinstrumentation Project Lab
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6a.html#6.123">6.123J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, and <a href="m2a.html#2.004">2.004</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.003">6.003</a>; or <a href="m20a.html#20.309">20.309</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-7-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-336</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>In-depth examination of instrumentation design, principles and techniques for studying biological systems, from single molecules to entire organisms. Lectures cover optics, advanced microscopy techniques, electronics for biological measurement, magnetic resonance imaging, computed tomography, MEMs, microfluidic devices, and limits of detection. Students select two lab exercises during the first half of the semester and complete a final design project in the second half. Lab emphasizes design process and skillful realization of a robust system.
<br><I>E. Boyden, M. Jonas, S. F. Nagle, P. So, S. Wasserman, M. F. Yanik</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=20.345');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.360"></a>
<p><h3>20.360J Tissue Engineering for Analysis, Prevention, and Treatment of Human Disease
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m10a.html#10.499">10.499J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.07">5.07</a> or <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>; <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>; <a href="m20a.html#20.110">20.110</a> or <a href="m5b.html#5.60">5.60</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analysis of fundamental processes in tissue engineering with an emphasis on use of comparative animal models and in vitro tissue engineered models to understand human disease and develop therapies for human disease and for regenerating human tissues and organs.  using representative examples of metabolic tissue (e.g., liver) and connective tissue (e.g., bone). Design principles and engineering approaches (e.g., use of synthetic materials) for controlling receptor-mediated processes such as cell migration, growth, and differentiation. Mass transfer limitations in design of devices for cell encapsulation and in scaffold-guided regeneration. Guided organization of multicellular structures. Current clinical prospects.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.361"></a>
<p><h3>20.361J Molecular and Engineering Aspects of Biotechnology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m7a.html#7.37">7.37J</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.441">10.441J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.005">2.005</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.012">3.012</a>, <a href="m5b.html#5.60">5.60</a>, <a href="m20a.html#20.110">20.110</a>, or <a href="m20a.html#20.111">20.111</a>; <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW3-5</i> (Whitehead-7TH)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers biological and bioengineering principles underlying the development and therapeutic use of recombinant proteins and stem cells; glycoengineering of recombinant proteins; normal and pathological signaling by growth factors and their receptors; receptor trafficking; monoclonal antibodies as therapeutics; protein pharmacology and delivery; stem cell-derived tissues as therapeutics; RNA therapeutics; combinatorial protein engineering; and new antitumor drugs.
<br><I>H. Lodish, L. Griffith</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=20.361');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.363"></a>
<p><h3>20.363J Biomaterials Science and Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m3a.html#3.055">3.055J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m3b.html#3.963">3.963J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.463">20.463J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.034">3.034</a>, <a href="m20a.html#20.110">20.110</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers, at a molecular scale, the analysis and design of materials used in contact with biological systems, and biomimetic strategies aimed at creating new materials based on principles found in biology. Topics include molecular interaction between bio- and synthetic molecules and surfaces; design, synthesis, and processing approaches for materials that control cell functions; and application of materials science to problems in tissue engineering, drug delivery, vaccines, and cell-guiding surfaces. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>D. Irvine, K. Ribbeck</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.370"></a>
<p><h3>20.370J Cellular Biophysics and Neurophysiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.791">2.791J</A>, <A HREF="m6a.html#6.021">6.021J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m2b.html#2.794">2.794J</A>, <A HREF="m6b.html#6.521">6.521J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.470">20.470J</A>, <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.541">HST.541J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>; <a href="m2a.html#2.005">2.005</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.002">6.002</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.003">6.003</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.071">6.071</a>, <a href="m10a.html#10.301">10.301</a>, <a href="m20a.html#20.110">20.110</a>, <a href="m20a.html#20.111">20.111</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 5-2-5
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Integrated overview of the biophysics of cells from prokaryotes to neurons, with a focus on mass transport and electrical signal generation across cell membrane. First half of course focuses on mass transport through membranes: diffusion, osmosis, chemically mediated, and active transport. Second half focuses on electrical properties of cells: ion transport to action potentials in electrically excitable cells. Electrical properties interpreted via kinetic and molecular properties of single voltage-gated ion channels. Laboratory and computer exercises illustrate the concepts. Provides instruction in written and oral communication. Students taking graduate version complete different assignments. Preference to juniors and seniors.
<br><I>D. M. Freeman, J. Han, J. Voldman, M. F. Yanik</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.371"></a>
<p><h3>20.371J Quantitative Systems Physiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.792">2.792J</A>, <A HREF="m6a.html#6.022">6.022J</A>, <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.542">HST.542J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m2b.html#2.796">2.796J</A>, <A HREF="m6b.html#6.522">6.522J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.471">20.471J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-2-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-124</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E25">E25-117</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E25">E25-117</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Application of the principles of energy and mass flow to major human organ systems. Mechanisms of regulation and homeostasis. Anatomical, physiological and pathophysiological features of the cardiovascular, respiratory and renal systems. Systems, features and devices that are most illuminated by the methods of physical sciences. Laboratory work includes some animal studies. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>R. G. Mark, C. M. Stultz</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=20.371');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.380"></a>
<p><h3>20.380 Biological Engineering Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a>, <a href="m20a.html#20.309">20.309</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-614</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-614</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Illustrates how knowledge and principles of biology, biochemistry, and engineering are integrated to create new products for societal benefit. Uses case study format to examine recently developed products of pharmaceutical and biotechnology industries: how a product evolves from initial idea, through patents, testing, evaluation, production, and marketing. Emphasizes scientific and engineering principles, as well as the responsibility scientists, engineers, and business executives have for the consequences of their technology. Instruction and practice in written and oral communication provided. Enrollment limited; preference to Course 20 undergraduates.
<br><I>J. Essigmann, D. Irvine, K. Ribbeck</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.385"></a>
<p><h3>20.385 Understanding Current Research in Synthetic Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m20a.html#20.020">20.020</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m20a.html#20.109">20.109</a>, <a href="m20a.html#20.320">20.320</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an in-depth understanding of the state of research in synthetic biology. Critical evaluation of primary research literature covering a range of approaches to the design, modeling and programming of cellular behaviors. Focuses on developing the skills needed to read, present and discuss primary research literature, and to manage and lead small teams. Students mentor a small undergraduate team of 20.020 students. Open to advanced students with appropriate background in biology.
<br><I>N. Kuldell</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.390"></a>
<p><h3>20.390J Foundations of Computational and Systems Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m7a.html#7.36">7.36J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.91">7.91J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.490">20.490J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>; <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a> or <a href="m5a.html#5.07">5.07</a>; <a href="m1a.html#1.00">1.00</a>, <a href="m1a.html#1.001">1.001</a>, or <a href="m6a.html#6.00">6.00</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/7.91/">http://web.mit.edu/7.91/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-141</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-160</a>) or <i>R4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-162</a>) or <i>F4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-168</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to computational and systems biology. Includes units on the analysis of protein and nucleic acid sequences, protein structures, and biological networks. Presents principles and methods used for sequence alignment, motif finding, expression array analysis, structural modeling, structure design and prediction, and network analysis and modeling. Techniques include dynamic programming, Markov and hidden Markov models, Bayesian networks, clustering methods, and energy minimization approaches. Exposes students to emerging research areas. Designed for students with strong backgrounds in either molecular biology or computer science. Some foundational material covering basic programming skills, probability and statistics is provided for students with less quantitative backgrounds. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>C. Burge, E. Fraenkel, D. Gifford</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=20.390');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.405"></a>
<p><h3>20.405J Principles of Synthetic Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6b.html#6.589">6.589J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6b.html#6.580">6.580J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.305">20.305J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the basics of synthetic biology, including quantitative cellular network characterization and modeling. Considers the discovery and genetic factoring of useful cellular activities into reusable functions for design. Emphasizes the principles of biomolecular system design and diagnosis of designed systems. Illustrates cutting-edge applications in synthetic biology and enhances skills in analysis and design of synthetic biological applications. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>R. Weiss</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.409"></a>
<p><h3>20.409 Biological Engineering II: Instrumentation and Measurement
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m2b.html#2.673">2.673J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.309">20.309J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>
<br>Units: 2-7-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-237</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>TBA</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-336</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-154</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Sensing and measurement aimed at quantitative molecular/cell/tissue analysis in terms of genetic, biochemical, and biophysical properties. Methods include light and fluorescence microscopies, electronic circuits, and electro-mechanical probes (atomic force microscopy, optical traps, MEMS devices). Application of statistics, probability, signal and noise analysis, and Fourier techniques to experimental data. Limited to 5 graduate students.
<br>Fall: <I>P. Blainey, A. Jasanoff, S. Manalis, S. Nagle, S. Wasserman</I><br>Spring: <I>E. Boyden, S. Nagle, P. So, S. Wasserman, M. Yanik</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=20.409');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.410"></a>
<p><h3>20.410J Molecular, Cellular, and Tissue Biomechanics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.798">2.798J</A>, <A HREF="m3b.html#3.971">3.971J</A>, <A HREF="m6b.html#6.524">6.524J</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.537">10.537J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>; <a href="m2a.html#2.002">2.002</a>, <a href="m2a.html#2.006">2.006</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.013">6.013</a>, <a href="m10a.html#10.301">10.301</a>, or <a href="m10a.html#10.302">10.302</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops and applies scaling laws and the methods of continuum mechanics to biomechanical phenomena over a range of length scales. Topics include structure of tissues and the molecular basis for macroscopic properties; chemical and electrical effects on mechanical behavior; cell mechanics, motility and adhesion; biomembranes; biomolecular mechanics and molecular motors. Experimental methods for probing structures at the tissue, cellular, and molecular levels.
<br><I>R. D. Kamm</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.411"></a>
<p><h3>20.411J Cell-Matrix Mechanics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.785">2.785J</A>, <A HREF="m3b.html#3.97">3.97J</A>, <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.523">HST.523J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.001">2.001</a>, or <a href="m2a.html#2.01">2.01</a> and <a href="m2a.html#2.02A">2.02A</a>; <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Mechanical forces play a decisive role during development of tissues and organs, during remodeling following injury as well as in normal function. A stress field influences cell function primarily through deformation of the extracellular matrix to which cells are attached. Deformed cells express different biosynthetic activity relative to undeformed cells. The unit cell process paradigm combined with topics in connective tissue mechanics form the basis for discussions of several topics from cell biology, physiology, and medicine.
<br><I>I. V. Yannas, M. Spector</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.415"></a>
<p><h3>20.415 Physical Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-220</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops and applies principles of probability and physical chemistry to molecular and cellular biological systems. Information theory is used to analyze sequence conservation and co-evolution, statistical mechanics is used to treat binding equilibria and biopolymer conformation, and transition-state theory is used to analyze kinetics of rate processes in the cell. Example case studies include transcription factor binding and target site recognition in DNA, cooperative binding of ligands to cell surface receptors, and DNA and RNA structure and dynamics in viruses, bacteria, and eukaryotic cells. Quantitative experimental assays to measure protein and nucleic acid structure and dynamics are discussed in detail.
<br><I>M. Bathe, P. Blainey</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=20.415');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.416"></a>
<p><h3>20.416J Topics in Biophysics and Physical Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m7a.html#7.74">7.74J</A>, <A HREF="m8b.html#8.590">8.590J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides broad exposure to research in biophysics and physical biology, with emphasis on the critical evaluation of scientific literature. Weekly meetings include in-depth discussion of scientific literature led by distinct faculty on active research topics. Each session also includes brief discussion of non-research topics including effective presentation skills, writing papers and fellowship proposals, choosing scientific and technical research topics, time management, and scientific ethics.
<br><I>M. Bathe, J. Gore</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.420"></a>
<p><h3>20.420J Biomolecular Kinetics and Cellular Dynamics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m10a.html#10.538">10.538J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Fundamental analysis of biological rate processes using approaches from biomolecular reaction kinetics and dynamical systems engineering. Topics include binding and hybridization interactions, enzyme reactions, metabolic cycles, gene regulation, receptor/ligand trafficking systems, intra- and intercellular signaling, and cell population dynamics.
<br><I>K. D. Wittrup, B. Tidor, A. Jasanoff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.430"></a>
<p><h3>20.430J Fields, Forces, and Flows in Biological Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.795">2.795J</A>, <A HREF="m6b.html#6.561">6.561J</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.539">10.539J</A>, <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.544">HST.544J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.013">6.013</a>, <a href="m2a.html#2.005">2.005</a>, <a href="m10a.html#10.302">10.302</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/beh.430/www/">http://web.mit.edu/beh.430/www/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Molecular diffusion, diffusion-reaction, conduction, convection in biological systems; fields in heterogeneous media; electrical double layers; Maxwell stress tensor, electrical forces in physiological systems. Fluid and solid continua: equations of motion useful for porous, hydrated biological tissues. Case studies of membrane transport, electrode interfaces, electrical, mechanical, and chemical transduction in tissues, convective-diffusion/reaction, electrophoretic, electroosmotic flows in tissues/MEMs, and ECG. Electromechanical and physicochemical interactions in cells and biomaterials; musculoskeletal, cardiovascular, and other biological and clinical examples.
<br><I>M. Bathe, A. J. Grodzinsky, R. D. Kamm</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.440"></a>
<p><h3>20.440 Analysis of Biological Networks
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW2-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-614</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Conceptual and experimental approaches to analyzing complex biological networks and systems, from molecules to human populations, focusing on human pathophysiology and disease. Moving from single component analysis to pathways and networks, combines didactic lectures with in-depth analysis of current literature. Emphasizes the chemistry and biochemistry of underlying biological processes. Topics include linking genes/SNPs to disease, defining pathways, analysis of pathways <i>in vivo</i>, systems-level analysis, and applications of network biology. First half of term focuses on fundamental biological processes and tools/analyses needed by biological engineers, and the second half elaborates on these fundamentals by covering complex biological processes. Students acquire skills in the fundamentals of grant preparation using an NIH format and make an oral presentation.
<br><I>D. Lauffenburger, F. White, M. Yaffe</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.441"></a>
<p><h3>20.441J Biomaterials: Tissue Interactions
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as 2.79J, <A HREF="m3b.html#3.96">3.96J</A>, <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.522">HST.522J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Principles of materials science and cell biology underlying the design of medical implants, artificial organs, and matrices for tissue engineering. Methods for biomaterials surface characterization and analysis of protein adsorption on biomaterials. Molecular and cellular interactions with biomaterials are analyzed in terms of unit cell processes, such as matrix synthesis, degradation, and contraction. Mechanisms underlying wound healing and tissue remodeling following implantation in various organs. Tissue and organ regeneration. Design of implants and prostheses based on control of biomaterials-tissue interactions. Comparative analysis of intact, biodegradable, and bioreplaceable implants by reference to case studies. Criteria for restoration of physiological function for tissues and organs.
<br><I>I. V. Yannas, M. Spector</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.445"></a>
<p><h3>20.445J Methods and Problems in Microbiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1c.html#1.86">1.86J</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.492">7.492J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor or <I>Coreq: <a href="m7a.html#7.493">7.493</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students will read and discuss primary literature covering key areas of microbial research with emphasis on methods and approaches used to understand and manipulate microbes. Limited to students in the microbiology program.
<br><I>L. Samson</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.446"></a>
<p><h3>20.446J Microbial Genetics and Evolution
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1c.html#1.87">1.87J</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.493">7.493J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.28">7.28</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers aspects of microbial genetic and genomic analyses, central dogma, horizontal gene transfer, and evolution.
<br><I>A. D. Grossman, E. Alm</I><br>

<a name="20.450"></a>
<p><h3>20.450 Molecular and Cellular Pathophysiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m20a.html#20.420">20.420</a>, <a href="m20a.html#20.440">20.440</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Compares the complex molecular and cellular interactions in health and disease between commensal microbial communities,  pathogens and the human or animal host. Special focus is given to current research on microbe/host interactions, infection of significant importance to public health, and chronic infectious disease. Classwork will include lecture, but emphasize critical evaluation and class discussion of recent scientific papers, and the development of new research agendas in the fields presented.
<br><I>J. C. Niles, R. Sasisekharan</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.451"></a>
<p><h3>20.451J Design of Medical Devices and Implants
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.782">2.782J</A>, <A HREF="m3b.html#3.961">3.961J</A>, <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.524">HST.524J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-134</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Solution of clinical problems by use of implants and other medical devices. Systematic use of cell-matrix control volumes. The role of stress analysis in the design process. Anatomic fit: shape and size of implants. Selection of biomaterials. Instrumentation for surgical implantation procedures. Preclinical testing for safety and efficacy: risk/benefit ratio assessment. Evaluation of clinical performance: design of clinical trials. Project materials drawn from orthopedic devices, soft tissue implants, artificial organs, and dental implants.
<br><I>I. V. Yannas, M. Spector</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=20.451');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.452"></a>
<p><h3>20.452J Principles of Neuroengineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m9a.html#9.422">9.422J</A>, <A HREF="mMASa.html#MAS.881">MAS.881J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.03">8.03</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.003">6.003</a>, <a href="m9a.html#9.01">9.01</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://neuro.media.mit.edu/classes/prinneuro/">http://neuro.media.mit.edu/classes/prinneuro/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers how to innovate technologies for brain analysis and engineering, for accelerating the basic understanding of the brain, and leading to new therapeutic insight and inventions.  Focuses on using physical, chemical and biological principles to understand technology design criteria governing ability to observe and alter brain structure and function.  Topics include optogenetics, noninvasive brain imaging and stimulation, nanotechnologies, stem cells and tissue engineering, and advanced molecular and structural imaging technologies.  Design projects by students. Limited to 28.
<br><I>E. S. Boyden, III</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.454"></a>
<p><h3>20.454J Neurotechnology Ventures
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m9a.html#9.455">9.455J</A>, <A HREF="m15a.html#15.128">15.128J</A>, <A HREF="mMASa.html#MAS.883">MAS.883J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-7
<br>URL: <a href="http://neuro.media.mit.edu/classes/neuroven/">http://neuro.media.mit.edu/classes/neuroven/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Special seminar focusing on envisioning, launching, and building start-ups that are commercializing innovations from neuroscience and neuroengineering.  Topics include neuroimaging, diagnostics, motor rehabilitation, affective computing, novel scientific tools, and novel therapeutics including neuropharmaceuticals, neuromodulation, neuroprosthetics, regenerative medicine, and more.  Each class is devoted to a specific topic area, exploring issues from the deeply technical through the market opportunity.  Working in small groups students prepare a business plan executive summary for a new neurotechnology start-up.
<br><I>E. S. Boyden, R. Ellis-Behnke, J. Bonsen</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.463"></a>
<p><h3>20.463J Biomaterials Science and Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m3b.html#3.963">3.963J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m3a.html#3.055">3.055J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.363">20.363J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.034">3.034</a>, <a href="m20a.html#20.110">20.110</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers, at a molecular scale, the analysis and design of materials used in contact with biological systems, and biomimetic strategies aimed at creating new materials based on principles found in biology. Topics include molecular interaction between bio- and synthetic molecules and surfaces; design, synthesis, and processing approaches for materials that control cell functions; and application of materials science to problems in tissue engineering, drug delivery, vaccines, and cell-guiding surfaces. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>D. Irvine, K. Ribbeck</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.470"></a>
<p><h3>20.470J Cellular Biophysics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>

<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.794">2.794J</A>, <A HREF="m6b.html#6.521">6.521J</A>, <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.541">HST.541J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m2b.html#2.791">2.791J</A>, <A HREF="m6a.html#6.021">6.021J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.370">20.370J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>; <a href="m2a.html#2.005">2.005</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.002">6.002</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.003">6.003</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.071">6.071</a>, <a href="m10a.html#10.301">10.301</a>, <a href="m20a.html#20.110">20.110</a>, or permission of instructor
