<tr><td>&nbsp;</td></tr>
<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Course 21L: Literature<br>Spring
2014</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://lit.mit.edu"><i>Course 21L Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course21L.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=+21L&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>21L.00-21L.URG</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<p>Consult Literature Headquarters, 14N-407, for the most up-to-date information about requirements and subject offerings.
<p>The subjects listed below are arranged in three graduated categories or tiers:
<p>1) Introductory subjects (<a href="m21La.html#21L.000">21L.000</a>-<a href="m21La.html#21L.048">21L.048</a>) all carry HASS Distribution and Communications Intensive (CI-H or CI-HW) credit.
<p>2) Samplings (<a href="m21La.html#21L.310">21L.310</a>-<a href="m21La.html#21L.339">21L.339</a>, <a href="m21La.html#21L.345">21L.345</a>-<a href="m21La.html#21L.355">21L.355</a>) are 6-unit subjects that provide both an alternative route into literary study and a less intensive means for students to sustain a commitment to reading and textual interpretation.  Their focus is on critical exploration, comprehension, and group discussion, with less sustained attention to analytic writing skills.  Students can combine most two 6-unit Samplings subjects to count as a HASS subject in the Humanities category and the equivalent of a subject in the Intermediate tier.  (Students who began their studies prior to Fall 2010 may combine Sampling subjects, by petition to the Subcommittee on the HASS Requirement, for HASS Elective credit.)) No more than four 6-unit subjects may be combined in this manner.  See http://web.mmit.eedu/hassreq/ and contact Literature Headquarters for details.
<p>3) Intermediate subjects (<a href="m21La.html#21L.430">21L.430</a>-<a href="m21La.html#21L.512">21L.512</a>) explore literary and visual forms in greater depth and center on historical periods, literary themes, or genres; others focus on media studies, comparative cultural studies, or national literatures.  Students are encouraged to consult individual instructors about prerequisite requirements.
<p>4) Seminars (<a href="m21La.html#21L.616">21L.616</a>-<a href="m21La.html#21L.715">21L.715</a>), usually restricted to students who have taken at least two previous subjects in literature.  Enrollment in seminars is strictly limited to a maximum of 12 students.
<p>A supplement to this catalog, available online and from the Literature Section offices, offers more detailed descriptions of all literature subjects and includes specific information about required texts, writing assignments, and examinations.
<h2>Introductory Subjects</h2>
<a name="21L.000"></a>
<p><h3>21L.000J Writing About Literature
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cihw.gif" alt="Communication Intensive Writing" title="Communication Intensive Writing" width="32" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.041">21W.041J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW10-11.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-253</a>) or <i>TR2-3.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-144</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Intensive focus on the reading and writing skills used to analyze literary texts such as poems by Emily Dickinson, Shakespeare or Langston Hughes; short stories by Chekhov, Joyce, or Alice Walker; and a short novel by Melville or Toni Morrison. Designed not only to prepare students for further work in writing and literary and media study, but also to provide increased confidence and pleasure in their reading, writing, and analytical skills. Students write or revise essays weekly. Enrollment limited.
<br>Fall: <I>A. Bahr, N. Jackson</I><br>Spring: <I>S. Alexandre, W. Kelley</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=21L.000');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21L.001"></a>
<p><h3>21L.001 Foundations of Western Literature: Homer to Dante
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hass2.gif" alt="HASS-D, Category 2" title="HASS-D, Category 2" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies a broad range of texts essential to understanding the two great sources of Western conceptions of the world and humanity's place within it: the ancient world of Greece and Rome and the Judeo-Christian world that challenged and absorbed it. Readings vary but usually include works by Homer, Sophocles, Aristotle, Plato, Virgil, St. Augustine, and Dante. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>H. Eiland</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21L.002"></a>
<p><h3>21L.002 Foundations of Western Literature: From Shakespeare to the Present
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hass2.gif" alt="HASS-D, Category 2" title="HASS-D, Category 2" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Complementary to 21L.001. A broad survey of texts, literary, philosophical, and sociological, studied to trace the growth of secular humanism, the loss of a supernatural perspective upon human events, and changing conceptions of individual, social, and communal purpose. Stresses appreciation and analysis of texts that came to represent the common cultural possession of our time. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>A. Kibel</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21L.003"></a>
<p><h3>21L.003 Reading Fiction
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hass1.gif" alt="HASS-D, Category 1" title="HASS-D, Category 1" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW2-3.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-162</a>) or <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-146</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces prose fiction, both stories and novels. Emphasizes historical context, narrative structure and close reading. Enrollment limited.
<br>Fall: <I>I. Lipkowitz, K. Delaney</I><br>Spring: <I>I. Lipkowitz, J. Panko</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=21L.003');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21L.004"></a>
<p><h3>21L.004 Reading Poetry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hass1.gif" alt="HASS-D, Category 1" title="HASS-D, Category 1" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/lit/www/21L.004/21L.004.html">http://web.mit.edu/lit/www/21L.004/21L.004.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW3.30-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-231</a>) or <i>TR12.30-2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-144</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Emphasis on poetry in various forms (lyric, epic, and dramatic), chiefly in English-speaking countries. Syllabus usually includes works by Shakespeare, Milton, Donne, Keats, Dickinson, Frost, Eliot, Langston Hughes, Lowell, and Plath. Enrollment limited.
<br>Fall: <I>S. Tapscott, K. Delaney</I><br>Spring: <I>N. Jackson, H. Eiland</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=21L.004');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21L.005"></a>
<p><h3>21L.005 Introduction to Drama
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hass3.gif" alt="HASS-D, Category 3" title="HASS-D, Category 3" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A study of the history of theater art and practice from its origins to the modern period, including its roles in non-Western cultures. Special attention to the relationship between the literary and performative dimensions of drama, and the relationship between drama and its cultural context. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21L.006"></a>
<p><h3>21L.006 American Literature
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hass1.gif" alt="HASS-D, Category 1" title="HASS-D, Category 1" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies the national literature of the United States since the early 19th century. Considers a range of texts - including, novels, essays, films, and electronic media - and their efforts to define the notion of American identity. Readings usually include works by such authors as Nathaniel Hawthorne, Henry David Thoreau, Frederick Douglass, Emily Dickinson, Flannery O'Connor, William Faulkner, Sherman Alexie, and Toni Morrison. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>S. Alexandre</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21L.007"></a>
<p><h3>21L.007 World Literatures
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hass1.gif" alt="HASS-D, Category 1" title="HASS-D, Category 1" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/lit/www/21L.007/21L.007.html">http://web.mit.edu/lit/www/21L.007/21L.007.html</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces students to a coherent set of textual and visual materials drawn from different geographical regions, languages, artistic genres, and historical periods.  The focus may vary but usually cuts across national boundaries. Includes non-English works read in translation and examines different kinds of writing, both fiction and nonfiction. Pays special attention to such issues as identity formation, cultural contact, exploration, and exile. Previously taught topics include contemporary writing from Africa and South Asia, the impact of the discovery of the New World, and Caribbean literature.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21L.008"></a>
<p><h3>21L.008J Black Matters:  Introduction to Black Studies
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassAH.gif" alt="Arts + Humanities" title="Arts + Humanities" width="35" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hass4.gif" alt="HASS-D, Category 4" title="HASS-D, Category 4" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m24b.html#24.912">24.912J</A>, <A HREF="m21Aa.html#21A.125">21A.125J</A>, <A HREF="m21Ha.html#21H.106">21H.106J</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.741">21W.741J</A>, <A HREF="mWGSa.html#WGS.190">WGS.190J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-167</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Interdisciplinary survey of people of African descent that draws on the overlapping approaches of history, literature, anthropology, legal studies, media studies, performance, linguistics, and creative writing. Connects the experiences of African-Americans and of other American minorities, focusing on social, political, and cultural histories, and on linguistic patterns. Includes lectures, discussions, workshops, and required field trips that involve minimal cost to students.
<br><I>Staff</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=21L.008');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21L.009"></a>
<p><h3>21L.009 Shakespeare
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hass1.gif" alt="HASS-D, Category 1" title="HASS-D, Category 1" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR3.30-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-676</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on the close reading of six to eight of Shakespeare plays, as well as their adaptation for stage and/or film.  Selected texts cover the range of genres in which Shakespeare wrote (i.e., history, comedy, tragedy, and romance). Special emphasis in some terms on performances and adaptions of Shakespearean drama around the world. Plays studied vary across sections and from term to term, and have recently included <I>Henry IV Part 1</I>, <I>Hamlet</I>, <I>A Midsummer Night's Dream</I>, <I>King Lear</I>, <I>Othello</I>, and <I>The Tempest</I>. Enrollment limited.
<br>Fall: <I>P. Donaldson, S. Raman</I><br>Spring: <I>P. Donaldson</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=21L.009');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21L.010"></a>
<p><h3>21L.010J Writing with Shakespeare
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cihw.gif" alt="Communication Intensive Writing" title="Communication Intensive Writing" width="32" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.042">21W.042J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on writing and speaking using Shakespeare as a model and means for mastery of English language skills. Emphasizes the development of students' ability to write clearly and effectively in a range of genres with an awareness of audience. Designed to increase students' confidence and pleasure in verbal communication and analysis of language. Students write frequently, give and receive feedback, improve their work through revision, and participate actively in class discussions and presentations. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>D. Henderson</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21L.011"></a>
<p><h3>21L.011 The Film Experience
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hass3.gif" alt="HASS-D, Category 3" title="HASS-D, Category 3" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T3.30-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-270</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>T EVE (7-10 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-270</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>R3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-180</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-191</a>) or <i>R4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-180</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-191</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Concentrates on close analysis and criticism of a wide range of films, including works from the early silent period, documentary and avant-garde films, European art cinema, and contemporary Hollywood fare. Through comparative reading of films from different eras and countries, students develop the skills to turn their in-depth analyses into interpretations and explore theoretical issues related to spectatorship. Syllabus varies from term to term, but usually includes such directors as Coppola, Eisentein, Fellini, Godard, Griffith, Hawks, Hitchcock, Kubrick, Kurosawa, Tarantino, Welles, Wiseman, and Zhang.
<br>Fall: <I>D. Thorburn</I><br>Spring: <I>M. Marks</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=21L.011');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21L.012"></a>
<p><h3>21L.012 Forms of Western Narrative
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hass1.gif" alt="HASS-D, Category 1" title="HASS-D, Category 1" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-253</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines a wide assortment of narrative forms, from Homer to the present, and considers why and how stories are told. Focuses on the close reading of literary and cultural issues, the emergence of different narrative genres, and how different media affect the construction and interpretation of narratives. Syllabus varies by term, but usually includes materials such as epics, novels, tales, short stories, films, television programs, graphic novels, and interactive games.
<br>Fall: <I>E. Brinkema</I><br>Spring: <I>Staff</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=21L.012');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21L.013"></a>
<p><h3>21L.013J The Supernatural in Music, Literature and Culture
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassAH.gif" alt="Arts + Humanities" title="Arts + Humanities" width="35" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hass3.gif" alt="HASS-D, Category 3" title="HASS-D, Category 3" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Aa.html#21A.201">21A.201J</A>, <A HREF="m21Ma.html#21M.013">21M.013J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the relationship between music and the supernatural, focusing on the social history and context of supernatural beliefs as reflected in key literary and musical works from 1600 to the present. Provides an understanding of the place of ambiguity and the role of interpretation in culture, science and art. Explores great works of art by Shakespeare, Verdi, Goethe (in translation), Gounod, Henry James and Benjamin Britten. Readings also include selections from the most recent scholarship on magic and the supernatural. Writing assignments range from web-based projects to analytic essays. No previous experience in music is necessary.  Projected guest lectures, musical performances, field trips. Limited to 36.
<br><I>C. Shadle, M. Fuller</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21L.014"></a>
<p><h3>21L.014J Empire: Introduction to Ancient and Medieval Studies
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Ha.html#21H.007">21H.007J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-261</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>T11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-180</a>) or <i>R12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-154</a>) or <i>R1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-154</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Interdisciplinary and comparative investigation of the Roman empire of Augustus, the Frankish empire of Charlemagne, and the English empire in the age of the Hundred Years' War. Focuses on how large, multi-ethnic empires were created, sustained, legitimated, and contested through conquest, government, literature, art, and economic organization. Students examine different types of evidence, read across a variety of disciplines, and develop skills to identify continuities and changes in ancient and medieval societies.
<br><I>A. Bahr, W. Broadhead, E. Goldberg</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=21L.014');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21L.017"></a>
<p><h3>21L.017 The Art of the Probable
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hass2.gif" alt="HASS-D, Category 2" title="HASS-D, Category 2" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines literary texts and/or films in relation to the history of the idea of probability. Traces the growing importance of probability as a basic property of things and the world, as well as a measure of the reliability of our ideas and beliefs. Connects the development and use of probabilistic reasoning (e.g., in the lottery and in statistics) with literary and cultural concerns regarding the rationality of belief, risk and uncertainty, free will and determinism, chance and fate. Discussion of the work of scientific and philosophical pioneers of probabilistic thought (e.g., Pascal, Leibniz, Bernoulli, Laplace) in conjunction with works by Shakespeare, Voltaire, H. G. Wells, Pynchon and Stoppard, among others.
<br><I>N. Jackson, A. Kibel, S. Raman</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21L.018"></a>
<p><h3>21L.018 Introduction to English Literature
<br>(21L.420)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW3.30-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-146</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the rich heritage of English literature across genre and historical period. Designed for students who want to know more about English literature or about English culture and history. Studies the relationships between literary themes, forms, and conventions and the times in which they were produced. Explores (for instance) Renaissance lyrics and drama, Enlightenment satires in word image, the 19th-century novel, and modern and contemporary stories, poems and film.
<br><I>S. Tapscott</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=21L.018');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21L.019"></a>
<p><h3>21L.019 Introduction to European and Latin American Fiction
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hass1.gif" alt="HASS-D, Category 1" title="HASS-D, Category 1" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies great works of European and Latin American fiction. Attention to a variety of forms including: the picaresque, epistolary, realist, naturalist, and magical realist fiction. Emphasizes ways in which the unique history of each country shaped the imaginative responses of its writers. Authors include Cervantes, Laclos, Goethe, Mann, Dostoevsky, Flaubert, Zola, Unamuno, Wolf, Garc?a M?rquez, and Allende. Taught in English.
<br><I>M. Resnick</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21L.020"></a>
<p><h3>21L.020J Globalization:  The Good, the Bad and the In-Between
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hass4.gif" alt="HASS-D, Category 4" title="HASS-D, Category 4" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Fa.html#21F.076">21F.076J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="m21Fb.html#21F.171">21F.171</a>-175, <a href="m21Fb.html#21F.181">21F.181</a>-185, <a href="m21Fd.html#21F.371">21F.371</a>-374, <a href="m21Fe.html#21F.471">21F.471</a>-474, <a href="m21Ff.html#21F.571">21F.571</a>-576, <a href="m21Fs.html#21F.771">21F.771</a>-774, <a href="m21Fs.html#21F.792">21F.792</a>, <a href="m21Fh.html#21F.870">21F.870</a>, or <a href="m21Fh.html#21F.871">21F.871</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the cultural paradoxes of contemporary globalization. Studies the cultural, linguistic, social and political impact of globalization across international borders and on specific language communities. Students analyze contending definitions of globalization and principal agents of change, and why some of them engender backlash; learn to distinguish what is considered new, hybrid, and traditional; identify the agents, costs and benefits of global networks; and explore how world citizens preserve cultural specificity. Students also develop cultural literacy through study of second language and culture, research, development of virtual materials, and interactions with MIT's international students. Students cannot receive credit without simultaneous completion of a 9-unit language subject. Preference to freshmen.
<br><I>M. Resnick</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21L.021"></a>
<p><h3>21L.021 Comedy
<br>(21L.421)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hass1.gif" alt="HASS-D, Category 1" title="HASS-D, Category 1" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-257</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Surveys a range of comic texts in different media, the cultures that produced them, and various theories of comedy. Authors and directors studied may include Aristophanes, Shakespeare, Moliere, Austen, Wilde and Chaplin.
<br>Fall: <I>W. Kelley</I><br>Spring: <I>A. Kibel</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21L.022"></a>
<p><h3>21L.022J Darwin and Design
<br>(21L.448)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hass2.gif" alt="HASS-D, Category 2" title="HASS-D, Category 2" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as 21W.739J)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>In <I>The Origin of Species</I>, Darwin provided a model for understanding the existence of objects and systems manifesting evidence of design without positing a designer, and of purpose and mechanism without intelligent agency. Texts deal with pre-Darwinian and later treatment of this topic within literature and speculative thought since the 18th century, with some attention to the modern study of feedback mechanism in artificial intelligence. Readings in Hume, Voltaire, Malthus, Darwin, Butler, Hardy, H. G. Wells, and Freud.
<br><I>A. Kibel</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21L.023"></a>
<p><h3>21L.023J Folk Music of the British Isles and North America
<br>(21L.423)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hass3.gif" alt="HASS-D, Category 3" title="HASS-D, Category 3" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Ma.html#21M.223">21M.223J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-1-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines  the production, transmission, preservation and the qualities of folk music in the British Isles and North America from the 18th century to the folk revival of the 1960s and the present. Special emphasis on balladry, fiddle styles, and African-American influences. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>R. Perry, W. Donaldson</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21L.044"></a>
<p><h3>21L.044J Classics of Chinese Literature in Translation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Fa.html#21F.044">21F.044J</A>, <A HREF="mWGSa.html#WGS.235">WGS.235J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m21Fb.html#21F.195">21F.195</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to some of the major genres of traditional Chinese poetry, fiction, and drama. Intended to give students a basic understanding of the central features of traditional Chinese literary genres, as well as to introduce students to the classic works of the Chinese literary tradition. Works read include <I>Journey to the West, Outlaws of the Margin, Dream of the Red Chamber,</I> and the poetry of the major Tang dynasty poets. Literature read in translation. Taught in English.
<br><I>E. Teng</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21L.048"></a>
<p><h3>21L.048J International Women's Voices
<br>(21L.522)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hass1.gif" alt="HASS-D, Category 1" title="HASS-D, Category 1" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Fa.html#21F.022">21F.022J</A>, <A HREF="mWGSa.html#WGS.141">WGS.141J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces students to a variety of fictional works by contemporary women writers. International perspective emphasizes the extent to which each author's work reflects her distinct cultural heritage and to what extent, if any, there is an identifiable female voice that transcends national boundaries. Uses a variety of interpretive perspectives, including sociohistorical, psychoanalytic, and feminist criticism, to examine texts. Authors include Mariama Ba, Isabel Allende, Anita Desai, Maxine Hong Kingston, Toni Morrison, Doris Lessing, Alifa Riyaat, Yang Jiang, Nawal Al-Saadawi, and Sawako Ariyoshi. Taught in English.
<br><I>M. Resnick</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21L.285"></a>
<p><h3>21L.285 Modern Fiction
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: One subject in Literature
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m21La.html#21L.485">21L.485</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR3.30-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-253</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Tradition and innovation in representative fiction of the early modern period. Recurring themes include the role of the artist in the modern period; the representation of psychological and sexual experience; and the virtues (and defects) of the aggressively experimental character. Works by Conrad, Kipling, Babel, Kafka, James, Lawrence, Mann, Ford Madox Ford, Joyce, Woolf, Faulkner, and Nabokov.  Meets with 21L.485 when offered concurrently. Students taking the 12-unit version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>H. Eiland</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=21L.285');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21L.286"></a>
<p><h3>21L.286 Modern Drama
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: One subject in Literature
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m21La.html#21L.486">21L.486</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students analyze major modern plays. Typically features the works of Beckett and Brecht.  Additional writers may include Churchill, Friel, Kushner, O'Neill, Shaw, Deveare Smith, Stoppard, Soyinka, Williams, and Wilson. Special consideration of performance, sociopolitical and aesthetic contexts, and the role of theater in the world of modern multimedia. Meets with 21L.486 when offered concurrently. Students taking the 12-unit version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>S. Tapscott</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21L.301"></a>
<p><h3>21L.301J Doing Right
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m24a.html#24.190">24.190J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines how literary fiction dramatizes a variety of ethical issues, such as self-protection and altruism, lawfulness and justice, and gender and race. Discussions focus on unpacking the ethical implications of literary texts and the literary means by which these implications are communicated. Students are encouraged to attend the Technology and Culture public forums whenever relevant to the text at hand.
<br><I>R. Perry, R. Langton</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<h2>Samplings</h2>
<p>Samplings are 6-unit subjects that provide an alternative and less intensive route to literary study at MIT. Students can combine most two 6-unit Samplings subjects to count as a HASS subject in the Humanities category and the equivalent of a subject in the Intermediate tier. (Students who began their studies prior to Fall 2010 may combine Sampling subjects, by petition to the Subcommittee on the HASS Requirement, for HASS Elective credit.) No more than four 6-unit subjects may be combined in this manner. Contact Literature Headquarters (14N-407) or consult the <i>Literature Supplement to the Bulletin</i> for more detailed descriptions.
<a name="21L.310"></a>
<p><h3>21L.310 Bestsellers
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">; first half of term
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br>Ends March 21. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW3.30-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-148</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on works that caught the popular imagination in the past or present. Emphasizes texts that are related by genre, theme or style. Books studied vary from term to term. May be repeated once for credit if content differs. Enrollment limited.
<br>Fall: <I>R. Perry</I><br>Spring: <I>W. Kelley</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=21L.310');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21L.315"></a>
<p><h3>21L.315 Prizewinners
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">; second half of term
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br>Begins March 31. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW3.30-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-148</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the work of major prize-winning writers or filmmakers. Texts and authors are chosen that have won such prestigious literary awards as the Nobel Prize, the Booker Prize, or the National Book Award, or films that have been feted at major international film festivals. Authors and works vary from term to term. May be repeated once for credit if the specific works studied differ. Enrollment limited.
<br>Fall: <I>D. Thorburn</I><br>Spring: <I>W. Kelley</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=21L.315');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21L.320"></a>
<p><h3>21L.320 Big Books
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T EVE (7-8.30 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=14">14N-325</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Intensive study of a single major literary work or a very small set of related literary works. Emphasizes texts that encourage close analysis in a way that cannot easily be integrated into the regular literature curriculum. The Big Books taught in previous terms include Moby-Dick, Canterbury Tales, and the Faerie Queene. May be repeated once for credit if the works studied differ. Enrollment limited.
<br>Fall: <I>S. Alexandre</I><br>Spring: <I>M. Fuller</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=21L.320');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21L.325"></a>
<p><h3>21L.325 Small Wonders
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">; first half of term
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br>Ends March 21. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-253</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Close examination of a coherent set of short texts and/or visual works. The selections may be the shorter works of one or more authors (poems, short stories or novellas), or short films and other visual media. Content varies from term to term. May be repeated once for credit if the works studied differ. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>W. Donaldson</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=21L.325');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21L.338"></a>
<p><h3>21L.338 Reading in the Original
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">

<br><I>Staff</I><br>
