<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Selected topics in philosophy of mind. Content varies from year to year. Topics may include consciousness, mental representation, perception, and mental causation.
<br><I>D. Smithies</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="24.501"></a>
<p><h3>24.501 Problems in Metaphysics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W12-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-D831</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Systematic examination of selected problems in metaphysics. Content varies from year to year and subject may be taken repeatedly with permission of instructor and advisor.
<br><I>J. Spencer</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="24.502"></a>
<p><h3>24.502 Topics in Metaphysics and Ethics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Systematic examination of selected problems concerning the relation between metaphysics and ethics, for example questions about personal identity and its relation to issues about fairness and distribution, or questions about the relation between causation and responsibility.  Content may vary from year to year, and the subject may be taken repeatedly with the permission of the instructor and the student's advisor.
<br><I>C. Hare</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="24.503"></a>
<p><h3>24.503 Topics in Philosophy of Religion
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Selected topics in philosophy of religion. Content varies from year to year. Topics may include the traditional arguments for the existence of God, religious experience, the problem of evil, survival after death, God and ethics.
<br><I>A. Byrne</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="24.601"></a>
<p><h3>24.601 Topics in Moral Philosophy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-D831</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Systematic examination of selected problems in moral philosophy. Content varies from year to year. Subject may be repeated only with permission of instructor and advisor.
<br>Fall: <I>C. Hare</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Markovits</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="24.611"></a>
<p><h3>24.611J Political Philosophy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m17a.html#17.000">17.000J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T11-1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E53">E53-438</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Systematic examination of selected issues in political philosophy. Topic changes each year and subject may be taken repeatedly with permission of instructor.
<br><I>L. Stanczyk</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="24.711"></a>
<p><h3>24.711 Topics in Philosophical Logic
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Problems of ontology, epistemology, and philosophy of language that bear directly on questions about the nature of logic and the conceptual analysis of logical theory, such as logical truth, logical consequence, and proof. Content varies from year to year and subject may be taken repeatedly upon permission of instructor and advisor.
<br><I>V. McGee</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="24.729"></a>
<p><h3>24.729 Topics in Philosophy of Language
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Major issues in the philosophy of language. Topics change each year and subject may be taken repeatedly with permission of instructor.
<br><I>J. Khoo</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="24.805"></a>
<p><h3>24.805 Topics in Theory of Knowledge
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M11-2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-D831</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Major issues in theory of knowledge. Topics change each year and subject may be taken repeatedly with permission of instructor.
<br><I>R. White</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="24.810"></a>
<p><h3>24.810 Topics in Philosophy of Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>R2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-D461</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Topics in the foundations of science: the nature of concepts and theories, the distinction between empirical and theoretical knowledge claims, realist and instrumentalist interpretation of such claims, and the analysis of scientific explanation. The central topic varies from year to year. Subject may be taken repeatedly with the permission of instructor and advisor.
<br><I>B. Skow</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=24.810');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="24.891"></a>
<p><h3>24.891 Independent Study: Philosophy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of advisor
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>No required or recommended textbooks
<a name="24.892"></a>
<h3>24.892 Independent Study: Philosophy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of advisor
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Open to qualified graduate students in philosophy who wish to pursue special studies or projects.
<br>Consult Department Headquarters<br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="24.899"></a>
<p><h3>24.899 Topics in Linguistics and Philosophy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Selected topics at the intersection of linguistics and philosophy. Intended for graduate students in either linguistics or philosophy. Topics vary from year to year.
<br><I>K. von Fintel</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="24.THG"></a>
<p><h3>24.THG Graduate Thesis

<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Course 2: Mechanical Engineering<br>Spring
2014</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://meche.mit.edu/"><i>Course 2 Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course2.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=+++2&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>2.000-2.199</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m2b.html">2.20-2.7999</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m2c.html">2.80-2.999 plus Thesis, UROP, UPOP</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<h2>Freshman Year Introductory Subjects</h2>
<a name="2.00A"></a>
<p><h3>2.00AJ Fundamentals of Engineering Design: Explore Space, Sea and Earth
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m16a.html#16.00A">16.00AJ</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-3-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Student teams formulate and complete space/earth/ocean exploration-based design projects with weekly milestones. Introduces core engineering themes, principles, and modes of thinking. Specialized learning modules enable teams to focus on the knowledge required to complete their projects, such as machine elements, electronics, design process, visualization and communication. Includes exercises in written and oral communication and team building. Examples of projects include surveying a lake for millfoil, from a remote controlled aircraft, and then sending out robotic harvesters to clear the invasive growth; and exploration to search for the evidence of life on a moon of Jupiter, with scientists participating through teleoperation and supervisory control of robots. Enrollment limited; preference to freshmen.
<br><I>A. H. Techet, D. Newman</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="2.00B"></a>
<p><h3>2.00B Toy Product Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-5-1
<br><img align="bottom" width=16 height=16 alt="Subject Cancelled" title="Subject Cancelled" src="/icns/buttonx.gif"> <i><b>Subject Cancelled</b></i> <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides students with an overview of design for entertainment and play, as well as opportunities in creative product design and community service. Students develop ideas for new toys that serve clients in the community, and work in teams with local sponsors and with experienced mentors on a themed toy design project. Students enhance creativity and experience fundamental aspects of the product development process, including determining customer needs, brainstorming, estimation, sketching, sketch modeling, concept development, design aesthetics, detailed design, and prototyping. Includes written, visual, and oral communication. Enrollment limited; preference to freshmen.
<br><I>D. R. Wallace</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<h2>Core Undergraduate Subjects</h2>
<a name="2.00"></a>
<p><h3>2.00 Introduction to Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">); second half of term
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-3-1
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Project-based introduction to product development and engineering design. Emphasizes key elements of the design process, including defining design problems, generating ideas, and building solutions. Presents a range of design techniques to help students think about, evaluate, and communicate designs, from sketching to physical prototyping, as well as other types of modeling. Students work both individually and in teams. Enrollment limited; preference to Course 2-A sophomores.
<br><I>M. Yang</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="2.001"></a>
<p><h3>2.001 Mechanics and Materials I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>; <I>Coreq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-2-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-370</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>R1-2.30 (BEGINS FEB 13)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-307</a>) or <i>R3-4.30 (BEGINS FEB 13)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-307</a>) or <i>F9-10.30 (BEGINS FEB 14)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-307</a>) or <i>F11-12.30 (BEGINS FEB 14)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-307</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to statics and the mechanics of deformable solids. Emphasis on the three basic principles of equilibrium, geometric compatibility, and material behavior. Stress and its relation to force and moment; strain and its relation to displacement; linear elasticity with thermal expansion. Failure modes. Application to simple engineering structures such as rods, shafts, beams, and trusses.  Application to biomechanics of natural materials and structures.
<br><I>G. Barbastathis, A. E. Hosoi, K. Kamrin</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=2.001');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
<a name="2.002"></a>
<p><h3>2.002 Mechanics and Materials II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.001">2.001</a>, or <a href="m2a.html#2.01">2.01</a> and <a href="m2a.html#2.02B">2.02B</a>; <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-270</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>M3-5 (BEGINS FEB 10)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-307</a>) or <i>T10-12 (BEGINS FEB 11)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-307</a>) or <i>T1-3 (BEGINS FEB 11)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-307</a>) or <i>T3-5 (BEGINS FEB 11)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-307</a>) or <i>W1-3 (BEGINS FEB 12)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-307</a>) or <i>W3-5 (BEGINS FEB 12)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-307</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces mechanical behavior of engineering materials, and the use of materials in mechanical design.  Emphasizes the fundamentals of mechanical behavior of materials, as well as design with materials.  Major topics: elasticity, plasticity, limit analysis, fatigue, fracture, and creep.  Materials selection.  Laboratory experiments involving projects related to materials in mechanical design.
<br><I>L. Anand, K. Kamrin, P. Reis</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=2.002');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="2.003"></a>
<p><h3>2.003J Dynamics and Control I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1a.html#1.053">1.053J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>, or permission of instructor; <I>Coreq: <a href="m2a.html#2.086">2.086</a> or <a href="m1a.html#1.020">1.020</a></I>
<br>Units: 4-1-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-270</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>R2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-375</a>) or <i>R4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-375</a>) or <i>F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-375</a>) or <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-375</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the dynamics and vibrations of lumped-parameter models of mechanical systems. Kinematics. Force-momentum formulation for systems of particles and rigid bodies in planar motion. Work-energy concepts.  Virtual displacements and virtual work. Lagrange's equations for systems of particles and rigid bodies in planar motion. Linearization of equations of motion. Linear stability analysis of mechanical systems. Free and forced vibration of linear multi-degree of freedom models of mechanical systems; matrix eigenvalue problems.
<br><I>J. K. Vandiver, N. C. Makris, N. M. Patrikalakis, T. Peacock, D. Gossard, K. Turitsyn</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=2.003');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
<a name="2.004"></a>
<p><h3>2.004 Dynamics and Control II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.003">2.003</a> or <a href="m2a.html#2.03">2.03</a>; <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-2-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11,F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-190</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>M1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-062</a>) or <i>T1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-062</a>) or <i>T3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-062</a>) or <i>W1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-062</a>) or <i>R1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-062</a>) or <i>R3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-062</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Modeling, analysis, and control of dynamic systems. System modeling: lumped parameter models of mechanical, electrical, and electromechanical systems; interconnection laws; actuators and sensors. Linear systems theory: linear algebra; Laplace transform; transfer functions, time response and frequency response, poles and zeros; block diagrams; solutions via analytical and numerical techniques; stability. Introduction to feedback control: closed-loop response; PID compensation; steady-state characteristics, root-locus design concepts, frequency-domain design concepts. Laboratory experiments and control design projects.
<br><I>G. Barbastathis, D. Del Vecchio, D. C. Gossard, D. E. Hardt, S. Lloyd, D. Rowell</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=2.004');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="2.005"></a>
<p><h3>2.005 Thermal-Fluids Engineering I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m2a.html#2.086">2.086</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.00">6.00</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-190</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-379</a>) or <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-379</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-379</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-379</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Integrated development of the fundamental principles of thermodynamics, fluid mechanics, and heat transfer with applications. Focuses on the development of the first and second laws of thermodynamics with special consideration of the rate processes associated with heat transfer and work transfer. Entropy generation and its influence on the performance of engineering systems. Conduction heat transfer in solids including steady-state and transient situations. Finned surfaces. Coupled and uncoupled fluid models. Hydrostatics. Inviscid flow analysis and Bernoulli equation. Internal and external laminar viscous flows. Turbulence. Boundary layers. Head loss in pipes.
<br><I>J. G. Brisson, J. Buongiorno, P. F. J. Lermusiaux, K. Varanasi</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=2.005');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
<a name="2.006"></a>
<p><h3>2.006 Thermal-Fluids Engineering II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.005">2.005</a>; or <a href="m2a.html#2.051">2.051</a>, <a href="m2a.html#2.06">2.06</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11,F9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-270</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>R1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-135</a>) or <i>R2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-135</a>) or <i>R3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-135</a>) or <i>R4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-135</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on the application of the principles of thermodynamics, heat transfer, and fluid mechanics to the design and analysis of engineering systems. Laminar and turbulent flow. Heat transfer associated with laminar and turbulent flow of fluids in free and forced convection in channels and over surfaces. Pure substance model. Heat transfer in boiling and condensation. Thermodynamics and fluid mechanics of steady flow components of thermodynamic plants. Heat exchanger design. Power cycles and refrigeration plants. Design of thermodynamic plants. Radiation heat transfer. Multi-mode heat transfer and fluid flow in thermodynamic plants.
<br><I>J. G. Brisson, A. E. Hosoi, R. Karnik, G. H. McKinley</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=2.006');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="2.007"></a>
<p><h3>2.007 Design and Manufacturing I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.001">2.001</a> or <a href="m2a.html#2.01">2.01</a>; <I>Coreq: <a href="m2a.html#2.086">2.086</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-4-5
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=10">10-250</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>M2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-050</a>) or <i>M2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-050</a>) or <i>T2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-050</a>) or <i>T2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-050</a>) or <i>W9-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-050</a>) or <i>W9-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-050</a>) or <i>R2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-050</a>) or <i>R2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-050</a>) or <i>F9-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-050</a>) or <i>F9-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-050</a>) or <i>T EVE (7-10 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=N52">N52-342</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops students' competence and self-confidence as design engineers. Emphasis on the creative design process bolstered by application of physical laws.  Instruction on how to complete projects on schedule and within budget. Robustness and manufacturability are emphasized. Subject relies on active learning via a major design-and-build project. Lecture topics include idea generation, estimation, concept selection, visual thinking, computer-aided design (CAD), mechanism design, machine elements, basic electronics, technical communication, and ethics.
<br><I>D. Frey, S. Kim, A. Winter</I><br>No textbook information available
<a name="2.008"></a>
<p><h3>2.008 Design and Manufacturing II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/HalfLab.gif" alt="1/2 Institute Lab" title="1/2 Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.007">2.007</a> or <I>Coreq: <a href="m2a.html#2.017">2.017</a>; <a href="m2a.html#2.005">2.005</a> or <a href="m2a.html#2.051">2.051</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/2.008/www/">http://web.mit.edu/2.008/www/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW12.30-2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-225</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>T9-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-125</a>) or <i>T2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-125</a>) or <i>W9-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-125</a>) or <i>W2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-125</a>) or <i>R9-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-125</a>) or <i>R2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-125</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Integration of design, engineering, and management disciplines and practices for analysis and design of manufacturing enterprises. Emphasis is on the physics and stochastic nature of manufacturing processes and systems, and their effects on quality, rate, cost, and flexibility. Topics include process physics and control, design for manufacturing, and manufacturing systems. Group project requires design and fabrication of parts using mass-production and assembly methods to produce a product in quantity. Six units may be applied to the General Institute Lab Requirement.
<br><I>J.-H. Chun, M. L. Culpepper, S. Kim, S. G. Kim, S. E. Sarma</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=2.008');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="2.009"></a>
<p><h3>2.009 The Product Engineering Process
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.001">2.001</a> or <a href="m2a.html#2.01">2.01</a>; <a href="m2a.html#2.003">2.003</a> or <a href="m2a.html#2.03">2.03</a>; <a href="m2a.html#2.005">2.005</a> or <a href="m2a.html#2.051">2.051</a>; <a href="m2b.html#2.670">2.670</a>, <a href="m2b.html#2.678">2.678</a> or <a href="m2a.html#2.00B">2.00B</a>; senior standing or permission of instructor also required.
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/2.009/www/">http://web.mit.edu/2.009/www/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students develop an understanding of product development phases and experience working in teams to design and construct high-quality product prototypes. Design process learned is placed into a broader development context. Primary goals are to improve ability to reason about design alternatives and apply modeling techniques appropriate for different development phases; understand how to gather and process customer information and transform it into engineering specifications; and use teamwork to resolve the challenges in designing and building a substantive product prototype. Instruction and practice in oral communication provided.
<br><I>D. R. Wallace</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="2.01"></a>
<p><h3>2.01 Elements of Structures
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); second half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>, <I>Coreq: <a href="m2a.html#2.087">2.087</a></I>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11 (BEGINS MARCH 31)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-333</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>M2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-217</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to statics and mechanics of deformable structural elements. Emphasizes simple engineering structures, such as rods (axial loading), shafts (torsion), beams (bending), and columns (buckling). Presents basic principles of equilibrium, geometric compatibility, and linear material response. Covers fundamental concepts of continuum mechanics including internal forces, stress, strain, and displacement.
<br><I>A. Hosoi, S. Socrate, A. Kolpak</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="2.013"></a>
<p><h3>2.013 Engineering Systems Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.001">2.001</a> or <a href="m2a.html#2.01">2.01</a>; <a href="m2a.html#2.003">2.003</a> or <a href="m2a.html#2.03">2.03</a>; <a href="m2a.html#2.005">2.005</a> or <a href="m2a.html#2.051">2.051</a>; <a href="m2b.html#2.670">2.670</a>, <a href="m2b.html#2.678">2.678</a> or <a href="m2a.html#2.00B">2.00B</a>
<br>Units: 0-6-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on the design of engineering systems to satisfy stated performance, stability, and/or control requirements. Emphasizes individual initiative, application of fundamental principles, and the compromises inherent in the engineering design process. Culminates in the design of an engineering system, typically a vehicle or other complex system. Includes instruction and practice in written and oral communication through team presentations, design reviews, and written reports.
<br><I>D. Hart</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="2.014"></a>
<p><h3>2.014 Engineering Systems Development
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.001">2.001</a> or <a href="m2a.html#2.01">2.01</a>; <a href="m2a.html#2.003">2.003</a> or <a href="m2a.html#2.03">2.03</a>; <a href="m2a.html#2.005">2.005</a> or <a href="m2a.html#2.051">2.051</a>; <a href="m2b.html#2.670">2.670</a>, <a href="m2b.html#2.678">2.678</a> or <a href="m2a.html#2.00B">2.00B</a>
<br>Units: 0-6-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>F11-2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-442</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>R9-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=BEAVERWORKS">BEAVERWORKS</a>) or <i>F9-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=BEAVERWORKS">BEAVERWORKS</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on implementation and operation of engineering systems. Emphasizes system integration and performance verification using methods of experimental inquiry. Students refine their subsystem designs and the fabrication of working prototypes. Includes experimental analysis of subsystem performance and comparison with physical models of performance and with design goals. Component integration into the full system, with detailed analysis and operation of the complete vehicle in the laboratory and in-the-field. Includes written and oral reports. Students carry out formal reviews of the overall system design.
<br><I>D. Hart</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="2.016"></a>
<p><h3>2.016 Hydrodynamics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>
<br>Units: 4-2-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Principles of conservation of mass, momentum and energy in fluid mechanics.  Basic geophysical fluid mechanics, including the effects of salinity, temperature, and density; heat balance in the ocean; large scale flows.  Hydrostatics.  Linear free surface waves, wave forces on floating and submerged structures.  Added mass, lift and drag forces.  Introduction to ocean acoustics; sound propagation and refraction.  Sonar equation. Laboratory sessions in wave propagation, lift and drag forces on submerged bodies, and sound propagation.
<br><I>A. H. Techet, P. D. Sclavounos</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="2.017"></a>
<p><h3>2.017J Design of Electromechanical Robotic Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/HalfLab.gif" alt="1/2 Institute Lab" title="1/2 Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1a.html#1.015">1.015J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.003">2.003</a> or <a href="m2a.html#2.03">2.03</a>; <I>Coreq: <a href="m2a.html#2.005">2.005</a>, <a href="m2a.html#2.05">2.05</a> and <a href="m2a.html#2.051">2.051</a>, or <a href="m2a.html#2.016">2.016</a>; <a href="m2b.html#2.671">2.671</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-4-5
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-132</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>W2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-007</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Design, construction, and testing of field robotic systems, through team projects with each student responsible for a specific subsystem. Projects focus on electronics, instrumentation, and machine elements. Design for operation in uncertain conditions is a focus point, with ocean waves and marine structures as a central theme. Basic statistics, linear systems, Fourier transforms, random processes, spectra and extreme events with applications in design.  Lectures on ethics in engineering practice included. Enrollment may be limited due to laboratory capacity.
<br><I>F. S. Hover, J. J. Leonard</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="2.019"></a>
<p><h3>2.019 Design of Ocean Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.001">2.001</a>; <a href="m2a.html#2.003">2.003</a>; <a href="m2a.html#2.005">2.005</a> or <a href="m2a.html#2.016">2.016.</a> Senior standing or permission of instructor also required.
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M2.30-4,F11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-134</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>F2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-308</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Complete cycle of designing an ocean system using computational design tools for the conceptual and preliminary design stages. Team projects assigned, with each student responsible for a specific subsystem. Lectures cover hydrodynamics; structures; power and thermal aspects of ocean vehicles, environment, materials, and construction for ocean use; generation and evaluation of design alternatives. Focus on innovative design concepts chosen from high-speed ships, submersibles, autonomous vehicles, and floating and submerged deep-water offshore platforms. Lectures on ethics in engineering practice included. Instruction and practice in oral and written communication provided.
<br><I>C. Chryssostomidis, M. S. Triantafyllou</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="2.02A"></a>
<p><h3>2.02A Engineering Materials: Properties and Applications
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">); second half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.01">2.01</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the physical mechanisms that give rise to mechanical properties of engineering materials: stiffness, creep, stress-relaxation, strength, fracture-toughness, and fatigue. Also covers materials selection for mechanical design. Includes case studies on materials-limited problems in engineering design.
<br><I>A. Kolpak</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="2.02B"></a>
<p><h3>2.02B Mechanics of Structures
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">); second half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.01">2.01</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to continuum mechanics of deformable solids, emphasizing strain-displacement and stress-equilibrium relations while specializing material constitutive response to linear elasticity and its limits. Teaches students to solve example boundary value problems and consider the engineering implications of the solutions. Corresponding numerical solutions based on finite element methods are introduced and explored.
<br><I>D. M. Parks</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="2.03"></a>
<p><h3>2.03 Dynamics I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); first half of term
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="m2a.html#2.086">2.086</a></I>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m2a.html#2.S03">2.S03</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11 (ENDS MARCH 21)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-270</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>R2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-375</a>) or <i>R4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-375</a>) or <i>F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-375</a>) or <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-375</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the dynamics of one and two degree-of-freedom mechanical systems. Kinematics. Force-momentum formulation for particles and rigid bodies. Work-energy concepts. Rotation of rigid bodies, angular momentum, torques and moments of inertia. Newton, Euler equations (direct method in dynamics). Conservation laws in dynamics. Basics of equilibrium, linearization and stability analysis. Includes MATLAB modeling of dynamical systems with applications. Meets with 2.003 first half of term.
<br><I>D. Gossard, K. Turitsyn, T. Peacock</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
<a name="2.S03"></a>
<p><h3>2.S03 Special Subject: Dynamics I
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.086">2.086</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m2a.html#2.03">2.03</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Experimental version of 2.03, which offers a combination of online and in-person lectures. See description of 2.03. Licensed for Summer 2014 by the Committee on Curricula as an acceptable alternative to 2.03.
<br><I>S. Mahajan</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="2.031"></a>
<p><h3>2.031 Dynamics II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); second half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.03">2.03</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11 (BEGINS MARCH 31)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-270</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>R2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-375</a>) or <i>R4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-375</a>) or <i>F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-375</a>) or <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-375</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Continuation of topics introduced in 2.03, including work-energy concepts, Lagrange's equations for systems of particles and rigid bodies in planar motion, and matrix eigenvalue problems.  Meets with 2.003 second half of term.
<br><I>D. Gossard, K. Turitsyn, T. Peacock</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="2.04A"></a>
<p><h3>2.04A Systems and Controls
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); first half of term
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="m2a.html#2.03">2.03</a></I>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW2.30-4 (ENDS MARCH 21)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-270</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>M11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-062</a>) or <i>W11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-062</a>) or <i>R9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-062</a>) or <i>F10.30-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-062</a>) or <i>F1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-062</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to linear systems, transfer functions, and Laplace transforms. Covers stability and feedback, and provides basic design tools for specifications of transient response. Briefly covers frequency-domain techniques.
<br><I>G. Barbastathis</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=2.04A');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="2.04B"></a>
<p><h3>2.04B Introduction to Mechanical Vibration
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); second half of term<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.03">2.03</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analyzes the time domain response of single- and multiple-degree-of-freedom (DOF) systems to initial conditions and force inputs. Uses matrix formulation of multiple-DOF problems, including finding natural frequencies and mode shapes. Provides an introduction to the method of normal mode superposition. Includes transfer function analysis of the response of linear systems to steady state harmonic inputs, with application to vibration isolation and dynamic absorbers. Also includes application to the analysis of machines with rotating imbalances.
<br><I>J. K. Vandiver</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="2.05"></a>
<p><h3>2.05 Thermodynamics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">); first half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.087">2.087</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to thermodynamics, including first law (coupled and uncoupled systems, incompressible liquid, ideal gas) and second law (equilibrium, reversibility and irreversibility). Explores systems in communication with heat reservoirs; quasi-static processes; and heat engines and refrigeration.  Properties of open systems, including mass, energy and entropy transfer.
<br><I>C. Buie</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="2.051"></a>
<p><h3>2.051 Introduction to Heat Transfer
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">); second half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.05">2.05</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces fundamental processes of heat transfer. Fourier's law. Heat conduction processes including thermal resistance, lumped capacitance, fins, and the heat equation. Elementary convection, including laminar and turbulent boundary layers, internal flow, and natural convection. Thermal radiation, including Stefan-Boltzmann law, small object in large enclosure, and parallel plates. Basic concepts of heat exchangers.
<br><I>J. H. Lienhard, E. N. Wang, A. Hosoi</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="2.06"></a>
<p><h3>2.06 Fluid Dynamics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); second half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.01">2.01</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW2.30-4 (BEGINS MARCH 31)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-270</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-442</a>) or <i>F9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-442</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to principal concepts and methods of fluid mechanics. Pressure, hydrostatics, and buoyancy. Control volume analysis. Mass conservation and momentum conservation for moving fluids. Viscous fluid flows, flow through pipes. Dimensional analysis. Boundary layers, and lift and drag on objects.
<br><I>G. H. McKinley, A. Hosoi, K. Varanasi</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="2.086"></a>
<p><h3>2.086 Numerical Computation for Mechanical Engineers
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>; <I>Coreq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m2a.html#2.087">2.087</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-270</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>M2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-115</a>) or <i>W2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-115</a>) or <i>F10-1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-150</a>) or <i>F2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-115</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers elementary programming concepts, including variable types, data structures, and flow control. Provides an introduction to linear algebra and probability. Numerical methods relevant to MechE, including approximation (interpolation, least squares, and statistical regression), integration, solution of linear and nonlinear equations, and ordinary differential equations. Presents deterministic and probabilistic approaches. Uses examples from MechE, particularly from robotics, dynamics, and structural analysis. Assignments require MATLAB programming.
<br><I>N. Hadjiconstantinou, A. Patera, D. Frey, A. Hosoi</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="2.087"></a>
<p><h3>2.087 Engineering Mathematics: Linear Algebra and ODEs I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); first half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 2-1-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11 (ENDS MARCH 21)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-333</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>M2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-217</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to linear algebra and ordinary differential equations (ODEs), including general numerical approaches to solving systems of equations. Linear systems of equations, existence and uniqueness of solutions, Gaussian elimination. Initial value problems, 1st and 2nd order systems, forward and backward Euler, RK4. Eigenproblems, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, including complex numbers, functions, vectors and matrices.
<br><I>A. Hosoi, T. Peacock</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=2.087');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
<h2>Dynamics and Acoustics</h2>
<a name="2.032"></a>
<p><h3>2.032 Dynamics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.003">2.003</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/2.032/www/">http://web.mit.edu/2.032/www/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Review of momentum principles. Hamilton's principle and Lagrange's equations. Three-dimensional kinematics and dynamics of rigid bodies. Study of steady motions and small deviations therefrom, gyroscopic effects, causes of instability. Free and forced vibrations of lumped-parameter and continuous systems. Nonlinear oscillations and the phase plane. Nonholonomic systems. Introduction to wave propagation in continuous systems.
<br><I>T. R. Akylas, T. Peacock, N. Hadjiconstantinou</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="2.034"></a>
<p><h3>2.034J Nonlinear Dynamics and Waves
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1c.html#1.685">1.685J</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.377">18.377J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/2.034/www/">http://web.mit.edu/2.034/www/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A unified treatment of nonlinear oscillations and wave phenomena with applications to mechanical, optical, geophysical, fluid, electrical and flow-structure interaction problems. Nonlinear free and forced vibrations; nonlinear resonances; self-excited oscillations; lock-in phenomena.  Nonlinear dispersive and nondispersive waves; resonant wave interactions; propagation of wave pulses and nonlinear Schrodinger equation.  Nonlinear long waves and breaking; theory of characteristics; the Korteweg-de Vries equation; solitons and solitary wave interactions.  Stability of shear flows.  Some topics and applications may vary from year to year.
<br><I>T. R. Akylas, R. R. Rosales</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="2.036"></a>
<p><h3>2.036J Nonlinear Dynamics and Chaos
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m18a.html#18.385">18.385J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.034">18.034</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.385">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.385</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the theory of nonlinear dynamical systems with applications from science and engineering. Local and global existence of solutions, dependence on initial data and parameters. Elementary bifurcations, normal forms. Phase plane, limit cycles, relaxation oscillations, Poincare-Bendixson theory. Floquet theory. Poincare maps. Averaging. Near-equilibrium dynamics. Synchronization.  Introduction to chaos. Universality. Strange attractors. Lorenz and Rossler systems. Hamiltonian dynamics and KAM theory. Uses MATLAB computing environment.
<br><I>R. R. Rosales</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="2.050"></a>
<p><h3>2.050J Nonlinear Dynamics: Chaos
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m12a.html#12.006">12.006J</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.353">18.353J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.034">18.034</a>; <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to nonlinear dynamics and chaos in dissipative systems. Forced and parametric oscillators. Phase space. Periodic, quasiperiodic, and aperiodic flows. Sensitivity to initial conditions and strange attractors. Lorenz attractor. Period doubling, intermittency, and quasiperiodicity. Scaling and universality. Analysis of experimental data: Fourier transforms, Poincare sections, fractal dimension, and Lyapunov exponents. Applications to mechanical systems, fluid dynamics, physics, geophysics, and chemistry. See 12.207J/18.354J for Nonlinear Dynamics: Continuum Systems.
<br><I>R. Lagrange</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="2.060"></a>
<p><h3>2.060J Structural Dynamics and Vibrations
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1c.html#1.581">1.581J</A>, <A HREF="m16a.html#16.221">16.221J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m1a.html#1.058">1.058</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-1-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Single- and multiple-degree-of-freedom vibration problems, using matrix formulation and normal mode superposition methods. Time and frequency domain solution techniques including convolution and Fourier transforms. Applications to vibration isolation, damping treatment, and dynamic absorbers. Analysis of continuous systems by exact and approximate methods. Applications to buildings, ships, aircraft and offshore structures. Vibration measurement and analysis techniques. Students should possess basic knowledge in structural mechanics and in linear algebra. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>E. Kausel, J. K. Vandiver</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="2.062"></a>
<p><h3>2.062J Wave Propagation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1a.html#1.138">1.138J</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.376">18.376J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.003">2.003</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.075">18.075</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.376/">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.376/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-133</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Theoretical concepts and analysis of wave problems in science and engineering with examples chosen from elasticity, acoustics, geophysics, hydrodynamics, blood flow, nondestructive evaluation, and other applications.  Progressive waves, group velocity and dispersion, energy density and transport. Reflection, refraction and transmission of plane waves by an interface. Mode conversion in elastic waves. Rayleigh waves. Waves due to a moving load. Scattering by a two-dimensional obstacle.  Reciprocity theorems. Parabolic approximation. Waves on the sea surface. Capillary-gravity waves. Wave resistance. Radiation of surface waves. Internal waves in stratified fluids.  Waves in rotating media.  Waves in random media.
<br><I>T. R. Akylas, R. R. Rosales</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=2.062');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="2.065"></a>
<p><h3>2.065 Acoustics and Sensing
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m2a.html#2.066">2.066</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.003">2.003</a>, <a href="m2a.html#2.04B">2.04B</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.003">6.003</a>, <a href="m8a.html#8.03">8.03</a>, or <a href="m16a.html#16.03">16.03</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-233</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=2.065');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
<a name="2.066"></a>
<h3>2.066 Acoustics and Sensing
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m2a.html#2.065">2.065</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.003">2.003</a>, <a href="m2a.html#2.04B">2.04B</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.003">6.003</a>, <a href="m8a.html#8.03">8.03</a>, <a href="m16a.html#16.03">16.03</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-233</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the fundamental concepts of acoustics and sensing with waves. Provides a unified theoretical approach to the physics of image formation through scattering and wave propagation in sensing. The linear and nonlinear acoustic wave equation, sources of sound, including musical instruments. Reflection, refraction, transmission and absorption. Bearing and range estimation by sensor array processing, beamforming, matched filtering, and focusing. Diffraction, bandwidth, ambient noise and reverberation limitations. Scattering from objects, surfaces and volumes by Green's Theorem. Forward scatter, shadows, Babinet's principle, extinction and attenuation. Ray tracing and waveguides in remote sensing. Applications to acoustic, radar, seismic, thermal and optical sensing and exploration. Students taking the graduate version of the subject complete additional assignments.
<br><I>N. C. Makris</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=2.066');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<h2>Solid Mechanics and Materials</h2>
<a name="2.071"></a>
<p><h3>2.071 Mechanics of Solid Materials
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.002">2.002</a> or <a href="m2a.html#2.02A">2.02A</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-333</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-135</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Fundamentals of solid mechanics applied to the mechanical behavior of engineering materials. Kinematics of deformation, stress, and balance principles. Isotropic linear elasticity and isotropic linear thermal elasticity. Variational and energy methods. Linear viscoelasticity. Small-strain elastic-plastic deformation. Mechanics of large deformation; nonlinear hyperelastic material behavior. Foundations and methods of deformable-solid mechanics, including relevant applications. Provides base for further study and specialization within solid mechanics, including continuum mechanics, computational mechanics (e.g., finite-element methods), plasticity, fracture mechanics, structural mechanics, and nonlinear behavior of materials.
<br><I>L. Anand, D. M. Parks</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="2.072"></a>
<p><h3>2.072 Mechanics of Continuous Media
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.071">2.071</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Principles and applications of continuum mechanics. Kinematics of deformation. Thermomechanical conservation laws. Stress and strain measures. Constitutive equations including some examples of their microscopic basis.  Solution of some basic problems for various materials as relevant in materials science, fluid dynamics, and structural analysis. Inherently nonlinear phenomena in continuum mechanics. Variational principles.
<br><I>L. Anand</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="2.073"></a>
<p><h3>2.073 Solid Mechanics: Plasticity and Inelastic Deformation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.071">2.071</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Physical basis of plastic/inelastic deformation of solids; metals, polymers, granular/rock-like materials. Continuum constitutive models for small and large deformation of elastic-(visco)plastic solids. Analytical and numerical solution of selected boundary value problems. Applications to deformation processing of metals.
<br><I>L. Anand, D. M. Parks</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="2.074"></a>
<p><h3>2.074 Solid Mechanics: Elasticity
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.002">2.002</a>, <I>Coreq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the theory and applications of elastic solids. Review strain, stress, and stress-strain law. Several of the following topics: Anisotropic material behavior. Piezoelectric materials. Effective properties of composites. Structural mechanics of beams and plates. Energy methods for structures. Two-dimensional problems. Stress concentration at cavities, concentrated loads, cracks, and dislocations. Variational methods and their applications; introduction to the finite element method. Introduction to wave propagation.
<br><I>D. M. Parks</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="2.080"></a>
<p><h3>2.080J Structural Mechanics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1c.html#1.573">1.573J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.002">2.002</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents fundamental concepts of structural mechanics with applications to marine, civil, and mechanical structures. Covers residual stresses; thermal effects; analysis of beams, columns, tensioned beams, trusses, frames, arches, cables, and shafts of general shape and material, including composites; elastic buckling of columns; exact and approximate methods, energy methods, principle of virtual work, and introduction to computational structural mechanics.
<br><I>T. Wierzbicki, J. J. Connor, Jr., H. Schmidt</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="2.081"></a>
<p><h3>2.081J Plates and Shells
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">; first half of term
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m16a.html#16.230">16.230J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.074">2.074</a>, <a href="m2a.html#2.080">2.080</a>, or <a href="m16a.html#16.21">16.21</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-2.30 (ENDS MARCH 21)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-217</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Derivation of elastic and plastic stress-strain relations for plate and shell elements. Bending and buckling of rectangular plates. Nonlinear geometric effects. Post-buckling and ultimate strength of cold formed sections and typical stiffened panels used in naval architecture. General theory of elastic shells and axisymmetric shells. Buckling, crushing and bending strength of cylindrical shells with application to offshore structures. Application to crashworthiness of vehicles and explosive and impact loading of structures.
<br><I>T. Wierzbicki</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="2.082"></a>
<p><h3>2.082 Ship Structural Analysis and Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">; second half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.081">2.081</a>, <a href="m2b.html#2.701">2.701</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-2.30 (BEGINS MARCH 31)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-217</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Design application of analysis developed in 2.081J. Ship longitudinal strength and hull primary stresses. Ship structural design concepts. Design limit states including plate bending, column and panel buckling, panel ultimate strength, and plastic analysis. Matrix stiffness, and introduction to finite element analysis. Computer projects on the structural design of a midship module.
<br><I>R. S. McCord, T. Wierzbicki</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=2.082');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="2.084"></a>
<p><h3>2.084J Structural Mechanics in Nuclear Power Technology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1c.html#1.56">1.56J</A>, <A HREF="m22b.html#22.314">22.314J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.001">2.001</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Structural components in nuclear power plant systems, their functional purposes, operating conditions, and mechanical/structural design requirements. Combines mechanics techniques with models of material behavior to determine adequacy of component design. Considerations include mechanical loading, brittle fracture, inelastic behavior, elevated temperatures, neutron irradiation, vibrations and seismic effects.
