<a name="3.042"></a>
<p><h3>3.042 Materials Project Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.014">3.014</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.032">3.032</a>, or <a href="m3a.html#3.044">3.044</a>
<br>Units: 1-6-5
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>R1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-265</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>TR2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-602</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Student project teams design and fabricate a working prototype using materials processing technologies (e.g. solid works 3-D design software, computer numerical controlled mill, injection molding, thermoforming, investment casting, powder processing, three-dimensional printing, physical vapor deposition) appropriate for the materials and device of interest. Goals include using MSE fundamentals in a practical application; understanding trade-offs between design, processing, and performance and cost; and fabrication of a deliverable prototype. Emphasis on teamwork, project management, communications and computer skills, with extensive hands-on work using student and MIT laboratory shops. Teams document their progress and final results by means of written and oral communication. Limited to 25.
<br><I>M. Tarkanian</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.044"></a>
<p><h3>3.044 Materials Processing
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.012">3.012</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.022">3.022</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m3a.html#3.S044">3.S044</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW2-3.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-231</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=13">13-4101</a>) or <i>TR12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=13">13-4101</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to materials processing science, with emphasis on heat transfer, chemical diffusion, and fluid flow. Uses an engineering approach to analyze industrial-scale processes, with the goal of identifying and understanding physical limitations on scale and speed. Covers materials of all classes, including metals, polymers, electronic materials, and ceramics. Considers specific processes, such as melt-processing of metals and polymers, deposition technologies (liquid, vapor, and vacuum), colloid and slurry processing, viscous shape forming, and powder consolidation.
<br><I>C. Schuh, E. Olivetti</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.S044"></a>
<p><h3>3.S044 Special Subject: Materials Processing
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.012">3.012</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.022">3.022</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-10
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m3a.html#3.044">3.044</A>
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Experimental version of 3.044, which offers a combination of online and in-person lectures. See description of 3.044. Licensed for Spring 2014 by the Committee on Curricula as an acceptable alternative to 3.044.
<br><I>C. Schuh</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.046"></a>
<p><h3>3.046 Thermodynamics of Materials
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.034">18.034</a>, or <a href="m3a.html#3.016">3.016</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>The laws of thermodynamics and their application to equilibrium and the properties of materials. Foundation to treat general phenomena in materials science and engineering, including chemical reactions, magnetism, polarizability, and elasticity. Relations pertaining to multiphase equilibria as determined by a treatment of solution thermodynamics. Graphical constructions that are essential for the interpretation of phase diagrams. Electrochemical equilibria and surface thermodynamics. Aspects of statistical thermodynamics as they relate to macroscopic equilibrium phenomena.
<br><I>W. C. Carter</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.048"></a>
<p><h3>3.048 Advanced Materials Processing
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.022">3.022</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.044">3.044</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Fundamentals of materials processing. Building engineering structures from the atomic- and nano-scales  to macroscopic levels. Case studies illustrating application of processing science to creation of modern metallic, ceramic, polymeric and biomaterials devices and components.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.051"></a>
<p><h3>3.051J Materials for Biomedical Applications
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m20a.html#20.340">20.340J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.034">3.034</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.012">3.012</a> or <a href="m3a.html#3.046">3.046</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the interactions between cells and surfaces of biomaterials. Surface chemistry and physics of selected metals, polymers, and ceramics. Surface characterization methodology. Modification of biomaterials surfaces. Quantitative assays of cell behavior in culture. Biosensors and microarrays. Bulk properties of implants. Acute and chronic response to implanted biomaterials. Topics in biomimetics, drug delivery, and tissue engineering.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.052"></a>
<p><h3>3.052 Nanomechanics of Materials and Biomaterials
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.032">3.032</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Latest scientific developments and discoveries in the field of nanomechanics, i.e. the deformation of extremely tiny (10-9 meters) areas of synthetic and biological materials. Lectures include a description of normal and lateral forces at the atomic scale, atomistic aspects of adhesion, nanoindentation, molecular details of fracture, chemical force microscopy, elasticity of individual macromolecular chains, intermolecular interactions in polymers, dynamic force spectroscopy, biomolecular bond strength measurements, and molecular motors.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.053"></a>
<p><h3>3.053J Molecular, Cellular, and Tissue Biomechanics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.797">2.797J</A>, <A HREF="m6a.html#6.024">6.024J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.310">20.310J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2b.html#2.370">2.370</a> or <a href="m2b.html#2.772">2.772J</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m3a.html#3.016">3.016</a>; <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-270</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>M4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-304</a>) or <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-303</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops and applies scaling laws and the methods of continuum mechanics to biomechanical phenomena over a range of length scales. Topics include structure of tissues and the molecular basis for macroscopic properties; chemical and electrical effects on mechanical behavior; cell mechanics, motility and adhesion; biomembranes; biomolecular mechanics and molecular motors. Experimental methods for probing structures at the tissue, cellular, and molecular levels.
<br><I>R. D. Kamm, A. J. Grodzinsky</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=3.053');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.054"></a>
<p><h3>3.054 Cellular Solids: Structure, Properties, Applications
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m3a.html#3.36">3.36</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.032">3.032</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW10-11.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-304</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Begins with a review of the structure and mechanical behavior of cellular solids as they are created from polymers, metals, ceramics, glasses, and composites. Exploits the unique properties of honeycombs and foams through applications such as lightweight structural panels, energy absorption devices and thermal insulation. Second half of the term discusses applications of cellular solids in medicine as it relates to increased fracture risk due to trabecular bone loss in patients with osteoporosis, the development of metal foam coatings for orthopaedic implants, and designing porous scaffolds for tissue engineering that mimic the extracellular matrix.  Modelling of cellular materials applied to natural materials and biomimicking. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>L. Gibson</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=3.054');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.055"></a>
<p><h3>3.055J Biomaterials Science and Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m20a.html#20.363">20.363J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m3b.html#3.963">3.963J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.463">20.463J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.034">3.034</a>, <a href="m20a.html#20.110">20.110</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers, at a molecular scale, the analysis and design of materials used in contact with biological systems, and biomimetic strategies aimed at creating new materials based on principles found in biology. Topics include molecular interaction between bio- and synthetic molecules and surfaces; design, synthesis, and processing approaches for materials that control cell functions; and application of materials science to problems in tissue engineering, drug delivery, vaccines, and cell-guiding surfaces. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>D. Irvine, K. Ribbeck</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.063"></a>
<p><h3>3.063 Polymer Physics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.012">3.012</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-159</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>The mechanical, optical, electrical, and transport properties of polymers and other types of "soft matter" are presented with respect to the underlying physics and physical chemistry of polymers and colloids in solution, and solid states. Topics include how enthalpy and entropy determine conformation, molecular dimensions and packing of polymer chains and colloids and supramolecular materials. Examination of the structure of glassy, crystalline, and rubbery elastic states of polymers; thermodynamics of solutions, blends, crystallization; liquid crystallinity, microphase separation, and self-assembled organic-inorganic nanocomposites. Case studies of relationships between structure and function in technologically important polymeric systems.
<br><I>A. Alexander-Katz</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.064"></a>
<p><h3>3.064 Polymer Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.032">3.032</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.044">3.044</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/course/3/3.064/www/">http://web.mit.edu/course/3/3.064/www/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Overview of engineering analysis and design techniques for synthetic polymers. Treatment of materials properties selection, mechanical characterization, and processing in design of load-bearing and environment-compatible structures.
<br><I>N. Holten-Andersen</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.07"></a>
<p><h3>3.07 Introduction to Ceramics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.012">3.012</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Discusses structure-property relationships in ceramic materials. Includes hierarchy of structures from the atomic to microstructural levels. Defects and transport, solid-state electrochemical processes, phase equilibria, fracture and phase transformations are discussed in the context of controlling properties for various applications of ceramics. Numerous examples from current technology.
<br><I>Y. Chiang</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.072"></a>
<p><h3>3.072 Symmetry, Structure and Tensor Properties of Materials
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m3b.html#3.60">3.60</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.016">3.016</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Addresses the structure of crystalline materials and the role of crystal symmetries in controlling their properties. Topics include lattices, point groups, space groups, and their properties; use of symmetry in tensor representation of crystal properties, including transport properties, piezoelectricity and elasticity; crystallographic texture, microstructure, and anisotropy; and design of microstructures comprising anisotropic crystals. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>E. Fitzgerald</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.073"></a>
<p><h3>3.073 Diffraction and Structure
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m3a.html#3.271">3.271</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.024">3.024</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Describes x-ray and neutron diffraction using Laue equations, Bragg's law, and the reciprocal lattice. Use of Fourier transforms and series to establish relations between intensity and distribution of scattering density. Applications to identification of materials, texture, small angle scattering and Rietveld analysis. Determines structure through diffraction effects: the phase problem, Patterson function, and direct methods for phase determination. Quantitative description and refinement of atomic arrangements.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.074"></a>
<p><h3>3.074 Imaging of Materials
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m3a.html#3.34">3.34</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.024">3.024</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.073">3.073</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-133</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Principles and applications of imaging techniques for materials characterization including transmission and scanning electron microscopy and scanning probe microscopy. Topics include electron diffraction; image formation in transmission and scanning electron microscopy; diffraction and phase contrast; imaging of crystals and crystal imperfections; review of the most recent advances in electron microscopy for bio- and nanosciences; analysis of chemical composition and electronic structure at the atomic scale. Lectures, real-case studies and computer simulations.
<br><I>S. Grade&#269;ak</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=3.074');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.080"></a>
<p><h3>3.080 Economic and Environmental Materials Selection
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.012">3.012</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.014">3.014</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.022">3.022</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.024">3.024</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides a survey of methods for evaluating choice of material and explores the implications of that choice. Topics include choice of materials, manufacturing economics, and life-cycle environmental evaluation. Students carry out a group project selecting materials technology options based on economic and environmental characteristics.
<br><I>R. Kirchain</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.086"></a>
<p><h3>3.086 Innovation and Commercialization of Materials Technology
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m3a.html#3.207">3.207</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m3a.html#3.S086">3.S086</A>

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers the fundamental process of innovation through its implications on organizations and innovation ecosystems. Emphasizes historical and modern examples of innovation in materials and devices. Discusses the final implications for innovation ecosystems.
<br><I>E. Fitzgerald</I><br>No textbook information available

<a name="3.091"></a>
<p><h3>3.091 Introduction to Solid-State Chemistry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/chem.gif" alt="Chemistry" title="Chemistry" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.3091">ES.3091</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m5a.html#5.111">5.111</A>, <A HREF="m5a.html#5.112">5.112</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.5111">CC.5111</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.5111">ES.5111</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.5112">ES.5112</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-270</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=13">13-5101</a>) or <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=13">13-5101</a>) or <i>TR3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=13">13-5101</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Basic principles of chemistry and their application to engineering systems. The relationship between electronic structure, chemical bonding, and atomic order. Characterization of atomic arrangements in crystalline and amorphous solids: metals, ceramics, semiconductors, and polymers (including proteins). Topical coverage of organic chemistry, solution chemistry, acid-base equilibria, electrochemistry, biochemistry, chemical kinetics, diffusion, and phase diagrams. Examples from industrial practice (including the environmental impact of chemical processes), from energy generation and storage (e.g., batteries and fuel cells), and from emerging technologies  (e.g., photonic and biomedical devices). For Fall 2013, class will incorporate online quizzes and background materials.
<br>Fall: <I>M. Cima, N. Holten-Andersen</I><br>Spring: <I>N. Holten-Andersen, D. Paul</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=3.091');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.094"></a>
<p><h3>3.094 Materials in Human Experience
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-3-4
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-154</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>T EVE (7-10 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-605</a>) or <i>W EVE (7-10 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-605</a>) or <i>R EVE (7-10 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-605</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the ways in which people in ancient and contemporary societies have selected, evaluated, and used materials of nature, transforming them to objects of material culture. Some examples: glass in ancient Egypt and Rome; sounds and colors of powerful metals in Mesoamerica; cloth and fiber technologies in the Inca empire. Explores ideological and aesthetic criteria often influential in materials development. Laboratory/workshop sessions provide hands-on experience with materials discussed in class. Subject complements 3.091. Enrollment may be limited.
<br><I>H. N. Lechtman, D. Hosler, L. Hobbs</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.14"></a>
<p><h3>3.14 Physical Metallurgy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m3a.html#3.40">3.40J</A>, <A HREF="m22c.html#22.71">22.71J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.022">3.022</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.032">3.032</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on the links between the processing, structure, and properties of metals and alloys. First, the physical bases for strength, stiffness, and ductility are discussed with reference to crystallography, defects, and microstructure.  Second, phase transformations and microstructural evolution are studied in the context of alloy thermodynamics and kinetics. Together, these components comprise the modern paradigm for designing metallic microstructures for optimized properties. Concludes with a focus on processing/microstructure/property relationships in structural engineering alloys, particularly steels and aluminum alloys. Students taking the graduate version explore the subject in greater depth.
<br><I>J. Li</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.15"></a>
<p><h3>3.15 Electrical, Optical, and Magnetic Materials and Devices
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.024">3.024</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m3a.html#3.S15">3.S15</A>
<br><img align="bottom" width=16 height=16 alt="Subject Cancelled" title="Subject Cancelled" src="/icns/buttonx.gif"> <i><b>Subject Cancelled</b></i> <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the relationships between the performance of electrical, optical, and magnetic devices and the microstructural characteristics of the materials from which they are constructed. Features a device-motivated approach that places strong emphasis on emerging technologies.  Applications include diodes, transistors, photodetectors, solar cells (photovoltaics), displays, light emitting diodes, lasers, optical fibers and optical communications, photonic devices, magnetic data storage and spintronics.
<br><I>C. A. Ross</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.S15"></a>
<p><h3>3.S15 Special Subject: Electrical, Optical, and Magnetic Materials and Devices
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.024">3.024</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-10
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m3a.html#3.15">3.15</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-144</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Experimental version of 3.15, which offers a combination of online and in-person lectures. See description of 3.15. Licensed for Spring 2014 by the Committee on Curricula as an acceptable alternative to 3.15.
<br><I>C. A. Ross</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=3.S15');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.152"></a>
<p><h3>3.152 Magnetic Materials
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m3a.html#3.45">3.45</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.024">3.024</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Topics include origin of magnetism in materials, magnetic domains and domain walls, magnetostatics, magnetic anisotropy, antiferro- and ferrimagnetism, magnetism in thin films and nanoparticles, magnetotransport phenomena, and magnetic characterization. Discusses a range of applications, including magnetic recording, spin-valves, and tunnel-junction sensors. Assignments include problem sets and a term paper on a magnetic device or technology. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>C. Ross</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.153"></a>
<p><h3>3.153 Nanoscale Materials
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.024">3.024</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-180</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the most recent advances in the synthesis, lithographic patterning and characterization of nanomaterials and to their physical and electronic properties. The materials presented include semiconductor and metal nanoparticles and nanowires, carbon fullerenes and nanotubes, organic nanoparticles and dendrimers. Fundamental concepts of surface physics and chemistry used to explain the working principles of devices such as nanotransistors and nanosensors.
<br><I>Y. Fink</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.154"></a>
<p><h3>3.154J Materials Performance in Extreme Environments
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m22a.html#22.054">22.054J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.032">3.032</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.044">3.044</a>
<br>Units: 3-2-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9-10.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=8">8-119</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>TBA</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=8">8-107</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies the behavior of materials in extreme environments typical of those in which advanced energy systems (including fossil, nuclear, solar, fuel cells, and battery) operate. Takes both a science and engineering approach to understanding how current materials interact with their environment under extreme conditions. Explores the role of modeling and simulation in understanding material behavior and the design of new materials. Focuses on energy and transportation related systems.
<br><I>R. Ballinger</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=3.154');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.155"></a>
<p><h3>3.155J Micro/Nano Processing Technology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6a.html#6.152">6.152J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-4-5
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the theory and technology of micro/nano fabrication. Lectures and laboratory sessions on basic processing techniques such as vacuum processes, lithography, diffusion, oxidation, and pattern transfer. Students fabricate MOS capacitors, nanomechanical cantilevers, and microfluidic mixers. Emphasis on the interrelationships between material properties and processing, device structure, and the electrical, mechanical, optical, chemical  or biological behavior of devices. Provides background for thesis work in micro/nano fabrication. Students engage in extensive written and oral communication exercises.
<br><I>A. Agarwal, L. A. Kolodziejski, M. A. Schmidt</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.156"></a>
<p><h3>3.156 Photonic Materials and Devices
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m3a.html#3.46">3.46</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.016">3.016</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>; <a href="m3a.html#3.024">3.024</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Optical materials design for semiconductors, dielectrics, organic and nanostructured materials. Ray optics, electromagnetic optics and guided wave optics. Physics of light-matter interactions. Device design principles: LEDs, lasers, photodetectors, solar cells, modulators, fiber and waveguide interconnects, optical filters, and photonic crystals. Device processing: crystal growth, substrate engineering, thin film deposition, etching and process integration for dielectric, silicon and compound semiconductor materials. Micro- and nanophotonic systems. Organic, nanostructured and biological optoelectronics. Assignments include three design projects that emphasize materials, devices and systems applications. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>P. Anikeeva</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.19"></a>
<p><h3>3.19 Sustainable Chemical Metallurgy
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.012">3.012</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.022">3.022</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=8">8-119</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers principles of extractive metallurgy processes design. Provides a direct application of the fundamentals of thermodynamics and kinetics to the industrial production of metals from their ores, e.g. iron, aluminum, or reactive metals and silicon. Discusses the corresponding economics and global challenges. Addresses advanced techniques for sustainable metal extraction, particularly with respect to greenhouse gas emissions.
<br><I>A. Allanore</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.20"></a>
<p><h3>3.20 Materials at Equilibrium
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.012">3.012</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.014">3.014</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.022">3.022</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.024">3.024</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.034">3.034</a>, and <a href="m3a.html#3.042">3.042</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 5-0-10
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Laws of thermodynamics: general formulation and applications to mechanical, electromagnetic and electrochemical systems, solutions, and phase diagrams. Computation of phase diagrams. Statistical thermodynamics and relation between microscopic and macroscopic properties, including ensembles, gases, crystal lattices, phase transitions.  Applications to phase stability and properties of mixtures.  Computational modeling. Interfaces.
<br><I>G. Ceder</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.207"></a>
<p><h3>3.207 Innovation and Commercialization
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m3a.html#3.086">3.086</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m3a.html#3.S086">3.S086</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W3.30-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-265</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores in depth projects on a particular materials-based technology. Investigates the science and technology of materials advances and their strategic value, explore potential applications for fundamental advances, and determine intellectual property related to the materials technology and applications. Students map progress with presentations, and are expected to create an end-of-term document enveloping technology, intellectual property, applications, and potential commercialization. Lectures cover aspects of technology, innovation, entrepreneurship, intellectual property, and commercialization of fundamental technologies.
<br><I>E. A. Fitzgerald</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.21"></a>
<p><h3>3.21 Kinetic Processes in Materials
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.012">3.012</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.022">3.022</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.044">3.044</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 5-0-10
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11,F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-237</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-265</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-265</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Unified treatment of phenomenological and atomistic kinetic processes in materials. Provides the foundation for the advanced understanding of processing, microstructural evolution, and behavior for a broad spectrum of materials. Emphasis on analysis and development of rigorous comprehension of fundamentals. Topics include: irreversible thermodynamics; diffusion; nucleation; capillarity; grain growth; phase transformations;  and morphological instabilities; gas-solid, liquid-solid, and solid-solid reactions.
<br><I>C. Thompson</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=3.21');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.22"></a>
<p><h3>3.22 Mechanical Behavior of Materials
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.032">3.032</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/3.22/www/">http://web.mit.edu/3.22/www/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-237</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=13">13-4101</a>) or <i>W1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=13">13-4101</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores how the macroscale mechanical behavior of materials originates from fundamental, microscale mechanisms of elastic and inelastic deformation. Topics include: elasticity, viscoelasticity, plasticity, creep, fracture, and fatigue. Case studies and examples  are drawn from a variety of material classes: metals, ceramics, polymers, thin films, composites, and cellular materials.
<br><I>M. J. Demkowicz</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.23"></a>
<p><h3>3.23 Electrical, Optical, and Magnetic Properties of Materials
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.03">8.03</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Origin of electrical, magnetic and optical properties of materials. Focus on the acquisition of quantum mechanical tools. Analysis of the properties of materials. Presentation of the postulates of quantum mechanics. Examination of the hydrogen atom, simple molecules and bonds, and the behavior of electrons in solids and energy bands. Introduction of the variation principle as a method for the calculation of wavefunctions. Investigation of how and why materials respond to different electrical, magnetic and electromagnetic fields and probes. Study of the conductivity, dielectric function, and magnetic permeability in metals, semiconductors, and insulators. Survey of common devices such as transistors, magnetic storage media, optical fibers.
<br><I>G. Beach</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.271"></a>
<p><h3>3.271 Diffraction and Structure
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m3a.html#3.073">3.073</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.024">3.024</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Describes x-ray and neutron diffraction using Laue equations, Bragg's law, and the reciprocal lattice. Use of Fourier transforms and series to establish relations between intensity and distribution of scattering density. Applications to identification of materials, texture, small angle scattering and Rietveld analysis. Determines structure through diffraction effects: the phase problem, Patterson function, and direct methods for phase determination. Quantitative description and refinement of atomic arrangements.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.320"></a>
<p><h3>3.320 Atomistic Computer Modeling of Materials
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.022">3.022</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.20">3.20</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.23">3.23</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/3.320/www/">http://web.mit.edu/3.320/www/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-145</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Theory and application of atomistic computer simulations to model, understand, and predict the properties of real materials.  Energy models: from classical potentials to first-principles approaches.  Density-functional theory and the total-energy pseudopotential method.  Errors and accuracy of quantitative predictions.  Thermodynamic ensembles: Monte Carlo sampling and molecular dynamics simulations.  Free energies and phase transitions.  Fluctations and transport properties.  Coarse-graining approaches and mesoscale models.
<br><I>G. Ceder, J. Grossman</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.33"></a>
<p><h3>3.33 Defects in Materials
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.21">3.21</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.22">3.22</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines point, line, and surface defects in materials. Relates their properties to diffusion, deformation, radiation response, phase transformations, microstructure evolution, and corrosion in solids. Focuses on atomic defects in crystals, with special attention to optical properties, dislocation dynamics, and charged defects. Examples also drawn from other systems, e.g., disclinations in liquid crystals, domain walls in ferromagnets, and flaws in periodic network foams. Uses atomistic modeling to examine defect structure.
<br><I>M. Demkowicz</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.34"></a>
<p><h3>3.34 Imaging of Materials
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m3a.html#3.074">3.074</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.23">3.23</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://www-dmse.mit.edu/courses/3.34/3.34.html">http://www-dmse.mit.edu/courses/3.34/3.34.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-133</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Principles and applications of imaging techniques for materials characterization including transmission and scanning electron microscopy and scanning probe microscopy. Topics include electron diffraction; image formation in transmission and scanning electron microscopy; diffraction and phase contrast; imaging of crystals and crystal imperfections; review of the most recent advances in electron microscopy for bio- and nanosciences; analysis of chemical composition and electronic structure at the atomic scale. Lectures, real-case studies and computer simulations. Graduate students complete additional assignments.
<br><I>S. Grade&#269;ak</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=3.34');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.35"></a>
<p><h3>3.35 Fracture and Fatigue
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.032">3.032</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR3-4.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-145</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Linear elastic and elastic-plastic fracture mechanics. Theory and asymptotic analysis of crack-tip fields. Experimental methods. Microstructural effects on fracture in metals, ceramics, polymers, thin films, biological materials, and composites. Toughening mechanisms. Crack growth resistance and creep fracture. Interface fracture mechanics. Fatigue damage and dislocation substructures in single crystals. Stress- and strain-life approach to fatigue. Fatigue crack growth models and mechanisms. Variable amplitude fatigue. Corrosion fatigue. Case studies of fracture and fatigue in structural, bioimplant, and microelectronic components. Limited to 10.
<br><I>M. Dao</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=3.35');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.36"></a>
<p><h3>3.36 Cellular Solids: Structure, Properties, Applications
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m3a.html#3.054">3.054</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.032">3.032</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW10-11.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-145</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Begins with a review of the structure and mechanical behavior of cellular solids as they are created from polymers, metals, ceramics, glasses, and composites. Exploits the unique properties of honeycombs and foams through applications such as lightweight structural panels, energy absorption devices and thermal insulation. Second half of the term discusses applications of cellular solids in medicine as it relates to increased fracture risk due to trabecular bone loss in patients with osteoporosis, the development of metal foam coatings for orthopaedic implants, and designing porous scaffolds for tissue engineering that mimic the extracellular matrix. Modelling of cellular materials applied to natural materials and biomimicking. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>L. Gibson</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=3.36');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.370"></a>
<p><h3>3.370 Manufacturing and Use of Structural Materials
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-145</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-145</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Discusses a range of technologies related to structural materials, including welding, brazing, soldering, wear, corrosion, non-destructive testing, and fracture. Emphasizes the underlying science of a given process rather than a detailed description of the technique or equipment.
<br><I>T. Eagar</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.371"></a>
<p><h3>3.371J Materials Manufacturing
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2c.html#2.821">2.821J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Discusses selection design and processing for structural materials, including casting, forging, rolling, drawing, extrusion, powder consolidation, welding, brazing, soldering, wear, corrosion, non-destructive testing and fracture. Emphasizes the underlying science of a given process rather than a detailed description of the technique or equipment.
<br><I>T. W. Eagar</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.372"></a>
<p><h3>3.372 Selection and Processing of Structural Materials
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Discusses selection design and processing for structural materials, including casting, forging, rolling, drawing, extrusion, and powder consolidation. Emphasizes the underlying science of a given process rather than a detailed description of the technique or equipment.
<br><I>T. Eagar</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.40"></a>
<p><h3>3.40J Modern Physical Metallurgy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m22c.html#22.71">22.71J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m3a.html#3.14">3.14</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.022">3.022</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.032">3.032</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines how the presence of 1-, 2- and 3-D defects and second phases control the mechanical, electromagnetic and chemical behavior of metals and alloys. Considers point, line and interfacial defects in the context of structural transformations including annealing, spinodal decomposition, nucleation, growth, and particle coarsening. Concentrates on structure-function relationships, and in particular how grain size, interstitial and substitutional solid solutions, and second-phase particles impact mechanical and other properties  Industrially relevant case studies illustrate lecture concepts. Students taking the graduate version explore the subject in greater depth.
<br><I>J. Li</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.41"></a>
<p><h3>3.41 Colloids, Surfaces, Absorption, Capillarity, and Wetting Phenomena
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.20">3.20</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.21">3.21</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW3-4.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-180</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Integrates elements of physics and chemistry toward the study of material surfaces. Begins with classical colloid phenomena and the interaction between surfaces in different media. Discusses the mechanisms of surface charge generation as well as how dispersion forces are created and controlled. Continues with exploration of chemical absorption processes and surface design of inorganic and organic materials. Includes examples in which such surface design can be used to control critical properties of materials in applications. Addresses lastly how liquids interact with solids as viewed by capillarity and wetting phenomena. Studies how materials are used in processes and applications that are intended to control liquids, and how the surface chemistry and structure of those materials makes such applications possible.
<br><I>M. Cima</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.42"></a>
<p><h3>3.42 Electronic Materials Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.23">3.23</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Extensive and intensive examination of structure-processing-property correlations for a wide range of materials including metals, semiconductors, dielectrics, and optical materials.  Topics covered include defect equilibria; junction characteristics; photodiodes, light sources and displays; bipolar and field effect transistors; chemical, thermal and mechanical transducers; data storage.  Emphasis on materials design in relation to device performance.
<br><I>H. L. Tuller</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.43"></a>
<p><h3>3.43J Integrated Microelectronic Devices
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6b.html#6.720">6.720J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.012">6.012</a> or <a href="m3a.html#3.42">3.42</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>The physics of microelectronic semiconductor devices for silicon integrated circuit applications. Topics: semiconductor fundamentals, p-n junction, metal-oxide semiconductor structure, metal-semiconductor junction, MOS field-effect transistor, and bipolar junction transistor. Emphasis on physical understanding of device operation through energy band diagrams and short-channel MOSFET device design. Issues in modern device scaling outlined. Includes device characterization projects and device design project.
<br><I>J. A. del Alamo, H. L. Tuller</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.44"></a>
<p><h3>3.44 Materials Processing for Micro- and Nano-Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.20">3.20</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.21">3.21</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Processing of bulk, thin film, and nanoscale materials for applications in electronic, magnetic, electromechanical, and photonic devices and microsystems. Topics include growth of bulk, thin-film, nanoscale single crystals via vapor and liquid phase processes; formation, patterning and processing of thin films, with an emphasis on relationships among processing, structure, and properties; and processing of systems of nanoscale materials. Examples from materials processing for applications in high-performance integrated electronic circuits, integrated sensors, and data storage systems.
<br><I>C. V. Thompson</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.45"></a>
<p><h3>3.45 Magnetic Materials
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m3a.html#3.152">3.152</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.23">3.23</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Foundation topics include magnetostatics, origin of magnetism in materials, magnetic domains and domain walls, magnetic anisotropy, reversible and irreversible magnetization processes; hard and soft magnetic materials and magnetic recording. Special topics are selected from magnetism at nanoscale (thin films, surfaces, particles); amorphous and nanocrystalline magnetic materials; electronic transport in ferromagnets including magnetoresistive, spin-valve and spin-tunnel junction sensors.
<br><I>C. Ross</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="3.46"></a>
<p><h3>3.46 Photonic Materials and Devices
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m3a.html#3.156">3.156</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.23">3.23</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Optical materials design for semiconductors, dielectrics and polymers. Ray optics, electromagnetic optics and guided wave optics. Physics of light-matter interactions.  Device design principles: LEDs, lasers, photodetectors, modulators, fiber and waveguide interconnects, optical filters, and photonic crystals. Device processing:  crystal growth, substrate engineering, thin film deposition, etching and process integration for dielectric, silicon and compound semiconductor materials. Microphotonic integrated circuits.  Telecom/datacom systems. Assignments include three design projects that emphasize materials, devices and systems applications. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>P. Anikeeva</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
</td></tr></table>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
