<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Course 4: Architecture<br>Spring
2014</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/"><i>Course 4 Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course4.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=+++4&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>Architecture Design</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m4b.html">Architecture Studies</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m4c.html">Art, Culture and Technology</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m4d.html">Building Technology</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m4e.html">Computation</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m4f.html">History, Theory and Criticism of Architecture and Art</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m4g.html">Thesis and UROP</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<h2>Architecture Design</h2>
<a name="4.100"></a>
<p><h3>4.100 Architecture Workshop: Form and Material
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 0-3-0 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Intensive design and fabrication workshop in which students create models and half-size prototypes that explore the characteristics of concrete and wood. Examines the behavior of these materials and their inherent structural qualities. Studies how architectural detail can impact the perception and creation of larger built structures and environments. Lab fee. Limited to 15; preference to freshmen.
<br><I>Architecture Design Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.105"></a>
<p><h3>4.105 Geometric Disciplines and Architecture Skills
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-2-5
<br>URL: <a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/fall-2013-4105">http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/fall-2013-4105</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Intensive introduction to architectural design tools and process, taught through a series of short exercises. The conceptual basis of each exercise is in the interrogation of the geometric principles that lie at the core of each skill. Skills covered range from techniques of hand drafting, to generation of 3-D computer models, physical model-building, sketching, and diagramming. Weekly lectures and pin-ups address the conventions associated with modes of architectural representation and their capacity to convey ideas. Restricted to level one MArch students.
<br><I>Architecture Design Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.107"></a>
<p><h3>4.107 Geometric Disciplines and Architecture Skills II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4a.html#4.105">4.105</a>
<br>Units: 2-2-5
<br>URL: <a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2014-4107">http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2014-4107</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW2-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-442</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Investigation of specific geometric design tools and principles essential to architectural design. Examination of generative techniques, conventional representation, and how architecture confronts eroding formal constraints within architecture design. Weekly workshops and pin-ups lead to exploration of contemporary digital tools, including Grasshopper, Python Scripting, Processing and rendering. Restricted to first-year MArch students.
<br><I>J. Lamere</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.109"></a>
<p><h3>4.109 ProtoArchitecture
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 0-3-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides students with the tools for developing complex geometries from flat components; fine-tuning press fit constructions, molding and casting; and making repeatable molds for customization. Using the potentials of rapid, iterative prototyping, architectural issues are examined through interactions between occupant and architecture. Preference to first-year MArch students.
<br><I>J. Lavallee</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.110"></a>
<p><h3>4.110J Design Across Scales, Disciplines and Problem Contexts
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mMASa.html#MAS.330">MAS.330J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mMASa.html#MAS.650">MAS.650</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-2-8
<br>URL: <a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2014-4110">http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2014-4110</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T10-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E14">E14-633</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>W EVE (7-9 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E14">E14-525</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the reciprocal relationships among design, science, and technology. Covers a wide range of topics, such as industrial design, architecture, visualization/perception, design computation, material ecology, environmental design and environmental sustainability. Examines how transformations in science and technology have influenced design thinking and vice versa. Students develop methodologies for design research and collaborate on design solutions to interdisciplinary problems. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version.
<br><I>N. Oxman, J. M. Yoon</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.111"></a>
<p><h3>4.111 Introduction to Architecture and Environmental Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m4a.html#4.11A">4.11A</A>
<br><b>4.111:</b> URL: <a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2014-4111">http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2014-4111</a>
<br><b>4.111:</b> <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-133</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br><b>4.111:</b> No textbook information available
<a name="4.11A"></a>
<h3>4.11A Introduction to Architecture and Environmental Design Intensive
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-3-3
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m4a.html#4.111">4.111</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides a foundation to the design of the built environment, from the scale of the object, to the building, to the larger territory. Focuses on the shared foundations of the allied design disciplines of architecture, landscape, and urbanism, developing skills in critical thinking and analysis, spatial representation and design methodologies. Examines the larger influences of the arts and sciences on these disciplines. Through lectures and design exercises, students are provided an opportunity to establish a reference for understanding the discipline of architecture and environmental design, and are provided an introduction to design fundamentals and design process.
<br><I>L. Bello</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.112"></a>
<p><h3>4.112 Architecture Design Fundamentals I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br>URL: <a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/fall-2013-4112">http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/fall-2013-4112</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides the foundations for architectural design, introducing design logic and skills that enable design thinking, representation, and development. Beginning with spatially abstract exercises, provides studio instruction in the architectural design process. Introduces techniques for describing form, space, and architecture. Focuses on the translation of conceptual strategies into more integrated design propositions through both digital and analog means. Preference to Course 4 majors and minors.
<br><I>Architecture Design Staff</I><br>
<a name="4.113"></a>
<p><h3>4.113 Architecture Design Fundamentals II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4a.html#4.111">4.111</a> or <a href="m4a.html#4.11A">4.11A</a>; <a href="m4a.html#4.112">4.112</a>
<br>Units: 3-6-6
<br>URL: <a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2014-4113">http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2014-4113</a>
<br><b>Design:</b> <i>MWF2-5</i> (STUDIO) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on the translation of conceptual strategies of form and space into more complex design propositions that engage a larger set of architectural issues, including technological, social, cultural, experiential and environmental determinants. Students work on the integration of architecture with program, structure, materiality, and site. Preference to Course 4 majors and minors.
<br><I>C. Parreo</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.114"></a>
<p><h3>4.114 Architecture Design Studio I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4a.html#4.113">4.113</a>, <a href="m4c.html#4.302">4.302</a>, <a href="m4d.html#4.401">4.401</a>, <a href="m4e.html#4.500">4.500</a>, <a href="m4f.html#4.605">4.605</a>
<br>Units: 0-12-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/fall-2013-4114">http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/fall-2013-4114</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on how to design in a natural or urban site through analysis of landscape and urban form. Students conceptualize design decisions through drawings and models. Working directly with materials and fabrication techniques, they gain experience in the tectonics of architecture. Several design assignments lead to a final integrated design project. Instruction and practice in oral and written communication provided. Preference to Course 4 majors and minors. Mandatory lottery.
<br><I>Architecture Design Staff</I><br>
<a name="4.115"></a>
<p><h3>4.115 Architecture Design Studio II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4a.html#4.114">4.114</a>
<br>Units: 0-12-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2014-4115">http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2014-4115</a>
<br><b>Design:</b> <i>TRF1-5</i> (STUDIO) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces skills needed to build within contemporary cities, extending from the historical center to expanding edges. Students analyze an existing environment and design a built structure that fosters relationships between its intended activities and the larger urban territory and redefines the urban environment. Design project emphasizes social, cultural or civic programs. Preference to Course 4 majors. Mandatory lottery.
<br><I>William O'Brien, Jr.</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
<a name="4.116"></a>
<p><h3>4.116 Architecture Design Studio III
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4a.html#4.115">4.115</a>, <a href="m4d.html#4.440">4.440</a>
<br>Units: 0-12-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/fall-2013-4116">http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/fall-2013-4116</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Projects develop more advanced design skills engaging complex issues of program, site, and form. Focuses on how architecture creates environments for living, working and learning in varied settings. Integrates architectural theory, building technology and computation into the design process. Preference to Course 4 majors. Mandatory lottery.
<br><I>Architecture Design Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.119"></a>
<p><h3>4.119 Preparation for Undergraduate Architecture Design Thesis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4a.html#4.115">4.115</a>
<br>Units: 1-0-2
<br>URL: <a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/fall-2013-4119">http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/fall-2013-4119</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Selection of thesis topic, defining method of approach, and preparation of thesis proposal for BSA degree in architecture. Weekly class meeting as well as individual conference with faculty.
<br><I>Architecture Design Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.120"></a>
<p><h3>4.120 Furniture Making Workshop
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-2-5
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides instruction in designing and building a functional piece of furniture from an original design. Develops woodworking techniques from use of traditional hand tools to digital fabrication. Gives students the opportunity to practice design without using a building program or code. Surveys the history of furniture making and includes site visits to local collections and artists/craftsmen. Limited to 12 students.
<br><I>C. Dewart, J. Lavallee</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.121"></a>
<p><h3>4.121 Workshop in Making and Designing Space
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4a.html#4.122">4.122</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4a.html#4.151">4.151</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 0-6-3
<br>URL: <a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/fall-2013-4121">http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/fall-2013-4121</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>
<a name="4.122"></a>
<h3>4.122 Workshop in Making and Designing Space
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4a.html#4.121">4.121</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4a.html#4.111">4.111</a>
<br>Units: 0-6-3
<br>URL: <a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/fall-2013-4121">http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/fall-2013-4121</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Interactive architecture design workshop focuses on the logistics of designing. Examines a variety of spaces and studies space design through material exploration and building techniques. Students develop a design project by joining wood, forging and welding steel, and casting concrete.  Additional work required of students taking the graduate version.
<br><I>C. Dewart, J. Wampler</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.130"></a>
<p><h3>4.130 Architectural Design Theory and Methodologies
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br>URL: <a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/fall-2013-4130">http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/fall-2013-4130</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies design as an interrogative technique to examine material sciences, media arts and technology, cultural studies, computation and emerging fabrication protocols. Provides in-depth, theoretical grounding to the notion of 'design' in architecture, and to the consideration of contemporary design methodologies, while encouraging speculation on emerging design thinking. Topical focus varies with instructor. May be repeated for credit with permission of department.
<br><I>M. Goulthorpe</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.140"></a>
<p><h3>4.140J How to Make (Almost) Anything
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mMASa.html#MAS.863">MAS.863J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-9-0
<br>URL: <a href="http://fab.cba.mit.edu/classes/MAS.863/">http://fab.cba.mit.edu/classes/MAS.863/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides a practical hands-on introduction to digital fabrication, including CAD/CAM/CAE, NC machining, 3-D printing and scanning, molding and casting, composites, laser and waterjet cutting, PCB design and fabrication; sensors and actuators; mixed-signal instrumentation, embedded processing, and wired and wireless communications. Develops an understanding of these capabilities through projects using them individually and jointly to create functional systems.
<br><I>N. Gershenfeld, J. DiFrancesco, S. Tibbits</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.151"></a>
<p><h3>4.151 Architecture Design Core Studio I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 0-12-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/fall-2013-4151">http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/fall-2013-4151</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Establishes foundational processes, techniques and attitudes towards architectural design. Includes projects of increasing scope and complexity engaging issues of structure, circulation, program, organization, building systems, materiality and tectonics. Develops methods of representation that incorporate both analogue and digital drawings and models.  Must be taken in sequence. Limited to first-year MArch students.
<br><I>Architecture Design Staff</I><br>
<a name="4.152"></a>
<p><h3>4.152 Architecture Design Core Studio II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4a.html#4.151">4.151</a>
<br>Units: 0-12-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2014-4152">http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2014-4152</a>
<br><b>Design:</b> <i>TRF EVE (1-5 PM)</i> (STUDIO) or <i>TRF EVE (1-5 PM)</i> (STUDIO)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Builds on Core I skills and expands the constraints of the architectural problem to include issues of urban site logistics, cultural and programmatic material (inhabitation and human factors), and long span structures. Two related projects introduce a range of disciplinary issues, such as working with precedents, site, sectional and spatial proposition of the building, and the performance of the outer envelope. Emphasizes the clarity of intentions and the development of appropriate architectural and representational solutions. Limited to first-year MArch students.
<br><I>J. Lamere
A. Miljacki</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
<a name="4.153"></a>
<p><h3>4.153 Architecture Design Core Studio III
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4a.html#4.152">4.152</a>
<br>Units: 0-12-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/fall-2013-4153">http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/fall-2013-4153</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Interdisciplinary approach to design through studio design problems that engage the domains of building technology, computation, and the cultural/historical geographies of energy. Uses different modalities of thought to examine architectural agendas for 'sustainability'; students position their work with respect to a broader understanding of the environment and its relationship to society and technology. Students develop a project with a comprehensive approach to programmatic organization, energy load considerations, building material assemblies, exterior envelope and structure systems. Limited to second-year MArch students.
<br><I>Architecture Design Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.154"></a>
<p><h3>4.154 Architecture Design Option Studio
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4a.html#4.145">4.145</a> or <a href="m4a.html#4.153">4.153</a>
<br>Units: 0-10-11
<br>URL: <a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/subjects">http://architecture.mit.edu/subjects</a>
<br><b>Design:</b> <i>TR EVE (1-6 PM)</i> (STUDIO) or <i>TR EVE (1-6 PM)</i> (STUDIO) or <i>TR EVE (1-6 PM)</i> (STUDIO) or <i>TR EVE (1-6 PM)</i> (STUDIO) or <i>TR EVE (1-6 PM)</i> (STUDIO) or <i>TR EVE (1-6 PM)</i> (STUDIO)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Offers a broad range of advanced-level investigations in architectural design in various contexts, including international sites. Integrates theoretical and technological discourses into specific topics. Studio problems may include urbanism and city scale strategies, habitation and urban housing systems, architecture in landscapes, material investigations and new production technologies, programmatic and spatial complex building typologies, and research centered studies. Mandatory lottery process.
<br><I>Architecture Design Staff</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.162"></a>
<p><h3>4.162 Introductory Urban Design Studio
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 0-10-11
<br>URL: <a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/fall-2013-4162">http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/fall-2013-4162</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Project-based introduction to urban observation, research, analysis, and design. Focuses on urban elements, urban and architectural interventions, and landscape in existing cities. Emphasizes city form, sustainability, and social conditions. Projects require both conventional and digital techniques. Preference to Urbanism SMArchS students.
<br><I>Architecture Design Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.163"></a>
<p><h3>4.163J Urban Design Studio
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11c.html#11.332">11.332J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4a.html#4.145">4.145</a>, <a href="m4a.html#4.162">4.162</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br>URL: <a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2014-4163">http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2014-4163</a>
<br><b>Design:</b> <i>TR EVE (1-6 PM)</i> (STUDIO)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>The design of urban environments. Strategies for change in large areas of cities, to be developed over time, involving different actors. Fitting forms into natural, man-made, historical, and cultural contexts; enabling desirable activity patterns; conceptualizing built form; providing infrastructure and service systems; guiding the sensory character of development. Involves architecture and planning students in joint work; requires individual designs or design and planning guidelines.
<br><I>Architecture Design Staff</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.166"></a>
<p><h3>4.166 Beijing Urban Design Studio
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m11c.html#11.307">11.307</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4a.html#4.144">4.144</a>
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Design and development studio that involves architects and planners, working in teams on a contemporary design project of importance in Beijing, China. Students analyze conditions, explore alternatives, and synthesize architecture, city design, and implementation plans. Supplemented by lectures and brief study tours that expose students to history and contemporary issues of urbanism in China. Offered every other summer in residence at Tsinghua University, Beijing, involving students and faculty from both schools. Limited to 10.
<br><I>J. Wampler, D. Frenchman</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.170"></a>

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<br>Interactive design research in developing areas outside of the USA. Assist in drawing, modeling and constructing small buildings appropriate for the culture, climate and specific population under consideration.

<a name="4.171"></a>
<p><h3>4.171 Design Workshop: The Space Between
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Design research into the space between and the space within buildings and cities. Projects include the development and understanding of existing space in buildings and cities, as well as designing new structures looking at the space first and the object second.

<a name="4.183"></a><a name="4.184"></a><a name="4.185"></a>
<h3>4.183-4.185 Architectural Design Workshop
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><b>4.183:</b> URL: <a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2014-4183">http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2014-4183</a>
<br><img align="bottom" width=16 height=16 alt="Subject Cancelled" title="Subject Cancelled" src="/icns/buttonx.gif"> <i><b>4.183 Cancelled</b></i> <!--s--><br><b>4.184:</b> <b>Lecture:</b> <i>T9-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-216</a>)<!--s--><br><img align="bottom" width=16 height=16 alt="Subject Cancelled" title="Subject Cancelled" src="/icns/buttonx.gif"> <i><b>4.185 Cancelled</b></i> <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Addresses design inquiry in a studio format. In-depth consideration of selected issues of the built world. The problem may be prototypical or a particular aspect of a whole project, but is always interdisciplinary in nature.

<a name="4.189"></a>
<p><h3>4.189 Preparation for MArch Thesis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-1-5
<br>URL: <a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2014-4189">http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2014-4189</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>F9-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-234</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Preparatory research development leading to a well-conceived proposition for the MArch design thesis. Students formulate a cohesive thesis argument and critical project using supportive research and case studies through a variety of representational media, critical traditions, and architectural/artistic conventions. Group study in seminar and studio format, with periodic reviews supplemented by conference with faculty and a designated committee member for each individual thesis. Restricted to MArch students.
<br><I>M. Goulthorpe</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.190"></a>
<p><h3>4.190 Practical Experience in Architecture
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 0-0-3 [P/D/F]
<br>URL: <a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/fall-2013-4190">http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/fall-2013-4190</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Practical experience through summer internships secured by the student in the field of architecture, urbanism, digital design, art, or building technology.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.191"></a>

<br>Units arranged
<br>Consult instructor <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>No textbook information available (IAP 2014); No required or recommended textbooks (Spring 2014)

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<h3>4.S14 Special Subject: Architecture Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department

<h1 align="center">Course 5: Chemistry<br>Spring
2014</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://web.mit.edu/chemistry/www/index.html"><i>Course 5 Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course5.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=+++5&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>5.00-5.4999</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m5b.html">5.50-5.999, plus UROP and Theses</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<a name="5.03"></a>
<p><h3>5.03 Principles of Inorganic Chemistry I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.12">5.12</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-155</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>MW2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-328</a>) or <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-322</a>) or <i>TR12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-322</a>) or <i>TR2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-210</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents principles of chemical bonding and molecular structure, and their application to the chemistry of representative elements of the periodic system.
<br><I>C. C. Cummins, R. R. Schrock</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=5.03');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
<a name="5.04"></a>
<p><h3>5.04 Principles of Inorganic Chemistry II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.03">5.03</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Systematic presentation of the chemical applications of group theory. Emphasis on the formal development of the subject and its applications to the physical methods of inorganic chemical compounds. Against the backdrop of electronic structure, the electronic, vibrational, and magnetic properties of transition metal complexes are presented and their investigation by the appropriate spectroscopy described.
<br><I>M. Dinca, Y. Surendranath</I><br>
<a name="5.05"></a>
<p><h3>5.05 Principles of Inorganic Chemistry III
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.03">5.03</a>, <a href="m5a.html#5.04">5.04</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br>Begins March 31. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>M EVE (5.30-8.30 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=8">8-205</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Principles of main group (s and p block) element chemistry with an emphasis on synthesis, structure, bonding, and reaction mechanisims.
<br><I>C. C. Cummins</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.061"></a>
<p><h3>5.061 Principles of Organometallic Chemistry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">; partial term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.03">5.03</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A comprehensive treatment of organometallic compounds of the transition metals with emphasis on structure, bonding, synthesis, and mechanism.
<br><I>R. Schrock</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.062"></a>
<p><h3>5.062 Principles of Bioinorganic Chemistry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">; first half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.03">5.03</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR8.30-10 (ENDS MARCH 21)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-105</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Delineates principles that form the basis for understanding how metal ions function in biology. Includes the choice, uptake and assembly of metal-containing units; metal-induced folding of biomolecules; control of metal ion concentrations in cells; electron-transfer chemistry; atom and group transfer chemistry; protein tuning of metal properties; and applications to diagnosis and treatment of disease.
<br><I>S. Lippard</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=5.062');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.063"></a>
<p><h3>5.063 Organometallic Compounds in Catalytic Reactions
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">; first half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.061">5.061</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>An exploration of organometallic chemistry from the perspective of catalytic reactions in organic and polymer chemistry.
<br><I>R. Schrock</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.067"></a>
<p><h3>5.067 Crystal Structure Refinement
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.068">5.068</a>, <a href="m5a.html#5.069">5.069</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-3-1
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Practical aspects of crystal structure determination from data collection strategies to data reduction and basic and advanced refinement problems of organic and inorganic molecules.
<br><I>P. Mueller</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.068"></a>
<p><h3>5.068 Physical Inorganic Chemistry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">; second half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.03">5.03</a>, <a href="m5a.html#5.04">5.04</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR8.30-10 (BEGINS MARCH 31)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-105</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Discusses the physical methods used to probe the electronic and geometric structures of inorganic compounds, with additional techniques employed in the characterization of inorganic solids and surfaces. Includes vibrational spectroscopy, solid state and solution magnetochemical methods, M?ssbauer spectroscopy, electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy, electrochemical methods, and a brief survey of surface techniques. Applications to current research problems in inorganic and solid-state chemistry.
<br><I>M. Dinca</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.069"></a>
<p><h3>5.069 Crystal Structure Analysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">; first half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.03">5.03</a>, <a href="m5a.html#5.04">5.04</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW8.30-10 (ENDS MARCH 21)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-105</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to X-ray crystallography: symmetry in real and reciprocal space, space and Laue groups, geometry of diffraction, structure factors, phase problem, direct and Patterson methods, electron density maps, structure refinement, crystal growth, powder methods, limits of diffraction methods, structure data bases.
<br><I>P. Mueller</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=5.069');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.07"></a>
<p><h3>5.07J Biological Chemistry I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m20a.html#20.507">20.507J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.12">5.12</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Chemical and physical properties of the cell and its building blocks. Structures of proteins and principles of catalysis. The chemistry of organic/inorganic cofactors required for chemical transformations within the cell. Basic principles of metabolism and regulation in pathways, including glycolysis, gluconeogenesis, fatty acid synthesis/degradation, pentose phosphate pathway, Krebs cycle and oxidative phosphorylation, DNA replication, and transcription and translation.
<br><I>J. Essigmann, J. Stubbe</I><br>
<a name="5.08"></a>
<p><h3>5.08J Biological Chemistry II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m7a.html#7.08">7.08J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.80">7.80</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.12">5.12</a>; <a href="m5a.html#5.07">5.07</a> or <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-105</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-132</a>) or <i>R1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-132</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-132</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-132</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>More advanced treatment of biochemical mechanisms that underlie biological processes.  Topics include macromolecular machines such as the ribosome, the proteosome, fatty acid synthases as a paradigm for polyketide synthases and non-ribosomal polypeptide synthases, and polymerases. Emphasis is on experimental methods used to unravel these processes and how these processes fit into the cellular context and coordinate regulation.
<br><I>J. Stubbe, E. Nolan</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.111"></a>
<p><h3>5.111 Principles of Chemical Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/chem.gif" alt="Chemistry" title="Chemistry" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.5111">ES.5111</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m3a.html#3.091">3.091</A>, <A HREF="m5a.html#5.112">5.112</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.5111">CC.5111</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.3091">ES.3091</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.5112">ES.5112</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-123</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-168</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=13">13-5101</a>) or <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=13">13-5101</a>) or <i>TR12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-375</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-246</a>) or <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-375</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-442</a>) or <i>TR2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-442</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-233</a>) or <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-375</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to chemistry, with emphasis on basic principles of atomic and molecular electronic structure, thermodynamics, acid-base and redox equilibria, chemical kinetics, and catalysis. Introduction to the chemistry of biological, inorganic, and organic molecules.
<br>Fall: <I>A. Klibanov, C. Drennan</I><br>Spring: <I>M. Shoulders, T. Van Voorhis</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=5.111');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.112"></a>
<p><h3>5.112 Principles of Chemical Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/chem.gif" alt="Chemistry" title="Chemistry" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.5112">ES.5112</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m3a.html#3.091">3.091</A>, <A HREF="m5a.html#5.111">5.111</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.5111">CC.5111</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.3091">ES.3091</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.5111">ES.5111</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to chemistry for students with an unusually strong background in chemistry. Knowledge of calculus equivalent to 18.01 is recommended. Emphasis on basic principles of atomic and molecular electronic structure, thermodynamics, acid-base and redox equilibria, chemical kinetics, and catalysis. Applications of basic principles to problems in metal coordination chemistry, organic chemistry, and biological chemistry.
<br><I>S. Lippard, K. Nelson</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.12"></a>
<p><h3>5.12 Organic Chemistry I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=10">10-250</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>MW1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-310</a>) or <i>MW2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-310</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-156</a>) or <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-310</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-150</a>) or <i>TR12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-310</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-136</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-150</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-302</a>) or <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=13">13-3101</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-302</a>) or <i>TR2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=13">13-3101</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-277</a>) or <i>TR3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-132</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to organic chemistry. Development of basic principles to understand the structure and reactivity of organic molecules. Emphasis on substitution and elimination reactions and chemistry of the carbonyl group. Introduction to the chemistry of aromatic compounds.
<br>Fall: <I>T. Swager</I><br>Spring: <I>R. Danheiser, M. Movassaghi</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=5.12');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
<a name="5.13"></a>
<p><h3>5.13 Organic Chemistry II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.12">5.12</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on synthesis, structure determination, mechanism, and the relationships between structure and reactivity. Selected topics illustrate the role of organic chemistry in biological systems and in the chemical industry.
<br><I>T. Jamison, S. Buchwald</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.24"></a>
<p><h3>5.24J Archaeological Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m3b.html#3.985">3.985J</A>, <A HREF="m12a.html#12.011">12.011J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a> or <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-1-5
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M EVE (7-10 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-370</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Pressing issues in archaeology as an anthropological science. Stresses the natural science and engineering methods archaeologists use to address these issues. Reconstructing time, space, and human ecologies provides one focus; materials technologies that transform natural materials to material culture provide another. Topics include 14C dating, ice core and palynological analysis, GIS and other remote sensing techniques for site location, soil micromorphology and site formation, sourcing of metal artifacts, and microstructural and mechanical analyses of cementitious materials used in ancient monumental buildings.
<br><I>H. N. Lechtman, J. Stubbe, F. A. Frey</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.301"></a>
<p><h3>5.301 Chemistry Laboratory Techniques
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 1-4-1 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Practical training in basic chemistry laboratory techniques. Intended to provide freshmen with the skills necessary to undertake original research projects in chemistry. Freshmen only. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>J. Dolhun</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014JA&Subject=5.301');" >Textbooks (IAP 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.310"></a>
<p><h3>5.310 Laboratory Chemistry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="m5a.html#5.12">5.12</a></I>
<br>Units: 2-8-2
<br>1st lec mandatory. <b>Compulsory:</b> <i>Mandatory Safety Lec 2/4 1pm (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=10">10-250</a>) or Mandatory Safety Lec 2/5 1pm (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-123</a>)</i> <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-370</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>MW1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces experimental chemistry for students who are not majoring in Course V. Principles and applications of chemical laboratory techniques, including preparation and analysis of chemical materials, measurement of pH, gas and liquid chromatography, visible-ultraviolet spectrophotometry, infrared spectroscopy, kinetics, data analysis, and elementary synthesis. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>J. Dolhun</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=5.310');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.35"></a>
<p><h3>5.35 Introduction to Experimental Chemistry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m5a.html#5.35U">5.35U</A>)
<br>Prereq: See module descriptions
<br>Units arranged
<br>URL: <a href="http://chemistry.mit.edu/urieca/urieca-module-signup-form-535535u">http://chemistry.mit.edu/urieca/urieca-module-signup-form-535535u</a>
<br><b>Lab:</b> <i>MW 1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>) or <i>TR 1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>MW 1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>) or <i>TR 1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>This 12-unit subject consists of 3 modules, which may be taken during different terms. Modules and prerequisites are as follows:<br>Module 1 (Prereq: 5.111, 5.112 or 3.091) Survey of spectroscopy.<br> Module 2 (Prereq: 5.111, 5.112 or 3.091; <i> Module 1</i>) Synthesis of coordination compounds and kinetics.<br> Module 3 (Prereq: 5.111, 5.112 or 3.091;<i> 5.12, Module 2</i>) Fabrication of a polymeric light emitting device.<br> Enrollment limited; preference to Course 5 majors.
<br><I>K. Nelson (Module 1), M. Twardowski (Module 2), T. Swager (Module 3)</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.35U"></a>

<a name="5.36"></a>
<p><h3>5.36 Biochemistry and Organic Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m5a.html#5.36U">5.36U</A>)
<br>Prereq: See module descriptions
<br>Units arranged
<br>URL: <a href="http://chemistry.mit.edu/urieca/urieca-module-signup-536536u">http://chemistry.mit.edu/urieca/urieca-module-signup-536536u</a>
<br><b>Lab:</b> <i>MW 1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>) or <i>TR 1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>MW 1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>) or <i>TR 1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>This 12-unit subject consists of 3 modules, which may be taken during different terms. Instruction and practice in the written and oral presentation of experimental results provided. Modules and prerequisites are as follows:<br>Module 4 Spring (Prereq: 5.07 or 7.05, Module 2 or 5.310, <i>Module 5</i>) Expression and Purification of Enzyme Mutants. Must be taken simultaneously with Module 5.<br>Module 5 Spring (Prereq: 5.07 or 7.05, Module 2 or 5.310, <i>Module 4</i>) Kinetics of Enzyme Inhibition. Must be taken simultaneously with Module 4.<br>Module 6 Fall (Prereq: 5.12, Module 2 or 5.310, <i>5.13</i>) Organic Structure Determination.<br> Enrollment limited; preference to Course 5 majors.
<br>Fall: <I>R. L. Danheiser (Module 6)</I><br>Spring: <I>A. Ting (Modules 4 & 5)</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.36U"></a>
<p><h3>5.36U Biochemistry and Organic Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m5a.html#5.36">5.36</A>)
<br>Prereq: See module descriptions under subject <a href="m5a.html#5.36">5.36</a>
<br>Units arranged
<br>URL: <a href="http://chemistry.mit.edu/urieca/urieca-module-signup-536536u">http://chemistry.mit.edu/urieca/urieca-module-signup-536536u</a>
<br><b>Lab:</b> <i>MW 1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>) or <i>TR 1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>MW 1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>) or <i>TR 1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>For students who might not take all modules of 5.36.  Consult department when choosing a version of 5.36.  See description for 5.36.  May be taken for 8 or 4 units and repeated for credit up to a total of 12 units.
<br>Fall: <I>R. L. Danheiser (Module 6)</I><br>Spring: <I>B. Pentelute (Modules 4 & 5)</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.37"></a>
<p><h3>5.37 Organic and Inorganic Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m5a.html#5.37U">5.37U</A>)
<br>Prereq: See module descriptions
<br>Units arranged
<br>URL: <a href="http://chemistry.mit.edu/urieca/urieca-module-signup-537537u">http://chemistry.mit.edu/urieca/urieca-module-signup-537537u</a>
<br><b>Compulsory:</b> <i>Mandatory Safety Lec 2/4 1pm (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=10">10-250</a>) or Mandatory Safety Lec 2/5 1pm (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-123</a>)</i> <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-153</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>MW1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>This 12-unit subject consists of 3 modules, which may be taken during different terms. Modules and prerequisites are as follows:<br> Module 7 Spring (Prereq: 5.13, Module 6) Introduction to Organic Synthesis.<br>Module 8 Fall (Prereq: 5.03, Module 6, <i>5.61</i>) Two Electron Bond. <br>Module 9 Fall (Prereq: 5.03, Module 6, <i>5.61</i>) Dinitrogen Cleavage.<br> Enrollment limited; preference to Course 5 majors.
<br>Fall: <I>M. Twardowski  (Module 8), C. C. Cummins (Module 9)</I><br>Spring: <I>M. Twardowski (Module 7)</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.37U"></a>
<p><h3>5.37U Organic and Inorganic Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m5a.html#5.37">5.37</A>)
<br>Prereq: See module descriptions under subject <a href="m5a.html#5.37">5.37</a>
<br>Units arranged
<br>URL: <a href="http://chemistry.mit.edu/urieca/urieca-module-signup-537537u">http://chemistry.mit.edu/urieca/urieca-module-signup-537537u</a>
<br><b>Compulsory:</b> <i>Mandatory Safety Lec 2/4 1pm (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=10">10-250</a>) or Mandatory Safety Lec 2/5 1pm (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-123</a>)</i> <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-153</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>MW1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>For students who might not take all modules of 5.37.  Consult department when choosing a version of 5.37.  See description for 5.37.  May be taken for 8 or 4 units and repeated for credit up to a total of 12 units.
<br>Fall: <I>D. Nocera (Module 8), C. C. Cummins (Module 9)</I><br>Spring: <I>M. Twardowski (Module 7)</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.38"></a>
<p><h3>5.38 Physical Chemistry Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: See module descriptions
<br>Units arranged
<br>URL: <a href="http://chemistry.mit.edu/urieca/urieca-module-signup-538">http://chemistry.mit.edu/urieca/urieca-module-signup-538</a>
<br><b>Compulsory:</b> <i>Mandatory Safety Lec 2/4 1pm (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=10">10-250</a>) or Mandatory Safety Lec 2/5 1pm (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-123</a>)</i> <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-153</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>MW1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>This 12-unit subject consists of 3 modules, which may be taken during different terms. Instruction and practice in the written and oral presentation of experimental results provided. Modules and prerequisites are as follows: <br>Module 10 (Prereq: 5.61, Module 6) Quantum Dots. <br>Module 11 (Prereq: 5.61, 5.07 or 7.05, Module 5) Time Resolved Molecular Spectroscopy. <br> Module 12 (Prereq: 5.61, 5.07 or 7.05, Module 6) Solid State NMR.<br> Enrollment limited; preference to Course 5 majors.
<br><I>M. G. Bawendi (Module 10), K. Nelson (Module 11), J. Simpson (Module 12)</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.43"></a>
<p><h3>5.43 Advanced Organic Chemistry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m5b.html#5.53">5.53</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.13">5.13</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Reaction mechanisms in organic chemistry: methods of investigation, relation of structure to reactivity, and reactive intermediates.  Photochemistry and organometallic chemistry, with an emphasis on fundamental reactivity, mechanistic studies, and applications in organic chemistry.
<br><I>J. Johnson</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.44"></a>
<p><h3>5.44 Organometallic Chemistry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">; first half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.43">5.43</a>, <a href="m5a.html#5.47">5.47</a>, <a href="m5a.html#5.061">5.061</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examination of the most important transformations of organotransition-metal species. Emphasizes basic mechanisms of their reactions, structure-reactivity relationships, and applications in synthesis.
<br><I>S. Buchwald</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.45"></a>
<p><h3>5.45 Heterocyclic Chemistry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">; second half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.43">5.43</a>, <a href="m5b.html#5.511">5.511</a>, <a href="m5b.html#5.53">5.53</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br>Begins March 31. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>T EVE (5.30-8.30 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-105</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to the chemistry of heterocyclic compounds. Surveys synthesis and reactivity of the major classes of heterocyclic organic compounds. Discusses the importance of these molecules in the pharmaceutical and other industries.
<br><I>S. L. Buchwald</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.46"></a>
<p><h3>5.46 NMR Spectroscopy and Organic Structure Determination
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">; first half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.43">5.43</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF10 (ENDS MARCH 21)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=8">8-119</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Applications of 1-D and 2-D <SUP>1</SUP>H and <SUP>13</SUP>C NMR spectroscopy to organic structure determination.
<br><I>J. H. Simpson</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.47"></a>
<p><h3>5.47 Tutorial in Organic Chemistry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">; first half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.43">5.43</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Systematic review of basic principles concerned with the structure and transformations of organic molecules. Problem-solving workshop format. The program is intended primarily for first-year graduate students with a strong interest in organic chemistry. Meets during the month of September.
<br><I>R. Danheiser</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.48"></a>
<p><h3>5.48J Protein Folding and Human Disease
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m7a.html#7.88">7.88J</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.543">10.543J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.51">7.51</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>R2.30-5.30</i> (Whitehead-6TH)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Addresses the multifaceted biochemical problem of protein folding and the surprising ways it affects biological systems. Considers underlying chemistry and cellular biology, folding intermediates and off-pathway reactions, and the roles of chaperones and other folding assistants. Covers the amyloid fold, beneficial amyloid functions, major protein folding diseases (such as Alzheimer's and Prion diseases) and the effects of protein folding on the evolution of novel functions.
<br><I>S. Lindquist, J. A. King</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=5.48');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
</td></tr></table>
