<h1 align="center">Course 6: Electrical Engineering and Computer Science<br>Spring
2014</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://www.eecs.mit.edu/"><i>Course 6 Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course6.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=+++6&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>6.00-6.299</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m6b.html">6.30-6.799</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m6c.html">6.80-6.ZZZ</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<h2>Basic Undergraduate Subjects</h2>
<a name="6.00"></a>
<p><h3>6.00 Introduction to Computer Science and Programming
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-7-2
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-123</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-145</a>) or <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-145</a>) or <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-145</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-145</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-145</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-153</a>) or <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-153</a>) or <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-153</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to computer science and programming for students with little or no programming experience.  Students learn how to program and how to use computational techniques to solve problems.  Topics include algorithms, data analysis, simulation techniques, and use of software libraries.  Assignments are done using the Python programming language.
<br><I>J. V. Guttag</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.01"></a>
<p><h3>6.01 Introduction to EECS I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/HalfLab.gif" alt="1/2 Institute Lab" title="1/2 Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a></I>
<br>Units: 2-4-6
<br>URL: <a href="http://mit.edu/6.01/index.html">http://mit.edu/6.01/index.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-100</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>M11-12.30,W9.30-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-501</a>) or <i>M2-3.30,W2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-501</a>) or <i>T11-12.30,R9.30-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-501</a>) or <i>T2-3.30,R2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-501</a>) or <i>M12.30-2,F9.30-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-501</a>) or <i>M3.30-5,F2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-501</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>An integrated introduction to electrical engineering and computer science, taught using substantial laboratory experiments with mobile robots. Key issues in the design of engineered artifacts operating in the natural world: measuring and modeling system behaviors; assessing errors in sensors and effectors; specifying tasks; designing solutions based on analytical and computational models; planning, executing, and evaluating experimental tests of performance; refining models and designs. Issues addressed in the context of computer programs, control systems, probabilistic inference problems, circuits and transducers, which all play important roles in achieving robust operation of a large variety of engineered systems.  6 Engineering Design Points. 
<br><I>D. M. Freeman, L. P. Kaelbling, T. Lozano-Perez</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
<a name="6.02"></a>
<p><h3>6.02 Introduction to EECS II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/HalfLab.gif" alt="1/2 Institute Lab" title="1/2 Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.01">6.01</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>
<br>Units: 4-4-4
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m6a.html#6.S02">6.S02</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores communication signals, systems and networks. Substantial laboratory experiments illustrate the role of abstraction and modularity in engineering design. Students gain practical experience in building reliable systems using imperfect components; selecting appropriate design metrics; choosing effective representations for information; and evaluating tradeoffs in complex systems. Topics include physical characterization and modeling of transmission systems in the time and frequency domains; analog and digital signaling; coding; detecting and correcting errors; relating information transmission rate to signal power, bandwidth and noise; and engineering of packet-switched networks.  6 Engineering Design Points. 
<br><I>H. Balakrishnan, J. K. White</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.S02"></a>
<p><h3>6.S02 Special Subject: Introduction to EECS II from a Medical Technology Perspective
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/HalfLab.gif" alt="1/2 Institute Lab" title="1/2 Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-4-4
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m6a.html#6.02">6.02</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-101</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>R9.30-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=38">38-501</a>) or <i>R2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=38">38-501</a>) or <i>F9.30-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=38">38-501</a>) or <i>F2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=38">38-501</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Experimental version of 6.02 that provides a medical technology context for learning fundamental concepts in information extraction and representation. Explores biomedical signals generated from electrocardiograms, glucose detectors, and magnetic resonance images. Topics include physical characterization and modeling of systems in the time and frequency domains; analog and digital signals and noise; basic machine learning including decision trees, clustering, and classification; and introductory machine vision. Licensed through Spring 2014 by the Committee on Curricula as an acceptable alternative to 6.02.  6 Engineering Design Points. 
<br><I>C. M. Stultz, E. Adalsteinson</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.07"></a>
<p><h3>6.07J Projects in Microscale Engineering for the Life Sciences
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.410">HST.410J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-4-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A project-based introduction to manipulating and characterizing cells and biological molecules using microfabricated tools. In the first half of the term, students perform laboratory exercises designed to introduce the design, manufacture, and use of microfluidic channels; techniques for sorting and manipulating cells and biomolecules; and making quantitative measurements using optical detection and fluorescent labeling. In the second half of the term, students work in small groups to design and test a microfluidic device to solve a real-world problem of their choosing. Includes exercises in written and oral communication and team building. Limited to 20; preference to freshmen.
<br><I>D. Freeman, M. Gray, A. Aranyosi</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.002"></a>
<p><h3>6.002 Circuits and Electronics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>; <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.01">6.01</a>
<br>Units: 4-1-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-101</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>TBA</i> <b>Recitation:</b> <i>WF10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-310</a>) or <i>WF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-310</a>) or <i>WF12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-310</a>) or <i>WF1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-310</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Fundamentals of the lumped circuit abstraction. Resistive elements and networks, independent and dependent sources, switches and MOS devices, digital abstraction, amplifiers, and energy storage elements. Dynamics of first- and second-order networks; design in the time and frequency domains; analog and digital circuits and applications. Design exercises. Occasional laboratory.  4 Engineering Design Points. 
<br><I>A. Agarwal, J. del Alamo, J. H. Lang, D. J. Perreault</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=6.002');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.003"></a>
<p><h3>6.003 Signals and Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.02">6.02</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>URL: <a href="http://stellar.mit.edu/S/course/6/fa13/6.003/">http://stellar.mit.edu/S/course/6/fa13/6.003/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-155</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>TBA</i> <b>Recitation:</b> <i>WF10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-155</a>) or <i>WF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-155</a>) or <i>WF1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=24">24-307</a>) or <i>WF2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=24">24-307</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents the fundamentals of signal and system analysis. Topics include discrete-time and continuous-time signals, Fourier series and transforms, Laplace and Z transforms, and analysis of linear, time-invariant systems. Applications drawn broadly from engineering and physics, including audio and image processing, communications, and automatic control.  4 Engineering Design Points. 
<br><I>D. M. Freeman, Q. Hu, J. S. Lim</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=6.003');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.004"></a>
<p><h3>6.004 Computation Structures
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>URL: <a href="http://6004.lcs.mit.edu/">http://6004.lcs.mit.edu/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-123</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>WF10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-301</a>) or <i>WF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-301</a>) or <i>WF12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-301</a>) or <i>WF1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-301</a>) or <i>WF2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-301</a>) or <i>WF3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-301</a>) or <i>WF12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-302</a>) or <i>WF1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-302</a>) or <i>WF2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-302</a>) or <i>WF3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-302</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces architecture of digital systems, emphasizing structural principles common to a wide range of technologies. Multilevel implementation strategies; definition of new primitives (e.g., gates, instructions, procedures, and processes) and their mechanization using lower-level elements. Analysis of potential concurrency; precedence constraints and performance measures; pipelined and multidimensional systems. Instruction set design issues; architectural support for contemporary software structures.  4 Engineering Design Points. 
<br><I>S. A. Ward, C. J. Terman</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.005"></a>
<p><h3>6.005 Elements of Software Construction
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.01">6.01</a>; <I>Coreq: <a href="m6a.html#6.042">6.042</a></I>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-101</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-304</a>) or <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-304</a>) or <i>TR12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-304</a>) or <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-304</a>) or <i>TR2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-304</a>) or <i>TR10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-265</a>) or <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-265</a>) or <i>TR12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-265</a>) or <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-302</a>) or <i>TR2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-302</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces fundamental principles and techniques of software development, i.e., how to write software that is safe from bugs, easy to understand, and ready for change. Topics include specifications and invariants; testing, test-case generation, and coverage; state machines; abstract data types and representation independence; design patterns for object-oriented programming; concurrent programming, including message passing and shared concurrency, and defending against races and deadlock; and functional programming with immutable data and higher-order functions. Includes weekly programming exercises and two substantial group projects. 12 Engineering Design Points. 
<br><I>D. N. Jackson, R. C. Miller</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.006"></a>
<p><h3>6.006 Introduction to Algorithms
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.01">6.01</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.042">6.042</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-123</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>WF10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-153</a>) or <i>WF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-153</a>) or <i>WF12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-153</a>) or <i>WF1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-153</a>) or <i>WF2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-153</a>) or <i>WF3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-153</a>) or <i>WF4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-153</a>) or <i>WF12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-302</a>) or <i>WF1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-302</a>) or <i>WF2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-302</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to mathematical modeling of computational problems, as well as common algorithms, algorithmic paradigms, and data structures used to solve these problems. Emphasizes the relationship between algorithms and programming, and introduces basic performance measures and analysis techniques for these problems.
<br><I>R. L. Rivest, S. Devadas</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=6.006');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.007"></a>
<p><h3>6.007 Electromagnetic Energy: From Motors to Lasers
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.01">6.01</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>
<br>Units: 5-1-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-156</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>T3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-304</a>) or <i>T4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-304</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Discusses applications of electromagnetic and equivalent quantum mechanical principles to classical and modern devices. Covers energy conversion and power flow in both macroscopic and quantum-scale electrical and electromechanical systems, including electric motors and generators, electric circuit elements, quantum tunneling structures and instruments. Studies photons as waves and particles and their interaction with matter in optoelectronic devices, including solar cells, displays, and lasers.
<br><I>V. Bulovic, R. J. Ram</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.011"></a>
<p><h3>6.011 Introduction to Communication, Control, and Signal Processing
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.003">6.003</a>; <a href="m6a.html#6.041">6.041</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.440">18.440</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-141</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-301</a>) or <i>TR12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-301</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers signals, systems and inference in communication, control and signal processing. Topics include input-output and state-space models of linear systems driven by deterministic and random signals; time- and transform-domain representations in discrete and continuous time; and group delay. State feedback and observers. Probabilistic models; stochastic processes, correlation functions, power spectra, spectral factorization. Least-mean square error estimation; Wiener filtering. Hypothesis testing; detection; matched filters.
<br><I>A. V. Oppenheim, G. C. Verghese</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.012"></a>
<p><h3>6.012 Microelectronic Devices and Circuits
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.002">6.002</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-144</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>WF1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=13">13-5101</a>) or <i>WF2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=13">13-5101</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Microelectronic device modeling, and basic microelectronic circuit analysis and design. Physical electronics of semiconductor junction and MOS devices. Relating terminal behavior to internal physical processes, developing circuit models, and understanding the uses and limitations of different models. Use of incremental and large-signal techniques to analyze and design transistor circuits, with examples chosen from digital circuits, linear amplifiers, and other integrated circuits. Design project.  4 Engineering Design Points. 
<br><I>A. I. Akinwande, D. A. Antoniadis, C. G. Fonstad, Jr., C. G. Sodini</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=6.012');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.013"></a>
<p><h3>6.013 Electromagnetics and Applications
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.003">6.003</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.007">6.007</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m6b.html#6.630">6.630</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-155</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>WF10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-302</a>) or <i>WF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-302</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores electromagnetic phenomena in modern applications, including wireless and optical communications, circuits, computer interconnects and peripherals, microwave communications and radar, antennas, sensors, micro-electromechanical systems, and power generation and transmission. Fundamentals include quasistatic and dynamic solutions to Maxwell's equations; waves, radiation, and diffraction; coupling to media and structures; guided waves; resonance; acoustic analogs; and forces, power, and energy.
<br><I>L. Daniel, M. R. Watts</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=6.013');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.021"></a>
<p><h3>6.021J Cellular Biophysics and Neurophysiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.791">2.791J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.370">20.370J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m2b.html#2.794">2.794J</A>, <A HREF="m6b.html#6.521">6.521J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.470">20.470J</A>, <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.541">HST.541J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>; <a href="m2a.html#2.005">2.005</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.002">6.002</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.003">6.003</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.071">6.071</a>, <a href="m10a.html#10.301">10.301</a>, <a href="m20a.html#20.110">20.110</a>, <a href="m20a.html#20.111">20.111</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 5-2-5
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Integrated overview of the biophysics of cells from prokaryotes to neurons, with a focus on mass transport and electrical signal generation across cell membrane. First half of course focuses on mass transport through membranes: diffusion, osmosis, chemically mediated, and active transport. Second half focuses on electrical properties of cells: ion transport to action potentials in electrically excitable cells. Electrical properties interpreted via kinetic and molecular properties of single voltage-gated ion channels. Laboratory and computer exercises illustrate the concepts. Provides instruction in written and oral communication. Students taking graduate version complete different assignments. Preference to juniors and seniors.  4 Engineering Design Points. 
<br><I>D. M. Freeman, J. Han, J. Voldman, M. F. Yanik</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.022"></a>
<p><h3>6.022J Quantitative Systems Physiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.792">2.792J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.371">20.371J</A>, <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.542">HST.542J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m2b.html#2.796">2.796J</A>, <A HREF="m6b.html#6.522">6.522J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.471">20.471J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-2-6
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/6.022j/www/">http://web.mit.edu/6.022j/www/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-124</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E25">E25-117</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E25">E25-117</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Application of the principles of energy and mass flow to major human organ systems. Mechanisms of regulation and homeostasis. Anatomical, physiological and pathophysiological features of the cardiovascular, respiratory and renal systems. Systems, features and devices that are most illuminated by the methods of physical sciences. Laboratory work includes some animal studies. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.  2 Engineering Design Points. 
<br><I>R. G. Mark, C. M. Stultz</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=6.022');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.023"></a>
<p><h3>6.023J Fields, Forces and Flows in Biological Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.793">2.793J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.330">20.330J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m2a.html#2.005">2.005</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.021">6.021</a>, <a href="m20a.html#20.320">20.320</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-237</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>T10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-180</a>) or <i>T12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-180</a>) or <i>T4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-144</a>) or <i>W4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-144</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to electric fields, fluid flows, transport phenomena and their application to biological systems. Flux and continuity laws, Maxwell's equations, electro-quasistatics, electro-chemical-mechanical driving forces, conservation of mass and momentum, Navier-Stokes flows, and electrokinetics. Applications include biomolecular transport in tissues, electrophoresis, and microfluidics.
<br><I>J. Han, S. Manalis</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.024"></a>
<p><h3>6.024J Molecular, Cellular, and Tissue Biomechanics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.797">2.797J</A>, <A HREF="m3a.html#3.053">3.053J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.310">20.310J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2b.html#2.370">2.370</a> or <a href="m2b.html#2.772">2.772J</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m3a.html#3.016">3.016</a>; <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-270</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>M4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-304</a>) or <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-303</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops and applies scaling laws and the methods of continuum mechanics to biomechanical phenomena over a range of length scales. Topics include structure of tissues and the molecular basis for macroscopic properties; chemical and electrical effects on mechanical behavior; cell mechanics, motility and adhesion; biomembranes; biomolecular mechanics and molecular motors. Experimental methods for probing structures at the tissue, cellular, and molecular levels.
<br><I>R. D. Kamm, A. J. Grodzinsky</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=6.024');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.025"></a>
<p><h3>6.025J Medical Device Design
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.750">2.750J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m2b.html#2.75">2.75J</A>, <A HREF="m6b.html#6.525">6.525J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2b.html#2.72">2.72</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.071">6.071</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.115">6.115</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/7.38j/">http://web.mit.edu/7.38j/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Application of mechanical and electrical engineering fundamentals to the design of medical devices that address clinical needs. Throughout the term, students work in small teams on a major project to translate a clinical challenge into a proof-of-concept prototype device. Students conduct user analysis, develop design specifications, and follow a structured process to cultivate creative designs and apply analytical techniques to optimize them. They deepen their understanding of art and intellectual property by researching prior representations. Develops practical skills in prototyping and testing as well as project management. Includes lectures, problem sets and exams that focus on design fundamentals. Instruction and practice in written and oral communication provided. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>A. H. Slocum, C. G. Sodini</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.033"></a>
<p><h3>6.033 Computer System Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.004">6.004</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.02">6.02</a>
<br>Units: 5-1-6
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/6.033/www/">http://web.mit.edu/6.033/www/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-123</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-204</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-204</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-210</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-210</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-142</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-304</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-372</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-372</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-310</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-310</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-314</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-314</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-303</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-302</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-308</a>) or <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-303</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-308</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-372</a>) or <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-303</a>) or <i>TR2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-303</a>) or <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-372</a>) or <i>TR2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-372</a>) or <i>TR12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-328</a>) or <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-328</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Topics on the engineering of computer software and hardware systems: techniques for controlling complexity; strong modularity using client-server design, operating systems; performance, networks; naming; security and privacy; fault-tolerant systems, atomicity and coordination of concurrent activities, and recovery; impact of computer systems on society.  Case studies of working systems and readings from the current literature provide comparisons and contrasts.  Two design projects.  Students engage in extensive written communication exercises. Enrollment may be limited.  4 Engineering Design Points. 
<br><I>M. F. Kaashoek, H. Balakrishnan</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=6.033');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.034"></a>
<p><h3>6.034 Artificial Intelligence
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.01">6.01</a>
<br>Units: 5-3-4
<br>URL: <a href="http://courses.csail.mit.edu/6.034/">http://courses.csail.mit.edu/6.034/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces representations, techniques, and architectures used to build applied systems and to account for intelligence from a computational point of view. Applications of rule chaining, heuristic search, constraint propagation, constrained search, inheritance, and other problem-solving paradigms. Applications of identification trees, neural nets, genetic algorithms, and other learning paradigms. Speculations on the contributions of human vision and language systems to human intelligence.  4 Engineering Design Points. 
<br><I>P. H. Winston</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.035"></a>
<p><h3>6.035 Computer Language Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.004">6.004</a> and <a href="m6a.html#6.005">6.005</a>
<br>Units: 4-4-4
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/6.035/6035.html">http://web.mit.edu/6.035/6035.html</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analyzes issues associated with the implementation of higher-level programming languages. Fundamental concepts, functions, and structures of compilers. The interaction of theory and practice. Using tools in building software. Includes a multi-person project on compiler design and implementation.  8 Engineering Design Points. 
<br><I>S. P. Amarasinghe</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.036"></a>
<p><h3>6.036 Introduction to Machine Learning
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.01">6.01</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>URL: <a href="http://stellar.mit.edu/S/course/6/sp14/6.036/index.html">http://stellar.mit.edu/S/course/6/sp14/6.036/index.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=10">10-250</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-156</a>) or <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-156</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-261</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-261</a>) or <i>F3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-261</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces principles, algorithms, and applications of machine learning from the point of view of modeling and prediction; formulation of learning problems; representation, over-fitting, generalization; clustering, classification, probabilistic modeling; and methods such as support vector machines, hidden Markov models, and Bayesian networks.
<br><I>R. Barzilay, T. Jaakkola, L. P. Kaelbling</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.037"></a>
<p><h3>6.037 Structure and Interpretation of Computer Programs
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 1-0-5 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies the structure and interpretation of computer programs which transcend specific programming languages. Demonstrates thought patterns for computer science using Scheme. Includes weekly programming projects. Enrollment may be limited.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>No textbook information available

<a name="6.041"></a>
<p><h3>6.041 Probabilistic Systems Analysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6b.html#6.431">6.431</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.440">18.440</A>
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/6.041/www/home.html">http://web.mit.edu/6.041/www/home.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-101</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-155</a>) or <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-155</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>An introduction to probability theory, and the modeling and analysis of probabilistic systems. Probabilistic models, conditional probability. Discrete and continuous random variables. Expectation and conditional expectation. Limit Theorems. Bernoulli and Poisson processes. Markov chains. Bayesian estimation and hypothesis testing. Elements of statistical inference. Meets with graduate subject 6.431, but assignments differ.
<br><I>D. P. Bertsekas, J. N. Tsitsiklis</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=6.041');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.042"></a>
<p><h3>6.042J Mathematics for Computer Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m18a.html#18.062">18.062J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>URL: <a href="http://theory.csail.mit.edu/classes/6.042">http://theory.csail.mit.edu/classes/6.042</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-044</a>) or <i>MWF2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-044</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Elementary discrete mathematics for computer science and engineering. Emphasis on mathematical definitions and proofs as well as on applicable methods.  Topics: formal logic notation, proof methods; induction, well-ordering; sets, relations; elementary graph theory; integer congruences; asymptotic notation and growth of functions; permutations and combinations, counting principles; discrete probability.  Further selected topics such as: recursive definition and structural induction; state machines and invariants; recurrences; generating functions.
<br><I>A. R. Meyer, T. Leighton</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.045"></a>
<p><h3>6.045J Automata, Computability, and Complexity
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m18a.html#18.400">18.400J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.042">6.042</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.400">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.400</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-141</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-303</a>) or <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-303</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to some of the central ideas of theoretical computer science, including circuits, finite automata, Turing machines and computability, efficient algorithms and reducibility, the P versus NP problem, NP-completeness, the power of randomness, cryptography, computational learning theory, and quantum computing. Examines the classes of problems that can and cannot be solved in various computational models.
<br><I>S. Aaronson</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=6.045');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.046"></a>
<p><h3>6.046J Design and Analysis of Algorithms
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m18a.html#18.410">18.410J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.006">6.006</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.410">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.410</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-101</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-112</a>) or <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-112</a>) or <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-112</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-112</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-112</a>) or <i>F3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-112</a>) or <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-144</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Techniques for the design and analysis of efficient algorithms, emphasizing methods useful in practice. Topics include sorting; search trees, heaps, and hashing; divide-and-conquer; dynamic programming; greedy algorithms; amortized analysis; graph algorithms; and shortest paths. Advanced topics may include network flow; computational geometry; number-theoretic algorithms; polynomial and matrix calculations; caching; and parallel computing.
<br><I>C. E. Leiserson, M. Goemans</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=6.046');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.047"></a>
<p><h3>6.047 Computational Biology: Genomes, Networks, Evolution
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6c.html#6.878">6.878J</A>, <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.507">HST.507J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.006">6.006</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.041">6.041</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers the algorithmic and machine learning foundations of computational biology, combining theory with practice. Principles of algorithm design, influential problems and techniques, and analysis of large-scale biological datasets. Topics include (a) genomes: sequence analysis, gene finding, RNA folding, genome alignment and assembly, database search; (b) networks: gene expression analysis, regulatory motifs, biological network analysis; (c) evolution: comparative genomics, phylogenetics, genome duplication, genome rearrangements, evolutionary theory.  These are coupled with fundamental algorithmic techniques including: dynamic programming, hashing, Gibbs sampling, expectation maximization, hidden Markov models, stochastic context-free grammars, graph clustering, dimensionality reduction, Bayesian networks.
<br><I>M. Kellis</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.049"></a>
<p><h3>6.049J Evolutionary Biology:  Concepts, Models and Computation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m7a.html#7.33">7.33J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>; <a href="m6a.html#6.00">6.00</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.01">6.01</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores and illustrates how evolution explains biology, with an emphasis on computational model building for analyzing evolutionary data.  Covers key concepts of biological evolution, including adaptive evolution, neutral evolution, evolution of sex, genomic conflict, speciation, phylogeny and comparative methods, life's history, coevolution, human evolution, and evolution of disease.
<br><I>R. Berwick, D. Bartel</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.050"></a>
<p><h3>6.050J Information, Entropy, and Computation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2a.html#2.110">2.110J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-5
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>WF1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-234</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the ultimate limits to communication and computation, with an emphasis on the physical nature of information and information processing. Topics include information and computation, digital signals, codes, and compression. Biological representations of information. Logic circuits, computer architectures, and algorithmic information. Noise, probability, and error correction. The concept of entropy applied to channel capacity and to the second law of thermodynamics. Reversible and irreversible operations and the physics of computation. Quantum computation.
<br><I>P. Penfield, Jr., S. Lloyd</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.057"></a>
<p><h3>6.057 Introduction to MATLAB
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 1-0-2 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Accelerated introduction to MATLAB and its popular toolboxes. Lectures are interactive, with students conducting sample MATLAB problems in real time. Includes problem-based MATLAB assignments. Students must provide their own laptop and software. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.058"></a>
<p><h3>6.058 Preview of Signals and Systems
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-2-2 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Preparation for 6.003 or 6.011, focusing on several key concepts, including LTI systems, convolution, CT and DT Fourier series and transforms, filtering, sampling, modulation, Laplace and z-transforms, and feedback.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.061"></a>
<p><h3>6.061 Introduction to Electric Power Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6b.html#6.690">6.690</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.002">6.002</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.013">6.013</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Electric circuit theory with application to power handling electric circuits. Modeling and behavior of electromechanical devices, including magnetic circuits, motors, and generators. Operational fundamentals of synchronous, induction and DC machinery. Interconnection of generators and motors with electric power transmission and distribution circuits. Power generation, including alternative and sustainable sources. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.  6 Engineering Design Points. 
<br><I>J. L. Kirtley, Jr.</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.S062"></a><a name="6.S063"></a><a name="6.S064"></a>

<a name="6.070"></a>
<p><h3>6.070J Electronics Project Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mECa.html#EC.120">EC.120J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-2-2
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M EVE (7-10 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-409</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Intuition-based introduction to electronics, electronic components and test equipment such as oscilloscopes, meters (voltage, resistance inductance, capacitance, etc.), and signal generators. Emphasizes individual instruction and development of skills, such as soldering, assembly, and troubleshooting. Students design, build, and keep a small electronics project, such as a simple robot, to put their new knowledge into practice. Intended for students with little or no previous background in electronics. Enrollment may be limited.
<br><I>J. Bales</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.071"></a>
<p><h3>6.071J Electronics, Signals, and Measurement
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m22a.html#22.071">22.071J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br>URL: <a href="http://www.mit.edu:8001/courses/6.071/">http://www.mit.edu:8001/courses/6.071/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF9-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=NW14">NW14-1112</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides the knowledge necessary for reading schematics and designing, building, analyzing, and testing fundamental analog and digital circuits. Students construct interactive examples and explore the practical uses of electronics in engineering and experimental science, including signals and measurement fundamentals. Uses state-of-the-art hardware and software for data acquisition, analysis, and control. Suitable for students with little or no previous background in electronics.
<br><I>A. White</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=6.071');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.072"></a>
<p><h3>6.072J Introduction to Digital Electronics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mECa.html#EC.110">EC.110J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 0-3-3 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M EVE (7-10 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-402</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Design your own circuits for times when off-the-shelf solutions are not available. Seminar begins with assembly of a utility board. Weekly labs cover digital logic gates, memory elements, and finite-state machine design. Seminar concludes with a team-based design project. Preference given to freshmen. Maximum of 10 students per term, lottery at the first class session if oversubscribed .
<br><I>J. Bales</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.073"></a>
<p><h3>6.073J Creating Video Games
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.611">CMS.611J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mCMSa.html#CMS.608">CMS.608</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.01">6.01</a>
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces students to the complexities of working in small, multidisciplinary teams to develop video games. Covers creative design and production methods, stressing design iteration and regular testing across all aspects of game development (design, visual arts, music, fiction, and programming). Assumes a familiarity with current video games, and the ability to discuss games critically. Previous experience in audio design, visual arts, or project management recommended. Limited to 24.
<br><I>P. Tan, S. Verrilli, O. Macindoe, P. Kaelbling</I><br>
</p><!--end-->

<p><h3>6.S076-6.S084 Special Subject in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor

<br><b>6.S076:</b> <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11 (BEGINS MARCH 31)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-154</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s--><br><b>6.S077:</b> <b>Lecture:</b> <i>T4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-124</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>R2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=38">38-600</a>)<!--s--><br><b>6.S078:</b> <b>Lecture:</b> <i>R3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-144</a>)<!--s--><br><b>6.S079:</b> <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-124</a>)<!--s--><br><b>6.S080:</b> <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-155</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-134</a>) or <i>TR12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-134</a>) or <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=13">13-4101</a>) or <i>TR2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=13">13-4101</a>)<!--s--><br><b>6.S081:</b> <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-310</a>)<!--s--><br><img align="bottom" width=16 height=16 alt="Subject Cancelled" title="Subject Cancelled" src="/icns/buttonx.gif"> <i><b>6.S083 Cancelled</b></i> <!--s--><br><img align="bottom" width=16 height=16 alt="Subject Cancelled" title="Subject Cancelled" src="/icns/buttonx.gif"> <i><b>6.S084 Cancelled</b></i> <!--s-->

<a name="6.S085"></a><a name="6.S086"></a><a name="6.S087"></a><a name="6.S088"></a><a name="6.S089"></a><a name="6.S090"></a><a name="6.S091"></a><a name="6.S092"></a><a name="6.S093"></a><a name="6.S094"></a><a name="6.S095"></a><a name="6.S096"></a><a name="6.S097"></a><a name="6.S098"></a><a name="6.S099"></a>
<p><h3>6.S085-6.S099 Special Subject in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
