<h2>Undergraduate Laboratory Subjects</h2>
<a name="6.100"></a>
<p><h3>6.100 Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Project
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged
<br>Consult undergrad office <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Individual experimental work related to electrical engineering and computer science. Student must make arrangements with a project supervisor and file a proposal endorsed by the supervisor. Departmental approval required. Written report to be submitted upon completion of work.
<br><I>D. M. Freeman</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.101"></a>
<p><h3>6.101 Introductory Analog Electronics Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.002">6.002</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.071">6.071</a>
<br>Units: 2-9-1
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/6.101/www/">http://web.mit.edu/6.101/www/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-153</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introductory experimental laboratory explores the design, construction, and debugging of analog electronic circuits. Lectures and six laboratory projects investigate the performance characteristics of diodes, transistors, JFETs, and op-amps, including the construction of a small audio amplifier and preamplifier. Seven weeks are devoted to the design and implementation, and written and oral presentation of a project in an environment similar to that of engineering design teams in industry. Provides opportunity to simulate real-world problems and solutions that involve trade offs and the use of engineering judgment. Engineers from local analog engineering companies come to campus to help students with their design projects. 12 Engineering Design Points. 
<br><I>Staff</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=6.101');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.102"></a>
<p><h3>6.102 Introductory RF Design Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.002">6.002</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.071">6.071</a>
<br>Units: 2-9-1
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introductory experimental laboratory focuses on the fundamentals of radio frequency design through the study of radio receiver circuits from 1920 to 1960. Five labs using JFETs (arranged to behave like triodes and pentodes) investigate the behavior of series and parallel tuned circuits, bandwidth control, RF amplifiers, local oscillators, mixers, IF amplifiers, AM and FM detectors, audio stages, and RF measurements. Lecture topics include regenerative receivers and detectors; tuned RF, neutrodyne, superheterodyne and FM receivers; the "All-American 5" AC-DC AM receiver; and common vacuum tube triode and pentode topologies. Five weeks of the term are devoted to the restoration and circuit analysis of an antique FM-only radio or tuner and an AM-only radio or tuner, both supplied by the instructor. 12 Engineering Design Points. 
<br><I>B. M. Roscoe</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.111"></a>
<p><h3>6.111 Introductory Digital Systems Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.002">6.002</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.071">6.071</a>, or <a href="m16a.html#16.004">16.004</a>
<br>Units: 3-7-2
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Lectures and labs on digital logic, flip flops, PALs, FPGAs, counters, timing, synchronization, and finite-state machines prepare students for the design and implementation of a final project of their choice: games, music, digital filters, wireless communications, video, or graphics. Extensive use of Verilog  for describing and implementating digital logic designs. Students engage in extensive written and oral communication exercises. 12 Engineering Design Points. 
<br><I>A. P. Chandrakasan, G. P. Hom</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.115"></a>
<p><h3>6.115 Microcomputer Project Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.002">6.002</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.003">6.003</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.004">6.004</a>, or <a href="m6a.html#6.007">6.007</a>
<br>Units: 3-6-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-101</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-101</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the analysis and design of embedded systems. Microcontrollers  provide adaptation, flexibility, and real-time control. Emphasis placed on the construction of complete systems, including a five-axis robot arm, a fluorescent lamp ballast, a tomographic imaging station (e.g. a CAT scan), and a simple calculator. Introduces a wide range of basic tools, including software and development tools, peripheral components such as A/D converters, communication schemes, signal processing  techniques, closed-loop digital feedback control, interface and power electronics, and modeling of electromechanical systems. Includes a sequence of assigned projects, followed by a final project of the student's choice, emphasizing creativity and uniqueness. Final project may be expanded to satisfy a 6.UAP project.  Provides instruction in written and oral communication. 12 Engineering Design Points. 
<br><I>S. B. Leeb</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=6.115');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.117"></a>
<p><h3>6.117 Introduction to Electrical Engineering Lab Skills
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 1-3-2 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces basic electrical engineering concepts, components, and laboratory techniques. Covers analog integrated circuits, power supplies, and digital circuits. Lab exercises provide practical experience in constructing projects using multi-meters, oscilloscopes, logic analyzers, and other tools. Includes a project in which students build a circuit to display their own EKG. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>G. P. Hom</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.123"></a>
<p><h3>6.123J Bioinstrumentation Project Lab
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m20a.html#20.345">20.345J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, and <a href="m2a.html#2.004">2.004</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.003">6.003</a>; or <a href="m20a.html#20.309">20.309</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-7-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-336</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>In-depth examination of instrumentation design, principles and techniques for studying biological systems, from single molecules to entire organisms. Lectures cover optics, advanced microscopy techniques, electronics for biological measurement, magnetic resonance imaging, computed tomography, MEMs, microfluidic devices, and limits of detection. Students select two lab exercises during the first half of the semester and complete a final design project in the second half. Lab emphasizes design process and skillful realization of a robust system.
<br><I>E. Boyden, M. Jonas, S. F. Nagle, P. So, S. Wasserman, M. F. Yanik</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=6.123');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.129"></a>
<p><h3>6.129J Biological Circuit Engineering Laboratory
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m20a.html#20.129">20.129J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 2-8-2
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-121</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>MW1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-077</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students assemble individual genes and regulatory elements into larger-scale circuits; they characterize these circuits using quantitative techniques, including flow cytometry, and model their results computationally. Emphasizes concepts and techniques to perform independent synthetic biology research. Discusses current literature and ongoing research in the field of synthetic biology. Instruction and practice in oral and written communication provided. Enrollment limited. 12 Engineering Design Points. 
<br><I>T. Lu</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.131"></a>
<p><h3>6.131 Power Electronics Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.002">6.002</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.003">6.003</a>, or <a href="m6a.html#6.007">6.007</a>
<br>Units: 3-6-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the design and construction of power electronic circuits and motor drives.  Laboratory exercises include the construction of drive circuitry for an electric go-cart, flash strobes, computer power supplies, three-phase inverters for AC motors, and resonant drives for lamp ballasts and induction heating. Basic electric machines introduced include DC, induction, and permanent magnet motors, with drive considerations. Final project may be expanded to serve as a 6.UAP project, with instructor permission.  Provides instruction in written and oral communication. 12 Engineering Design Points. 
<br><I>S. B. Leeb</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.141"></a>
<p><h3>6.141J Robotics: Science and Systems I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m16a.html#16.405">16.405J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-6-4
<br>URL: <a href="http://courses.csail.mit.edu/rss/">http://courses.csail.mit.edu/rss/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-155</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>MW3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=38">38-630</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents concepts, principles, and algorithms for sensing and computation related to the physical world. Topics include motion planning, geometric reasoning, kinematics and dynamics, state estimation, tracking, map building, manipulation, human-robot interaction, fault diagnosis, and embedded system development. Students specify and design a small-scale yet complex robot capable of real-time interaction with the natural world. Students may continue content in 6.142. Prior knowledge of one or more of the following areas would be useful: control (2.004, 6.302, or 16.30); software (1.00, 6.005, or 16.35); electronics (6.002, 6.070, 6.111, or 6.115); mechanical engineering (2.007); or independent experience such as MasLAB, 6.270, or a relevant UROP. Students engage in extensive written and oral communication exercises. Enrollment limited. 12 Engineering Design Points. 
<br><I>N. Roy, D. Rus, S. Teller</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=6.141');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
<a name="6.142"></a>
<p><h3>6.142J Robotics: Science and Systems II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m16a.html#16.406">16.406J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.141">6.141</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-6-4
<br>URL: <a href="http://courses.csail.mit.edu/rss/">http://courses.csail.mit.edu/rss/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Implementation and operation of the embedded system designed in 6.141. Addresses open research issues such as sustained autonomy, situational awareness, and human interaction. Students carry out experiments to assess their design and deliver a final written report. Prior knowledge of one or more of the following areas would be useful: control (2.004, 6.302, or 16.30), software (1.00, 6.005, or 16.35), electronics (6.002, 6.070, 6.111, or 6.115), mechanical engineering (2.007), independent experience (MasLAB, 6.270, or a UROP). 12 Engineering Design Points. 
<br><I>D. Rus, S. Teller, N. Roy</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.145"></a>
<p><h3>6.145 Autonomous Robot Design Competition
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 1-2-2 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Teams build an autonomous LEGO robot and compete for prizes. Provides an opportunity to explore closed-loop control and artificial intelligence, and apply knowledge of algorithms and signal processing. Crash course in programming available to students without experience in robotics. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.146"></a>
<p><h3>6.146 Mobile Autonomous Systems Laboratory: MASLAB
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-2-2 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Autonomous robotics contest emphasizing technical AI, vision, mapping and navigation from a robot-mounted camera. Few restrictions are placed on materials, sensors, and/or actuators enabling teams to build robots very creatively. Teams should have members with varying engineering, programming and mechanical backgrounds. Culminates with a robot competition at the end of IAP. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.147"></a>
<p><h3>6.147 The BattleCode Programming Competition
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-3 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Artificial Intelligence programming contest in Java. Student teams program virtual robots to play BattleCode, a real-time strategy game. Competition culminates in a live BattleCode tournament. Assumes basic knowledge of programming in Java.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.148"></a>
<p><h3>6.148 Web Programming Competition
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 1-0-5 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Teams compete to build the most functional and user-friendly website. Competition is judged by industry experts and includes novice and advanced divisions. Prizes awarded. Lectures and workshops cover website basics. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.149"></a>

<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)

<a name="6.150"></a>
<p><h3>6.150 Mobile Applications Competition
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-2-2 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Student teams design and build an Android application based on a given theme. Lectures and labs led by experienced students and leading industry experts, covering the basics of Android development, concepts and tools to help participants build great apps. Contest culminates with a public presentation in front of a judging panel comprised of professional developers and MIT faculty. Prizes awarded. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.151"></a>
<p><h3>6.151 iOS Game Design and Development Competition
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-2-2 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to iOS game design and development for students already familiar with object-oriented programming. Provides a set of basic tools (Objective-C and Cocos2D) and exposure to real-world issues in game design. Working in small teams, students complete a final project in which they create their own iPhone game. At the end of IAP, teams present their games in competition for prizes awarded by a judging panel of gaming experts. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.152"></a>
<p><h3>6.152J Micro/Nano Processing Technology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m3a.html#3.155">3.155J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-4-5
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the theory and technology of micro/nano fabrication. Lectures and laboratory sessions on basic processing techniques such as vacuum processes, lithography, diffusion, oxidation, and pattern transfer. Students fabricate MOS capacitors, nanomechanical cantilevers, and microfluidic mixers. Emphasis on the interrelationships between material properties and processing, device structure, and the electrical, mechanical, optical, chemical  or biological behavior of devices. Provides background for thesis work in micro/nano fabrication. Students engage in extensive written and oral communication exercises.  6 Engineering Design Points. 
<br><I>A. Agarwal, L. A. Kolodziejski, M. A. Schmidt</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.161"></a>
<p><h3>6.161 Modern Optics Project Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6b.html#6.637">6.637</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.003">6.003</a>
<br>Units: 3-5-4
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/6.161/www/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/6.161/www/index.html</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Lectures, laboratory exercises and projects on optical signal generation, transmission, detection, storage, processing and display. Topics include polarization properties of light; reflection and refraction; coherence and interference; Fraunhofer and Fresnel diffraction; holography; Fourier optics; coherent and incoherent imaging and signal processing systems; optical properties of materials; lasers and LEDs; electro-optic and acousto-optic light modulators; photorefractive and liquid-crystal light modulation; display technologies; optical waveguides and fiber-optic communication systems; photodetectors. Students may use this subject to find an advanced undergraduate project. Students engage in extensive oral and written communcation exercises. Recommended prerequisites: 6.007 or 8.03. 12 Engineering Design Points. 
<br><I>C. Warde</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.163"></a>
<p><h3>6.163 Strobe Project Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-8-2
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-149</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>TBA</i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Application of electronic flash sources to measurement and   photography. First half covers fundamentals of photography and   electronic flashes, including experiments on application of electronic   flash to photography, stroboscopy, motion analysis, and high-speed   videography. Students write five extensive lab reports.  In the second half, students work in small groups to select, design,   and execute independent projects in measurement or photography that apply learned techniques. Project planning and execution skills are discussed and developed over the term.  Students engage in extensive written and oral communication exercises. Enrollment limited. 12 Engineering Design Points. 
<br><I>J. K. Vandiver, J. W. Bales</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.169"></a>

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)

<br>Units: 1-1-1
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TBA</i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Building on the framework of 6.002, provides a deeper understanding of the theory and applications of circuits and electronics.
<br><I>A. Agarwal, J. del Alamo, J. H. Lang, D. J. Perreault</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)

<a name="6.182"></a>
<p><h3>6.182 Psychoacoustics Project Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-6-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-308</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the methods used to measure human auditory abilities. Discusses auditory function, principles of psychoacoustic measurement, models for psychoacoustic performance, and experimental techniques. Project topics: absolute and differential auditory sensitivity, operating characteristics of human observers, span of auditory judgment, adaptive measurement procedures, and scaling sensory magnitudes. Knowledge of probability helpful. Students engage in extensive written and oral communication exercises. 12 Engineering Design Points. 
<br><I>L. D. Braida</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->

<h2>Advanced Undergraduate Subjects and Graduate Subjects by Area</h2>
<h3>Systems Science and Control Engineering</h3>
<a name="6.207"></a>
<p><h3>6.207J Networks
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m14a.html#14.15">14.15J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.041">6.041</a> or <a href="m14a.html#14.30">14.30</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-155</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-156</a>) or <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-144</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Highlights common principles that permeate the functioning of diverse technological, economic and social networks. Utilizes three sets of tools for analyzing networks--random graph models, optimization, and game theory--to study informational and learning cascades; economic and financial networks; social influence networks; formation of social groups; communication networks and the Internet; consensus and gossiping; spread and control of epidemics; control and use of energy networks; and biological networks.
<br>Consult D. Acemoglu, M. Dahleh<br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=6.207');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.231"></a>
<p><h3>6.231 Dynamic Programming and Stochastic Control
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.041">6.041</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.313">18.313</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.100">18.100</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/6.231/www/6231.html">http://web.mit.edu/6.231/www/6231.html</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Sequential decision-making via dynamic programming. Unified approach to optimal control of stochastic dynamic systems and Markovian decision problems. Applications in linear-quadratic control, inventory control, resource allocation, scheduling, and planning. Optimal decision making under perfect and imperfect state information. Certainty equivalent, open loop-feedback control, rollout,  aggregation, and other suboptimal control methods. Infinite horizon problems: discounted, stochastic shortest path, average cost, and semi-Markov models. Value and policy iteration. Approximate/neurodynamic programming. Simulation based methods. Discussion of current research on the solution of large-scale problems.
<br><I>D. P. Bertsekas</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.241"></a>
<p><h3>6.241J Dynamic Systems and Control
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m16a.html#16.338">16.338J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.003">6.003</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=37">37-212</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-328</a>) or <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-328</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Linear, discrete- and continuous-time, multi-input-output systems in control, related areas. Least squares and matrix perturbation problems. State-space models, modes, stability, controllability, observability, transfer function matrices, poles and zeros, and minimality. Internal stability of interconnected systems, feedback compensators, state feedback, optimal regulation, observers, and observer-based compensators. Measures of control performance, robustness issues using singular values of transfer functions. Introductory ideas on nonlinear systems. Recommended prerequisite: 6.302.
<br><I>M. A. Dahleh, A. Megretski, E. Frazzoli</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.242"></a>
<p><h3>6.242 Advanced Linear Control Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.241">6.241</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to uncertain multivariable control systems, plus modeling assumptions and objectives. Stability of linear time invariant systems, coprime factorization, parametrization of all stabilizing compensators. Design using H<SUB>2</SUB>, H&infin; L<SUP>1</SUP> -optimization. Stability and performance robustness in the presence of structured uncertainty.
<br><I>M. A. Dahleh, A. Megretski</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.243"></a>
<p><h3>6.243 Dynamics of Nonlinear Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.241">6.241</a>; <I>Coreq: <a href="m18a.html#18.100">18.100</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to nonlinear deterministic dynamical systems. Nonlinear ordinary differential equations. Planar autonomous systems. Fundamental theory: Picard iteration, contraction mapping theorem, and Bellman-Gronwall lemma. Stability of equilibria by Lyapunov's first and second methods. Feedback linearization. Application to nonlinear circuits and control systems.
<br><I>J. L. Wyatt, Jr., A. Megretski, M. Dahleh</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.245"></a>
<p><h3>6.245 Multivariable Control Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.241">6.241</a> or <a href="m16a.html#16.31">16.31</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/6.245/www/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/6.245/www/index.html</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Computer-aided design methodologies for synthesis of multivariable feedback control systems. Performance and robustness trade-offs. Model-based compensators; Q-parameterization; ill-posed optimization problems; dynamic augmentation; linear-quadratic optimization of controllers; H-infinity controller design; Mu-synthesis; model and compensator simplification; nonlinear effects. Computer-aided (MATLAB) design homework using models of physical processes.  6 Engineering Design Points. 
<br><I>A. Megretski</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.246"></a><a name="6.247"></a>
<p><h3>6.246, 6.247 Advanced Topics in Control
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Advanced study of topics in control. Specific focus varies from year to year.
<br>Consult Department<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.248"></a><a name="6.249"></a>
<p><h3>6.248, 6.249 Advanced Topics in Numerical Methods
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department

<a name="6.251"></a>
<p><h3>6.251J Introduction to Mathematical Programming
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m15a.html#15.081">15.081J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to linear optimization and its extensions emphasizing both methodology and the underlying mathematical structures and geometrical ideas. Covers classical theory of linear programming as well as some recent advances in the field. Topics: simplex method; duality theory; sensitivity analysis; network flow problems; decomposition; integer programming; interior point algorithms for linear programming; and introduction to combinatorial optimization and NP-completeness.
<br><I>J. N. Tsitsiklis, A. Schulz</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.252"></a>
<p><h3>6.252J Nonlinear Programming
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m15a.html#15.084">15.084J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.100">18.100</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-361</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F10.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-390</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A unified analytical and computational approach to nonlinear optimization problems. Unconstrained optimization methods include gradient, conjugate direction, Newton, and quasi-Newton methods. Constrained optimization methods include feasible directions, projection, interior point, and Lagrange multiplier methods. Convex analysis, Lagrangian relaxation, nondifferentiable optimization, and applications in integer programming. Comprehensive treatment of optimality conditions, Lagrange multiplier theory, and duality theory. Applications drawn from control, communications, power systems, and resource allocation problems.
<br><I>R. M. Freund, D. P. Bertsekas, G. Perakis</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=6.252');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.253"></a>
<p><h3>6.253 Convex Analysis and Optimization
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.100">18.100</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-141</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Core analytical issues of continuous optimization, duality, and saddle point theory, and development using a handful of unifying principles that can be easily visualized and readily understood. Discusses in detail the mathematical theory of convex sets and functions which are the basis for an intuitive, highly visual, geometrical approach to the subject. Convex optimization algorithms focus on large-scale problems, drawn from several types of applications, such as resource allocation and machine learning. Includes batch and incremental subgradient, cutting plane, proximal, and bundle methods.
<br><I>D. P. Bertsekas</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=6.253');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.254"></a>
<p><h3>6.254 Game Theory with Engineering Applications
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.041">6.041</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to fundamentals of game theory and mechanism design with motivations for each topic drawn from engineering applications (including distributed control of wireline/wireless communication networks, transportation networks, pricing). Emphasis on the foundations of the theory, mathematical tools, as well as modeling and the equilibrium notion in different environments. Topics include normal form games, supermodular games, dynamic games, repeated games, games with incomplete/imperfect information, mechanism design, cooperative game theory, and network games.
<br><I>A. Ozdaglar</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.255"></a>
<p><h3>6.255J Optimization Methods
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m15a.html#15.093">15.093J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the principal algorithms for linear, network, discrete, robust, nonlinear, dynamic optimization and optimal control. Emphasizes methodology and the underlying mathematical structures. Topics include the simplex method, network flow methods, branch and bound and cutting plane methods for discrete optimization, optimality conditions for nonlinear optimization, interior point methods for convex optimization, Newton's method, heuristic methods, and dynamic programming and optimal control methods.
<br><I>D. Bertsimas, P. Parrilo</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.256"></a>
<p><h3>6.256 Algebraic Techniques and Semidefinite Optimization
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.251">6.251</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.255">6.255</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>WF1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=13">13-3101</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Theory and computational techniques for optimization problems involving polynomial equations and inequalities with particular, emphasis on the connections with semidefinite optimization. Develops algebraic and numerical approaches of general applicability, with a view towards methods that simultaneously incorporate both elements, stressing convexity-based ideas, complexity results, and efficient implementations. Examples from several engineering areas, in particular systems and control applications. Topics include semidefinite programming, resultants/discriminants, hyperbolic polynomials, Groebner bases, quantifier elimination, and sum of squares.
<br><I>P. Parrilo</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=6.256');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.260"></a><a name="6.261"></a>
<p><h3>6.260, 6.261 Advanced Topics in Communications
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<br>Units: 3-0-9

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Advanced study of topics in communications. Specific focus varies from year to year.
<br>Consult Department<br><b>6.261:</b> No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.262"></a>
<p><h3>6.262 Discrete Stochastic Processes
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.041">6.041</a>, <a href="m6b.html#6.431">6.431</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.313">18.313</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-154</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Review of probability and laws of large numbers; Poisson counting process and renewal processes; Markov chains (including Markov decision theory), branching processes, birth-death processes, and semi-Markov processes; continuous-time Markov chains and reversibility; random walks, martingales, and large deviations; applications from queueing, communication, control, and operations research.
<br><I>R. G. Gallager, J. L. Wyatt</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=6.262');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.263"></a>
<p><h3>6.263J Data-Communication Networks
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m16a.html#16.37">16.37J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.041">6.041</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.313">18.313</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to data networks with an analytic perspective, using  telephone networks, wireless networks, optical networks, the Internet and data centers as primary applications. Presents basic tools for modeling and performance analysis accompanied by elementary, meaningful simulations. Develops insights for large networks by means of simple approximations. Draws upon concepts from queueing theory and optimization.
<br><I>E. Modiano, D. Shah</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.264"></a>
<p><h3>6.264J Queues: Theory and Applications
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m15a.html#15.072">15.072J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.262">6.262</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Modeling and analysis of queueing systems, with applications in communications, manufacturing, computers, call centers, service industries and transportation. Topics include birth-death processes and simple Markovian queues, networks of queues and product form networks, single and multi-server queues, multi-class queueing networks, fluid models, adversarial queueing networks, heavy-traffic theory and diffusion approximations. Covers state of the art results which lead to research opportunities.
<br><I>D. Bertsimas, D. Gamarnik, J. N. Tsitsiklis</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.265"></a>
<p><h3>6.265J Advanced Stochastic Processes
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m15a.html#15.070">15.070J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6b.html#6.431">6.431</a>, <a href="m15a.html#15.085">15.085J</a>, or <a href="m18a.html#18.100">18.100</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analysis and modeling of stochastic processes. Topics include measure theoretic probability, martingales, filtration, and stopping theorems; elements of large deviations theory; Brownian motion and reflected Brownian motion; stochastic integration and Ito calculus; functional limit theorems. Applications to finance theory, insurance, queueing and inventory models.
<br><I>D. Gamarnik, D. Shah</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.266"></a>
<p><h3>6.266 Network Algorithms
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6b.html#6.436">6.436</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.262">6.262</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Modern theory of networks from the algorithmic perspective with emphasis on the foundations in terms of modeling, performance analysis, and design. Topics include algorithmic questions arising in the context of scheduling, routing and congestion control in a communication network; information processing and data fusion in peer-to-peer, sensor and social networks; and efficient data storage/retrieval in a distributed storage network.
<br><I>D. Shah</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.267"></a>
<p><h3>6.267 Heterogeneous Networks: Architecture, Transport, Proctocols, and Management
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.041">6.041</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.042">6.042</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to modern heterogeneous networks and the provision of heterogeneous services. Architectural principles, analysis, algorithmic techniques, performance analysis, and existing designs are developed and applied to understand current problems in network design and architecture. Begins with basic principles of networking. Emphasizes development of mathematical and algorithmic tools; applies them to understanding network layer design from the performance and scalability viewpoint. Concludes with network management and control, including the architecture and performance analysis of interconnected heterogeneous networks. Provides background and insight to understand current network literature and to perform research on networks with the aid of network design projects.  4 Engineering Design Points. 
<br><I>V. W. S. Chan, R. G. Gallager</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.268"></a>
<p><h3>6.268 Network Science and Models
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.041">6.041</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the main mathematical models used to describe large networks and dynamical processes that evolve on networks. Static models of random graphs, preferential attachment, and other graph evolution models.  Epidemic propagation, opinion dynamics, and social learning. Applications drawn from social, economic, natural, and infrastructure networks, as well as networked decision systems such as sensor networks.
<br><I>J. N. Tsitsiklis, P. Jaillet</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.281"></a>
<p><h3>6.281J Logistical and Transportation Planning Methods
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1b.html#1.203">1.203J</A>, <A HREF="m15a.html#15.073">15.073J</A>, <A HREF="m16b.html#16.76">16.76J</A>, <A HREF="mESDa.html#ESD.216">ESD.216J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.041">6.041</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Quantitative techniques of operations research with emphasis on applications in transportation systems analysis (urban, air, ocean, highway, and pickup and delivery systems) and in the planning and design of logistically oriented urban service systems (e.g., fire and police departments, emergency medical services, and emergency repair services). Unified study of functions of random variables, geometrical probability, multi-server queuing theory, spatial location theory, network analysis and graph theory, and relevant methods of simulation. Computer exercises and discussions of implementation difficulties.
<br><I>R. C. Larson, A. R. Odoni, A. I. Barnett</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.291"></a>
<p><h3>6.291 Seminar in Systems, Communications, and Control Research
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Advanced topics in systems, communications, control, optimization, and signal processing. Topics selected according to student and instructor interest. See instructor for specific topics to be offered in a particular term.
<br><I>S. K. Mitter</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
</td></tr></table>
