<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Course 7: Biology<br>Spring
2014</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="https://biology.mit.edu/"><i>Course 7 Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course7.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=+++7&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>7.00-7.999 plus UROP and Thesis</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<h2>Undergraduate Subjects</h2>
<h3><br>Introductory Biology</h3>
<p>All five subjects cover the same core material, comprising about 50% of the course, while the remaining material is specialized for each version as described below. Core material includes fundamental principles of biochemistry, genetics, molecular biology, and cell biology. These topics address structure and regulation of genes, structure and synthesis of proteins, how these molecules are integrated into cells and how cells communicate with one another. Specialized material includes a focus on genomic approaches to human health (7.012), genomic approaches, focusing on human disorders, neuroscience, development and repair (7.013), ecology and the biosphere (7.014), microbiology and immunology (7.015), biochemistry and molecular genetics (7.016).
<a name="7.012"></a>
<p><h3>7.012 Introductory Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/bio.gif" alt="Biology" title="Biology" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m7a.html#7.013">7.013</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.014">7.014</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.015">7.015</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.016">7.016</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.7012">ES.7012</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.7013">ES.7013</A>
<br>URL: <a href="https://biology.mit.edu/course_listings_undergraduate/701x_introductory_biology">https://biology.mit.edu/course_listings_undergraduate/701x_introductory_biology</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Exploration into areas of current research in cell biology, immunology, neurobiology, human genetics, developmental biology, and evolution. Enrollment limited to seating capacity of classroom. Admittance may be controlled by lottery.
<br><I>E. Lander, R. Weinberg</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.013"></a>
<p><h3>7.013 Introductory Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/bio.gif" alt="Biology" title="Biology" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m7a.html#7.012">7.012</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.014">7.014</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.015">7.015</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.016">7.016</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.7012">ES.7012</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.7013">ES.7013</A>
<br>URL: <a href="https://biology.mit.edu/course_listings_undergraduate/701x_introductory_biology">https://biology.mit.edu/course_listings_undergraduate/701x_introductory_biology</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-100</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>MW1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-204</a>) or <i>MW2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-204</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-210</a>) or <i>MW3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-204</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-210</a>) or <i>TR10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-204</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-210</a>) or <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-204</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-210</a>) or <i>TR12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-210</a>) or <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-204</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-210</a>) or <i>TR2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-204</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Genomic approaches to human biology, focusing on neuroscience, development, repair and disease (including infectious agents, inherited diseases and cancer. Enrollment limited to seating capacity of classroom. Admittance may be controlled by lottery.
<br><I>T. Jacks, H. Sive</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=7.013');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.014"></a>
<h3>7.014 Introductory Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/bio.gif" alt="Biology" title="Biology" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m7a.html#7.012">7.012</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.013">7.013</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.015">7.015</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.016">7.016</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.7012">ES.7012</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.7013">ES.7013</A>
<br>URL: <a href="https://biology.mit.edu/course_listings_undergraduate/701x_introductory_biology">https://biology.mit.edu/course_listings_undergraduate/701x_introductory_biology</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E25">E25-111</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-112</a>) or <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-112</a>) or <i>TR12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=38">38-166</a>) or <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=38">38-166</a>) or <i>TR12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-261</a>) or <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-261</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Application of the fundamental principles toward an understanding of microorganisms as geochemical agents responsible for the evolution and renewal of the biosphere and of their role in human health and disease. Topics include biogeochemical cycles; population growth; ecosystem ecology; microbial diversity. Enrollment limited to seating capacity of classroom. Admittance may be controlled by lottery.
<br><I>G. C. Walker, S. W. Chisholm</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=7.014');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.015"></a>
<p><h3>7.015 Introductory Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/bio.gif" alt="Biology" title="Biology" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Advanced high school course covering cellular and molecular biology, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m7a.html#7.012">7.012</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.013">7.013</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.014">7.014</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.016">7.016</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.7012">ES.7012</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.7013">ES.7013</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Emphasizes the application of the fundamental principles to trending topics in microbiology- and immunology-related issues, and allows students to understand how biological principles are used in a direct, human health context. Introduces evolutionary principles, demonstrating their relevance to current topics in infectious diseases. Includes written assignments, discussions, and group presentations. Enrollment limited to 60. Admittance may be controlled by lottery.
<br><I>M. Laub, H. Ploegh</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.016"></a>
<p><h3>7.016 Introductory Biology
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/bio.gif" alt="Biology" title="Biology" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m7a.html#7.012">7.012</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.013">7.013</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.014">7.014</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.015">7.015</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.7012">ES.7012</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.7013">ES.7013</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to fundamental principles of biochemistry, molecular biology and genetics for understanding the functions of living systems. Covers examples of the use of chemical biology and 21st-century molecular genetics in understanding human health and therapeutic intervention. Enrollment limited to seating capacity of classroom. Admittance may be controlled by lottery.
<br><I>A. Amon, B. Imperiali, D. Page</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.02"></a>
<p><h3>7.02J Introduction to Experimental Biology and Communication
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m10a.html#10.702">10.702J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-8-6
<br>1st lec mandatory. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-270</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-074</a>) or <i>WF1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-074</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>M9-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-144</a>) or <i>M1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=12">12-134</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-191</a>) or <i>T9-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-148</a>) or <i>W9-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-121</a>) or <i>W1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=14">14N-112</a>) or <i>R9-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-144</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the experimental concepts and methods of molecular biology, biochemistry, and genetic analysis. Emphasis on experimental design, critical data analysis, and the development of written communications skills. 12 units may be applied to the General Institute Laboratory Requirement. Concurrent registration with 7.03 strongly recommended. Enrollment limited.
<br>Fall: <I>L. Boyer, P. Gupta</I><br>Spring: <I>M. Gehring,  T. Schwartz</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.03"></a>
<p><h3>7.03 Genetics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>URL: <a href="https://biology.mit.edu/course_listings_undergraduate/703_genetics">https://biology.mit.edu/course_listings_undergraduate/703_genetics</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-123</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>M1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-310</a>) or <i>M2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-310</a>) or <i>M3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-310</a>) or <i>T10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-310</a>) or <i>T11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-310</a>) or <i>T12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-310</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>The principles of genetics with application to the study of biological function at the level of molecules, cells, and multicellular organisms, including humans. Structure and function of genes, chromosomes, and genomes. Biological variation resulting from recombination, mutation, and selection. Population genetics. Use of genetic methods to analyze protein function, gene regulation, and inherited disease.
<br>Fall: <I>G. Fink, P. Reddien</I><br>Spring: <I>M. Hemann, A. Regev</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.05"></a>
<p><h3>7.05 General Biochemistry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.12">5.12</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m5a.html#5.07">5.07</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.507">20.507</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=10">10-250</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>M3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-314</a>) or <i>T12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-204</a>) or <i>T4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-314</a>) or <i>T EVE (7 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-314</a>) or <i>W1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-210</a>) or <i>R11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-302</a>) or <i>R EVE (7 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-314</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-328</a>) or <i>F3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-314</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Contributions of biochemistry toward an understanding of the structure and functioning of organisms, tissues, and cells. Chemistry and functions of constituents of cells and tissues and the chemical and physical-chemical basis for the structures of nucleic acids, proteins, and carbohydrates. General metabolism of carbohydrates, fats, and nitrogen-containing materials such as amino acids, proteins, and related compounds.
<br><I>G. M. Brown, M. Vander Heiden, M. Yaffe</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=7.05');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.06"></a>
<p><h3>7.06 Cell Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-270</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-308</a>) or <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-308</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-308</a>) or <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-310</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents the biology of cells of higher organisms.  Studies the structure, function, and biosynthesis of cellular membranes and organelles; cell growth and oncogenic transformation; transport, receptors, and cell signaling; the cytoskeleton, the extracellular matrix, and cell movements; cell division and cell cycle; functions of specialized cell types.  Emphasizes the current molecular knowledge of cell biological processes as well as the genetic, biochemical, and other experimental approaches that resulted in these discoveries.
<br>Fall: <I>A. Martin, S. Bell, T. Littleton</I><br>Spring: <I>I. Cheeseman, T. Orr-Weaver</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=7.06');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.08"></a>
<p><h3>7.08J Biological Chemistry II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m5a.html#5.08">5.08J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.80">7.80</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.12">5.12</a>; <a href="m5a.html#5.07">5.07</a> or <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-105</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-132</a>) or <i>R1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-132</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-132</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-132</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>More advanced treatment of biochemical mechanisms that underlie biological processes.  Topics include macromolecular machines such as the ribosome, the proteosome, fatty acid synthases as a paradigm for polyketide synthases and non-ribosomal polypeptide synthases, and polymerases. Emphasis is on experimental methods used to unravel these processes and how these processes fit into the cellular context and coordinate regulation.
<br><I>J. Stubbe, E. Nolan</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.10"></a>
<p><h3>7.10J Physical Chemistry of Biomolecular Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m20a.html#20.111">20.111J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>; <I>Coreq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a></I>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m2b.html#2.772">2.772</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.110">20.110</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-370</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>M2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-145</a>) or <i>T1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=8">8-205</a>) or <i>R1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=8">8-205</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides a quantitative approach to understanding the physical and chemical laws that govern the behavior of biological macromolecules.  Basic thermodynamics, state of a system, state variables. Work, heat, first, second, and third laws of thermodynamics.  Entropy and its statistical basis, free energy representations, Legendre transforms, Maxwell relations, Gibbs function, Boltzmann distribution and partition functions.  Equilibrium properties of macroscopic and microscopic systems; macromolecular structure and interactions in solution. Driving forces for molecular self-assembly. Binding, cooperativity, solvation, and titration of macromolecules. Meets with 5.60 first half of term.
<br><I>E. Alm, C. Voigt</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=7.10');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.11"></a>
<p><h3>7.11 Biology Teaching
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>For qualified undergraduate students interested in gaining some experience in teaching. Laboratory, tutorial, or classroom teaching under the supervision of a faculty member. Students selected by interview.
<br>Consult Biology Education Office<br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.13"></a>
<p><h3>7.13 Experimental Microbial Genetics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.02">7.02</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>
<br>Units: 4-16-10
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Molecular genetics used to examine the biology of genetically tractable organisms, including questions of development, physiology, and stress responses. Experiments may involve the bacterium <i>Caulobacter crescentus</i> and/or the nematode <i>Caenorhabditis elegans</i>. Projects aim to discover the molecular basis for physiological processes using traditional and cutting-edge techniques. Basic methodology that will be covered includes plasmid manipulation, genetic complementation, mutagenesis, PCR, DNA sequencing, enzyme assays, and gene expression studies. instruction and practice in written and oral communication provided. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.15"></a>
<p><h3>7.15 Experimental Molecular Genetics
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.02">7.02</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>
<br>Units: 4-16-10
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MTWRF1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-156</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>MTWRF1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-089</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>In this project-based laboratory subject, students carry out independent experiments that develop skills in the planning, execution, and analysis of original experimental biological research. Specific research topic, which is determined by teaching staff, involves the application of modern methods of molecular genetics. Reading and writing assignments focus on the critical evaluation and discussion of relevant scientific literature. Emphasis placed on instruction in laboratory methods and the testing of hypotheses, as well as the critical analysis of experimental results. Designed for sophomores with a strong interest in research; serves as a bridge between the introductory laboratory subject (7.02) and independent research opportunities at MIT.
<br><I>D. Kim</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=7.15');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.16"></a>
<p><h3>7.16 Experimental Molecular Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.02">7.02</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>
<br>Units: 4-16-10
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Applies high-throughput genetic approaches to study the  response of mammalian cells to cytotoxic or infectious stimuli. RNA interference (RNAi) screening and microarray expression analysis will be used to examine the genetics of cellular pro-survival and pro-death pathways.  Teams of two or three students design and carry out experiments to address questions regarding the mechanisms that govern the regulation and execution of cellular responses. Some projects involve the use of DNA damaging agents or other cytotoxic drugs to help understand the pathways that control a cell's response to chemotherapy. Other projects examine the genes that underlie the cellular response to conserved pathogen molecules. Instruction and practice in written and oral communication provided.
<br><I>J. Saeij</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.18"></a>
<p><h3>7.18 Topics in Experimental Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.19">7.19</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.02">7.02</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>
<br>Units: 4-16-10
<br>URL: <a href="https://biology.mit.edu/undergraduate/course_listings/project_labs/718_topics_experimental_biology">https://biology.mit.edu/undergraduate/course_listings/project_labs/718_topics_experimental_biology</a>
<br><b>Compulsory:</b> <i>1st Mtg Feb 5 At 9 Am (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-180</a>)</i> <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-156</a>) or <i>TR9-11</i> (Whitehead-7TH)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Independent experimental study under the direction of a member of the Biology Department faculty. Allows students with a strong interest in independent research to fulfill the project laboratory requirement for the Biology Department Program in the context of a research laboratory at MIT. The research must be conducted on the MIT campus and be a continuation of a previous 12-unit UROP project or full-time work over the summer. Written and oral presentation of the research results is required. Journal club discussions are used to help students evaluate and write scientific papers. Instruction and practice in written and oral communication is provided. Permission of the faculty research supervisor and the Biology Education Office must be obtained in advance.
<br>Fall: <I>M. L. Pardue, A. J. Sinskey</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Chen, S. Lindquist</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.19"></a>
<p><h3>7.19 Communication in Experimental Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.18">7.18</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.02">7.02</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>
<br>Units: 4-4-4
<br>URL: <a href="https://biology.mit.edu/undergraduate/course_listings/project_labs/718_topics_experimental_biology">https://biology.mit.edu/undergraduate/course_listings/project_labs/718_topics_experimental_biology</a>
<br><b>Compulsory:</b> <i>1st Mtg Feb 5 At 9 Am (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-180</a>)</i> <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-156</a>) or <i>TR9-11</i> (Whitehead-7TH)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students carry out independent literature research. Meets with the seminar and writing tutorial portions of 7.18. Journal club discussions are used to help students evaluate and write scientific papers. Instruction and practice in written and oral communication is provided. Permission of the instructor and the Biology Education Office must be obtained in advance.
<br>Fall: <I>M. L. Pardue, A. J. Sinskey</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Chen, S. Lindquist</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.20"></a>
<p><h3>7.20J Human Physiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.540">HST.540J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Comprehensive subject in human physiology, emphasizing the molecular basis and applied aspects of organ function and regulation in health and disease. Includes a review of cell structure and function, as well as the mechanisms by which the endocrine and nervous systems integrate cellular metabolism. Special emphasis on examining the cardiovascular, pulmonary, gastrointestinal, and renal systems.
<br><I>M. Krieger, D. Sabatini</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.21"></a>
<p><h3>7.21 Microbial Physiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.62">7.62</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Biochemical properties of bacteria and other microorganisms that enable them to grow under a variety of conditions. Interaction between bacteria and bacteriophages. Genetic and metabolic regulation of enzyme action and enzyme formation. Structure and function of components of the bacterial cell envelope. Protein secretion with a special emphasis on its various roles in pathogenesis. Additional topics include bioenergetics, symbiosis, quorum sensing, global responses to DNA damage, and biofilms.  Students taking the graduate version are expected to explore the subject in greater depth.
<br><I>G. C. Walker, A. J. Sinskey</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.22"></a>
<p><h3>7.22 Development and Evolution
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Topics include development of animal body plans, tissue patterning, cell type determination, organogenesis, morphogenesis, stem cells, and the evolution of developmental diversity and processes. Covers experimental approaches to problems of development and evolution, such as the study of vertebrate (mouse, chick, frog, fish) and invertebrate (fly, worm) models.
<br><I>R. O. Hynes, P. Reddien</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.23"></a>
<p><h3>7.23 Immunology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.63">7.63</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-154</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-168</a>) or <i>W EVE (7 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-168</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Comprehensive survey of molecular, genetic, and cellular aspects of the immune system. Topics include innate and adaptive immunity; cells and organs of the immune system; immunoglobulin, T cell receptor, and major histocompatibility complex (MHC) proteins and genes; development and functions of B and T lymphocytes; immune responses to infections and tumors; hypersensitivity, autoimmunity, and immunodeficiencies. Particular attention to the development and function of the immune system as a whole, as studied by modern methods and techniques. Students taking the graduate version are expected to explore the subject in greater depth.
<br><I>H. Ploegh, J. Chen, L. Steiner</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=7.23');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.25"></a>
<p><h3>7.25 Biological Regulatory Mechanisms
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.02">7.02</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Cells utilize a variety of mechanisms to regulate gene expression, growth, development, and behavior in response to both external and internal conditions. Examines basic principles of biological regulation, focusing on several well-studied examples, usually drawn from microbial species. Reading includes primary literature and review articles with emphasis on how we know what we know, and how to think experimentally.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.26"></a>
<p><h3>7.26 Molecular Basis of Infectious Disease
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.66">7.66</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-333</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>R3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-167</a>) or <i>F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-154</a>) or <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-154</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on the principles of host-pathogen interactions with an emphasis on infectious diseases of humans. Presents key concepts of pathogenesis through the study of various human pathogens. Includes critical analysis and discussion of assigned readings.  Students taking the graduate version are expected to explore the subject in greater depth.
<br><I>D. Kim, J. Saeij</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.27"></a>
<p><h3>7.27 Principles of Human Disease
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-144</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>R3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-204</a>) or <i>F9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-328</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers current understanding of and modern approaches to human disease, emphasizing the molecular and cellular basis of both genetic disease and cancer. Topics include the genetics of simple and complex traits; karyotypic analysis and positional cloning; genetic diagnosis; the roles of oncogenes and tumor suppressors in tumor initiation, progression, and treatment; the interaction between genetics and environment; animal models of human disease; cancer; aging and disease; and conventional and gene therapy treatment strategies.
<br><I>D. Housman, L. Guarente</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.28"></a>
<p><h3>7.28 Molecular Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.58">7.58</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>; <I>Coreq: <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a></I>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-370</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-160</a>) or <i>W12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-160</a>) or <i>W EVE (7 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-160</a>) or <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-160</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Detailed analysis of the biochemical mechanisms that control the maintenance, expression, and evolution of prokaryotic and eukaryotic genomes. Topics covered in lecture and readings of relevant literature include: gene regulation, DNA replication, genetic recombination, and mRNA translation. Logic of experimental design and data analysis emphasized. Presentations include both lectures and group discussions of representative papers from the literature. Students taking the graduate version are expected to explore the subject in greater depth.
<br><I>T. Baker, S. Bell, W.Gilbert</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=7.28');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.29"></a>
<p><h3>7.29J Cellular and Molecular Neurobiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m9a.html#9.09">9.09J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-3310</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-1015</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the structure and function of the nervous system. Emphasizes the cellular properties of neurons and other excitable cells. Includes the structure and biophysical properties of excitable cells, synaptic transmission, neurochemistry, neurodevelopment, integration of information in simple systems, and detection and information coding during sensory transduction.
<br><I>W. G. Quinn, T. Littleton</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=7.29');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.30"></a>
<p><h3>7.30J Ecology I: The Earth System
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1a.html#1.018">1.018J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-1-8
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/7.30j">http://web.mit.edu/7.30j</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Fundamentals of ecology, considering Earth as an integrated dynamic living system. Coevolution of the biosphere, geosphere, atmosphere and oceans. Introduction to biological energy transfer and thermodynamics. The Earth's energy budget. Photosynthesis and respiration. The hydrologic, carbon, phosphorus, and nitrogen cycles. Flow of energy and materials through ecosystems, regulation of the distribution and abundance of organisms, structure and function of ecosystems. Metabolic diversity; productivity. Trophic dynamics; models of population growth, competition, mutualism and predation. Instruction and practice in oral and written communication provided. 7.012-7.014 recommended.
<br><I>E. DeLong, A. Mueller</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.31"></a>
<p><h3>7.31 Current Topics in Mammalian Biology: Medical Implications
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers recent advances in mammalian cell and developmental biology with particular emphasis on approaches that utilize mouse genetics. Combines formal lectures on selected topics with readings of original papers which are discussed in class. Major emphasis on the implications of mechanisms of human genetic diseases. Topics include early mammalian development; genomic imprinting; X inactivation; embryonic stem cells; nuclear reprogramming of somatic cells; cell migration; nervous system development; and central nervous system degenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's and Huntington's disease. Limited to 20.
<br><I>F. Gertler, R. Jaenisch</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.32"></a>
<p><h3>7.32 Systems Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.81">7.81J</A>, <A HREF="m8b.html#8.591">8.591J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to cellular and population-level systems biology with an emphasis on synthetic biology, modeling of genetic networks, cell-cell interactions, and evolutionary dynamics.  Cellular systems include genetic switches and oscillators, network motifs, genetic network evolution, and cellular decision-making.  Population-level systems include models of pattern formation, cell-cell communications, and evolutionary systems biology.  Students taking graduate version explore the subject in more depth.
<br><I>J. Gore</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.33"></a>
<p><h3>7.33J Evolutionary Biology:  Concepts, Models and Computation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6a.html#6.049">6.049J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>; <a href="m6a.html#6.00">6.00</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.01">6.01</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores and illustrates how evolution explains biology, with an emphasis on computational model building for analyzing evolutionary data.  Covers key concepts of biological evolution, including adaptive evolution, neutral evolution, evolution of sex, genomic conflict, speciation, phylogeny and comparative methods, life's history, coevolution, human evolution, and evolution of disease.
<br><I>R. Berwick, D. Bartel</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.340"></a><a name="7.341"></a><a name="7.342"></a><a name="7.343"></a><a name="7.344"></a>
<p><h3>7.340-7.344 Advanced Undergraduate Seminar
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a>, or <a href="m7a.html#7.28">7.28</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><b>7.340:</b> URL: <a href="https://biology.mit.edu/undergraduate/course_listings/advanced_undergraduate_seminars ">https://biology.mit.edu/undergraduate/course_listings/advanced_undergraduate_seminars </a><br><b>7.344:</b> URL: <a href="https://biology.mit.edu/undergraduate/course_listings/advanced_undergraduate_seminars ">https://biology.mit.edu/undergraduate/course_listings/advanced_undergraduate_seminars </a>
<br><b>7.341:</b> <b>Lecture:</b> <i>F11-1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-150</a>)<!--s--><br><b>7.342:</b> <b>Lecture:</b> <i>R11-1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-150</a>)<!--s--><br><b>7.343:</b> <b>Lecture:</b> <i>R3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-150</a>)<!--s--><br><b>7.344:</b> <b>Lecture:</b> <i>W3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-150</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminars covering topics of current interest in biology with a focus on how to understand experimental methods and design and how to critically read the primary research literature. Small class size facilitates discussions and interactions with an active research scientist. Students visit research laboratories to see firsthand how biological research is conducted. Contact Biology Education Office for topics.
<br><I>H. R. Horvitz</I><br><b>7.341:</b> No required or recommended textbooks<br><b>7.342:</b> No required or recommended textbooks<br><b>7.343:</b> No required or recommended textbooks<br><b>7.344:</b> No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->

<br><b>7.345:</b> <b>Lecture:</b> <i>W11-1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-150</a>)<!--s--><br><b>7.346:</b> <b>Lecture:</b> <i>W1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-150</a>)<!--s--><br><b>7.347:</b> <b>Lecture:</b> <i>R1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-150</a>)<!--s-->

<a name="7.35"></a>
<p><h3>7.35 Topics in Metabolic Biochemistry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m5b.html#5.77">5.77J</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.75">7.75J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a> or <a href="m5a.html#5.07">5.07</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Topics include major metabolic pathways for the biosynthesis of certain cellular constituents and oxidative metabolism. Emphasizes enzymology and methods used to understand metabolism and enzymatic processes.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.36"></a>
<p><h3>7.36J Foundations of Computational and Systems Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m20a.html#20.390">20.390J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.91">7.91J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.490">20.490J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>; <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a> or <a href="m5a.html#5.07">5.07</a>; <a href="m1a.html#1.00">1.00</a>, <a href="m1a.html#1.001">1.001</a>, or <a href="m6a.html#6.00">6.00</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/7.91/">http://web.mit.edu/7.91/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-141</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-160</a>) or <i>R4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-162</a>) or <i>F4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-168</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to computational and systems biology. Includes units on the analysis of protein and nucleic acid sequences, protein structures, and biological networks. Presents principles and methods used for sequence alignment, motif finding, expression array analysis, structural modeling, structure design and prediction, and network analysis and modeling. Techniques include dynamic programming, Markov and hidden Markov models, Bayesian networks, clustering methods, and energy minimization approaches. Exposes students to emerging research areas. Designed for students with strong backgrounds in either molecular biology or computer science. Some foundational material covering basic programming skills, probability and statistics is provided for students with less quantitative backgrounds. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>C. Burge, E. Fraenkel, D. Gifford</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=7.36');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.37"></a>
<p><h3>7.37J Molecular and Engineering Aspects of Biotechnology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m10a.html#10.441">10.441J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.361">20.361J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.005">2.005</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.012">3.012</a>, <a href="m5b.html#5.60">5.60</a>, <a href="m20a.html#20.110">20.110</a>, or <a href="m20a.html#20.111">20.111</a>; <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/7.37j/">http://web.mit.edu/7.37j/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW3-5</i> (Whitehead-7TH)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers biological and bioengineering principles underlying the development and therapeutic use of recombinant proteins and stem cells; glycoengineering of recombinant proteins; normal and pathological signaling by growth factors and their receptors; receptor trafficking; monoclonal antibodies as therapeutics; protein pharmacology and delivery; stem cell-derived tissues as therapeutics; RNA therapeutics; combinatorial protein engineering; and new antitumor drugs.
<br><I>H. Lodish, L. Griffith</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=7.37');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.38"></a>
<p><h3>7.38 Forces in Cell Biology and Development
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.83">7.83</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/7.38j/">http://web.mit.edu/7.38j/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-265</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers the current understanding of how physical forces are generated in cells and how these forces organize and shape cells and tissues. Topics include methods to measure and detect forces for single molecules or in cells, mechanisms of force generation, sensing of force in signal transduction, and the roles of force in key cell biological and developmental processes and human disease.  Includes lectures on concepts and experimental approaches related to forces in biology and discussions of representative recent papers. Students taking the graduate version are expected to explore the subject in greater depth.
<br><I>I. Cheeseman, A. Martin</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.41"></a>
<p><h3>7.41 Topics in Chemical Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on the application of chemical approaches for investigating complex biological systems. Subject is organized into themes, including semisynthesis and biosynthesis of proteins and nucleic acids; biosynthesis of complex natural products; chemical genetics; methods and approaches for studying the interactome; bioorthogonal labeling; and chemical methods for studying protein post-translational modification reaction.
<br><I>B. Imperiali, A. Keating</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.49"></a>
<p><h3>7.49J Developmental Neurobiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m9a.html#9.18">9.18J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.69">7.69J</A>, <A HREF="m9a.html#9.181">9.181J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m9a.html#9.01">9.01</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-1015</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Considers molecular control of neural specification, formation of neuronal connections, construction of neural systems, and the contributions of experience to shaping brain structure and function. Topics include: neural induction and pattern formation, cell lineage and fate determination, neuronal migration, axon guidance, synapse formation and stabilization, activity-dependent development and critical periods, development of behavior. Instruction and practice in oral communication provided. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>E. Nedivi, M. Heiman</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=7.49');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->

<h2>Graduate Subjects</h2>
<h3>MIT-WHOI Joint Program in Oceanography</h3>
<a name="7.410"></a>
<p><h3>7.410 Applied Statistics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9 [P/D/F]
<br>TBA at WHOI. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to modern applied statistics. Topics include likelihood-based methods for estimation, confidence intervals, and hypothesis-testing; bootstrapping; time series modeling; linear models; nonparametric regression; and model selection. Organized around examples drawn from the recent literature.
<br><I>A. Solow</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->

<a name="7.440"></a>
<p><h3>7.440 An Introduction to Mathematical Ecology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>, <a href="m1a.html#1.018">1.018J</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers the basic models of population growth, demography, population interaction (competition, predation, mutualism), food webs, harvesting, and infectious disease, and the mathematical tools required for their analysis. Because these tools are also basic to the analysis of models in biochemistry, physiology, and behavior, subject also broadly relevant to students whose interests are not limited to ecological problems.
<br><I>M. Neubert, H. Caswell (WHOI)</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.47"></a>
<p><h3>7.47 Biological Oceanography
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Advanced training in biology
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>TBA at WHOI. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Intensive overview of biological oceanography. Major paradigms discussed, and dependence of biological processes in the ocean on physical and chemical aspects of the environment examined. Surveys the diversity of marine habitats, major groups of taxa inhabiting those habitats, and the general biology of the various taxa: the production and consumption of organic material in the ocean, as well as factors controlling those processes. Species diversity, structure of marine food webs, and the flow of energy within different marine habitats are detailed and contrasted.
<br><I>WHOI Staff</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=7.47');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.491"></a>
<p><h3>7.491 Research in Biological Oceanography
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>

<h3>Microbiology (MICRO)</h3>
<a name="7.492"></a>
<p><h3>7.492J Methods and Problems in Microbiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1c.html#1.86">1.86J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.445">20.445J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor or <I>Coreq: <a href="m7a.html#7.493">7.493</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students will read and discuss primary literature covering key areas of microbial research with emphasis on methods and approaches used to understand and manipulate microbes. Limited to students in the microbiology program.
<br><I>L. Samson</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.493"></a>
<p><h3>7.493J Microbial Genetics and Evolution
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1c.html#1.87">1.87J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.446">20.446J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.28">7.28</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers aspects of microbial genetic and genomic analyses, central dogma, horizontal gene transfer, and evolution.
<br><I>A. D. Grossman, E. Alm</I><br>
</p><!--end-->

<a name="7.499"></a>
<p><h3>7.499 Research Rotations in Microbiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor; <I>Coreq: <a href="m7a.html#7.492">7.492</a>, or <a href="m7a.html#7.493">7.493</a></I>
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces students to faculty participating in the interdepartmental Microbiology graduate program through a series of three lab rotations, which provide broad exposure to microbiology research at MIT. Students select a lab for thesis research by the end of their first year. Given the interdisciplinary nature of the program and the many research programs available, students may be able to work jointly with more than one research supervisor. Limited to students in the Microbiology graduate program. Limited to students in the microbiology program.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.MTHG"></a>
<p><h3>7.MTHG Microbiology Graduate Thesis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
