<br><I>Staff</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<h3>Biology</h3>
<a name="7.50"></a>
<p><h3>7.50 Method and Logic in Molecular Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor or <I>Coreq: <a href="m7a.html#7.51">7.51</a> and <a href="m7a.html#7.52">7.52</a></I>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Logic and experimental design: an in-depth discussion and assessment of biochemical, physical, genetic, and cell biological methods employed in testing hypotheses. Limited to Course 7 graduate students.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.51"></a>
<p><h3>7.51 Principles of Biochemical Analysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 6-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Fundamental principles of biochemistry. Analysis of the structure and mechanism of catalytic and regulatory macromolecules.
<br><I>A. Keating, R. T. Sauer, F. Solomon</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.52"></a>
<p><h3>7.52 Genetics for Graduate Students
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Principles and approaches of genetic analysis, including Mendelian inheritance and prokaryotic genetics, yeast genetics, developmental genetics, neurogenetics, and human genetics.
<br><I>A. Amon, H. R. Horvitz</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.540"></a>
<p><h3>7.540J Frontiers in Chemical Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m5b.html#5.54">5.54J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.554">20.554J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.13">5.13</a>, <a href="m5a.html#5.07">5.07</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to current research at the interface of chemistry, biology, and bioengineering. Topics include imaging of biological processes, metabolic pathway engineering, protein engineering, mechanisms of DNA damage, RNA structure and function, macromolecular machines, protein misfolding and disease, metabolomics, and methods for analyzing signaling network dynamics. Lectures are interspersed with class discussions and student presentations based on current literature.
<br><I>B. Pentelute, M. Shoulders</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.547"></a>
<p><h3>7.547J Principles and Practice of Drug Development
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m10a.html#10.547">10.547J</A>, <A HREF="m15a.html#15.136">15.136J</A>, <A HREF="mESDa.html#ESD.691">ESD.691J</A>, <A HREF="mHSTb.html#HST.920">HST.920J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br>URL: <a href="http://hst-hu-mit.mit.edu/courses/HST920.shtml">http://hst-hu-mit.mit.edu/courses/HST920.shtml</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Description and critical assessment of the major issues and stages of developing a pharmaceutical or biopharmaceutical. Drug discovery, preclinical development, clinical investigation, manufacturing and regulatory issues considered for small and large molecules. Economic and financial considerations of the drug development process. Multidisciplinary perspective from faculty in clinical; life; and management sciences; as well as industry guests.
<br><I>T. J. Allen, C. L. Cooney, S. N. Finkelstein, A. J. Sinskey, G. K. Raju</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.549"></a>
<p><h3>7.549J Case Studies and Strategies in Drug Discovery and Development
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m15a.html#15.137">15.137J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.486">20.486J</A>, <A HREF="mHSTb.html#HST.916">HST.916J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br>URL: <a href="http://mit.edu/7.549j">http://mit.edu/7.549j</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M EVE (4-6 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-614</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>The stages in drug discovery and development begin with target identification and end with the submission of preclinical and clinical data to the regulatory authorities. Following identification of a lead compound, there is optimization of structures for pharmaceutical properties, bioavailability, and safety. Subject relies on actual cases presented by the scientist(s) involved in discovery and drug development. A major goal is to analyze the cases and determine how the discovery and development process might be influenced by new and future technologies.
<br><I>S. R. Tannenbaum, A. J. Sinskey, A. Wood</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.55"></a>
<p><h3>7.55 Case Studies in Modern Experimental Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>F11-1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-253</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on enhancing students' ability to analyze, design and present experiments, emphasizing modern techniques. Class discussions begin with papers that developed or utilized contemporary approaches (e.g., quantitative microscopy, biophysical and molecular genetic methods) to address important problems in biology. Each student prepares one specific aim of a standard research proposal for a project that emphasizes research strategy, experimental design, and writing.
<br><I>P. Chang, F. Solomon</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.57"></a>
<p><h3>7.57 Quantitative Biology for Graduate Students
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-114</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-115</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the fundamental concepts and tools of quantitative approaches to molecular and cellular biology.  Covers a wide range of mathematical, computational, and statistical methods, although no previous expertise in these areas is required. Focuses on understanding quantitative approaches through the analysis of particular problems and examples drawn from classical genetics, molecular biology, cell biology, genomics, and systems biology.
<br><I>P. Gupta, A. Regev</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.58"></a>
<p><h3>7.58 Molecular Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.28">7.28</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>; <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-370</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-160</a>) or <i>W12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-160</a>) or <i>W EVE (7 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-160</a>) or <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-160</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Detailed analysis of the biochemical mechanisms that control the maintenance, expression, and evolution of prokaryotic and eukaryotic genomes. Topics covered in lecture and readings of relevant literature include: gene regulation, DNA replication, genetic recombination, and mRNA translation. Logic of experimental design and data analysis emphasized. Presentations include both lectures and group discussions of representative papers from the literature. Students taking the graduate version are expected to explore the subject in greater depth.
<br><I>T. Baker, S. Bell, W. Gilbert</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=7.58');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.59"></a>
<p><h3>7.59J Teaching College-Level Science and Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1c.html#1.95">1.95J</A>, <A HREF="m5b.html#5.95">5.95J</A>, <A HREF="m6c.html#6.982">6.982J</A>, <A HREF="m8b.html#8.395">8.395J</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.094">18.094J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m2c.html#2.978">2.978</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-2 [P/D/F]
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Participatory seminar focuses on the knowledge and skills necessary for teaching science and engineering in higher education. Topics include theories of adult learning; course development; promoting active learning, problemsolving, and critical thinking in students; communicating with a diverse student body; using educational technology to further learning; lecturing; creating effective tests and assignments; and assessment and evaluation. Students research and present a relevant topic of particular interest. Appropriate for both novices and those with teaching experience.
<br><I>J. Rankin</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.60"></a>
<p><h3>7.60 Cell Biology: Structure and Functions of the Nucleus
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-121</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Eukaryotic genome structure, function, and expression, processing of RNA, and regulation of the cell cycle.  Emphasis on the techniques and logic used to address important problems in nuclear cell biology. Lectures on broad topic areas in nuclear cell biology and discussions on representative recent papers.
<br><I>P. Sharp, R. Young</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=7.60');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.61"></a>
<p><h3>7.61 Eukaryotic Cell Biology: Principles and Practice
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Emphasizes methods and logic used to analyze structure and function of eukaryotic cells in diverse systems (e.g., yeast, fly, worm, mouse, human; development, stem cells, neurons). Combines lectures and in-depth roundtable discussions of literature readings with the active participation of faculty experts. Focuses on membranes (structure, function, traffic), organelles, the cell surface, cytoskeleton and extracellular matrix. Ranges from basic studies to applications to human disease, while stressing critical analysis of experimental approaches. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>R. O. Hynes, M. Krieger</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.62"></a>
<p><h3>7.62 Microbial Physiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.21">7.21</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Biochemical properties of bacteria and other microorganisms that enable them to grow under a variety of conditions. Interaction between bacteria and bacteriophages. Genetic and metabolic regulation of enzyme action and enzyme formation. Structure and function of components of the bacterial cell envelope. Protein secretion with a special emphasis on its various roles in pathogenesis. Additional topics include bioenergetics, symbiosis, quorum sensing, global responses to DNA damage, and biofilms. Students taking the graduate version are expected to explore the subject in greater depth.
<br><I>G. C. Walker, A. J. Sinskey</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.63"></a>
<p><h3>7.63 Immunology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.23">7.23</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-154</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-168</a>) or <i>W EVE (7 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-168</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Comprehensive survey of molecular, genetic, and cellular aspects of the immune system. Topics include innate and adaptive immunity; cells and organs of the immune system; immunoglobulin, T cell receptor, and major histocompatibility complex (MHC) proteins and genes; development and functions of B and T lymphocytes; immune responses to infections and tumors; hypersensitivity, autoimmunity, and immunodeficiencies. Particular attention to the development and function of the immune system as a whole, as studied by modern methods and techniques. Students taking the graduate version are expected to explore the subject in greater depth.
<br><I>H. Ploegh, J. Chen, L. Steiner</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=7.63');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.64"></a>
<p><h3>7.64 Molecular Mechanisms, Pathology and Therapy of Human Neuromuscular Disorders
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M EVE (3-6 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-144</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Investigates the molecular and clinical basis of central nervous system and neuromuscular disorders with particular emphasis on strategies for therapeutic intervention. Considers the in-depth analysis of clinical features, pathological mechanisms, and responses to current therapeutic interventions. Covers neurodegenerative diseases, such as Huntington's disease, Parkinson's disease, Alzheimer's disease, Amyotropic Lateral Schlerosis, Frontal Temporal Dementia, and neuromuscular disorders, such as Myotonic Dystrophy, Facio Scapular Humoral Dystrophy, and Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy.
<br><I>D. Housman</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.65"></a>
<p><h3>7.65J Molecular and Cellular Neuroscience Core I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m9a.html#9.015">9.015J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Survey and primary literature review of major topic areas in molecular and cellular neurobiology. Covers neurogenomics, nervous system formation, axonal pathfinding, cytoskeletal regulation, synapse formation, neurotransmitter release, and cellular neurophysiology. Includes lectures and exam, together with presentation and discussion of primary literature. A final two-page research write-up is also due at the end of the term.
<br><I>J. T. Littleton, H. Sive, F. Gertler</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.66"></a>
<p><h3>7.66 Molecular Basis of Infectious Disease
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.26">7.26</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-333</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>R3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-167</a>) or <i>F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-154</a>) or <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-154</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on the principles of host-pathogen interactions with an emphasis on infectious diseases of humans. Presents key concepts of pathogenesis through the study of various human pathogens. Includes critical analysis and discussion of assigned readings.  Students taking the graduate version are expected to explore the subject in greater depth.
<br><I>D. Kim, J. Saeij</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.67"></a>
<p><h3>7.67J Genetic Methods in Neurobiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m9a.html#9.322">9.322J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br>URL: <a href="http://mit.edu/7.67j/">http://mit.edu/7.67j/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-4062</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents selected topics in which genetic analysis informs neurobiological issues, including action potential conduction and synaptic release in Drosophila, axon guidance in nematodes and Drosophila, olfaction and orienting behavior in nematodes. Studies hippocampal and cortical circuitry and function in mice, as well as genetically-determined and genetically-influenced human traits and diseases. Reviews methods such as mutagenesis, gene knockouts and transgene constructs, tissue-specific expression vectors, optically, chemically and thermally-inducible gene activation and inactivation.
<br><I>W. G. Quinn</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.68"></a>
<p><h3>7.68J Molecular and Cellular Neuroscience Core II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m9a.html#9.013">9.013J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-4062</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Survey and primary literature review of major areas in molecular and cellular neurobiology. Covers genetic neurotrophin signaling, adult neurogenesis, G-protein coupled receptor signaling, glia function, epigenetics, neuronal and homeostatic plasticity, neuromodulators of circuit function, and neurological/psychiatric disease mechanisms. Includes lectures and exams, and involves presentation and discussion of primary literature. 9.015 recommended, though the core subjects can be taken in any sequence.
<br><I>G. Feng, L.-H. Tsai, Y. Lin</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.69"></a>
<p><h3>7.69J Developmental Neurobiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m9a.html#9.181">9.181J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with 7.49J, <A HREF="m9a.html#9.18">9.18J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m9a.html#9.011">9.011</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-1015</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Considers molecular control of neural specification, formation of neuronal connections, construction of neural systems, and the contributions of experience to shaping brain structure and function. Topics include: neural induction and pattern formation, cell lineage and fate determination, neuronal migration, axon guidance, synapse formation and stabilization, activity-dependent development and critical periods, development of behavior. In addition to final exam, analysis and presentation of  research papers required for final grade. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>E. Nedivi, M. Heiman</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=7.69');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.70"></a>
<p><h3>7.70 Regulation of Gene Expression
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>F1-4</i> (Whitehead-7TH)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar examines basic principles of biological regulation of gene expression. Focuses on examples that underpin these principles, as well as those that challenge certain long-held views. Topics covered may include the role of transcription factors, enhancers, DNA modifications, non-coding RNAs, and chromatin structure in the regulation of gene expression and mechanisms for epigenetic inheritance of transcriptional states. Limited to 40.
<br><I>L. Boyer, M. Gehring</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.71"></a>
<p><h3>7.71 Biophysical Chemistry Techniques
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.13">5.13</a>, <a href="m5b.html#5.60">5.60</a>; <a href="m5a.html#5.07">5.07</a> or <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m5b.html#5.78">5.78</A>
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/5.78/www/">http://web.mit.edu/5.78/www/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-156</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>For students who want to understand the benefits and caveats of biophysical techniques used to ascertain the structure of macromolecules, especially on the 3-D level. The first half of the course focuses on x-ray crystallography, the single most important technique used in determining the 3-D structure of macromolecules. Discussion of crystallographic theory is complemented with exercises such as crystallization, data processing, and model building. In the second half of the course, biophysical techniques are covered that supplement the 3-D characterization of biological macromolecules. Topics include CD spectroscopy, isothermal calorimetry, analytical ultracentrifugation, dynamic light scattering, and surface plasmon resonance (BIAcore). Theoretical principles behind the techniques are covered, applications are discussed, and students are performing practical exercises using instrumentation available at MIT. Meets with 5.78 when offered concurrently.
<br><I>C. Drennan, T. Schwartz</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=7.71');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.72"></a>
<p><h3>7.72 Principles of Development and Evolution
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Lectures and literature discussion cover animal development and evolution. Focuses on molecular mechanisms, experimental approaches, and relevant disorders. Compares vertebrate (mouse, chick, frog, fish) and invertebrate (fly, worm) models. Topics include the early body plan, cell type determination and diversity, organogenesis, morphogenesis, maternal control, organismal growth, stem cells, and issues in human development.
<br><I>H. Sive, T. Orr-Weaver</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.74"></a>
<p><h3>7.74J Topics in Biophysics and Physical Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m8b.html#8.590">8.590J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.416">20.416J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides broad exposure to research in biophysics and physical biology, with emphasis on the critical evaluation of scientific literature. Weekly meetings include in-depth discussion of scientific literature led by distinct faculty on active research topics. Each session also includes brief discussion of non-research topics including effective presentation skills, writing papers and fellowship proposals, choosing scientific and technical research topics, time management, and scientific ethics.
<br><I>M. Bathe, J. Gore</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.75"></a>
<p><h3>7.75J Topics in Metabolic Biochemistry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m5b.html#5.77">5.77J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.35">7.35</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a> or <a href="m5a.html#5.07">5.07</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Topics include major metabolic pathways for the biosynthesis of certain cellular constituents and oxidative metabolism. Emphasizes enzymology and methods used to understand metabolism and enzymatic processes.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.76"></a>
<p><h3>7.76 Topics in Protein Biochemistry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>In-depth analysis and discussion of classic and current literature, with an emphasis on protein structure and function. Topics include binding specificity; cooperativity and allostery; protein folding and misfolding; macromolecular assembly; sequence homology and prediction of structure; and protein engineering and design. Undergraduates should have taken 7.71 or 5.64.
<br><I>A. Keating, R. T. Sauer</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.77"></a>
<p><h3>7.77 Nucleic Acids, Structure, Function, Evolution and Their Interactions with Proteins
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a> or <a href="m7a.html#7.51">7.51</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W EVE (3-6 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-121</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Surveys primary literature, focusing on biochemical, biophysical, genetic, and combinatorial approaches for understanding nucleic acids.  Topics include the general properties, functions, and structural motifs of DNA and RNA; RNAs as catalysts and as regulators of gene expression; RNA editing and surveillance, and the interaction of nucleic acids with proteins, such as zinc-finger proteins, modification enzymes, aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases and other proteins of the translational machinery. Includes some lectures but is mostly analysis and discussion of current literature in the context of student presentations.
<br><I>D. Bartel, U. RajBhandary</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.80"></a>
<p><h3>7.80 Biological Chemistry II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m5a.html#5.08">5.08J</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.08">7.08J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.12">5.12</a>; <a href="m5a.html#5.07">5.07</a> or <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-105</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-132</a>) or <i>R1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-132</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-132</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-132</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>More advanced treatment of biochemical mechanisms that underlie biological processes. Topics include macromolecular machines such as the ribosome, the proteosome, fatty acid synthases as a paradigm for polyketide synthases and non-ribosomal polypeptide synthases, and polymerases. Emphasis is on experimental methods used to unravel these processes and how these processes fit into the cellular context and coordinate regulation.  Students taking the graduate version are expected to explore the subject in greater depth.
<br><I>A. Y. Ting, E. Nolan</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.81"></a>
<p><h3>7.81J Systems Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m8b.html#8.591">8.591J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.32">7.32</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to cellular and population-level systems biology with an emphasis on synthetic biology, modeling of genetic networks, cell-cell interactions, and evolutionary dynamics.  Cellular systems include genetic switches and oscillators, network motifs, genetic network evolution, and cellular decision-making.  Population-level systems include models of pattern formation, cell-cell communication, and evolutionary systems biology. Students taking graduate version explore the subject in more depth.
<br><I>J. Gore</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.82"></a>
<p><h3>7.82 Topics of Mammalian Development and Genetics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M EVE (3-6 PM)</i> (Whitehead-7TH)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar covering embryologic, molecular, and genetic approaches to development in mice and humans. Topics include preimplantation development; gastrulation; embryonic stem cells, gene targeting and nuclear  reprogramming of somatic cells; genomic imprinting; X-inactivation; sex determination; and germ cells.
<br><I>R. Jaenisch, R. Young</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.83"></a>
<p><h3>7.83 Forces in Cell Biology and Development
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.38">7.38</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-265</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers the current understanding of how physical forces are generated in cells and how these forces organize and shape cells and tissues. Topics include methods to measure and detect forces for single molecules or in cells, mechanisms of force generation, sensing of force in signal transduction, and the roles of force in key cell biological and developmental processes and human disease.  Includes lectures on concepts and experimental approaches related to forces in biology and discussions of representative recent papers. Students taking the graduate version are expected to explore the subject in greater depth.
<br><I>I. Cheeseman, A. Martin</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.88"></a>
<p><h3>7.88J Protein Folding and Human Disease
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m5a.html#5.48">5.48J</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.543">10.543J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.51">7.51</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>R2.30-5.30</i> (Whitehead-6TH)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Addresses the multifaceted biochemical problem of protein folding and the surprising ways it affects biological systems. Considers underlying chemistry and cellular biology, folding intermediates and off-pathway reactions, and the roles of chaperones and other folding assistants. Covers the amyloid fold, beneficial amyloid functions, major protein folding diseases (such as Alzheimer's and Prion diseases) and the effects of protein folding on the evolution of novel functions.
<br><I>S. Lindquist, J. A. King</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=7.88');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.89"></a>
<p><h3>7.89J Topics in Computational and Systems Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mCSBa.html#CSB.100">CSB.100J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-10
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar based on research literature. Papers covered are selected to illustrate important problems and varied approaches in the field of computational and systems biology, and to provide students a framework from which to evaluate new developments. Preference to first-year CSB PhD students.
<br><I>C. Burge</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.91"></a>
<p><h3>7.91J Foundations of Computational and Systems Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m20a.html#20.490">20.490J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.36">7.36J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.390">20.390J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>; <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a> or <a href="m5a.html#5.07">5.07</a>; <a href="m1a.html#1.00">1.00</a>, <a href="m1a.html#1.001">1.001</a>, or <a href="m6a.html#6.00">6.00</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/7.91/">http://web.mit.edu/7.91/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-141</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-160</a>) or <i>R4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-162</a>) or <i>F4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-168</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to computational and systems biology. Includes units on the analysis of protein and nucleic acid sequences, protein structures, and biological networks. Presents principles and methods used for sequence alignment, motif finding, expression array analysis, structural modeling, structure design and prediction, and network analysis and modeling. Techniques include dynamic programming, Markov and hidden Markov models, Bayesian networks, clustering methods, and energy minimization approaches. Exposes students to emerging research areas. Designed for students with strong backgrounds in either molecular biology or computer science. Some foundational material covering basic programming skills, probability and statistics is provided for students with less quantitative backgrounds. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>C. Burge, E. Fraenkel, D. Gifford</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=7.91');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.931"></a>
<p><h3>7.931 Independent Study in Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>No required or recommended textbooks
<a name="7.932"></a>
<h3>7.932 Independent Study in Biology

</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.933"></a>
<p><h3>7.933 Research Rotations in Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces students to faculty participating in the Biology graduate program through a series of lab rotations, which provide broad exposure to biology research at MIT. Students select a lab for thesis research by the end of their first year. Limited to students in the Biology graduate program.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.934"></a>

<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">

<br><I>Staff</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.941"></a>

<a name="7.95"></a>
<p><h3>7.95 Cancer Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>R4-6</i> (Whitehead-7TH)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Intensive analysis of historical and current developments in cancer biology.  Topics include principles of transformation, viral and cellular oncogenes, tumor suppressor genes, tumor-cell growth, apoptosis, principles of cancer biology, and cancer genetics. Detailed analyses of the current research literature including important research reports published in recent years. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>M. Vander Heiden, R. Weinberg</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=7.95');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.98"></a>
<p><h3>7.98J Neural Plasticity in Learning and Memory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m9a.html#9.301">9.301J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/7.98/">http://web.mit.edu/7.98/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>R1-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-5305</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examination of the role of neural plasticity during learning and memory of invertebrates and mammals. Detailed critical analysis of the current literature of molecular, cellular, genetic, electrophysiological, and behavioral studies. Student-directed presentations and discussions of original papers supplemented by introductory lectures. Juniors and seniors require instructor's permission.
<br><I>S. Tonegawa, W. Quinn</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.S930"></a>

<h1 align="center">Course 8: Physics<br>Spring
2014</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/"><i>Course 8 Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course8.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=+++8&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>8.01-8.299 plus UROP and THU</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m8b.html">8.300-8.999 plus THG</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<h2>Undergraduate Subjects</h2>
<a name="8.01"></a>
<p><h3>8.01 Physics I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/phys1.gif" alt="Physics I" title="Physics I" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-2-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m8a.html#8.011">8.011</A>, <A HREF="m8a.html#8.012">8.012</A>, <A HREF="m8a.html#8.01L">8.01L</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.801">CC.801</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.8012">CC.8012</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.801">ES.801</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.8012">ES.8012</A>
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces classical mechanics. Space and time: straight-line kinematics; motion in a plane; forces and static equilibrium; particle dynamics, with force and conservation of momentum; relative inertial frames and non-inertial force; work, potential energy and conservation of energy; kinetic theory and the ideal gas; rigid bodies and rotational dynamics; vibrational motion; conservation of angular momentum; central force motions; fluid mechanics.  Subject taught using the TEAL (Technology-Enabled Active Learning) format which features students working in groups of three, discussing concepts, solving problems, and doing table-top experiments with the aid of computer data acquisition and analysis.
<br><I>D. Chakrabarty, P. Dourmashkin</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.011"></a>
<p><h3>8.011 Physics I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/phys1.gif" alt="Physics I" title="Physics I" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m8a.html#8.01">8.01</A>, <A HREF="m8a.html#8.012">8.012</A>, <A HREF="m8a.html#8.01L">8.01L</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.801">CC.801</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.8012">CC.8012</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.801">ES.801</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.8012">ES.8012</A>
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW10-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-144</a>) or <i>MW12-2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-144</a>) or <i>MW2-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-144</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces classical mechanics. Space and time: straight-line kinematics; motion in a plane; forces and equilibrium; experimental basis of Newton's laws; particle dynamics; universal gravitation; collisions and conservation laws; work and potential energy; vibrational motion; conservative forces; inertial forces and non-inertial frames; central force motions; rigid bodies and rotational dynamics. Designed for students with previous experience in 8.01; the subject is designated as 8.01 on the transcript.
<br><I>D. Pritchard</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.012"></a>
<p><h3>8.012 Physics I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/phys1.gif" alt="Physics I" title="Physics I" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m8a.html#8.01">8.01</A>, <A HREF="m8a.html#8.011">8.011</A>, <A HREF="m8a.html#8.01L">8.01L</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.801">CC.801</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.8012">CC.8012</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.801">ES.801</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.8012">ES.8012</A>
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Elementary mechanics, presented in greater depth than in 8.01. Newton's laws, concepts of momentum, energy, angular momentum, rigid body motion, and non-inertial systems. Uses elementary calculus freely; concurrent registration in a math subject more advanced than 18.01 is recommended. In addition to covering the theoretical subject matter, students complete a small experimental project of their own design. Freshmen admitted via AP or Math Diagnostic for Physics Placement results.
<br><I>M. Williams</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.01L"></a>
<p><h3>8.01L Physics I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">) <img src="/icns/phys1.gif" alt="Physics I" title="Physics I" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-2-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m8a.html#8.01">8.01</A>, <A HREF="m8a.html#8.011">8.011</A>, <A HREF="m8a.html#8.012">8.012</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.801">CC.801</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.8012">CC.8012</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.801">ES.801</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.8012">ES.8012</A>
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to classical mechanics (see description under 8.01). Includes components of the TEAL (Technology-Enabled Active Learning) format. Material covered over a longer interval so that the subject is completed by the end of the IAP. Substantial emphasis given to reviewing and strengthening necessary mathematics tools, as well as basic physics concepts and problem-solving skills. Content, depth, and difficulty is otherwise identical to that of 8.01. The subject is designated as 8.01 on the transcript.
<br><I>Y. Lee</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.02"></a>
<p><h3>8.02 Physics II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/phys2.gif" alt="Physics II" title="Physics II" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-2-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m8a.html#8.021">8.021</A>, <A HREF="m8a.html#8.022">8.022</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.802">CC.802</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.802">ES.802</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.8022">ES.8022</A>
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW10-12,F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-152</a>) or <i>MW12-2,F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-152</a>) or <i>MW2-4,F3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-152</a>) or <i>TR9-11,F9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-152</a>) or <i>TR11-1,F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-152</a>) or <i>TR1-3,F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-152</a>) or <i>TR3-5,F4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-152</a>) or <i>MW12-2,F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-082</a>) or <i>MW2-4,F3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-082</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to electromagnetism and electrostatics: electric charge, Coulomb's law, electric structure of matter; conductors and dielectrics. Concepts of electrostatic field and potential, electrostatic energy. Electric currents, magnetic fields and Ampere's law. Magnetic materials. Time-varying fields and Faraday's law of induction. Basic electric circuits. Electromagnetic waves and Maxwell's equations. Subject taught using the TEAL (Technology Enabled Active Learning) studio format which utilizes small group interaction and current technology to help students develop intuition about, and conceptual models of, physical phenomena.
<br>Fall: <I>R. Redwine, J. Conrad</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Belcher, P. Dourmashkin, and Staff</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=8.02');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.021"></a>
<p><h3>8.021 Physics II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/phys2.gif" alt="Physics II" title="Physics II" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m8a.html#8.02">8.02</A>, <A HREF="m8a.html#8.022">8.022</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.802">CC.802</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.802">ES.802</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.8022">ES.8022</A>
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to electromagnetism and electrostatics: electric charge, Coulomb's law, electric structure of matter; conductors and dielectrics. Concepts of electrostatic field and potential, electrostatic energy. Electric currents, magnetic fields and Ampere's law. Magnetic materials. Time-varying fields and Faraday's law of induction. Basic electric circuits. Electromagnetic waves and Maxwell's equations. Designed for students with previous experience in 8.02; the subject is designated as 8.02 on the transcript. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>G. Stephans</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.022"></a>
<p><h3>8.022 Physics II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/phys2.gif" alt="Physics II" title="Physics II" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>, <I>Coreq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a></I>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m8a.html#8.02">8.02</A>, <A HREF="m8a.html#8.021">8.021</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.802">CC.802</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.802">ES.802</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.8022">ES.8022</A>
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=6">6-120</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-328</a>) or <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-328</a>) or <i>TR3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-328</a>) or <i>TR4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-328</a>) or <i>MW3 (ES STUDENTS ONLY)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=24">24-610</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Parallel to 8.02, but more advanced mathematically. Some knowledge of vector calculus assumed. Maxwell's equations, in both differential and integral form. Electrostatic and magnetic vector potential. Properties of dielectrics and magnetic materials. In addition to the theoretical subject matter, several experiments in electricity and magnetism are performed by the students in the laboratory.
<br>Fall: <I>P. Zuccon</I><br>Spring: <I>N. Gedik</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=8.022');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.03"></a>
<p><h3>8.03 Physics III
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1.30-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=6">6-120</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>MW1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-314</a>) or <i>MW2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-314</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Mechanical vibrations and waves; simple harmonic motion, superposition, forced vibrations and resonance, coupled oscillations, and normal modes; vibrations of continuous systems; reflection and refraction; phase and group velocity. Optics; wave solutions to Maxwell's equations; polarization; Snell's Law, interference, Huygens's principle, Fraunhofer diffraction, and gratings.
<br>Fall: <I>N. Weinberg</I><br>Spring: <I>B. Wyslouch</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=8.03');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.033"></a>
<p><h3>8.033 Relativity
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Normally taken by Physics majors in their sophomore year. Einstein's postulates; consequences for simultaneity, time dilation, length contraction, and clock synchronization; Lorentz transformation; relativistic effects and paradoxes; Minkowski diagrams; invariants and four-vectors; momentum, energy, and mass; particle collisions. Relativity and electricity; Coulomb's law; magnetic fields. Brief introduction to Newtonian cosmology. Introduction to some concepts of general relativity; principle of equivalence. The Schwarzchild metric; gravitational red shift; particle and light trajectories; geodesics; Shapiro delay.
<br><I>P. Fisher</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.04"></a>
<p><h3>8.04 Quantum Physics I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.03">8.03</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.014">6.014</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.034">18.034</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=6">6-120</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>MW10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-261</a>) or <i>MW11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-261</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-142</a>) or <i>M3,W4 (W MEETS IN 26-322)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=8">8-119</a>) or <i>MW1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-134</a>) or <i>MW2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-134</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Experimental basis of quantum physics: photoelectric effect, Compton scattering, photons, Franck-Hertz experiment, the Bohr atom, electron diffraction, deBroglie waves, and wave-particle duality of matter and light. Introduction to wave mechanics: Schroedinger's equation, wave functions, wave packets, probability amplitudes, stationary states, the Heisenberg uncertainty principle, and zero-point energies. Solutions to Schroedinger's equation in one dimension: transmission and reflection at a barrier, barrier penetration, potential wells, the simple harmonic oscillator. Schroedinger's equation in three dimensions: central potentials and introduction to hydrogenic systems.
<br>Fall: <I>E. Farhi</I><br>Spring: <I>M. Evans</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=8.04');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.044"></a>
<p><h3>8.044 Statistical Physics I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.03">8.03</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW12.30-2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=6">6-120</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=12">12-142</a>) or <i>TR10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=12">12-142</a>) or <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=12">12-142</a>) or <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=12">12-142</a>) or <i>TR2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=12">12-142</a>) or <i>TR3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=12">12-142</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to probability, statistical mechanics, and thermodynamics. Random variables, joint and conditional probability densities, and functions of a random variable. Concepts of macroscopic variables and thermodynamic equilibrium, fundamental assumption of statistical mechanics, microcanonical and canonical ensembles. First, second, and third laws of thermodynamics. Numerous examples illustrating a wide variety of physical phenomena such as magnetism, polyatomic gases, thermal radiation, electrons in solids, and noise in electronic devices. Concurrent enrollment in 8.04 is recommended.
<br><I>R. Jaffe</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=8.044');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.05"></a>
<p><h3>8.05 Quantum Physics II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.04">8.04</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Together 8.05 and 8.06 cover quantum physics with applications drawn from modern physics. General formalism of quantum mechanics: states, operators, Dirac notation, representations, measurement theory. Harmonic oscillator: operator algebra, states. Quantum mechanics in three dimensions: central potentials and the radial equation, bound and scattering states, qualitative analysis of wavefunctions. Angular momentum: operators, commutator algebra, eigenvalues and eigenstates, spherical harmonics. Spin: Stern-Gerlach devices and measurements, nuclear magnetic resonance, spin and statistics. Addition of angular momentum: Clebsch-Gordan series and coefficients, spin systems, and allotropic forms of hydrogen.
<br><I>B. Zwiebach</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.06"></a>
<p><h3>8.06 Quantum Physics III
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.05">8.05</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=6">6-120</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>MW10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-210</a>) or <i>MW11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-210</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Continuation of 8.05. Units: natural units, scales of microscopic phenomena, applications. Time-independent approximation methods: degenerate and nondegenerate perturbation theory, variational method, Born-Oppenheimer approximation, applications to atomic and molecular systems. The structure of one- and two-electron atoms: overview, spin-orbit and relativistic corrections, fine structure, variational approximation, screening, Zeeman and Stark effects. Charged particles in a magnetic field: Landau levels and integer quantum hall effect. Scattering: general principles, partial waves, review of one-dimension, low-energy approximations, resonance, Born approximation. Time-dependent perturbation theory. Students research and write a paper on a topic related to the content of 8.05 and 8.06.
<br>Fall: <I>Staff</I><br>Spring: <I>A. Harrow</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=8.06');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.07"></a>
<p><h3>8.07 Electromagnetism II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.03">8.03</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Survey of basic electromagnetic phenomena: electrostatics, magnetostatics; electromagnetic properties of matter. Time-dependent electromagnetic fields and Maxwell's equations. Electromagnetic waves, emission, absorption, and scattering of radiation. Relativistic electrodynamics and mechanics.
<br><I>S. Hughes</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.08"></a>
<p><h3>8.08 Statistical Physics II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.044">8.044</a>, <a href="m8a.html#8.05">8.05</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>WF1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-322</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>M1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-322</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Probability distributions for classical and quantum systems. Microcanonical, canonical, and grand canonical partition-functions and associated thermodynamic potentials. Conditions of thermodynamic equilibrium for homogenous and heterogenous systems. Applications: non-interacting Bose and Fermi gases; mean field theories for real gases, binary mixtures, magnetic systems, polymer solutions; phase and reaction equilibria, critical phenomena. Fluctuations, correlation functions and susceptibilities, and Kubo formulae. Evolution of distribution functions: Boltzmann and Smoluchowski equations.
<br><I>Staff</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=8.08');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.09"></a>
<p><h3>8.09 Classical Mechanics III
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.223">8.223</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Formal introduction to classical mechanics, Euler-Lagrange equations, Hamilton's equations of motion used to describe central force motion, scattering, perturbation theory and Noether's theorem. Extension to continuous and relativistic systems and classical electrodynamics.
<br><I>I. Stewart</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<h2>Undergraduate Laboratory and Special Project Subjects</h2>
<a name="8.13"></a>
<p><h3>8.13 Experimental Physics I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.04">8.04</a>
<br>Units: 0-6-12
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><b>Lab:</b> <i>MW9-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-361</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=8.13');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
<a name="8.14"></a>
<h3>8.14 Experimental Physics II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.05">8.05</a>, <a href="m8a.html#8.13">8.13</a>
<br>Units: 0-6-12
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><b>Lab:</b> <i>MW1-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-361</a>) or <i>TR1-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-361</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Four fundamental laboratory experiments are carried out each term, covering most aspects of modern physics relating to names such as Rutherford, Franck-Hertz, Hall, Ramsauer, Doppler, Fraunhofer, Faraday, Mossbauer, Compton, and Stern-Gerlach. Stresses basic experimental techniques and data analysis, and written and oral presentation of experiment results. 8.14 requires knowledge of quantum mechanics at the 8.05 level.
<br>Fall: <I>G. Roland</I><br>Spring: <I>C. Paus, P. Zuccon</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=8.14');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.18"></a>
<p><h3>8.18 Research Problems in Undergraduate Physics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
