<br>Opportunity for undergraduates to engage in experimental or theoretical research under the supervision of a staff member. Specific approval required in each case.
<br>Consult N. Mavalvala<br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<h2>Undergraduate Elective Subjects</h2>
<a name="8.20"></a>
<p><h3>8.20 Introduction to Special Relativity
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-7
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the basic ideas and equations of Einstein's special theory of relativity. Topics include Lorentz transformations, length contraction and time dilation, four vectors, Lorentz invariants, relativistic energy and momentum, relativistic kinematics, Doppler shift, space-time diagrams, relativity paradoxes, and some concepts of general relativity. Intended for freshmen and sophomores. Not usable as a restricted elective by Physics majors. Credit cannot be received for 8.20 if credit for 8.033 is or has been received in the same or prior terms.
<br><I>M. Klute</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014JA&Subject=8.20');" >Textbooks (IAP 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.21"></a>
<p><h3>8.21 Physics of Energy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A comprehensive introduction to the fundamental physics of energy systems that emphasizes quantitative analysis.  Focuses on the fundamental physical principles underlying energy processes and on the application of these principles to practical calculations.  Applies mechanics and electromagnetism to energy systems; introduces and applies basic ideas from thermodynamics, quantum mechanics, and nuclear physics. Examines energy sources, conversion, transport, losses, storage, conservation, and end uses.  Analyzes the physics of side effects, such as global warming and radiation hazards. Provides students with technical tools and perspective to evaluate energy choices quantitatively at both national policy and personal levels.
<br><I>W. Taylor</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.223"></a>
<p><h3>8.223 Classical Mechanics II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A broad, theoretical treatment of classical mechanics, useful in its own right for treating complex dynamical problems, but essential to understanding the foundations of quantum mechanics and statistical physics. Generalized coordinates, Lagrangian and Hamiltonian formulations, canonical transformations, and Poisson brackets.  Applications to continuous media. The relativistic Lagrangian and Maxwell's equations.
<br><I>P. Fisher</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014JA&Subject=8.223');" >Textbooks (IAP 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.224"></a>
<p><h3>8.224 Exploring Black Holes: General Relativity and Astrophysics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.033">8.033</a> or <a href="m8a.html#8.20">8.20</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Study of physical effects in the vicinity of a black hole as a basis for understanding general relativity, astrophysics, and elements of cosmology. Extension to current developments in theory and observation. Energy and momentum in flat space-time; the metric; curvature of space-time near rotating and nonrotating centers of attraction; trajectories and orbits of particles and light; elementary models of the Cosmos. Weekly meetings include an evening seminar and recitation. The last third of the term is reserved for collaborative research projects on topics such as the Global Positioning System, solar system tests of relativity, descending into a black hole, gravitational lensing, gravitational waves, Gravity Probe B, and more advanced models of the cosmos. Subject has online components that are open to selected MIT alumni. Alumni wishing to participate should contact Professor Bertschinger at edbert@mit.edu. Limited to 40.
<br><I>E. Bertschinger</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.225"></a>
<p><h3>8.225J Einstein, Oppenheimer, Feynman: Physics in the 20th Century
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mSTSa.html#STS.042">STS.042J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the changing roles of physics and physicists during the 20th century. Topics range from relativity theory and quantum mechanics to high-energy physics and cosmology. Examines the development of modern physics within shifting institutional, cultural, and political contexts, such as physics in Imperial Britain, Nazi Germany, US efforts during World War II, and physicists' roles during the Cold War. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>D. I. Kaiser</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.226"></a>
<p><h3>8.226 Forty-three Orders of Magnitude
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.04">8.04</a>, <a href="m8a.html#8.044">8.044</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW12.30-2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-233</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the widespread societal implications of current scientific discoveries in physics across forty-three orders of magnitude in length scale.  Addresses topics ranging from climate change to nuclear nonproliferation.  Students develop their ability to express concepts at a level accessible to the public and to present a well-reasoned argument on a topic that is a part of the national debate.  Requires diverse writing assignments, including substantial papers. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>J. Conrad</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.231"></a>
<p><h3>8.231 Physics of Solids I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.044">8.044</a>, <I>Coreq: <a href="m8a.html#8.05">8.05</a></I>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the basic concepts of the quantum theory of solids. Topics: periodic structure and symmetry of crystals; diffraction; reciprocal lattice; chemical bonding; lattice dynamics, phonons, thermal properties; free electron gas; model of metals; Bloch theorem and band structure, nearly free electron approximation; tight binding method; Fermi surface; semiconductors, electrons, holes, impurities; optical properties, excitons; and magnetism.
<br><I>L. Fu</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.251"></a>
<p><h3>8.251 String Theory for Undergraduates
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.033">8.033</a>, <a href="m8a.html#8.044">8.044</a>, <a href="m8a.html#8.05">8.05</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the main concepts of string theory, i.e. quantum mechanics of a relativistic string. Develops aspects of string theory and makes it accessible to students familiar with basic electromagnetism and statistical mechanics, including the study of D-branes and string thermodynamics.
<br><I>B. Zwiebach</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.276"></a>
<p><h3>8.276 Nuclear and Particle Physics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.033">8.033</a>, <a href="m8a.html#8.04">8.04</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-168</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents a modern view of the fundamental structure of matter. Starting from the Standard Model, which views leptons and quarks as basic building blocks of matter, establishes the properties and interactions of these particles. Explores applications of this phenomenology to both particle and nuclear physics. Emphasizes current topics in nuclear and particle physics research at MIT. Intended for students with a basic knowledge of relativity and quantum physics concepts.
<br><I>M. Williams</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.277"></a>
<p><h3>8.277J Introduction to Particle Accelerators
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6b.html#6.608">6.608J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.013">6.013</a> or <a href="m8a.html#8.07">8.07</a>; permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW11-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-168</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Principles of acceleration: beam properties; linear accelerators, synchrotrons, and storage rings.  Accelerator technologies: radio frequency cavities, bending and focusing magnets, beam diagnostics. Particle beam optics and dynamics. Special topics: measures of accelerators performance in science, medicine and industry; synchrotron radiation sources; free electron lasers; high-energy colliders; and accelerators for radiation therapy.  May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 12 units.
<br><I>W. Barletta</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.282"></a>
<p><h3>8.282J Introduction to Astronomy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m12a.html#12.402">12.402J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-231</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Quantitative introduction to physics of the solar system, stars, interstellar medium, the galaxy, and universe, as determined from a variety of astronomical observations and models. Topics: planets, planet formation; stars, the Sun, "normal" stars, star formation; stellar evolution, supernovae, compact objects (white dwarfs, neutron stars, and black holes), plusars, binary x-ray sources; star clusters, globular and open clusters; interstellar medium, gas, dust, magnetic fields, cosmic rays; distance ladder; galaxies, normal and active galaxies, jets; gravitational lensing; large scaling structure; Newtonian cosmology, dynamical expansion and thermal history of the universe; cosmic microwave background radiation; big bang nucleosynthesis. No prior knowledge of astronomy necessary. Not usable as a restricted elective by Physics majors.
<br><I>A. Frebel</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=8.282');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.284"></a>
<p><h3>8.284 Modern Astrophysics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.04">8.04</a>, <I>Coreq: <a href="m8a.html#8.05">8.05</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=8">8-205</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Applications of physics (Newtonian, statistical, and quantum mechanics) to fundamental processes that occur in celestial objects. Includes main-sequence stars, collapsed stars (white dwarfs, neutron stars, and black holes), pulsars, supernovae, the interstellar medium, galaxies, and as time permits, active galaxies, quasars, and cosmology. Observational data discussed. No prior knowledge of astronomy is required.
<br>Fall: <I>Staff</I><br>Spring: <I>N. Weinberg</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.286"></a>
<p><h3>8.286 The Early Universe
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to modern cosmology. First half deals with the development of the big bang theory from 1915 to 1980, and latter half with recent impact of particle theory. Topics: special relativity and the Doppler effect, Newtonian cosmological models, introduction to non-Euclidean spaces, thermal radiation and early history of the universe, big bang nucleosynthesis, introduction to grand unified theories and other recent developments in particle theory, baryogenesis, the inflationary universe model, and the evolution of galactic structure.
<br><I>A. Guth</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.287"></a>
<p><h3>8.287J Observational Techniques of Optical Astronomy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m12a.html#12.410">12.410J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.282">8.282J</a>, <a href="m12a.html#12.402">12.402J</a>, <a href="m12a.html#12.409">12.409</a>, or other introductory astronomy course; <I>Coreq: <a href="m8a.html#8.03">8.03</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-4-8
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Fundamental physical and optical principles used for astronomical measurements at visible wavelengths and practical methods of astronomical observations. Topics: astronomical coordinates, time, optics, telescopes, photon counting, signal-to-noise ratios, data analysis (including least-squares model fitting), limitations imposed by the Earth's atmosphere on optical observations, CCD detectors, photometry, spectroscopy, astrometry, and time variability. Project at Wallace Astrophysical Observatory. Written and oral project reports. Limited to 18; preference to Course 8 and Course 12 majors and minors.
<br><I>R. Binzel, A. Bosh</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.292"></a>
<p><h3>8.292J Fluid Physics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m12a.html#12.330">12.330J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.044">8.044</a>, <a href="m5b.html#5.60">5.60</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A physics-based introduction to the properties of fluids and fluid systems, with examples drawn from a broad range of sciences, including atmospheric physics and astrophysics. Definitions of fluids and the notion of continuum. Equations of state and continuity, hydrostatics and conservation of momentum; ideal fluids and Euler's equation; viscosity and the Navier-Stokes equation. Energy considerations, fluid thermodynamics, and isentropic flow. Compressible versus incompressible and rotational versus irrotational flow; Bernoulli's theorem; steady flow, streamlines and potential flow. Circulation and vorticity. Kelvin's theorem. Boundary layers. Fluid waves and instabilities. Quantum fluids.
<br><I>D. Cziczo</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.297"></a>
<p><h3>8.297 Physics of the 21st Century
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.033">8.033</a>, <a href="m8a.html#8.044">8.044</a>, <a href="m8a.html#8.05">8.05</a>, <a href="m8a.html#8.13">8.13</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students study four topics in depth from themes of current interest over the course of the term.  Topic examples include Bose-Einstein condensates, dark energy, neutrino interactions, superconductivity, photonics, semiconductor nanostructures, exoplanets, and space plasmas.
<br><I>P. Fisher</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.298"></a>
<p><h3>8.298 Selected Topics in Physics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presentation of topics of current interest, with content varying from year to year.
<br>Consult I. Stewart<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.299"></a>
<p><h3>8.299 Physics Teaching
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>For qualified undergraduate students interested in gaining some experience in teaching. Laboratory, tutorial, or classroom teaching under the supervision of a faculty member. Students selected by interview.
<br>Consult N. Mavalvala<br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.UR"></a>
<p><h3>8.UR Undergraduate Research
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">

<br><I>N. Mavalvala</I><br>Textbooks arranged individually (IAP 2014); No required or recommended textbooks (Spring 2014)
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.THU"></a>
<p><h3>8.THU Undergraduate Physics Thesis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Course 9: Brain and Cognitive Sciences<br>Spring
2014</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://bcs.mit.edu/"><i>Course 9 Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course9.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=+++9&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>9.00-9.499</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m9b.html">9.50-9.999 plus Thesis, UROP</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<a name="9.00"></a>
<p><h3>9.00 Introduction to Psychological Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2-3.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-123</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>T4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-1015</a>) or <i>T EVE (7 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-1015</a>) or <i>W10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-1015</a>) or <i>W4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-3310</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-4062</a>) or <i>W EVE (7 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-1015</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-4062</a>) or <i>R4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-1015</a>) or <i>R EVE (7 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-167</a>) or <i>F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-180</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-160</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-168</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-3310</a>) or <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-3310</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A survey of the scientific study of human nature, including how the mind works, and how the brain supports the mind.  Topics include the mental and neural bases of perception, emotion, learning, memory, cognition, child development, personality, psychopathology, and social interaction.  Consideration of how such knowledge relates to debates about nature and nurture, free will, consciousness, human differences, self, and society.
<br><I>J. D. Gabrieli</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=9.00');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.01"></a>
<p><h3>9.01 Introduction to Neuroscience
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the mammalian nervous system, with emphasis on the structure and function of the human brain. Topics include the function of nerve cells, sensory systems, control of movement, learning and memory, and diseases of the brain.
<br><I>H. S. Seung, M. Bear</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.011"></a>
<p><h3>9.011 Systems Neuroscience
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 6-0-12
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Survey of brain and behavioral studies. Examines principles underlying the structure and function of the nervous system, with a focus on systems approaches. Topics include development of the nervous system and its connections, sensory systems of the brain, the motor system, higher cortical functions, and behavioral and cellular analyses of learning and memory. Preference to first-year graduate students in BCS.
<br><I>M. Wilson, E. K. Miller</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.012"></a>
<p><h3>9.012 Cognitive Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 6-0-12
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-5056</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Intensive survey of cognitive science. Topics include visual perception, language, memory, cognitive architecture, learning, reasoning, decision-making, and cognitive development. Topics covered from behavioral, computational, and neural perspectives.
<br><I>E. Gibson, P. Sinha, J. Tenenbaum</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.013"></a>
<p><h3>9.013J Molecular and Cellular Neuroscience Core II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m7a.html#7.68">7.68J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-4062</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Survey and primary literature review of major areas in molecular and cellular neurobiology. Covers genetic neurotrophin signaling, adult neurogenesis, G-protein coupled receptor signaling, glia function, epigenetics, neuronal and homeostatic plasticity, neuromodulators of circuit function, and neurological/psychiatric disease mechanisms. Includes lectures and exams, and involves presentation and discussion of primary literature. 9.015 recommended, though the core subjects can be taken in any sequence.
<br><I>G. Feng, L.-H. Tsai, Y. Lin</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
<a name="9.015"></a>
<p><h3>9.015J Molecular and Cellular Neuroscience Core I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m7a.html#7.65">7.65J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Survey and primary literature review of major topic areas in molecular and cellular neurobiology. Covers neurogenomics, nervous system formation, axonal pathfinding, cytoskeletal regulation, synapse formation, neurotransmitter release, and cellular neurophysiology. Includes lectures and exam, together with presentation and discussion of primary literature. A final two-page research write-up is also due at the end of the term.
<br><I>J. T. Littleton, H. Sive, F. Gertler</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.04"></a>
<p><h3>9.04 Sensory Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m9a.html#9.01">9.01</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the neural bases of sensory perception. Focuses on physiological and anatomical studies of the mammalian nervous system as well as behavioral studies of animals and humans. Topics include visual pattern, color and depth perception, auditory responses and sound localization, olfactory and somatosensory perception.
<br><I>P. H. Schiller, M. C. Brown</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.044"></a>
<p><h3>9.044J Brain Mechanisms for Hearing and Speech
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mHSTb.html#HST.722">HST.722J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mHSTb.html#HST.723">HST.723</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>An advanced subject covering anatomical, physiological, behavioral, and computational studies of the central nervous system relevant to speech and hearing.  Students learn primarily by discussions of scientific papers on topics of current interest. Recent topics include neural circuits in the auditory brainstem, organization and processing in the auditory cortex, auditory reflexes and descending systems, functional imaging of the human auditory system, quantitive methods for relating neural responses to behavior, speech motor control, and cortical representation of language.
<br><I>M. C. Brown, B. Delgutte, F. Guenther, J. Melcher</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.073"></a>
<p><h3>9.073J Statistics for Neuroscience Research
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.460">HST.460J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img align="bottom" width=16 height=16 alt="Subject Cancelled" title="Subject Cancelled" src="/icns/buttonx.gif"> <i><b>Subject Cancelled</b></i> <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A survey of statistical methods for neuroscience research. Core topics include introductions to the theory of point processes, the generalized linear model, Monte Carlo methods, Bayesian methods, multivariate methods, time-series analysis, spectral analysis and state-space modeling. Emphasis on developing a firm conceptual understanding of the statistical paradigm and statistical methods primarily through analyses of actual experimental data.
<br><I>E. N. Brown</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.09"></a>
<p><h3>9.09J Cellular and Molecular Neurobiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m7a.html#7.29">7.29J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-3310</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-1015</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the structure and function of the nervous system. Emphasizes the cellular properties of neurons and other excitable cells. Includes the structure and biophysical properties of excitable cells, synaptic transmission, neurochemistry, neurodevelopment, integration of information in simple systems, and detection and information coding during sensory transduction.
<br><I>W. G. Quinn, T. Littleton</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=9.09');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.10"></a>
<p><h3>9.10 Behavioral Neuroscience
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m9a.html#9.01">9.01</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10.30-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-3310</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the cognitive and neural processes that support attention, vision, language, motor control, navigation, and memory. Introduces basic neuroanatomy, functional imaging techniques, and behavioral measures of cognition. Discusses methods by which inferences about the brain bases of cognition are made. Considers evidence from human and animal models. Students prepare presentations summarizing journal articles.
<br><I>R. Desimone, E. K. Miller</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=9.10');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.12"></a>
<p><h3>9.12 Experimental Molecular Neurobiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m9a.html#9.01">9.01</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 2-4-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Experimental techniques in cellular and molecular neurobiology. Designed for students without previous experience in techniques of cellular and molecular biology. Experimental approaches include tissue culture of neuronal cell lines, dissection and culture of brain cells, DNA manipulation, synaptic protein analysis, immunocytochemistry, and fluorescent microscopy. One lab session plus one paper review session per week. Instruction and practice in written communication provided. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>Y. Lin, F. Zhang</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.14"></a>
<p><h3>9.14 Brain Structure and its Origins
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m9a.html#9.01">9.01</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-3015</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to functional neuroanatomy with a focus on mammals, aided by studies of comparative neuroanatomy and evolution and of brain development. Topics include early steps to a central nervous system, basic patterns of brain and spinal cord connections, regional development and differentiation, regeneration, motor and sensory pathways and structures, systems underlying motivations, innate action patterns, formation of habits, and various cognitive functions. Review of lab techniques. Optional brain dissections.
<br><I>G. E. Schneider</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=9.14');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.15"></a>
<p><h3>9.15 Neuromodulatory and Neuroendocrine Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m9a.html#9.40">9.40</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the brain from a neuropharmacological perspective, specifically interactions governed by catecholamines, monoamines, neuropeptides, and more. Covers the functional contribution of neuromodulatory systems to both health and disease, and their influence on behaviors relevant to appetite and feeding, social behavior, reward and motivation, anxiety and fear, as well as how drugs alter neural activity.
<br><I>K. Tye</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.16"></a>
<p><h3>9.16 Cellular Neurophysiology
<br>(9.161)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m9a.html#9.40">9.40</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Surveys the mechanisms of neuronal communication. Covers ion channels in excitable membrane, single cell computation, synaptic transmission, and synaptic plasticity. Correlates the properties of ion channels and synaptic transmission with their physiological function. Discusses the organizational principles for the formation of functional neural networks at synaptic and cellular levels. Involves discussion of primary literature.
<br><I>W. Xu</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.17"></a>
<p><h3>9.17 Systems Neuroscience Laboratory
<br>(9.02)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m9a.html#9.40">9.40</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.05">18.05</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.440">18.440</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-4-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-1015</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>W1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-1024</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>T9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-1015</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Consists of a series of laboratories designed to give students experience with basic techniques for conducting systems neuroscience research. Includes sessions on anatomical, neurophysiological, and data acquisition and analysis techniques, and how these techniques are used to study nervous system function. Involves the use of experimental animals. Assignments include weekly preparation for lab sessions, two major lab reports and a series of basic computer programming tutorials (MATLAB). Instruction and practice in written communication provided. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>J. J. DiCarlo, M. Jazayeri, K. Tye</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.173"></a>
<p><h3>9.173J Noninvasive Imaging in Biology and Medicine
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m20a.html#20.483">20.483J</A>, <A HREF="m22b.html#22.56">22.56J</A>, <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.561">HST.561J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>, <a href="m8a.html#8.03">8.03</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Background in the theory and application of noninvasive imaging methods in biology and medicine, with emphasis on neuroimaging. Focuses on the modalities most frequently used in scientific research (x-ray CT, PET/SPECT, MRI, and optical imaging), and includes discussion of molecular imaging approaches used in conjunction with these scanning methods. Lectures are supplemented by in-class discussions of problems in research and demonstrations of imaging systems.
<br><I>A. Jasanoff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.18"></a>
<p><h3>9.18J Developmental Neurobiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as 7.49J)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.69">7.69J</A>, <A HREF="m9a.html#9.181">9.181J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m9a.html#9.01">9.01</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-1015</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=9.18');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
<a name="9.181"></a>
<h3>9.181J Developmental Neurobiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m7a.html#7.69">7.69J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with 7.49J, <A HREF="m9a.html#9.18">9.18J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m9a.html#9.011">9.011</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-1015</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Considers molecular control of neural specification, formation of neuronal connections, construction of neural systems, and the contributions of experience to shaping brain structure and function. Topics include: neural induction and pattern formation, cell lineage and fate determination, neuronal migration, axon guidance, synapse formation and stabilization, activity-dependent development and critical periods, development of behavior. In addition to final exam, analysis and presentation of  research papers required for final grade. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>E. Nedivi, M. Heiman</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=9.181');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.20"></a>
<p><h3>9.20 Animal Behavior
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: <a href="m9a.html#9.00">9.00</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Reviews studies of animal behavior to stress major ideas and principles, with emphasis on concepts developed in ethology and sociobiology. Examines foraging and feeding, defensive and aggressive behavior, courtship and reproduction, migration and navigation, as well as various social activities and communication. Considers inherited abilities, motivational systems and motor patterns, together with influences of various types of learning. Reviews both field and laboratory studies, and considers human behavior in the context of primate studies.
<br><I>G. E. Schneider</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.24"></a>
<p><h3>9.24 Disorders and Diseases of the Nervous System
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m9a.html#9.00">9.00</a>, <a href="m9a.html#9.01">9.01</a>, <a href="m9a.html#9.09">9.09</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Topics examined include regional functional anatomy of the CNS; brain systems and circuits; neurodevelopmental disorders including autism; neuropsychiatric disorders such as schizophrenia; neurodegenerative diseases such as Parkinson's and Alzheimer's; autoimmune disorders such as multiple sclerosis; gliomas. Emphasis on diseases for which a molecular mechanism is understood. Diagnostic criteria, clinical and pathological findings, genetics, model systems, pathophysiology, and treatment are discussed for individual disorders and diseases.
<br><I>M. Sur</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.26"></a>
<p><h3>9.26J Principles and Applications of Genetic Engineering for Biotechnology and Neuroscience
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m20a.html#20.205">20.205J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.28">7.28</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.32">7.32</a>, or <a href="m20a.html#20.020">20.020</a>; <a href="m9a.html#9.01">9.01</a> or <a href="m9a.html#9.09">9.09</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-3015</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers principles underlying current and future genetic engineering approaches, ranging from single cellular organisms to whole animals. Focuses on development and invention of technologies for engineering biological systems at the genomic level, and applications of engineered biological systems for medical and biotechnological needs, with particular emphasis on genetic manipulation of the nervous system. Design projects by students.
<br><I>F. Zhang</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.272"></a>
<p><h3>9.272J Topics in Neural Signal Processing
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.576">HST.576J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW10-11.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-3015</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents signal processing and statistical methods used to study neural systems and analyze neurophysiological data. Topics include state-space modeling formulated using the Bayesian Chapman-Kolmogorov system, theory of point processes, EM algorithm, Bayesian and sequential Monte Carlo methods. Applications include dynamic analyses of neural encoding, neural spike train decoding, studies of neural receptive field plasticity, algorithms for neural prosthetic control, EEG and MEG source localization. Students should know introductory probability theory and statistics. Alternate years.
<br><I>E. N. Brown</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.285"></a>
<p><h3>9.285J Neural Coding and Perception of Sound
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mHSTb.html#HST.723">HST.723J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-1-8
<br>Final exam at harvard. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11.30</i> (HMS TBA)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Neural structures and mechanisms mediating the detection, localization, and recognition of sounds. Discussion of how acoustic signals are coded by auditory neurons, the impact of these codes on behavorial performance, and the circuitry and cellular mechanisms underlying signal transformations. Topics include temporal coding, neural maps and feature detectors, learning and plasticity, and feedback control. General principles are conveyed by theme discussions of auditory masking, sound localization, musical pitch, cochlear implants, and auditory scene analysis. Follows Harvard FAS calendar.
<br><I>B. Delgutte, M. C. Brown, J. J. Guinan, J. Melcher, D. Polley and D. K. Eddington</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.301"></a>
<p><h3>9.301J Neural Plasticity in Learning and Memory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m7a.html#7.98">7.98J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/7.98/">http://web.mit.edu/7.98/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>R1-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-5305</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examination of the role of neural plasticity during learning and memory of invertebrates and mammals. Detailed critical analysis of the current literature of molecular, cellular, genetic, electrophysiological, and behavioral studies. Student-directed presentations and discussions of original papers supplemented by introductory lectures. Juniors and seniors require instructor's permission.
<br><I>S. Tonegawa, W. Quinn</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.31"></a>
<p><h3>9.31 Neurophysiology of Learning and Memory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m9a.html#9.01">9.01</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Surveys the mechanisms supporting plasticity in neurons, focusing on how it contributes to learning in several systems. Examines cellular forms of associative plasticity, including long-term potentiation and depression, metaplasticity, homeostatic plasticity, and depotentiation. Relates these phenomena to associative memory in animal systems and humans. Completion of 9.09 recommended.
<br><I>K. Goosens</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.322"></a>
<p><h3>9.322J Genetic Methods in Neurobiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m7a.html#7.67">7.67J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br>URL: <a href="http://mit.edu/7.67j/">http://mit.edu/7.67j/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-4062</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents selected topics in which genetic analysis informs neurobiological issues, including action potential conduction and synaptic release in Drosophila, axon guidance in nematodes and Drosophila, olfaction and orienting behavior in nematodes. Studies hippocampal and cortical circuitry and function in mice, as well as genetically-determined and genetically-influenced human traits and diseases. Reviews methods such as mutagenesis, gene knockouts and transgene constructs, tissue-specific expression vectors, optically, chemically and thermally-inducible gene activation and inactivation.
<br><I>W. G. Quinn</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.35"></a>
<p><h3>9.35 Sensation and Perception
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m9a.html#9.40">9.40</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.05">18.05</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.440">18.440</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-3315</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-3015</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies how the senses work and how physical stimuli are transformed into signals in the nervous system. Examines how the brain uses those signals to determine what's out there in the world. Discusses all the senses, with emphasis on vision. Topics include perception of color, motion, form, and depth. Students design experiments and collect data to address questions related to specific aspects of perceptual processing.
<br><I>J. McDermott</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=9.35');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.357"></a>
<p><h3>9.357 Current Topics in Vision Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Advanced seminar on issues of current interest in human and machine vision. Topics vary from year to year. Participants discuss current literature as well as their ongoing research.
<br><I>E. H. Adelson</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.40"></a>
<p><h3>9.40 Introduction to Neural Computation
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.00">6.00</a>, <a href="m9a.html#9.01">9.01</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10.30-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-3015</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces quantitative approaches to understanding brain and cognitive functions. Topics include mathematical description of neurons, the response of neurons to sensory stimuli, simple neuronal networks, statistical inference and decision making. Also covers foundational quantitative tools of data analysis in neuroscience: correlation, convolution, spectral analysis, principal components analysis. Mathematical concepts include simple differential equations and linear algebra.
<br><I>M. Fee</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.41"></a>
<p><h3>9.41 Research and Communication in Neuroscience and Cognitive Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m9b.html#9.URG">9.URG</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-12-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Emphasizes research and scientific communication. Instruction and practice in written and oral communication provided. Based on results of his/her UROP research, each student creates a full-length paper and a poster as part of an oral presentation at the end of the term. Other assignments include peer editing and reading/critiquing published research papers. Prior to starting class, students must have collected enough data from their UROP research projects to write a paper. Limited to juniors and seniors.
<br><I>S. Jhaveri, L. Schulz</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.422"></a>
<p><h3>9.422J Principles of Neuroengineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m20a.html#20.452">20.452J</A>, <A HREF="mMASa.html#MAS.881">MAS.881J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.03">8.03</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.003">6.003</a>, <a href="m9a.html#9.01">9.01</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://neuro.media.mit.edu/classes/prinneuro/">http://neuro.media.mit.edu/classes/prinneuro/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers how to innovate technologies for brain analysis and engineering, for accelerating the basic understanding of the brain, and leading to new therapeutic insight and inventions.  Focuses on using physical, chemical and biological principles to understand technology design criteria governing ability to observe and alter brain structure and function.  Topics include optogenetics, noninvasive brain imaging and stimulation, nanotechnologies, stem cells and tissue engineering, and advanced molecular and structural imaging technologies.  Design projects by students. Limited to 28.
<br><I>E. S. Boyden, III</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.455"></a>
<p><h3>9.455J Neurotechnology Ventures
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m15a.html#15.128">15.128J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.454">20.454J</A>, <A HREF="mMASa.html#MAS.883">MAS.883J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-7
<br>URL: <a href="http://neuro.media.mit.edu/classes/neuroven/">http://neuro.media.mit.edu/classes/neuroven/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Special seminar focusing on envisioning, launching, and building start-ups that are commercializing innovations from neuroscience and neuroengineering.  Topics include neuroimaging, diagnostics, motor rehabilitation, affective computing, novel scientific tools, and novel therapeutics including neuropharmaceuticals, neuromodulation, neuroprosthetics, regenerative medicine, and more.  Each class is devoted to a specific topic area, exploring issues from the deeply technical through the market opportunity.  Working in small groups students prepare a business plan executive summary for a new neurotechnology start-up.
<br><I>E. S. Boyden, R. Ellis-Behnke, J. Bonsen</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.46"></a>
<p><h3>9.46 Neuroscience of Morality
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m9a.html#9.00">9.00</a>, <a href="m9a.html#9.01">9.01</a>; <a href="m9a.html#9.10">9.10</a>, <a href="m9a.html#9.20">9.20</a>, or <a href="m9b.html#9.85">9.85</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Advanced seminar that covers both classic and cutting-edge primary literature from psychology and the neuroscience of morality. Addresses questions about how the human brain decides which actions are morally right or wrong (including neural mechanisms of empathy and self-control), how such brain systems develop over childhood and differ across individuals and cultures, and how they are affected by brain diseases (such as psychopathy, autism, tumors, or addiction). Instruction and practice in written and oral communication provided. Limited to 24.
<br><I>R. Saxe</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.472"></a>
<p><h3>9.472J Neuroimaging Cells and Circuits
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m20a.html#20.472">20.472J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Offers an introduction to imaging methods at the forefront of modern neurobiology.  Emphasis is placed on <i>in vivo</i> imaging in the context of neural systems research.  Specific topics covered include classical optics, fluorescence and fluorescent dyes, multiphoton microscopy, reflectance-based imaging methods, functional and anatomical magnetic resonance imaging, and molecular neuroimaging. Both applications and underlying principles are discussed, and lectures are supplemented by demonstrations of imaging techniques in the laboratory. Limited to 15.
<br><I>A. Jasanoff, P. T. So</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.48"></a>
<p><h3>9.48J Philosophical Issues in Brain Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hass2.gif" alt="HASS-D, Category 2" title="HASS-D, Category 2" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m24a.html#24.08">24.08J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>An introduction to some central philosophical questions about the mind, specifically those intimately connected with contemporary psychology and neuroscience. Discussions focus on arguments over innate concepts; 'mental images' as pictures in the head; whether color is in the mind or in the world; and whether there can be a science of consciousness. Explains the relevant parts of psychology and neuroscience as the subject proceeds.
<br><I>A. Byrne</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
</td></tr></table>
