<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Aerospace Studies<br>Spring
2014</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://web.mit.edu/afrotc/"><i>AS Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=++AS&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>AS.00-AS.599</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<h3>ROTC subjects do not carry academic credit at MIT, but they can be counted toward the PE requirement. (Up to two points per year with a maximum of four points.)</h3>
<h2>Aerospace Studies</h2>
<a name="AS.101"></a>
<p><h3>AS.101 The Foundations of the United States Air Force
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.111">AS.111</a></I>
<br>Units: 1-0-1
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>
<a name="AS.102"></a>
<h3>AS.102 The Foundations of the United States Air Force
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.101">AS.101</a> or permission of instructor; <I>Coreq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.112">AS.112</a></I>
<br>Units: 1-0-1
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=W59">W59-164</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Survey designed to introduce students to the United States Air Force and Air Force Reserve Officer Training Corps. Topics include mission and organization of the Air Force, officership and professionalism, military customs and courtesies, Air Force officer opportunities, group leadership problems, and an introduction to communication skills. AS.102 is a continuation of AS.101.
<br><I>M. Parry</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="AS.111"></a>
<p><h3>AS.111 Leadership Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.101">AS.101</a></I>
<br>Units: 0-2-2 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>
<a name="AS.112"></a>
<h3>AS.112 Leadership Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.111">AS.111</a> or permission of instructor; <I>Coreq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.102">AS.102</a></I>
<br>Units: 0-2-2 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=W59">W59-073</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Includes a study of Air Force customs and courtesies, drill and ceremonies, and military commands. Also includes studying the environment of an Air Force officer and learning about areas of opportunity available to commissioned officers, as well as interviews, guidance, and information to increase the understanding, motivation, and performance of other cadets. AS.112 is a continuation of AS.111.
<br><I>M. Parry</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="AS.201"></a>
<p><h3>AS.201 The Evolution of USAF Air and Space Power
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.102">AS.102</a> or permission of instructor; <I>Coreq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.211">AS.211</a></I>
<br>Units: 1-0-1
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>
<a name="AS.202"></a>
<h3>AS.202 The Evolution of USAF Air and Space Power
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.201">AS.201</a> or permission of instructor; <I>Coreq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.212">AS.212</a></I>
<br>Units: 1-0-1
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=W59">W59-073</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Survey designed to facilitate the transition from Air Force ROTC cadet to Air Force ROTC officer candidate. Topics include Air Force heritage and leaders, Quality Air Force, an introduction to ethics and values, introduction to leadership, group leadership problems, and continuing application of communication skills. AS.202 is a continuation of AS.201.
<br><I>T. Weibel</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="AS.211"></a>
<p><h3>AS.211 Leadership Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.112">AS.112</a> or permission of instructor; <I>Coreq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.201">AS.201</a></I>
<br>Units: 0-2-2 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>
<a name="AS.212"></a>
<h3>AS.212 Leadership Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.211">AS.211</a> or permission of instructor; <I>Coreq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.202">AS.202</a></I>
<br>Units: 0-2-2 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=W59">W59-073</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Emphasizes development of techniques used to direct and inform. Students are assigned leadership and management positions in the AS.111 programs described above. AS.212 is a continuation of AS.211.
<br><I>M. Parry</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="AS.301"></a>
<p><h3>AS.301 Air Force Leadership Studies
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.202">AS.202</a> or permission of instructor; <I>Coreq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.311">AS.311</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>
<a name="AS.302"></a>
<h3>AS.302 Air Force Leadership Studies
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.301">AS.301</a> or permission of instructor; <I>Coreq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.312">AS.312</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=W59">W59-073</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Study of leadership, quality management fundamentals, professional knowledge, Air Force doctrine, leadership ethics, and communication skills required of an Air Force junior officer. Case studies are used to examine Air Force leadership and management situations as a means of demonstrating and exercising practical application of the concepts being studied. AS.302 is a continuation of AS.301.
<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="AS.311"></a>
<p><h3>AS.311 Leadership Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.212">AS.212</a> or permission of instructor; <I>Coreq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.301">AS.301</a></I>
<br>Units: 0-2-4 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>
<a name="AS.312"></a>
<h3>AS.312 Leadership Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.311">AS.311</a> or permission of instructor; <I>Coreq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.302">AS.302</a></I>
<br>Units: 0-2-4 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=W59">W59-073</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Consists of activities classified as advanced leadership experiences that involve the planning and controlling of military activities of the cadet corps and the preparation and presentation of briefings and other oral and written communications. Also includes interviews, guidance, and information to increase the understanding, motivation, and performance of other cadets. AS.312 is a continuation of AS.311.
<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="AS.401"></a>
<p><h3>AS.401 National Security Affairs/Preparation for Active Duty
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.302">AS.302</a> or permission of instructor; <I>Coreq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.411">AS.411</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>
<a name="AS.402"></a>
<h3>AS.402 National Security Affairs/Preparation for Active Duty
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.401">AS.401</a> or permission of instructor; <I>Coreq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.412">AS.412</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR8-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=W59">W59-073</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the national security process, regional studies, advanced leadership ethics, and Air Force doctrine. Special topics of interest focus on the military as a profession, officership, military justice, civilian control of the military, preparation for active duty, and current issues affecting military professionalism. Within this structure, continued emphasis on refining communication skills. AS.402 is a continuation of AS.401.
<br><I>T. Weibel</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="AS.411"></a>
<p><h3>AS.411 Leadership Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.312">AS.312</a> or permission of instructor; <I>Coreq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.401">AS.401</a></I>
<br>Units: 0-2-4 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>
<a name="AS.412"></a>
<h3>AS.412 Leadership Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.411">AS.411</a> or permission of instructor; <I>Coreq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.402">AS.402</a></I>
<br>Units: 0-2-4 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=W59">W59-073</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Consists of activities classified as advanced leadership experiences that involve the planning and controlling of military activities of the cadet corps, and the preparation and presentation of briefings and other oral and written communications.  Also includes interviews, guidance, and information to increase the understanding, motivation, and performance of other cadets. AS.412 is a continuation of AS.411.
<br><I>M. Parry</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="AS.511"></a>
<p><h3>AS.511 Leadership Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.412">AS.412</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 0-2-4 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>
<a name="AS.512"></a>
<h3>AS.512 Leadership Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.511">AS.511</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 0-2-4 [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>T3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=W59">W59-073</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Consists of activities classified as advanced leadership experiences to continue developing critical leadership, managerial and communication skills along with maintaining an active, physical lifestyle needed in today's Air Force. AS.512 is a continuation of AS.511.
<br><I>M. Parry</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->

2014</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://concourse.mit.edu"><i>CC Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=+CON&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>CC.00 - CC.UR</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>

<h2>Concourse Science Subjects</h2>
<h3><br>Chemistry</h3>
<a name="CC.5111"></a>
<p><h3>CC.5111 Principles of Chemical Science
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/chem.gif" alt="Chemistry" title="Chemistry" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m3a.html#3.091">3.091</A>, <A HREF="m5a.html#5.111">5.111</A>, <A HREF="m5a.html#5.112">5.112</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.3091">ES.3091</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.5111">ES.5111</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.5112">ES.5112</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-160</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-160</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Equivalent to 5.111; see 5.111 for description. Limited to students in Concourse.
<br><I>E. Vogel</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=CC.5111');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<h3><br>Mathematics</h3>
<a name="CC.181A"></a>
<p><h3>CC.181A Calculus
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/calc1.gif" alt="Calculus I" title="Calculus I" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Knowledge of differentiation and elememtary integration; <I>Coreq: CC.A10 or <a href="mCCa.html#CC.010">CC.010</a></I>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.01">18.01</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.01A">18.01A</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.181A">ES.181A</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Equivalent to 18.01A; see 18.01A for description. Limited to students in Concourse.
<br><I>R. Winters</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CC.182A"></a>
<p><h3>CC.182A Calculus
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">) <img src="/icns/calc2.gif" alt="Calculus II" title="Calculus II" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>; <I>Coreq: CC.A10, <a href="mCCa.html#CC.010">CC.010</a>, or <a href="mCCa.html#CC.011">CC.011</a></I>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.02">18.02</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.02A">18.02A</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.182A">ES.182A</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Equivalent to 18.02A; see 18.02A for descriptoin. Limited to students in Concourse.
<br><I>R. Winters</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CC.1802"></a>
<p><h3>CC.1802 Calculus
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/calc2.gif" alt="Calculus II" title="Calculus II" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>; <I>Coreq: CC.A10, <a href="mCCa.html#CC.010">CC.010</a>, or <a href="mCCa.html#CC.011">CC.011</a></I>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.02">18.02</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.022">18.022</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.023">18.023</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.024">18.024</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.02A">18.02A</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.182A">CC.182A</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.1802">ES.1802</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.182A">ES.182A</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Equivalent to 18.02; see 18.02 for description. Limited to students in Concourse.
<br><I>R. Winters</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CC.1803"></a>

<h3><br>Physics</h3>

<br>Units: 5-0-7

<h2>Concourse HASS Subjects</h2>
<a name="CC.110"></a>
<p><h3>CC.110 Becoming Human: Ancient Perspectives on the Best Life
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: CC.A10 or <a href="mCCa.html#CC.010">CC.010</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Considers how ancient writers thought about the best human life. Students examine the contrasting views of selected major works by authors such as Plato, Aristotle, Thucydides, Herodotus, Epicurus, Lucretius, and St. Augustine. Texts are also used as tools for thinking about the goals and purposes of modern life. Limited to students in Concourse.
<br><I>L. Rabieh</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CC.111"></a>
<p><h3>CC.111 Modern Conceptions of Freedom
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="mCCa.html#CC.011">CC.011</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students read early modern political theorists, and trace the growth of the value of freedom.  Examines the modern definition of freedom, and the obligations that people accept in honoring it.  Also investigates how these obligations are captured in the principles of our political association.  Studies how the centrality of freedom plays out in the political thought of such authors as Hobbes, Locke, Rousseau, Burke and Montesquieu.  Students also debate which notions of freedom inspire and sustain the American experiment by carefully reading the documents and arguments of the founding of the United States. Limited to students in Concourse.
<br><I>L. Rabieh</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CC.112"></a>
<p><h3>CC.112 Philosophy of Love
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W EVE (7-9.30 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-160</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the nature of love through works of philosophy, literature, film, poetry, and individual experience. Investigates the distinction among eros, philia, and agape. Students discuss ideas of love as a feeling, an action, a species of 'knowing someone,' or a way to give or take. Authors include Plato, Kant, Buber, D. H. Lawrence, Rumi, and Aristotle.
<br><I>L. Perlman, L. Rabieh</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CC.113"></a>
<p><h3>CC.113 Ancient Greek Philosophy and Mathematics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hass2.gif" alt="HASS-D, Category 2" title="HASS-D, Category 2" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: CC.A10 or <a href="mCCa.html#CC.010">CC.010</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the relationship between ancient Greek philosophy and mathematics. Investigates how ideas of definition, reason, argument and proof, rationality/irrationality, number, quality and quantity, truth, and even the idea of an idea were shaped by the interplay of philosophic and mathematical inquiry. Examines how discovery of the incommensurability of magnitudes challenged the Greek presumption that the cosmos is fully understandable. Explores the influence of mathematics on ancient Greek ethical theories. Authors: Euclid, Plato, Aristotle, Nicomachus, Theon of Smyrna, Bacon, Descartes, Dedekind, and Newton. Limited to students in Concourse.
<br><I>L. Perlman</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CC.116"></a>
<p><h3>CC.116 How to Rule the World: The Promises and Pitfalls of Politics, War, and Empire
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>R12-2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-160</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>T12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-160</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the ambitions and constraints of political rule in order to understand how transformational leaders have (or should have) managed both in the service of good government. Employs normative and empirical methods to assess effective leadership, with particular attention to trade-offs between justice and security and to competing notions of justice itself. Includes case studies and various foundational texts that address the theme of great political leadership. Drawing on the texts, students discern different criteria for good rule and assess both the adequacy of those criteria and whether case studies support them. Preference to Concourse students.
<br><I>L. Rabieh</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=CC.116');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->

<p><h3>CC.010 Seminar I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Comparative Media Studies<br>Spring
2014</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://cms.mit.edu"><i>CMS Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/courseCMS.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=+CMS&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>CMS.00-CMS.999 plus UROP and Thesis</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<h2>Undergraduate Subjects</h2>
<a name="CMS.100"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.100 Introduction to Media Studies
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hass4.gif" alt="HASS-D, Category 4" title="HASS-D, Category 4" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1.30-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-150</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>W1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-168</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Offers an overview of the social, cultural, political, and economic impact of mediated communication on modern culture. Combines critical discussions with experiments working with different media. Media covered include radio, television, film, the printed word, and digital technologies. Topics include the nature and function of media, core media institutions, and media in transition. Enrollment limited.
<br>Fall: <I>V. Bald, D. F. Harrell</I><br>Spring: <I>I. Condry</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=CMS.100');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.300"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.300 Introduction to Videogame Theory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.841">CMS.841</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-153</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-153</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=12">12-122</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the interdisciplinary study of videogames as texts through an examination of their cultural, educational, and social functions in contemporary settings. Students play and analyze videogames while reading current research and theory from a variety of sources in the sciences, social sciences, humanities, and industry. Assignments focus on game analysis in the context of the theories discussed in class.  Includes regular reading, writing, and presentation exercises. No prior programming experience required. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 20.
<br>Fall: <I>M. Jakobsson, T. L. Taylor</I><br>Spring: <I>M. Jakobsson</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.301"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.301 Introduction to Game Design Methods
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassT.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-142</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to the process of designing games and playful experiences. Familiarizes students with concepts, methods, techniques and tools used in the design of a wide variety of games. Focuses on aspects of the process such as rapid prototyping, play testing, and design iteration using a player-centered approach. Students work in project groups where they engage with a series of confined exercises, practice communicating design ideas, and discuss their own and others work in a constructive manner. No prior programming experience required. Limited to 15.
<br><I>M. Jakobsson, S. Verrilli</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.308"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.308 The Visual Story: Graphic Novel, Type to Tablet
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassT.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.808">CMS.808</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on the interactions between graphic stories and media technologies from the rotary press of the late 19th century to contemporary touch screens, exploring the changing relations among narrative expression, reader experience and media form. Working with examples from Pulitzer's Yellow Kid and McKay's Little Nemo, through the classic comics (from DC superheroes to EC horror) and graphic novels, to interactive and non-linear texts (Cognitos Operation Ajax), examines such elements as graphic design, interface, and form as well as the circulation and economies of these various media-based texts. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>J. Paradis, W. Uricchio</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.309"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.309J Transmedia Storytelling: Modern Science Fiction
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Wb.html#21W.763">21W.763J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.809">CMS.809</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-2-7
<br>URL: <a href="http://cms.mit.edu/academics/courseInfo.php?courseID=CMS.309">http://cms.mit.edu/academics/courseInfo.php?courseID=CMS.309</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR3-4.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-233</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores transmedia storytelling by investigating how science fiction stories are told across different media, such as the short story, the screenplay, moving image, and games. Students read and write critical essays and collaborate to produce their own work of science fiction in a roundtable workshop environment. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br>Fall: <I>H. Hendershot</I><br>Spring: <I>S. Lewitt</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.311"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.311J Media in Weimar and Nazi Germany
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Fa.html#21F.055">21F.055J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-2-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2-3.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E15">E15-335</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Debates over national and media identity in Weimar and Nazi Germany. Production and use of media under extreme political and social conditions with a focus on films (such as <I>Nosferatu, Berlin, M, </i>and <I>Triumph des Willens</i>) and other media. Media approached as both texts and systems. Considers the legacy of the period, in terms of stylistic influence (e.g. film noir), techniques of persuasion, and media's relationship to social and economic conditions. Taught in English. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>W. Uricchio</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.312"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.312 Topics in National and Post-National Cinema
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.812">CMS.812</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mCMSa.html#CMS.100">CMS.100</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies contemporary films emerging from nations such as South Korea, Iran, and Denmark. Explores the importance of cultural settings, the nature of local funding schemes and production practices, and deeper stylistic continuities with the past. Focuses on one nation's productions (including ?migr? filmmakers), considering their history, innovations, and meanings in a world in which the idea of nation is increasingly challenged by such factors as immigration, labor outsourcing, and multiculturalism. Examines film's relationship with other media forms, such as television and social media. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>H. J. Chung</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.313"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.313 Silent Film
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.813">CMS.813</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T EVE (7-10 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-114</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>M EVE (7-9 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-114</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines how the key elements of today's films - composition, continuity editing, lighting, narrative structure - were originally created. Studies the history of cinema, from its origins in the late 19th century to the transition to sound in the late 1920s and early 1930s. Students view a range of films (both mainstream and experimental) from all over the world, with a particular focus on US productions. Emphasis on how color, sound, and other developments paved the way for today's technological innovations.   Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>H. Hendershot</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.314"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.314J Phantasmal Media: Theory and Practice
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>(Same subject as 21W.753J)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.814">CMS.814</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Engages students in theory and practice of using computational techniques for developing expressive digital media works. Surveys approaches to understanding human imaginative processes, such as constructing concepts, metaphors, and narratives, and applies them to producing and understanding socially, culturally, and critically meaningful works in digital media. Readings engage a variety of theoretical perspectives from cognitive linguistics, literary and cultural theory, semiotics, digital media arts, and computer science. Students produce interactive narratives, games, and related forms of software art. Some programming and/or interactive web scripting experience (e.g., Flash, Javascript) is desirable. Students taking the graduate version complete a project requiring more in-depth theoretical engagement.
<br><I>D. Harrell</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.333"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.333J Production of Educational Videos:  Skills for Communicating Academic and Professional Content
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassT.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as ES.333J)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-1-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=24">24-618</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops communication and media skills through the production of educational videos. Students conceive, plan, script, shoot and edit video content to teach elements of MIT's curriculum. Each student creates a series of short videos that concisely explains and contextualizes specific problems of importance to disciplines at MIT, especially physics, math, chemistry, biology, or the humanities. The resulting videos present these problems through compelling use of illustrations, demonstrations, animations, and commentary, all from the student's perspective. Empowers students specifically to communicate their MIT expertise to communities of learners and generally to reach broad audiences with quality, accessible online content. Preference to students in ESG.
<br><I>D. Custer</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.334"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.334J South Asian America: Transnational Media, Culture, and History
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Wb.html#21W.788">21W.788J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T EVE (7-10 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-253</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the history of South Asian immigration, sojourning, and settlement from the 1880s to the present. Focuses on the US as one node in the global circulation, not only of people, but of media, culture and ideas, through a broader South Asian diaspora. Considers the concept of "global media" historically; emphasis on how ideas about, and self-representations of, South Asians have circulated via books, political pamphlets, performance, film, video/cassette tapes, and the internet. Students analyze and discuss scholarly writings, archival documents, memoirs, fiction, blogs and films, and write papers drawing on course materials, lectures, and discussions. Limited to 18.
<br><I>V. Bald</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.335"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.335J Short Attention Span Documentary
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Wb.html#21W.790">21W.790J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m21Wb.html#21W.890">21W.890</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR3.30-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E15">E15-335</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on the production of short (1- to 5-minute) digital video documentaries: a form of non-fiction filmmaking that has proliferated in recent years due to the ubiquity of palm-sized and mobile phone cameras and the rise of web-based platforms, such as YouTube. Students shoot, edit, workshop and revise a series of short videos meant to engage audiences in a topic, introduce them to new ideas, and/or persuade them. Screenings and discussions cover key principles of documentary film - narrative, style, pace, point of view, argument, character development - examining how they function and change in short format. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 16.
<br><I>V. Bald</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.336"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.336J The Social Documentary: Analysis and Production
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Wb.html#21W.786">21W.786J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.836">CMS.836</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>An introduction to the history of the social documentary from the 1960s through the 1980s. Explores how social upheaval and the shift to smaller, more portable film cameras, and ultimately hand-held video, converged to bring about an upsurge of socially engaged documentary film production. Students screen and analyze a series of key films from the period and work in groups to produce their own short documentary using digital video and computer-based editing. Limited to 18.
<br><I>V. Bald</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.338"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.338 Innovation in Documentary: Technologies and Techniques
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.838">CMS.838</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mCMSa.html#CMS.100">CMS.100</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E15">E15-335</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Discusses emerging technologies and techniques available to media-makers (e.g., location-based technologies, transmedia storytelling, crowdsourcing, and interactivity) and their implications on the film and television documentary. Studies the development of these tools and considers the many new directions in which they may take the genre. Includes screenings, meetings with documentary makers, and an experimental component in which students can explore new approaches to documentary production. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>W. Uricchio</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.350"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.350J Topics and Methods in 21st-Century Journalism
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassT.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Wb.html#21W.737">21W.737J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.850">CMS.850</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW3-4.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-261</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Gives a broad understanding of what it means to produce journalism today. Evaluates the limitations and strengths of specific types of media, ranging from New York Times stories to Twitter feeds. Provides students with tools to effectively communicate their own work and research to non-specialist audiences. Students submit assignments via an online portal, which mimics the style and substance of an online news source. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 18.
<br>Fall: <I>S. Mnookin</I><br>Spring: <I>T. Coates</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.360"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.360 Introduction to Civic Media
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.860">CMS.860</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines civic media in comparative, transnational and historical perspectives. Introduces various theoretical tools, research approaches, and project design methods. Students engage with multimedia texts on concepts such as citizen journalism, transmedia activism, media justice, and civic, public, radical, and tactical media. Case studies explore civic media across platforms (print, radio, broadcast, internet), contexts (from local to global, present-day to historical), and use (dialogic, contentious, hacktivist). As a final project, students develop a case study or project proposal. Students taking the graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 20.
<br><I>S. Costanza-Chock</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.361"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.361 Networked Social Movements: Media and Mobilization
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.861">CMS.861</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E15">E15-363</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an overview of social movement studies as a body of theoretical and empirical work, with an emphasis on understanding the relationship between social movements and the media. Explores multiple methods of social movement investigation, including textual and media analysis, surveys, interviews, focus groups, participant observation, and co-research. Covers recent innovations in social movement theory, as well as new data sources and tools for research and analysis. Includes short papers, a literature review, and a final research project. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 16.
<br><I>S. Costanza-Chock</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.362"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.362 Civic Media Collaborative Design Studio
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.862">CMS.862</A>)
<br>Prereq: One subject in CMS or MAS
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W EVE (7-10 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E15">E15-344</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Project-based studio focusing on collaborative design of civic media provides a service-learning opportunity for students interested in working with community organizations. Multidisciplinary teams create civic media projects based on real-world community needs. Covers co-design methods and best practices to include the user community in iterative stages of project ideation, design, implementation, testing, and evaluation. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 16.
<br><I>S. Costanza-Chock</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.363"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.363 Civic Media, Past and Future
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassT.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.873">CMS.873</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the history and futures of civic media and the corresponding vision of citizenship that civic media facilitates. Topics include orality and literacy during the rise of democratic governance in ancient Greece, the affordances and limitations of new civic media in the 19th and 20th centuries, the role of education in promoting civic media use, the "Gutenberg parenthesis," and the emergence of secondary orality in the digital age. Uses historical case studies to illustrate the political and economic effects of new civic media; to enhance theoretical and practical understanding of communication, technology, and political action; and to imagine future models to maximize the opportunities and efficacy of civic media. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>E. Schiappa</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.376"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.376 History of Media and Technology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.876">CMS.876</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img align="bottom" width=16 height=16 alt="Subject Cancelled" title="Subject Cancelled" src="/icns/buttonx.gif"> <i><b>Subject Cancelled</b></i> <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Surveys the interrelated histories of communications media and technological development, from the emergence of 19th-century forms of mass print media and telegraphy, to sound capture and image-based forms (e.g., film, radio, and television), to the shift from analog to digital cultures. Examines how new forms of communication exert social, political, and cultural influences in the global context. Explores how technological innovation and accelerating media affect social values and behaviors in the popular and global adoption of a media device. Includes two papers and a research project on aspects of media history. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>J. Paradis</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.400"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.400 Media Systems and Texts
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: One subject in Comparative Media Studies or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>F1-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E15">E15-335</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores theoretical, historical and critical approaches to the comparative study of media. Examines media from three perspectives: the historical evolution of particular media forms (media in transition); the migration of particular narratives across different media forms (trans-media texts); and the ways in which media texts and systems cross cultural and national boundaries (global crossings). Instruction and practice in written and oral communication provided.
<br><I>E. Schiappa, C. Peterson</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.403"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.403J Media and Methods: Performing
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Mb.html#21M.703">21M.703J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mCMSa.html#CMS.100">CMS.100</a>, <a href="m21La.html#21L.011">21L.011</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW11.30-1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=50">50-305</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>T EVE (7-10 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=50">50-305</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar examines an array of performance disciplines from the perspective of the performer. Explores what it means to read the human body as a dynamic medium of expression; how fundamental techniques of the performer shift across cultural borders and in step with changing social contexts and historical traditions; and how the expressive tactics of one media platform adapt to the demands of another. Students engage in close analysis of performance practices, acquiring a theoretical and historical framework for thinking about performance across disciplines. Complemented by outside readings, video viewings, short essays, and studio performances, this course is intended to provide students with an introduction to core concepts in performance studies as they relate more generally to the study of media. Instruction and practice in written and oral communication provided. Limited to 20.
<br><I>J. Scheib</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.405"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.405 Media and Methods: Seeing and Expression
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: <a href="m21La.html#21L.011">21L.011</a> or <a href="mCMSa.html#CMS.100">CMS.100</a>
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the process of making and sharing visual artifacts using a trans-cultural, trans-historical, constructionist approach. Explores the relationship between perceived reality and the narrative imagination, how an author's choice of medium and method constrains the work, how desire is integrated into the structure of a work, and how the cultural/economic opportunity for exhibition/distribution affects the realization of a work.  Instruction and practice in written and oral communication provided. Limited to 20.
<br><I>D. F. Harrell</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.407"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.407 Media and Methods: Sound
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m21Aa.html#21A.505">21A.505</A>, <A HREF="mSTSa.html#STS.065">STS.065</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the ways in which humans experience the realm of sound and how perceptions and technologies of sound emerge from cultural, economic, and historical worlds. Examines how environmental, linguistic, and musical sounds are construed cross-culturally. Describes the rise of telephony, architectural acoustics, and sound recording, and the globalized travel of these technologies. Addresses questions of ownership, property, authorship, and copyright in the age of digital file sharing. Particular focus on how the sound/noise boundary is imagined, created and modeled across diverse sociocultural and scientific contexts. Auditory examples--sound art, environmental recordings, music--will be provided and invited. Instruction and practice in written and oral communication provided. Limited to 20.
<br><I>J. Picker</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.590"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.590J Computer Games and Simulations for Investigation and Education
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11a.html#11.127">11.127J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m11b.html#11.252">11.252J</A>, <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.863">CMS.863J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-6-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E15">E15-301</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores how we learn from computer games and simulations, and delves into the process of building and testing interactive educational media.  First, students investigate the design and use of games and simulations in the classroom (including commercial off-the-shelf games), as well as the research and development issues associated with desktop computer-based, mobile, and non-computer based media. Students then develop their own simulations and games, study what and how others learn from them (including field testing of products), and how games and simulations can be implemented in educational settings. All levels of computer experience welcome. Graduate students are expected to complete additional assignments.
<br><I>E. Klopfer</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=CMS.590');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->

<a name="CMS.604"></a>
<h3>CMS.604 Independent Study
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Opportunity for individual research in comparative media studies. Registration subject to prior arrangement for subject matter and supervision by a faculty member.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>No textbook information available
