<a name="CMS.607"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.607 From Gamer to Player: Theory and Practice of Player Research
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.843">CMS.843</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mCMSa.html#CMS.300">CMS.300</a>, <a href="mCMSa.html#CMS.608">CMS.608</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on the theories and methods of researching digital game players. Draws on approaches from humanities, social science, and mass communication fields to inform and inspire student research. Examines the strengths, weaknesses, and appropriate use of different data collection methods. Emphasizes familiarity with research philosophy, rules and regulations for working with human subjects. Analyzes current research on digital games and their players to inform understanding of research in practice. Students theorize and develop a player-focused study, collect data, and produce a research paper analyzing their data over the course of the term. Students taking the graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 20.
<br><I>T. Harper</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.608"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.608 Game Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.864">CMS.864</A>)
<br>Prereq: One subject in Comparative Media Studies or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-142</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Practical instruction in the design and analysis of non-digital games. Provides students the texts, tools, references, and historical context to analyze and compare game designs across a variety of genres. In teams, students design, develop, and thoroughly test their original games to better understand the interaction and evolution of game rules. Covers various genres and types of games, including sports, game shows, games of chance, card games, schoolyard games, board games, and role-playing games. Students taking the graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 20.
<br><I>P. Tan</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=CMS.608');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.609"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.609J The Word Made Digital
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Wb.html#21W.764">21W.764J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.846">CMS.846</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-103</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Video games, digital art and literature, online texts, and source code are analyzed in the contexts of history, culture, and computing platforms. Approaches from poetics and computer science are used to understand the non-narrative digital uses of text. Students undertake critical writing and creative computer projects to encounter digital writing through practice. This involves reading and modifying computer programs; therefore previous programming experience, although not required, will be helpful. The graduate section includes additional assignments. Limited to 18.
<br><I>N. Montfort</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.610"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.610 Media Industries and Systems: The Art, Science and Business of Games
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.922">CMS.922</A>)
<br>Prereq: Two CMS subjects or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>F1-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=14">14E-310</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the interplay of art, science, law, and commerce in the production, marketing, distribution, and consumption of historic and contemporary videogames. Students create prototypes and develop marketing programs to illustrate the challenges of producing videogames in a professional context. Combines perspectives on media industries and systems with an examination of the creative process, development, and trends that shape content. Includes discussions with industry leaders in various areas. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>C. Weaver</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=CMS.610');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.611"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.611J Creating Video Games
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6a.html#6.073">6.073J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mCMSa.html#CMS.608">CMS.608</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.01">6.01</a>
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces students to the complexities of working in small, multidisciplinary teams to develop video games. Covers creative design and production methods, stressing design iteration and regular testing across all aspects of game development (design, visual arts, music, fiction, and programming). Assumes a familiarity with current video games, and the ability to discuss games critically. Previous experience in audio design, visual arts, or project management recommended. Limited to 24.
<br><I>P. Tan, S. Verrilli, O. Macindoe, P. Kaelbling</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.612"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.612J Writing for Videogames
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Wb.html#21W.767">21W.767J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.866">CMS.866</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the convergence of fiction, dramatic writing and game design in writing for videogames. Addresses the problematic relationship between storytelling and games, from both an analytical and practical standpoint. Discusses theory and analysis of pre-existing games. Assignments provide students the opportunity to tackle specific writing problems in a creative way. Basic programming knowledge and previous coursework in game design, videogame theory, interactive narrative or play writing is useful but not required. Graduate students complete additional assignments. Limited to 15.
<br><I>C. Fernandez Vara</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.613"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.613J Writing for Social Media
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Wb.html#21W.751">21W.751J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W1-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-191</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores how social media is changing our understanding of writing, multimedia, and authorship. Through individual assignments and collaborative work, students contribute to an overarching writing project developed in a networked software environment, and develop their own social media practices. Assigned readings include exemplary selections from existing public social media projects, as well as scholarly work and analysis by noted media critics. Limited to 18.
<br><I>F. Klink</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.614"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.614J Network Cultures
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as 21W.791J)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.867">CMS.867</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on the social and cultural aspects of networked life through internet-related technologies (including computers, mobile devices, entertainment technologies, and emerging media forms). Theories and readings focus on the cultural, social, economic, and political aspects of internet use and design. Topics include online communication and communities, social media, gender and race in network spaces, activism and hacking, networked publics, remix culture and intellectual property. Students taking the graduate version complete additional readings and assignments.
<br><I>T. L. Taylor</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.615"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.615 Games for Social Change
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.815">CMS.815</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines how various movements have tried over time to create games that enable players to enact social change. Students collaborate in teams to design and prototype games for social change and civic engagement. In a workshop setting, teams develop games and showcase them at an end-of-term open house. Features guest speakers from academia and industry as well as the nonprofit sector and the gaming community. Readings explore principals of game design and the social history of games. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>S. Osterweil</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.616"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.616J Games and Culture
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as 21W.768J)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.868">CMS.868</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR3.30-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=14">14N-325</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the social, cultural, economic, and political aspects of digital games. Topics include the culture of gameplay, gaming styles, communities, spectatorship and performance, gender and race within digital gaming, and the politics and economics of production processes, including co-creation and intellectual property. Students taking graduate version complete additional readings and assignments.
<br><I>T. L. Taylor</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.617"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.617 Advanced Game Studio
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassT.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: <a href="mCMSa.html#CMS.608">CMS.608</a> or <a href="mCMSa.html#CMS.611">CMS.611</a>
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>R1-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-168</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students join the class in pre-formed teams, which work under the supervision of experienced mentors to complete a term-long game creation project. Covers management best practices for software engineering teams; creative expression as a collaborative project; developing and evaluating prototypes for potential viability, and translating them into a final polished product; planning and running qualitative testing of design elements; and targeting and selecting an appropriate audience for testing. Includes regular reviews and critiques to discuss progress, design, and work plan. Culminates with public presentation of games. Limited to 15.
<br><I>P. Tan, S. Verrilli, T. L. Taylor</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.621"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.621 Fans and Fan Cultures
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.821">CMS.821</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T EVE (7-10 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-124</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines media audiences - specifically, fans - and the subcultures that evolve around them. Examines the different historical, contemporary and transnational understandings of fans. Explores products of fan culture, i.e., clubs, fiction, "vids," activism, etc. Readings place these products within the context of various disciplines. Students consider the concept of the "aca-fan" and reflect on their own "fannish" practices. Requires several short papers. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 20.
<br><I>K. Delaney</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=CMS.621');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.627"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.627 Imagination, Computation, and Expression Studio
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.827">CMS.827</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Aims to help students invent and analyze new forms of computer-based art, gaming, social media, interactive narrative, and related technologies. Students participate in a range of new and ongoing projects that are designed to hone skills in research, development, design, and evaluation. Topics vary from year to year; examples include cognitive science and artificial intelligence-based approaches to the arts; social aspects of game design; computing for social empowerment; and game character, avatar, and online profile design. May be repeated for credit with permission of instructor. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>D. Fox Harrell</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.628"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.628 Advanced Identity Representation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.828">CMS.828</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies and develops computational identity systems for games, social media, virtual worlds, and computer-based artwork. An interdisciplinary set of readings (cognitive science, computer science, art, and sociology) looks at both the underlying technology and the social/cultural aspects of identity. Includes topics such as developing improved characters, avatars, agents, social networking profiles, and online accounts. Engages students in on-going  research projects. Explores how social categories are formed in digital media, including gender, class, and ethnicity, along with everyday social categories (such as those based on personality or shared media preferences). Experience required in one of the following: computer programming, graphic design, web development, interaction design, or social science research methods. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>D. F. Harrell</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.631"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.631 Systems Visualization
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.831">CMS.831</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores methods of visualizing complex systems using a range of simple visual metaphors. Provides an appreciation of the importance of whole systems thinking, in contrast to silo-based, single component thinking. Presents powerful visualization methodologies to conceive and draw complex systems, be they financial, media, economic, biological, political, etc. Focuses on creating visualizations that go beyond conveying information to invoke an emotional response, integrating cultural and historical variables. Techniques include animations developed from hand-drawn illustrations, data-flow diagrams, and computer-designed visual stories. No previous drawing experience required. Work centers on readings, visualization exercises, and a final project. Visualizations can be done in any preferred medium. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.633"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.633 Digital Humanities: Topics, Techniques, and Technologies
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassT.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.833">CMS.833</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W EVE (7-10 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-676</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines theory and practice of using computational methods in the emerging field of digital humanities. Develops an understanding of key digital humanities concepts such as data representation, digital archives, information visualization, and user interaction through the study of contemporary research in conjunction with working on real-world projects for scholarly, educational, and public needs. Students create prototypes, write design papers, and conduct user studies. Some programming and design experience is helpful but not required.   Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>J. Paradis, K. Fendt</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.634"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.634J Designing Interactions: Media and Mobile Technologies
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassT.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m4e.html#4.568">4.568J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.834">CMS.834</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W10-1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E15">E15-335</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the future of mobile interactions and pervasive computing, taking into consideration design, technological, social and business aspects. Discusses theoretical works on human-computer interaction, mobile media and interaction design, and covers research and design methods. Students work in multidisciplinary teams and participate in user-centric design projects aimed to study, imagine and prototype concepts illustrating the future of mobile applications and ubiquitous computing. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 12.
<br><I>F. Casalegno, T. Nagakura</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.701"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.701 Behind the Headlines: Current Debates in Media
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.901">CMS.901</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mCMSa.html#CMS.100">CMS.100</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Addresses important, current debates in media with in-depth discussion of popular perceptions and policy implications. Students use multiple perspectives to analyze texts emanating from these debates, and present their findings through discussions and reports. Explores emerging topics (e.g., piracy and IP regimes, net neutrality, media effects, social media and social change, and changing literacies) across media forms and from various historical, transcultural, and methodological perspectives. Examines the framing of these issues, their ethical and policy implications, and strategies for repositioning the debate. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>M. Szablewicz</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.S60"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.S60 Special Subject: Comparative Media Studies

<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">

<a name="CMS.S62"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.S62 Special Subject: Comparative Media Studies
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>

<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar or lecture on a topic that is not covered in the regular curriculum.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>No textbook information available

<a name="CMS.THT"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.THT Comparative Media Studies Pre-Thesis Tutorial
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of advisor
<br>Units: 1-0-5
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Student works with an advisor to define his/her thesis. By the end of the term, student must have a substantial outline and bibilography for thesis and must have selected a three-person thesis committee. Advisor must approve outline and bibliography.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>Textbooks arranged individually
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.THU"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.THU Undergraduate Thesis in Comparative Media Studies
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="mCMSa.html#CMS.ThT">CMS.ThT</a>
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>The CMS Undergraduate Thesis is a substantial research project or comparable exercise. A written thesis ranges in length from 35 to 50 pages. Digital projects are assessed on the quality of research and argumentation, as well as presentation, and must include a substantial written component. Student gives an oral presentation of his/her thesis at the end of the term. Thesis is not required for CMS majors.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>Textbooks arranged individually
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.UR"></a>

<h3>CMS.URG Research in Comparative Media Studies
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<h2>Graduate Subjects</h2>
<a name="CMS.790"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.790 Media Theories and Methods I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>An advanced introduction to core theoretical and methodological issues in comparative media studies. Topics covered typically include the nature of theory, the gathering and evaluation of evidence, the relationship of media to reality, formal approaches to media analysis, the ethnographic documentation of media audiences, cultural hierarchy and taste, modes of production, models of readership and spectatorship.
<br><I>W. Uricchio</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.791"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.791 Media Theories and Methods II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="mCMSa.html#CMS.790">CMS.790</a>
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-167</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>T3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-191</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>An advanced introduction to core theoretical and methodological issues in comparative media studies. Topics covered typically include globalization, propaganda and persuasion, social and political effects of media change, political economy and the institutional analysis of media ownership, online communities, privacy and intellectual property, and the role of news and information within democratic cultures.
<br><I>H. Hendershot</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.796"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.796 Major Media Texts
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Intensive close study and analysis of historically significant media "texts" that have been considered landmarks or have sustained extensive critical and scholarly discussion. Such texts may include oral epic, story cycles, plays, novels, films, opera, television drama and digital works. Emphasizes close reading from a variety of contextual and aesthetic perspectives. Syllabus varies each year, and may be organized around works that have launched new modes and genres, works that reflect upon their own media practices, or on stories that migrate from one medium to another. At least one of the assigned texts is collaboratively taught, and visiting lectures and discussions are a regular feature of the subject.
<br><I>H. Hendershot</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.801"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.801 Media in Transition
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Centers on historical eras in which the form and function of media technologies were radically transformed. Includes consideration of the "Gutenberg Revolution," the rise of modern mass media, and the "digital revolution," among other case studies of media transformation and cultural change. Readings in cultural and social history and historiographic method.
<br><I>W. Uricchio</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.808"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.808 The Visual Story: Graphic Novel, Type to Tablet
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.308">CMS.308</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on the interactions between graphic stories and media technologies from the rotary press of the late 19th century to contemporary touch screens, exploring the changing relations among narrative expression, reader experience and media form. Working with examples from Pulitzers Yellow Kid and McKays Little Nemo, through the classic comics (from DC superheroes to EC horror) and graphic novels to interactive and non-linear texts (Cognitos Operation Ajax), the course examines such elements as graphic design, interface and form as well as the circulation and economies of these various media-based texts.
<br><I>J. Paradis, W. Uricchio</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.809"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.809 Transmedia Storytelling: Modern Science Fiction
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m21Wb.html#21W.763">21W.763J</A>, <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.309">CMS.309J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-2-7
<br>URL: <a href="http://cms.mit.edu/academics/courseInfo.php?courseID=CMS.309">http://cms.mit.edu/academics/courseInfo.php?courseID=CMS.309</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR3-4.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-233</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores transmedia storytelling by investigating how science fiction stories are told across different media, such as the short story, the screenplay, moving image, and games. Students read and write critical essays and collaborate to produce their own work of science fiction in a roundtable workshop environment. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>H. Hendershot</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.812"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.812 Topics in National and Post-National Cinema
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.312">CMS.312</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mCMSa.html#CMS.100">CMS.100</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies contemporary films emerging from nations such as South Korea, Iran, and Denmark. Explores the importance of cultural settings, the nature of local funding schemes and production practices, and deeper stylistic continuities with the past. Focuses on one nation's productions (including ?migr? filmmakers), considering their history, innovations, and meanings in a world in which the idea of nation is increasingly challenged by such factors as immigration, labor outsourcing, and multiculturalism. Examines film's relationship with other media forms, such as television and social media. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>H. J. Chung</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.813"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.813 Silent Film
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.313">CMS.313</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T EVE (7-10 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-114</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>M EVE (7-9 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-114</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines how the key elements of today's films - composition, continuity editing, lighting, narrative structure - were originally created. Studies the history of cinema, from its origins in the late 19th century to the transition to sound in the late 1920s and early 1930s. Students view a range of films (both mainstream and experimental) from all over the world, with a particular focus on US productions. Emphasis on how color, sound, and other developments paved the way for today's technological innovations.   Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>H. Hendershot</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.814"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.814 Phantasmal Media: Theory and Practice
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>(Subject meets with 21W.753J, <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.314">CMS.314J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Engages students in theory and practice of using computational techniques for developing expressive digital media works. Surveys approaches to understanding human imaginative processes, such as constructing concepts, metaphors, and narratives, and applies them to producing and understanding socially, culturally, and critically meaningful works in digital media. Readings engage a variety of theoretical perspectives from cognitive linguistics, literary and cultural theory, semiotics, digital media arts, and computer science. Students produce interactive narratives, games, and related forms of software art. Some programming and/or interactive web scripting experience (e.g., Flash, Javascript) is desirable. Students taking the graduate version complete a project requiring more in-depth theoretical engagement.
<br><I>D. Harrell</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.815"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.815 Games for Social Change
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.615">CMS.615</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students will collaborate in teams to design and prototype games for social change and civic engagement. Run as a workshop in which student teams develop their games and showcase them at a semester-end open house. Features guest speakers from academia and industry as well as the non-profit sector and the gaming community. Readings will explore principals of game design, and the social history of games. Graduate students will complete additional assignments.
<br><I>S. Osterweil</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.821"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.821 Fans and Fan Cultures
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.621">CMS.621</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T EVE (7-10 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-124</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines media audiences - specifically, fans - and the subcultures that evolve around them. Examines the different historical, contemporary and transnational understandings of fans. Explores products of fan culture, i.e., clubs, fiction, "vids," activism, etc. Readings place these products within the context of various disciplines. Students consider the concept of the "aca-fan" and reflect on their own "fannish" practices. Requires several short papers. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 20.
<br><I>K. Delaney</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=CMS.821');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.827"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.827 Imagination, Computation, and Expression Studio
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.627">CMS.627</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Aims to help students invent and analyze new forms of computer-based art, gaming, social media, interactive narrative, and related technologies. Students participate in a range of new and ongoing projects that are designed to hone skills in research, development, design, and evaluation. Topics vary from year to year; examples include cognitive science and artificial intelligence-based approaches to the arts; social aspects of game design; computing for social empowerment; and game character, avatar, and online profile design. May be repeated for credit with permission of instructor. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>D. Fox Harrell</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.828"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.828 Advanced Identity Representation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.628">CMS.628</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies and develops computational identity systems for games, social media, virtual worlds, and computer-based artwork. An interdisciplinary set of readings (cognitive science, computer science, art, and sociology) looks at both the underlying technology and the social/cultural aspects of identity. Includes topics such as developing improved characters, avatars, agents, social networking profiles, and online accounts. Engages students in on-going research projects. Explores how social categories are formed in digital media, including gender, class, and ethnicity, along with everyday social categories (such as those based on personality or shared media preferences). Experience required in one of the following: computer programming, graphic design, web development, interaction design, or social science research methods. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>D. F. Harrell</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.830"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.830 Studies in Film
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m21La.html#21L.706">21L.706</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br>URL: <a href="http://cms.mit.edu/academics/courseInfo.php?courseID=21L.706">http://cms.mit.edu/academics/courseInfo.php?courseID=21L.706</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR12.30-2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-103</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Intensive study of films from a particular period or genre, or films by a single director. Previous topics include Technologies of Seeing: Pre-Cinema to Early Cinema, Hollywood/Bollywood, Film Analysis, and Shakespeare on Film. Students taking graduate version complete different assignments. Limited to 12.
<br>Fall: <I>P. Donaldson</I><br>Spring: <I>A. Kibel</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.831"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.831 Systems Visualization
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.631">CMS.631</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores methods of visualizing complex systems using a range of simple visual metaphors. Provides an appreciation of the importance of whole systems thinking, in contrast to silo-based, single component thinking. Presents powerful visualization methodologies to conceive and draw complex systems, be they financial, media, economic, biological, political, etc. Focuses on creating visualizations that go beyond conveying information to invoke an emotional response, integrating cultural and historical variables. Techniques include animations developed from hand-drawn illustrations, data-flow diagrams, and computer-designed visual stories. No previous drawing experience required. Work centers on readings, visualization exercises, and a final project. Visualizations can be done in any preferred medium. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.833"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.833 Digital Humanities: Topics, Techniques, and Technologies
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.633">CMS.633</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W EVE (7-10 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-676</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines theory and practice of using computational methods in the emerging field of digital humanities. Develops an understanding of key digital humanities concepts such as data representation, digital archives, information visualization, and user interaction through the study of contemporary research in conjunction with working on real-world projects for scholarly, educational, and public needs. Students create prototypes, write design papers, and conduct user studies. Some programming and design experience is helpful but not required. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>J. Paradis, K. Fendt</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.834"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.834 Designing Interactions: Media and Mobile Technologies
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4e.html#4.568">4.568J</A>, <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.634">CMS.634J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W10-1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E15">E15-335</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the future of mobile interactions and pervasive computing,  taking into consideration design,  technological,  social and business aspects. Discusses theoretical works on human-computer interaction,  mobile media and interaction design,  and explores research and design methods. Students will work in multi-disciplinary teams and will be involved in user-centric design projects aimed to study, imagine and prototype concepts illustrating the future of mobile applications and ubiquitous computing. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 12.
<br><I>F. Casalegno, T. Nagakura</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.836"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.836 The Social Documentary: Analysis and Production
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m21Wb.html#21W.786">21W.786J</A>, <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.336">CMS.336J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>An introduction to the history of the social documentary from the 1960s through the 1980s. Explores how social upheaval and the shift to smaller, more portable film cameras, and ultimately hand-held video, converged to bring about an upsurge of socially engaged documentary film production. Students screen and analyze a series of key films from the period and work in groups to produce their own short documentary using digital video and computer-based editing. Limited to 18.
<br><I>V. Bald</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.837"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.837 Film, Music, and Social Change: Intersections of Media and Society
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m21Wb.html#21W.787">21W.787</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines films from the 1950s onward that document music subcultures and moments of social upheaval. Combines screening films about free jazz, glam rock, punk, reggae, hip-hop, and other genres with an examination of critical/scholarly writings to illuminate the connections between film, popular music, and processes of social change. Students critique each film in terms of the social, political, and cultural world it documents, and the historical context and effects of the film's reception. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 18.
<br><I>V. Bald</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.838"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.838 Innovation in Documentary: Technologies and Techniques
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.338">CMS.338</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mCMSa.html#CMS.100">CMS.100</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E15">E15-335</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Discusses emerging technologies and techniques available to media-makers (e.g., location-based technologies, transmedia storytelling, crowdsourcing, and interactivity) and their implications on the film and television documentary. Studies the development of these tools and considers the many new directions in which they may take the genre.  Includes screenings, meetings with documentary makers, and an experimental component in which students can explore new approaches to documentary production. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>W. Uricchio</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.840"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.840 Literature and Film
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m21La.html#21L.435">21L.435</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-6

<br>Meets with 21L.435, but assignments differ. See description under subject 21L.435.
