</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.841"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.841 Introduction to Videogame Theory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.300">CMS.300</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-153</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-153</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=12">12-122</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the interdisciplinary study of videogames as texts through an examination of their cultural, educational, and social functions in contemporary settings. Students play and analyze videogames while reading current research and theory from a variety of sources in the sciences, social sciences, humanities, and industry. Assignments focus on game analysis in the context of the theories discussed in class. Includes regular reading, writing, and presentation exercises. No prior programming experience required. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 20.
<br><I>M. Jakobsson</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.843"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.843 From Gamer to Player: Theory and Practice of Player Research
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.607">CMS.607</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mCMSa.html#CMS.300">CMS.300</a>, <a href="mCMSa.html#CMS.608">CMS.608</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on the theories and methods of researching digital game players. Draws on approaches from humanities, social science, and mass communication fields to inform and inspire student research. Examines the strengths, weaknesses, and appropriate use of different data collection methods. Emphasizes familiarity with research philosophy, rules and regulations for working with human subjects. Analyzes current research on digital games and their players to inform  understanding of research in practice. Students theorize and develop a player-focused study, collect data, and produce a research paper analyzing their data over the course of the term. Students taking the graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 20.
<br><I>T. Harper</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.845"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.845 Interactive and Non-Linear Narrative: Theory and Practice
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m21La.html#21L.489">21L.489J</A>, 21W.765J)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides a workshop environment for understanding interactive narrative (print and digital) through critical writing, narrative theory, and creative practice. Covers important multisequential books, hypertexts, and interactive fictions. Students write critically, and give presentations, about specific works; write a short multisequential fiction; and develop a digital narrative system, which involves significant writing and either programming or the structuring of text. Programming ability helpful. Graduate students complete additional assignments.
<br><I>N. Montfort</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.846"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.846 The Word Made Digital
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m21Wb.html#21W.764">21W.764J</A>, <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.609">CMS.609J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-103</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Considers the many uses of text, language, and writing in creative digital  media. Focuses on non-narrative uses of text, such as in information  display, visual and lyrical settings, and human-legible computer code.  Considers the use of text within the context of computing and different  computing platforms. Draws on concepts and approaches from poetics, the  material history of texts, and computer science. Assignments include  individual and group writing projects, which involve reading and modifying  computer programs. Previous programming experience and writing coursework  helpful. Students taking the graduate version of this subject (CMS.846)  complete additional assignments. Limited to 18.
<br><I>N. Montfort</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.850"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.850 Topics and Methods in 21st Century Journalism
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m21Wb.html#21W.737">21W.737J</A>, <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.350">CMS.350J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW3-4.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-261</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Gives a broad understanding of what it means to produce journalism today. Evaluates the limitations and strengths of specific types of media, ranging from New York Times stories to Twitter feeds. Provides students with tools to effectively communicate their own work and research to non-specialist audiences. Students submit assignments via an online portal, which mimics the style and substance of an online news source. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 18.
<br>Fall: <I>S. Mnookin</I><br>Spring: <I>T. Coates</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.860"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.860 Introduction to Civic Media
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.360">CMS.360</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines civic media in comparative, transnational and historical perspective. Introduces various theoretical tools, research approaches, and project design methods. Students engage with multimedia texts on concepts such as citizen journalism, transmedia activism, media justice, and civic, public, radical, and tactical media. Case studies explore civic media across platforms (print, radio, broadcast, internet), contexts (from local to global, present-day to historical), and use (dialogic, contentious, hacktivist). As a final project, students develop a case study or project proposal. Students taking the graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 20.
<br><I>S. Costanza-Chock</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.861"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.861 Networked Social Movements: Media and Mobilization
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.361">CMS.361</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E15">E15-363</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an overview of social movement studies as a body of theoretical and empirical work, with an emphasis on understanding the relationship between social movements and the media. Explores multiple methods of social movement investigation, including textual and media analysis, surveys, interviews, focus groups, participant observation, and co-research. Covers recent innovations in social movement theory, as well as new data sources and tools for research and analysis. Includes short papers, a literature review, and a final research project. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 16.
<br><I>S. Costanza-Chock</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.862"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.862 Civic Media Collaborative Design Studio
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.362">CMS.362</A>)
<br>Prereq: One subject in CMS or MAS
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W EVE (7-10 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E15">E15-344</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Project-based studio focusing on collaborative design of civic media provides a service-learning opportunity for students interested in working with community organizations. Multidisciplinary teams create civic media projects based on real-world community needs. Covers co-design methods and best practices to include the user community in iterative stages of project ideation, design, implementation, testing, and evaluation. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 16.
<br><I>S. Costanza-Chock</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.863"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.863J Computer Games and Simulations for Investigation and Education
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11b.html#11.252">11.252J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m11a.html#11.127">11.127J</A>, <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.590">CMS.590J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-6-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E15">E15-301</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Understand how we learn from computer games and simulations, and delve into the process of building and testing their own simulations. First, students explore the design and use of games and simulations in the classroom, and the research and development issues associated with desktop computer-based, handheld computer based and non-computer based media. Students then develop their own simulations and games, study what and how people learn from them (including field testing of products), and how games and simulations can be implemented in educational settings. All levels of computer experience welcome. Graduate students are expected to complete additional assignments.
<br><I>E. Klopfer</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=CMS.863');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.864"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.864 Game Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.608">CMS.608</A>)
<br>Prereq: One subject in Comparative Media Studies or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-142</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Practical instruction in the design and analysis of non-digital games. Provides students the texts, tools, references, and historical context to analyze and compare game designs across a variety of genres. In teams, students design, develop, and thoroughly test their original games to better understand the interaction and evolution of game rules. Covers various genres and types of games, including sports, game shows, games of chance, card games, schoolyard games, board games, and role-playing games. Students taking the graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 20.
<br><I>P. Tan</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=CMS.864');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.866"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.866 Writing for Videogames
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m21Wb.html#21W.767">21W.767J</A>, <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.612">CMS.612J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the convergence of fiction, dramatic writing and game design in writing for videogames. Addresses the problematic relationship between storytelling and games, from both an analytical and practical standpoint. Discusses theory and analysis of pre-existing games. Assignments provide students the opportunity to tackle specific writing problems in a creative way. Basic programming knowledge and previous coursework in game design, videogame theory, interactive narrative or play writing is useful but not required. Graduate students complete additional assignments. Limited to 15.
<br><I>C. Fernandez Vara</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.867"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.867 Network Cultures
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with 21W.791J, <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.614">CMS.614J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on the social and cultural aspects of networked life through internet-related technologies (including computers, mobile devices, entertainment technologies, and emerging media forms). Theories and readings focus on the cultural, social, economic, and political aspects of internet use and design. Topics include online communication and communities, social media, gender and race in network spaces, activism and hacking, networked publics, remix culture and intellectual property. Students taking the graduate version complete additional readings and assignments.
<br><I>T. L. Taylor</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.868"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.868 Games and Culture
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with 21W.768J, <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.616">CMS.616J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR3.30-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=14">14N-325</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the social, cultural, economic, and political aspects of digital games. Topics include the culture of gameplay, gaming styles, communities, spectatorship and performance, gender and race within digital gaming, and the politics and economics of production processes, including co-creation and intellectual property. Students taking graduate version complete additional readings and assignments.
<br><I>T. L. Taylor</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.871"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.871 Media in Cultural Context
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m21La.html#21L.715">21L.715</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br>URL: <a href="http://cms.mit.edu/academics/courseInfo.php?courseID=21L.715">http://cms.mit.edu/academics/courseInfo.php?courseID=21L.715</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar uses case studies to examine closely specific media or media configurations and the larger social, cultural, economic, political, or technological contexts within which they operate. Organized around recurring themes in media history, specific genres or movements, specific media, or specific historical moments. Instruction and practice in written and oral communication provided. Previously taught topics include Gendered Genres: Horror and Maternal Melodramas, Comics, Cartoons, and Graphic Storytelling, and Exploring Children's Culture. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Approved for credit in Women&apos;s and Gender Studies when content meets the requirements for subjects in that program. Limited to 12.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.873"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.873 Civic Media, Past & Future
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.363">CMS.363</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the history and futures of civic media and the corresponding vision of citizenship that civic media facilitates. Topics include orality and literacy during the rise of democratic governance in ancient Greece, the affordances and limitations of new civic media in the 19th and 20th centuries, the role of education in promoting civic media use, the "Gutenberg parenthesis," and the emergence of secondary orality in the digital age. Uses historical case studies to illustrate the political and economic effects of new civic media; to enhance theoretical and practical understanding of communication, technology, and political action; and to imagine future models to maximize the opportunities and efficacy of civic media. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>E. Schiappa</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.876"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.876 History of Media and Technology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.376">CMS.376</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img align="bottom" width=16 height=16 alt="Subject Cancelled" title="Subject Cancelled" src="/icns/buttonx.gif"> <i><b>Subject Cancelled</b></i> <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Surveys the interrelated histories of communications media and technological development, from the emergence of 19th-century forms of mass print media and telegraphy, to sound capture and image-based forms (e.g., film, radio, and television), to the shift from analog to digital cultures. Examines how new forms of communication exert social, political, and cultural influences in the global context. Explores how technological innovation and accelerating media affect social values and behaviors in the popular and global adoption of a media device. Includes two papers and a research project on aspects of media history. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>J. Paradis</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.880"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.880 From Print to Digital: Technologies of the Word, 1450-Present
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m21Hb.html#21H.343">21H.343</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the impact of new technology on the recording and distribution of words at three different times: the invention of the printing press ca. 1450; the adaptation of electricity to communication technology in the 19th century (telegraph, telephone, phonograph); and the emergence of digital media today. Assignments include essays and online projects. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.888"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.888 Advertising and Media: Comparative Perspectives
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m21Fa.html#21F.036">21F.036</A>, <A HREF="m21Fb.html#21F.190">21F.190</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=14">14N-217</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Meets with 21F.036 but assignments differ. See description under subject 21F.036.
<br><I>J. Wang</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=CMS.888');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.901"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.901 Behind the Headlines: Current Debates in Media
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.701">CMS.701</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Addresses important, current debates in media with in-depth discussion of popular perceptions and policy implications. Students use multiple perspectives to analyze texts emanating from these debates, and present their findings through discussions and reports. Explores emerging topics (e.g., piracy and IP regimes, net neutrality, media effects, social media and social change, and changing literacies) across media forms and from various historical, transcultural, and methodological perspectives. Examines the framing of these issues, their ethical and policy implications, and strategies for repositioning the debate. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>M. Szablewicz</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.915"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.915 Understanding Television
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m21La.html#21L.432">21L.432</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A cultural approach to television's evolution as a technology and system of representation. Considers television as a system of storytelling and mythmaking, and as a cultural practice studied from anthropological, literary, and cinematic perspectives. Focuses on prime-time commercial broadcasting, the medium's technological and economic history, and theoretical perspectives. Considerable television viewing and readings in media theory and cultural interpretation are required. Previously taught topics include American Television: A Cultural History. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>D. Thorburn</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.920"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.920 Popular Culture and Narrative
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m21La.html#21L.430">21L.430</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M EVE (7-10 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-145</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines relationships between popular culture and art, focusing on problems of evaluation and audience, and the uses of different media within a broader social context. Typically treats a range of narrative and dramatic works as well as films. Previously taught topics include Elements of Style; Gender, Sexuality and Popular Narrative. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Approved for credit in Women's and Gender Studies when content meets the requirements for subjects in that program. May be repeated for credit with permission of instructor.
<br><I>K. Delaney</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=CMS.920');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.922"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.922 Media Industries and Systems: The Art, Science and Business of Games
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.610">CMS.610</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>F1-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=14">14E-310</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the interplay of art, science, law, and commerce in the production, marketing, distribution, and consumption of historic and contemporary videogames. Students create prototypes and develop marketing programs to illustrate the challenges of producing videogames in a professional context. Combines perspectives on media industries and systems with an examination of the creative process, development, and trends that shape content. Includes discussions with industry leaders in various areas. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>C. Weaver</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=CMS.922');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.925"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.925 Film Music
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m21Ma.html#21M.284">21M.284</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW3.30-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-364</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>M EVE (7-10 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-105</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Surveys styles and dramatic functions of music for silent films of the 1910s-20s, and music in sound films from the 1930s to the present. Close attention given to landmark scores by American and European composers, including Korngold, Steiner, Rozsa, Prokofiev, Copland, Herrmann, Rota, Morricone, and Williams. Subsidiary topics include new trends in contemporary film-scoring, pop scores, the impact of electronics, and specialized genres (e.g., animation). Students taking the graduate version complete different assignments. Some background in the study of film and/or music is expected.
<br><I>M. Marks</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=CMS.925');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CMS.935"></a>
<p><h3>CMS.935 Documentary Photography and Photojournalism: Still Images of a World in Motion
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m21Wb.html#21W.749">21W.749</A>)

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Meets with 21W.749, but assignments differ.

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<h1 align="center">Computational and Systems Biology<br>Spring
2014</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://csbi.mit.edu/"><i>CSB Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=+CSB&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>CSB.00- CSB.ZZZ</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<a name="CSB.100"></a>
<p><h3>CSB.100J Topics in Computational and Systems Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m7a.html#7.89">7.89J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-10
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar based on research literature. Papers covered are selected to illustrate important problems and varied approaches in the field of computational and systems biology, and to provide students a framework from which to evaluate new developments. Preference to first-year CSB PhD students.
<br><I>C. Burge</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CSB.110"></a>
<p><h3>CSB.110 Research Rotations in Computational and Systems Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 0-12-0 [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students carry out research rotations with MIT faculty members or principal investigators working in the field of computational and systems biology.  Generally three one-month long rotations are pursued that together span theoretical and experimental approaches. Open only to CSB PhD students.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CSB.190"></a>
<p><h3>CSB.190 Research Problems in Computational and Systems Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Directed research in the field of computational and systems biology. Open only to CSB PhD students.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CSB.199"></a>
<p><h3>CSB.199 Teaching Experience in Computational Systems Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>For qualified graduate students in the CSB graduate program interested in teaching.    Classroom or laboratory teaching under the supervision of a faculty member.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="CSB.THG"></a>
<p><h3>CSB.THG Graduate Thesis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Program of research leading to the writing of SM or PhD thesis; to be arranged by the student and the MIT faculty advisor.
<br>Information: Faculty Advisor<br>Textbooks arranged individually
</p><!--end-->
