<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-1 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-390</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Designed to assist SDM students in discovering research areas of interest and matching these interests with faculty and organization research projects. At the end of the seminar, the student has faculty advisor, research project, thesis proposal and plan. Restricted to SDM students.
<br><I>P. Hale</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="ESD.803"></a>
<p><h3>ESD.803 Introduction to Supply Chain Leadership
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">); partial term
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-2 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Designed to enhance your ability to manage and lead in challenging times through a series of self assessment instruments, case studies, and workshops. The objectives are to increase awareness of your strengths and weaknesses as a leader, provide a battery of instruments and surveys to help one understand the way one operates in an organizational setting, and offer strategies and tips on how to leverage one's strengths and work on areas in need of development. Morning section restricted to students in the SCM program.
<br>Information: B. Arntzen<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="ESD.811"></a>
<p><h3>ESD.811 Technology Policy Internship Seminar
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="mESDa.html#ESD.10">ESD.10</a>
<br>Units: 1-1-1 [P/D/F]
<br>URL: <a href="http://command.mit.edu/ESD.811/">http://command.mit.edu/ESD.811/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar examines what technology policy is in practice. Considers the question of "Who achieves what, when, how, and why?" regarding technology policy. Students who completed summer internships present and dissect their experiences with special reference to specific cases in which they participated.
<br><I>F. Field</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="ESD.83"></a>
<p><h3>ESD.83 Doctoral Seminar in Engineering Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines core theory and contextual applications of the emerging field of Engineering Systems. Focuses on analysis of scholarship on key concepts such as complexity, uncertainty, fragility, and robustness, as well as a critical look at the historical roots of the field and related areas such as systems engineering, systems dynamics, agent modeling, and systems simulations. Contextual applications range from aerospace to technology implementation to regulatory systems to large-scale systems change. Special attention to the interdependence of social and technical dimensions of engineering systems. Restricted to students enrolled in ESD doctoral program.
<br><I>C. Magee, J. Sussman</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="ESD.86"></a>
<p><h3>ESD.86J Models, Data and Inference for Socio-Technical Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m15a.html#15.078">15.078J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mESDa.html#ESD.83">ESD.83</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.041">6.041</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW10.30-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-372</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F10.30-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-385</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Use data and systems knowledge to build models of complex socio-technical systems for improved system design and decision-making. Enhance model-building skills, including: review and extension of functions of random variables, Poisson processes, and Markov processes. Move from applied probability to statistics via Chi-squared t and f tests, derived as functions of random variables. Review classical statistics, hypothesis tests, regression, correlation and causation, simple data mining techniques, and Bayesian vs. classical statistics. Class project.
<br><I>R. Larson, R. Welsch</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="ESD.862"></a>
<p><h3>ESD.862 Modeling Risk, Dynamics, and Decisions
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="mESDa.html#ESD.86">ESD.86</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers advanced methods for modeling risk and decision-making under uncertainty. Topics include Monte Carlo methods, Markov chain Monte Carlo, dynamic and stochastic optimization, and advanced topics in simulation. Applications drawn primarily from energy and environmental systems modeling.
<br><I>M. Webster</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="ESD.863"></a>
<p><h3>ESD.863J System Safety Concepts
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m16b.html#16.863">16.863J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>F9-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=33">33-418</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers important concepts and techniques in designing and operating safety-critical systems. Topics include the nature of risk, formal accident and human error models, causes of accidents, fundamental concepts of system safety engineering, system and software hazard analysis, designing for safety, fault tolerance, safety issues in the design of human-machine interaction, verification of safety, creating a safety culture, and management of safety-critical projects. Includes a class project involving the high-level system design and analysis of a safety-critical system.
<br><I>N. G. Leveson</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=ESD.863');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="ESD.864"></a>
<p><h3>ESD.864J Modeling and Assessment for Policy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m12c.html#12.844">12.844J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mESDa.html#ESD.10">ESD.10</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10.30-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-057</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores how scientific information and quantitative models can be used to inform policy decision-making. Develops an understanding of quantitative modeling techniques and their role in the policy process through case studies and interactive activities. Addresses issues such as analysis of scientific assessment processes, uses of integrated assessment models, public perception of quantitative information, methods for dealing with uncertainties, and design choices in building policy-relevant models. Examples focus on models and information used in Earth system governance.
<br><I>N. Selin</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="ESD.87"></a>
<p><h3>ESD.87 Social Science Concepts and Methods
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="mESDa.html#ESD.83">ESD.83</a>, <a href="mESDa.html#ESD.86">ESD.86</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://command.mit.edu/ESD.87J/">http://command.mit.edu/ESD.87J/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to social science approaches to developing questions, designing research, and collecting data about complex systems. Overview of the different social science paradigms for developing research questions, as well as issues of measurement and research design. Covers various modes of data collection with emphasis on how the different elements of research design contribute to more powerful and persuasive results. Students develop skills in designing and completing social science-based research, as well as in critically assessing related work. Limited to 15.
<br><I>L. D'Ambrosio</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="ESD.875"></a>
<p><h3>ESD.875J Mechanical Assemblies: Their Design, Manufacture, and Role in Product Development
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2c.html#2.875">2.875J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.008">2.008</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces mechanical and economic models of assemblies and assembly automation on two levels. Assembly in the small comprises basic engineering models of rigid and compliant part mating and explains the operation of the Remote Center Compliance. Assembly in the large takes a system view of assembly, including the notion of product architecture, feature-based design and computer models of assemblies, analysis of mechanical constraint, assembly sequence analysis, tolerances, system-level design for assembly and JIT methods, and economics of assembly automation. Case studies and current research included. Class exercises and homework include analyses of real assemblies, the mechanics of part mating, and a semester long project.
<br><I>D. E. Whitney</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="ESD.88"></a>
<p><h3>ESD.88 Engineering Systems Scholarship Seminar
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="mESDa.html#ESD.83">ESD.83</a></I> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops skills and strategies for publishing in scholarly journals, writing grant proposals, applying for and succeeding in academic jobs, and shaping doctoral and postdoctoral research to further career goals. Includes panel discussions, presentations, workshops, and peer review. Special emphasis on the landscape of systems journals and the interdisciplinary acuity necessary for publishing in the broad range of journals that are of interest to engineering systems researchers. Students prepare a paper for submission to a journal.
<br><I>O. de Weck</I><br>
</p><!--end-->

<a name="ESD.S40"></a><a name="ESD.S41"></a><a name="ESD.S42"></a><a name="ESD.S43"></a>
<p><h3>ESD.S40-ESD.S43 Special Graduate Studies in Engineering Systems Division
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><b>ESD.S43:</b> URL: <a href="http://edgarblanco.mit.edu/sustainability/esd-s43-spring2014/">http://edgarblanco.mit.edu/sustainability/esd-s43-spring2014/</a>
<br><b>ESD.S40:</b> <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=9">9-057</a>)<!--s--><br><b>ESD.S43:</b> <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW2.30-4 (BEGINS MARCH 31)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-057</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Opportunity for individual or group study of advanced topics in Engineering Systems Division not otherwise included in the curriculum at MIT. Offerings are initiated by faculty on an ad-hoc basis subject to ESD approval.
<br>Information: R. Larson<br><b>ESD.S40:</b> <a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=ESD.S40');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font><br><b>ESD.S43:</b> No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="ESD.S50"></a><a name="ESD.S51"></a>
<h3>ESD.S50, ESD.S51 Special Graduate Studies in Engineering Systems Division
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Opportunity for individual or group study of advanced topics in ESD not otherwise included in the curriculum. Offerings are initiated by faculty on an ad-hoc basis subject to ESD approval.
<br>Information: R. Larson<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="ESD.THG"></a>
<p><h3>ESD.THG ESD Graduate Thesis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Program of research, leading to the writing of an SM or PhD thesis to be arranged by the student with a member of the ESD faculty. A minimum of 24 thesis units are required for the SM degree.
<br>Information: R. Larson<br>Textbooks arranged individually
</p><!--end-->

<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Health Sciences and Technology<br>Spring
2014</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://hst.mit.edu"><i>HST Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=+HST&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>HST.00-HST.599</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="mHSTb.html">HST.600-HST.999 plus UROP and Thesis</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<p>IMPORTANT NOTES regarding preclinical subjects (<a href="mHSTa.html#HST.011">HST.011</a>-<a href="mHSTa.html#HST.185">HST.185</a> and <a href="mHSTa.html#HST.191">HST.191</a>):<br><br>-Students not enrolled in an HST degree program may take preclinical subjects if space is available.  Non-HST students are limited to <I>one</I> HST preclinical course and must provide justification for enrolling in this course.  They must obtain permission from the course director and the Associate Master of HST at HMS.  Special students are not permitted to enroll in preclinical subjects.<br><br><br>-These subjects are scheduled according to the Harvard Medical School academic calendar, which differs from the MIT calendar.  Students whose graduation depends upon completing one or more of<br>these subjects should take particular care regarding the schedule.
<a name="HST.010"></a><a name="HST.011"></a>
<p><h3>HST.011 Human Functional Anatomy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.010">HST.010</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-11-10
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Lectures, detailed laboratory dissections, and prosections provide a thorough exploration of the gross structure and function of the human body. Fundamental principles of bioengineering are employed to promote analytical approaches to understanding the body's design. The embryology of major organ systems is presented, together with certain references to phylogenetic development, as a basis for comprehending anatomical complexity. Correlation clinics stress both normal and abnormal functions of the body and present evolving knowledge of genes responsible for normal and abnormal anatomy. Lecturers focus on current problems in organ system research. Only HST students may register under HST.010, graded P/D/F. Lab fee. Enrollment restricted to graduate students.
<br><I>L. Gehrke</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.020"></a><a name="HST.021"></a>
<p><h3>HST.021 Musculoskeletal Pathophysiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.020">HST.020</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of Instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Growth and development of normal bone and joints, the process of mineralization, the biophysics of bone and response to stress and fracture, calcium and phosphate homeostasis and regulation by parathyroid hormone and vitamin D, and the pathogenesis of metabolic bone diseases and disease of connective tissue, joints, and muscles, with consideration of possible mechanisms and underlying metabolic derangements. Only HST students may register under HST.020, graded P/D/F. Enrollment limited; restricted to medical and graduate students.
<br><I>M. Bouxsein, M. Seton</I><br><b>HST.020:</b> No required or recommended textbooks<br><b>HST.021:</b> No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.030"></a><a name="HST.031"></a>
<p><h3>HST.031 Human Pathology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.030">HST.030</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor; <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>, or <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-4-8
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.034">HST.034</A>, <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.035">HST.035</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the functional structure of normal cells and tissues, pathologic principles of cellular adaptation and injury, inflammation, circulatory disorders, immunologic injury, infection, genetic disorders, and neoplasia in humans. Lectures, conferences emphasizing clinical correlations and contemporary experimental biology. Laboratories with examination of microscopic and gross specimens, and autopsy case studies emphasizing modern pathology practice. Only HST students may register under HST.030, graded P/D/F. Lab fee. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>R. N. Mitchell</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.034"></a><a name="HST.035"></a>
<h3>HST.035 Principles and Practice of Human Pathology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.034">HST.034</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-2-10
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.030">HST.030</A>, <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.031">HST.031</A>
<br><b>HST.034:</b> Final exam at harvard. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9-11</i> (MEC-333) <b>Lab:</b> <i>T OR R 11-1</i> (HMS SKILLS)<!--s--><br><b>HST.035:</b> Final exam at harvard. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9-11</i> (MEC-333) <b>Lab:</b> <i>T OR R 11-1</i> (HMS SKILLS)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides a comprehensive overview of human pathology with emphasis on mechanisms of disease and modern diagnostic technologies. Topics include general mechanisms of disease (inflammation, infection, immune injury, transplantation, genetic disorders and neoplasia); pathology of lipids, enzymes, and molecular transporters; pathology of major organ systems; and review of diagnostic tools from surgical pathology to non-invasive techniques such as spectroscopy, imaging, and molecular markers of disease. The objectives of this subject are achieved by a set of integrated lectures and laboratories, as well as a student-driven term project leading to a formal presentation on a medical, socioeconomic, or technological issue in human pathology. Only HST students enrolled in specific degree programs may register under HST.034, graded P/D/F. Credit cannot also be received for HST.030 or HST.031.
<br><I>R. Drapkin</I><br><b>HST.034:</b> <a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=HST.034');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font><br><b>HST.035:</b> <a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=HST.035');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.040"></a><a name="HST.041"></a>
<p><h3>HST.041 Mechanisms of Microbial Pathogenesis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.040">HST.040</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-6-5
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Deals with the mechanisms of pathogenesis of bacteria, viruses, and other microorganisms. Approach spans mechanisms from molecular to clinical aspects of disease. Topics selected for intrinsic interest and cover the demonstrated spectrum of pathophysiologic mechanisms. Only HST students may register under HST.040, graded P/D/F. Lab fee. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>C. Crumpacker II, H. Simon</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.060"></a><a name="HST.061"></a>
<p><h3>HST.061 Endocrinology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.060">HST.060</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 6-0-6
<br><b>HST.060:</b> Meets 2/3 to 5/12. Final exam at harvard. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>M1-4</i> (MEC-227)<!--s--><br><b>HST.061:</b> Meets 2/3 to 5/12. Final exam at harvard. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>M1-4</i> (MEC-227)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Physiology and pathophysiology of the human endocrine system. Three hours of lecture and section each week concern individual parts of the endocrine system. Topics include assay techniques, physiological integration, etc. At frequent clinic sessions, patients are presented who demonstrate clinical problems considered in the didactic lectures. Only HST students may register under HST.060, graded P/D/F. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>W. Kettyle, D. Breault</I><br><b>HST.060:</b> No required or recommended textbooks<br><b>HST.061:</b> No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.070"></a><a name="HST.071"></a>
<p><h3>HST.071 Human Reproductive Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">; first half of term
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.070">HST.070</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 5-0-1
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Lectures and clinical case discussions designed to provide the student with a clear understanding of the physiology, endocrinology, and pathology of human reproduction. Emphasis is on the role of technology in reproductive science. Suggestions for future research contributions in the field are probed. Students become involved in the wider aspects of reproduction, such as prenatal diagnosis, in vitro fertilization, abortion, menopause, contraception and ethics relation to reproductive science. Only HST students may register under HST.070, graded P/D/F.
<br><I>A. Koniaris, J. Yeh</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.080"></a><a name="HST.081"></a>
<p><h3>HST.081 Hematology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">; second half of term
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.080">HST.080</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-6-4
<br><b>HST.080:</b> Meets 4/1 to 5/15. Final exam at harvard. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR8-11</i> (MEC-227)<!--s--><br><b>HST.081:</b> Meets 4/1 to 5/15. Final exam at harvard. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR8-11</i> (MEC-227)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Intensive survey of the biology, physiology and pathophysiology of blood with systematic consideration of hematopoiesis, white blood cells, red blood cells, platelets, coagulation, plasma proteins, and hematologic malignancies. Emphasis given equally to didactic discussion and analysis of clinical problems. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>H. F. Bunn, N. Berliner</I><br><b>HST.080:</b> <a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=HST.080');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font><br><b>HST.081:</b> <a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=HST.081');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.090"></a><a name="HST.091"></a>
<p><h3>HST.091 Cardiovascular Pathophysiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.090">HST.090</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mHSTa.html#HST.030">HST.030</a> or <a href="mHSTa.html#HST.031">HST.031</a>; permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-9
<br><b>HST.090:</b> Meets 2/3 to 5/16. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>WF11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-114</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>M8.30-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-114</a>)<!--s--><br><b>HST.091:</b> Meets 2/3 to 5/16. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>WF11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-114</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>M8.30-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-114</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Normal and pathologic physiology of the heart and vascular system. Emphasis includes hemodynamics, electrophysiology, gross pathology, and clinical correlates of cardiovascular function in normal and in a variety of disease states. Special attention given to congenital, rheumatic, valvular heart disease and cardiomyopathy. Only HST students may register under HST.090, graded P/D/F. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>E. Edelman</I><br><b>HST.090:</b> <a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=HST.090');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font><br><b>HST.091:</b> <a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=HST.091');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.100"></a><a name="HST.101"></a>
<p><h3>HST.101 Respiratory Pathophysiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.100">HST.100</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>HST.100:</b> Final exam at harvard. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>WF8-10</i> (MEC-209)<!--s--><br><b>HST.101:</b> Final exam at harvard. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>WF8-10</i> (MEC-209)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Lectures, seminars, and laboratories cover the histology, cell biology, and physiological function of the lung with multiple examples related to common diseases of the lung.  A quantitative approach to the physics of gases, respiratory mechanics, and gas exchange is provided to explain pathological mechanisms. Use of medical ventilators is discussed in lecture and in laboratory experiences. For MD candidates and other students with background in science. Only HST students may register under HST.100, graded P/D/F. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>J. Drazen, S. Loring, A. Malhotra</I><br><b>HST.100:</b> <a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=HST.100');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font><br><b>HST.101:</b> <a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=HST.101');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.110"></a><a name="HST.111"></a>
<p><h3>HST.111 Renal Pathophysiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.110">HST.110</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>HST.110:</b> Final exam at harvard. Meets 2/4 to 5/15. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR8-10.30 (ENDS MARCH 27)</i> (MEC-209) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR11-12.30 (BEGINS MARCH 31)</i> (MEC-209)<!--s--><br><b>HST.111:</b> Final exam at harvard. Meets 2/4 to 5/15. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR8-10.30 (ENDS MARCH 27)</i> (MEC-209) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR11-12.30 (BEGINS MARCH 31)</i> (MEC-209)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Considers the normal physiology of the kidney and the pathophysiology of renal disease. Renal regulation of sodium, potassium, acid, and water balance are emphasized as are the mechanism and consequences of renal failure. Included also are the pathology and pathophysiology of clinical renal disorders such as acute and chronic glomerulonephritis, pyelonephritis, and vascular disease. New molecular insights into transporter mutations and renal disease are discussed. Only HST students may register under HST.110, graded P/D/F. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>J. Seifter, A. Lam</I><br><b>HST.110:</b> <a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=HST.110');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font><br><b>HST.111:</b> <a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=HST.111');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.120"></a><a name="HST.121"></a>
<p><h3>HST.121 Gastroenterology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">; second half of term
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.120">HST.120</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-6-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents the anatomy, physiology, biochemistry, biophysics, and bioengineering of the gastrointestinal tract and associated pancreatic, liver, and biliary systems. Emphasis on the molecular and pathophysiological basis of disease where known. Covers gross and microscopic pathology and clinical aspects. Formal lectures given by core faculty, with some guest lectures by local experts. Selected seminars conducted by students with supervision of faculty. Only HST students may register under HST.120, graded P/D/F. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>M. C. Carey, C. Ukomadu</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.130"></a><a name="HST.131"></a>
<p><h3>HST.131 Neuroscience
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.130">HST.130</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 6-3-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Comprehensive study of neuroscience where students explore the brain on levels ranging from molecules and cells through neural systems, perception, memory, and behavior. Includes some aspects of clinical neuroscience, within neuropharmacology, pathophysiology, and neurology. Lectures supplemented by conferences and labs. Labs review neuroanatomy at the gross and microscopic levels. Only HST students may register under HST.130, graded P/D/F. Limited to 50.
<br><I>J. Assad</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.140"></a>
<p><h3>HST.140 Molecular Medicine
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Conducted as a seminar to study a variety of human diseases and the underlying molecular, genetic, and biochemical basis for the pathogenesis and pathophysiology of the disorders. Lectures by faculty and seminars conducted by students, with tutorials and supervision by faculty. Patients presented when feasible. Appropriate for students who have had a course in biochemistry and/or molecular biology.
<br><I>I. M. London, G. Q. Daley, D. E. Cohen</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.146"></a><a name="HST.147"></a>
<p><h3>HST.147 Human Biochemistry and Metabolic Diseases
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">; partial term
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.146">HST.146</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>First-year graduate level intensive subject in human biochemistry and physiological chemistry that focuses on intermediary metabolism, structures of key intermediates and enzymes important in human disease. Subject is divided into four areas: carbohydrates, lipids, amino acids and nucleic acids. The importance of these areas is underscored with examples from diseases and clinical correlations that are introduced by clinician-scientists. Only HST students may register under HST.146, graded P/D/F. Students must register for both Fall and IAP sections. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>D. Cohen, R. Mitchell</I><br><b>HST.146:</b> No required or recommended textbooks<br><b>HST.147:</b> No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.150"></a><a name="HST.151"></a>
<p><h3>HST.151 Principles of Pharmacology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">; first half of term
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.150">HST.150</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>HST.150:</b> Final exam at harvard. <b>Compulsory:</b> <i>1st Mtg Jan 27 (HMS)</i> <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9-12 (ENDS MARCH 27)</i> (MEC-250)<!--s--><br><b>HST.151:</b> Final exam at harvard. <b>Compulsory:</b> <i>1st Mtg Jan 27 (HMS)</i> <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9-12 (ENDS MARCH 27)</i> (MEC-250)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>An introduction to pharmacology. Topics include mechanisms of drug action, dose-response relations, pharmacokinetics, drug delivery systems, drug metabolism, toxicity of pharmacological agents, drug interactions, and substance abuse. Selected agents and classes of agents examined in detail. BEP students must register for HST.151 (graded) other HST students may register under HST.150 (P/D/F).  Course follows HMS calendar. Restricted to HST MD, HST MEMP or HST BEP students.
<br><I>C. Rosow</I><br><b>HST.150:</b> <a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=HST.150');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font><br><b>HST.151:</b> <a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=HST.151');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.160"></a>
<p><h3>HST.160 Molecular Biology and Genetics in Modern Medicine
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">; partial term
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.161">HST.161</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>
<br>Units: 6-0-6 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>
<a name="HST.161"></a>
<h3>HST.161 Molecular Biology and Genetics in Modern Medicine
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">; partial term
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.160">HST.160</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>
<br>Units: 6-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Foundation for understanding the relationship between molecular biology, developmental biology, genetics, genomics, bioinformatics, and medicine. Develops explicit connections between basic research, medical understanding, and the perspective of patients. Principles of human genetics reviewed. Translation of clinical understanding into analysis at the level of the gene, chromosome and molecule; the concepts and techniques of molecular biology and genomics; and the strategies and methods of genetic analysis, including an introduction to bioinformatics. Extends beyond basic principles to current research activity in human genetics. Only HST students may register under HST.160, graded P/D/F.
<br><I>A. Giersch, D. Housman</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.175"></a><a name="HST.176"></a>
<p><h3>HST.176 Cellular and Molecular Immunology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.175">HST.175</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers cells and tissues of the immune system, lymphocyte development, the structure and function of antigen receptors, the cell biology of antigen processing and presentation including molecular structure and assembly of MHC molecules, lymphocyte activation, the biology of cytokines, leukocyte-endothelial interactions, and the pathogenesis of immunologically mediated diseases. Consists of lectures and tutorials in which clinical cases are discussed with faculty tutors. Details of each case covering a number of immunological issues in the context of disease are posted on a student website. Only HST students may register under HST.175, graded P/D/F. Limited to 45.
<br><I>S. Pillai, B. Cherayil</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.190"></a><a name="HST.191"></a>
<p><h3>HST.191 Introduction to Biostatistics and Epidemiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.190">HST.190</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Fundamentals of biostatistics and epidemiology. Trains students how to comprehend, critique and communicate findings from biomedical literature. How to assess the importance of chance in the interpretation of experimental data. Topics include probability theory, normal sampling, chi-squared and t-tests, analysis of variance, linear regression and survival analysis, as well has how to perform elementary calculations using the statistical package STATA. How to identify and prevent bias in observational studies. Causal inference, types of bias (confounding, selection and information bias), key study designs (randomized trials, cohort and case-control studies, and screening programs). Only HST students may register under HST.190, graded P/D/F. Enrollment limited; restricted to medical and graduate students.
<br><I>R. Betensky, M. Hernan</I><br><b>HST.190:</b> <a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014JA&Subject=HST.190');" >Textbooks (IAP 2014)</a></font><br><b>HST.191:</b> <a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014JA&Subject=HST.191');" >Textbooks (IAP 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.192"></a>
<p><h3>HST.192 Medical Decision Analysis and Diagnostic Test Interpretation
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.193">HST.193</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of Course Instructor; <a href="mHSTa.html#HST.191">HST.191</a> recommended
<br>Units: 2-0-2 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Teaches the essentials of quantitative diagnostic reasoning and medical decision analysis. Guides participants through the process of choosing an appropriate contemporary medical problem in which risk-benefit tradeoffs play a prominent role, conducting a decision analysis, and ultimately publishing the results in a medical journal.  Topics include decision trees, influence diagrams, Markov decision models and Monte Carlo simulation, methods for quantifying patient values, Bayesian inference, decision thresholds, and the cognitive science of medical decision making. Limited to 8; preference to HST students
<br><I>M. B. Westover, M. Bianchi, S. Cash</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.193"></a>
<p><h3>HST.193 Medical Decision Analysis and Diagnostic Test Interpretation
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.192">HST.192</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-2
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Teaches the essentials of quantitative diagnostic reasoning and medical decision analysis. Guides participants through the process of choosing an appropriate contemporary medical problem in which risk-benefit tradeoffs play a prominent role, conducting a decision analysis, and ultimately publishing the results in a medical journal. Topics include decision trees, influence diagrams, Markov decision models and Monte Carlo simulation, methods for quantifying patient values, Bayesian inference, decision thresholds, and the cognitive science of medical decision making. Limited to 8; preference to HST students
<br><I>M. B. Westover, M.T. Bianchi, S.S. Cash</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->

<a name="HST.198"></a>
<p><h3>HST.198 Independent Study in Health Sciences and Technology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br>Consult instructor <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Opportunity for independent study of health sciences and technology under regular supervision by an HST faculty member. Projects require prior approval, as well as a substantive paper. Minimum 12 units required.
<br>Consult HST Faculty<br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.199"></a>
<p><h3>HST.199 Research in Health Sciences and Technology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>Consult instructor <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>For research assistants in HST where the assigned research is approved for academic credit by the department. Hours are arranged with research supervisor.
<br><I>S. S. Pillai, R. L. Maas, S. P. Balk, M. L. Bulyk, A. Rosenzweig</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.200"></a>
<p><h3>HST.200 Introduction to Clinical Medicine
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 9-25-12 [P/D/F]
<br>Meets 2/3 to 5/16. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF8-5</i> (HOSPITAL)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>February through May, Monday, Wednesday, Friday. Students learn the basic skills involved in examination of the patient and are introduced to history taking and patient interview. Students exposed to clinical problems in medicine, surgery, and pediatrics in groups of two or three students under one faculty member. Findings reported through history taking and oral presentation of the cases to the class. An intensive subject serving as prerequisite to clinical clerkships. Restricted to MD program students.
<br><I>W. Goessling</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.201"></a>
<p><h3>HST.201 Introduction to Clinical Medicine and Medical Engineering I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 0-20-0 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develop skills in patient interviewing and physical examination; become proficient at organizing and communicating clinical information in both written and oral forms; begin integrating history, physical, and laboratory data with pathophysiologic principles; and become familiar with the clinical decision-making process and broad economic, ethical, and sociological issues involved in patient care. There are two sections: one at Mount Auburn Hospital during IAP, and one at West Roxbury VA Hospital beginning in summer. Restricted to MEMP students.
<br><I>R. G. Mark, V. Pronio-Stelluto, J. Strymish</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.202"></a>
<p><h3>HST.202 Introduction to Clinical Medicine and Medical Engineering II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="mHSTa.html#HST.201">HST.201</a>
<br>Units: 0-20-0 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TBA</i> (HOSPITAL)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Strengthens the skills developed in HST.201 through a six-week clerkship in medicine at a Harvard-affiliated teaching hospital. Students serve as full-time members of a ward team and participate in longitudinal patient care. In addition, students participate in regularly scheduled teaching conferences focused on principles of patient management. Restricted to MEMP students.
<br><I>V. Pronio-Stelluto, R. G. Mark, J. Strymish</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.203"></a>
<p><h3>HST.203 Clinical Experience in Medical Engineering and Medical Physics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="mHSTa.html#HST.201">HST.201</a>, <a href="mHSTa.html#HST.202">HST.202</a>
<br>Units: 0-12-0 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TBA</i> (HOSPITAL)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>An individually arranged full-time one-month directed study in a clinical environment where active medical engineering/medical physics investigation is in progress. Students engage in patient care, particularly those aspects that interface closely with technology. Students also focus on in-depth exploration of the technical and research area. A project proposal is required at time of registration.  Term paper required.
<br><I>HST Faculty</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.211"></a>
<p><h3>HST.211 Biomedical Inventions: Clinical Introduction
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides students with an understanding of modern biomedicine. Explores the clinical areas where medical practice and biomedical enterprise intersect. Hear and interact with academic physicians engaged in care and treatment of patients, in the wards, ICUs, ORs and outpatient areas, and develop the knowledge base needed to obtain elective clinical experiences. Learn to interact with patients and clinicians. Focus is on the various needs of medical specialties, both device, IT and pharma to better treat common medical diseases.
<br><I>W. Zapol, R. Anderson</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.212"></a>
<p><h3>HST.212 Biomedical Inventions: Clinical Experience and Selected Success Analysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="mHSTa.html#HST.211">HST.211</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><img align="bottom" width=16 height=16 alt="Subject Cancelled" title="Subject Cancelled" src="/icns/buttonx.gif"> <i><b>Subject Cancelled</b></i> <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides students with a survey of key biomedical research needs by lecture-discussions and facilitating interaction with academic-clinicians and scientists active in medical care/research. Both drug and technology development in the various medical and surgical specialties are examined. Students develop the knowledge base needed to obtain elective clinical experiences. Unsolved clinical problems are sought by each student in a biomedical area of their interest and presented to the class. Interactions with academic physicians who have successfully developed technologies and drugs that are approved by the FDA and in widespread clinical use. How, where, when and why biomedical enterprise and medical practice can successfully intersect is explored. Students can interact with academic physicians engaged in the development of novel technology and drugs, analyze successes and autopsy failed biomedical enterprises.
<br><I>W. Zapol, R. Anderson</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.220"></a>
<p><h3>HST.220 Introduction to the Care of Patients
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-2 [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Elective subject for HST/MD candidates only. Provides an introduction to the care of patients through opportunities to observe and participate in doctor-patient interaction in an outpatient, office-based environment, and through patient-oriented seminars. Students are exposed to some of the practical realities of providing patient care. Topics include basic interviewing, issues of ethics and confidentiality, and other aspects of the doctor-patient relationship. Requirements include regular attendance, and a short paper on patient care. Limited to 15.
<br><I>W. M. Kettyle, MIT Medical Department Staff</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.240"></a>
<p><h3>HST.240 Translational Medicine Preceptorship
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="mHSTa.html#HST.035">HST.035</a>
<br>Units: 0-12-0
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Individually designed preceptorship joins together scientific research and clinical medicine. Students devote approximately half of their time to clinical experiences, and the remaining part to scholarly work in basic or clinical science. The two might run concomitantly or in series. Follow a clinical preceptor's daily activity, including aspects of patient care, attending rounds, conferences, and seminars. Research involves formal investigation of a focused and directed issue related to selected clinical area. Final paper required. Limited to students in the GEMS Program.
<br><I>E. Edelman</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.299"></a>
<p><h3>HST.299 Research in Health Sciences and Technology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>Consult instructor <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
