<br><I>HST Staff</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.410"></a>
<p><h3>HST.410J Projects in Microscale Engineering for the Life Sciences
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6a.html#6.07">6.07J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-4-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A project-based introduction to manipulating and characterizing cells and biological molecules using microfabricated tools. In the first half of the term, students perform laboratory exercises designed to introduce the design, manufacture, and use of microfluidic channels; techniques for sorting and manipulating cells and biomolecules; and making quantitative measurements using optical detection and fluorescent labeling. In the second half of the term, students work in small groups to design and test a microfluidic device to solve a real-world problem of their choosing. Includes exercises in written and oral communication and team building. Limited to 20; preference to freshmen.
<br><I>D. Freeman, M. Gray, A. Aranyosi</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.450"></a>
<p><h3>HST.450J Biological Physics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m8b.html#8.593">8.593J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.044">8.044</a> recommended but not necessary
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Designed to provide seniors and first-year graduate students with a quantitative, analytical understanding of selected biological phenomena. Topics include experimental and theoretical basis for the phase boundaries and equation of state of concentrated protein solutions, with application to diseases such as sickle cell anemia and cataract. Protein-ligand binding and linkage and the theory of allosteric regulation of protein function, with application to proteins as stores as transporters in respiration, enzymes in metabolic pathways, membrane receptors, regulators of gene expression, and self-assembling scaffolds. The physics of locomotion and chemoreception in bacteria and the biophysics of vision, including the theory of transparency of the eye, molecular basis of photo reception, and the detection of light as a signal-to-noise discrimination.
<br><I>G. Benedek</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.452"></a>
<p><h3>HST.452J Statistical Physics in Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m8b.html#8.592">8.592J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8b.html#8.333">8.333</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A survey of problems at the interface of statistical physics and modern biology: bioinformatic methods for extracting information content of DNA; gene finding, sequence comparison, phylogenetic trees. Physical interactions responsible for structure of biopolymers; DNA double helix, secondary structure of RNA, elements of protein folding. Considerations of force, motion, and packaging; protein motors, membranes. Collective behavior of biological elements; cellular networks, neural networks, and evolution.
<br><I>M. Kardar, L. Mirny</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.457"></a>
<p><h3>HST.457J Introduction to Molecular Simulations
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6b.html#6.502">6.502J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6b.html#6.582">6.582J</A>, <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.557">HST.557J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>; <a href="m6a.html#6.041">6.041</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.042">6.042</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the basic concepts underlying dynamical simulations of proteins and nucleic acids.  Basic definitions of components that form biological systems used to develop physical models that describe the dynamics of biomolecules.  Topics include classical statistical thermodynamics for calculation of macroscopic observables, normal-mode analyses of protein dynamics, and thermodynamic perturbation theory. Emphasizes actual techniques and algorithms used for such calculations.  Prior knowledge of biochemistry is not required. Students taking the graduate version complete an additional project.
<br><I>C. M. Stultz</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.460"></a>
<p><h3>HST.460J Statistics for Neuroscience Research
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m9a.html#9.073">9.073J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW10-11.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-3015</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A survey of statistical methods for neuroscience research. Core topics include introductions to the theory of point processes, the generalized linear model, Monte Carlo methods, Bayesian methods, multivariate methods, time-series analysis, spectral analysis and state-space modeling. Emphasis on developing a firm conceptual understanding of the statistical paradigm and statistical methods primarily through analyses of actual experimental data.
<br><I>E. N. Brown</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.491"></a>
<p><h3>HST.491 Reviewing Biomedical Literature
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 1-0-2
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Assessing the value and validity of select journal articles from biomedical literature. Detailed student presentations in a standard or journal review format. Limited to 15.
<br><I>D. S. Kohane</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.500"></a>
<p><h3>HST.500 Frontiers in (Bio)Medical Engineering and Physics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-154</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides a framework for mapping research topics at the intersection of medicine and engineering/physics in the Harvard-MIT community and covers the different research areas in MEMP (for example, regenerative biomedical technologies, biomedical imaging and biooptics). Lectures provide fundamental concepts and consider what's hot, and why, in each area. Training in scientific proposal writing (thesis proposals, fellowship applications, or research grant applications) through writing workshops.  Topics include how to structure a novel research project, how to position research within the scientific community, how to present preliminary data effectively, and how to give and respond to peer reviews.
<br><I>S. Bhatia, C. Stultz, S. Jhaveri</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.505"></a>
<p><h3>HST.505 Laboratory in Molecular and Cellular Sciences
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Biochemistry or cell biology
<br>Units: 3-4-5
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides laboratory training in state-of-the-art experimental approaches and techniques in molecular and cellular sciences. Lab training is reinforced with didactic lectures which stress the theory behind these methodologies. Topics include mammalian cell culture; tissue engineering; DNA cloning; gene transfer and gene therapy; transgenic animals; protein purification and analysis; and microscopy. Emphasis on the quantitative aspects of these methodologies. Students learn how to incorporate these approaches into an interdisciplinary research strategy aimed at addressing important questions in biomedical research.
<br><I>J. Shah, J. Chen, U. Demirci, J. Karp</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.506"></a>
<p><h3>HST.506J Computational Systems Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6c.html#6.874">6.874J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6c.html#6.802">6.802</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.440">18.440</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.041">6.041</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-141</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-162</a>) or <i>R4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-162</a>) or <i>F4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-162</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents computational approaches and algorithms for contemporary problems in systems biology, with a focus on models of biological systems, including regulatory network discovery and validation. Topics include genotypes, regulatory factor binding and motif discovery, and whole genome RNA expression; regulatory networks (discovery, validation, data integration, protein-protein interactions, signaling, whole genome chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis); and experimental design (model validation, interpretation of interventions). Discusses computational methods, including directed and undirected graphical models, such as Bayesian networks, factor graphs, Dirichlet processes, and topic models. Multidisciplinary team-oriented final research project. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>D. K. Gifford, T. S. Jaakkola</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.507"></a>
<p><h3>HST.507J Advanced Computational Biology: Genomes, Networks, Evolution
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6c.html#6.878">6.878J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6a.html#6.047">6.047</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.006">6.006</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.041">6.041</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>See description for 6.047.  Additionally examines recent publications in the areas covered, with research-style assignments. A more substantial final project is expected, which can lead to a thesis and publication.
<br><I>M. Kellis</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.508"></a>
<p><h3>HST.508 Quantitative Genomics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides in-depth quantitative understanding of evolutionary and population genetics, comparative and clinical genomics. Each module consists of a series of lectures, a journal club discussion of high impact publications, and lectures that provide clinical correlates. Homework assignments and final projects aim to develop understanding of genomic data from evolutionary principles.
<br><I>L. Mirny, G. Kryukov, S. Sunyaev</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.509"></a>
<p><h3>HST.509 Computational and Functional Genomics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>Begins Jan 28. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW2.30-4</i> (HMS TBA)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Experimental functional genomics and proteomics; DNA and protein sequence  analysis; cellular regulatory networks; phenotypic analysis; human genetic  variation. Primarily critical reading and discussion. Molecular biology,  solid understanding of basic probability and statistics recommended. Follows  Harvard FAS calendar.
<br><I>M. L. Bulyk, S. R. Sunyaev, S. Gaudet</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.510"></a>
<p><h3>HST.510 Genomics and Computational Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Integrates knowledge, research tools in new aspects of bioengineering, personalized medicine and genetically modified organisms. Interplays of biophysical, ecological, economic, and social/ethical modeling are explored through multi-disciplinary teams of students and individual brief reports. Follows Harvard FAS calendar.
<br><I>G. Church</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.514"></a>
<p><h3>HST.514J Sensory-Neural Systems: Spatial Orientation from End Organs to Behavior and Adaptation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m16a.html#16.430">16.430J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Neuroscience or systems engineering or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>R2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E25">E25-101</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces sensory systems,and multi-sensory fusion using the vestibular and spatial orientation systems as a model. Topics range from end organ dynamics to neural responses, to sensory integration, to behavior, and adaptation, with particular application to balance, posture and locomotion under normal gravity and space conditions. Depending upon the background and interests of the students, advanced term project topics might include motion sickness, astronaut adaptation, artificial gravity, lunar surface locomotion, vestibulo-cardiovascular responses, vestibular neural prostheses, or other topics of interest.
<br><I>D. M., Merfeld, T. K. Clark, F. Karmali</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.515"></a>
<p><h3>HST.515J Aerospace Biomedical and Life Support Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m16a.html#16.423">16.423J</A>, <A HREF="mESDa.html#ESD.65">ESD.65J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m16a.html#16.400">16.400</a>, <a href="m16a.html#16.06">16.06</a>, <a href="m16a.html#16.060">16.060</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-1-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Fundamentals of human performance, physiology, and life support impacting engineering design and aerospace systems. Topics include effects of gravity on the muscle, skeletal, cardiovascular, and neurovestibular systems; human/pilot modeling and human/machine design; flight experiment design; and life support engineering for extravehicular activity (EVA). Case studies of current research are presented. Assignments include a design project, quantitative homework sets, and quizzes emphasizing engineering and systems aspects.
<br><I>D. J. Newman</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.516"></a>
<p><h3>HST.516 Circadian Biology: From Cellular Oscillations to Sleep Regulation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Biological sciences
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Properties, mechanisms, and functional roles of circadian rhythms in organisms ranging from unicells to mammals. Cellular and molecular components, regulation of gene expression and physiological functions, genetic and biochemical analyses of circadian rhythms, and neurobiology of the mammalian circadian pacemaker. Mathematics and modeling of oscillatory systems and applications to circadian rhythms. Experimental studies of human rhythms, including the sleep-wake cycle and hormone rhythms, with applications to sleep disorders. Follows Harvard FAS calendar.
<br><I>C. A. Czeisler</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.521"></a>
<p><h3>HST.521 Biomaterials, Tissue Engineering, and Regenerative Therapeutics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="mHSTa.html#HST.031">HST.031</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-5
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers the structure, properties and therapeutic applications of biomaterials, as well as the opportunities and scientific and technological challenges of tissue engineering. Provides an interdisciplinary biological-engineering approach in an academic/corporate context, and probes mechanisms and methods of evaluation of tissue/biomaterials and patient/device interactions. Assesses current outcomes and challenges, and cutting-edge technological solutions to medical problems. Additional topics include key biological concepts; biofunctional/bioactive materials, drug delivery, and pertinent advances in nanotechnology; technical issues in design, development, fabrication and clinical evaluation; novel research directions and applications of materials to medicine; and ethical, economic and regulatory considerations.
<br><I>F. J. Schoen, A. Khademhosseini</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.522"></a>
<p><h3>HST.522J Biomaterials: Tissue Interactions
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as 2.79J, <A HREF="m3b.html#3.96">3.96J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.441">20.441J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Principles of materials science and cell biology underlying the design of medical implants, artificial organs, and matrices for tissue engineering. Methods for biomaterials surface characterization and analysis of protein adsorption on biomaterials. Molecular and cellular interactions with biomaterials are analyzed in terms of unit cell processes, such as matrix synthesis, degradation, and contraction. Mechanisms underlying wound healing and tissue remodeling following implantation in various organs. Tissue and organ regeneration. Design of implants and prostheses based on control of biomaterials-tissue interactions. Comparative analysis of intact, biodegradable, and bioreplaceable implants by reference to case studies. Criteria for restoration of physiological function for tissues and organs.
<br><I>I. V. Yannas, M. Spector</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.523"></a>
<p><h3>HST.523J Cell-Matrix Mechanics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.785">2.785J</A>, <A HREF="m3b.html#3.97">3.97J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.411">20.411J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.001">2.001</a>, or <a href="m2a.html#2.01">2.01</a> and <a href="m2a.html#2.02A">2.02A</a>; <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Mechanical forces play a decisive role during development of tissues and organs, during remodeling following injury as well as in normal function. A stress field influences cell function primarily through deformation of the extracellular matrix to which cells are attached. Deformed cells express different biosynthetic activity relative to undeformed cells. The unit cell process paradigm combined with topics in connective tissue mechanics form the basis for discussions of several topics from cell biology, physiology, and medicine.
<br><I>I. V. Yannas, M. Spector</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.524"></a>
<p><h3>HST.524J Design of Medical Devices and Implants
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.782">2.782J</A>, <A HREF="m3b.html#3.961">3.961J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.451">20.451J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-134</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Solution of clinical problems by use of implants and other medical devices. Systematic use of cell-matrix control volumes. The role of stress analysis in the design process. Anatomic fit: shape and size of implants. Selection of biomaterials. Instrumentation for surgical implantation procedures. Preclinical testing for safety and efficacy: risk/benefit ratio assessment. Evaluation of clinical performance: design of clinical trials. Project materials drawn from orthopedic devices, soft tissue implants, artificial organs, and dental implants.
<br><I>I. V. Yannas, M. Spector</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=HST.524');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.525"></a>
<p><h3>HST.525J Tumor Pathophysiology and Transport Phenomena: A Systems Biology Approach
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m10a.html#10.548">10.548J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>; <a href="m10a.html#10.301">10.301</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Tumor pathophysiology plays a central role in the growth, invasion, metastasis and treatment of solid tumors. Principles of transport phenomena are applied to develop a systems level, quantitative understanding of angiogenesis, blood flow and microcirculation, metabolism and microenvironment, transport and binding of small and large molecules, movement of cancer and immune cells, metastatic process, and treatment response.
<br><I>R. K. Jain</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.527"></a>
<p><h3>HST.527 Blood Vessels and Endothelial Phenotypes in Health and Disease
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><img align="bottom" width=16 height=16 alt="Subject Cancelled" title="Subject Cancelled" src="/icns/buttonx.gif"> <i><b>Subject Cancelled</b></i> <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Overview of the endothelium as a model system for understanding biological complexity in health and disease. Emphasis placed on: mechanisms of endothelial cell heterogeneity, including genetic and microenvironmental determinants; the role of endothelial cell trafficking, hemostasis, barrier function, antigen presentation and vasomotor tone; and the role of endothelial cell dysfunction in disease, including tumors, sickle cell disease, pulmonary hypertension, veno-occlusive disease of the liver, thrombotic microangiopathies and xenotransplanation. Additional topics covered include novel proteomic and genomic strategies for mapping endothelial cell phenotypes, evolutionary (Darwinian) principles, and complexity theory. Knowledge of introductory biology or physiology, and biochemistry or molecular biology required.
<br><I>W. Aird, G. Garcia-Cardena</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.531"></a>
<p><h3>HST.531 Medical Physics of Proton Radiation Therapy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M EVE (4.30-6 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E25">E25-119</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Acceleration of protons for radiation therapy; introduction into advanced techniques such as laser acceleration and dielectric wall acceleration. Topics include the interactions of protons with the patient, Monte Carlo simulation, and dose calculation methods; biological aspects of proton therapy, relative biological effectiveness (RBE), and the role of contaminating neutrons; treatment planning and treatment optimization methods, and intensity-modulated proton therapy (IMPT); the effect of organ motion and its compensation by use of image-guided treatment techniques; general dosimetry and advanced <i>in-vivo</i> dosimetry methods, including PET/CT and prompt gamma measurements. Outlook into therapy with heavier ions. Includes practical demonstrations at the Proton Therapy Center of the Massachusetts General Hospital.
<br><I>J. Unkelbach, J. Schuemann</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.535"></a>
<p><h3>HST.535 Principles and Practice of Tissue Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-6
<br><img align="bottom" width=16 height=16 alt="Subject Cancelled" title="Subject Cancelled" src="/icns/buttonx.gif"> <i><b>Subject Cancelled</b></i> <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Leaders in the field present the principles and practice of tissue engineering (and regenerative medicine). Topics include the principles underlying strategies for employing select exogenous cells, biomaterial scaffolds, soluble regulators or their genes, and mechanical loading for the regeneration of tissues and organs <i>in vitro</i> and <i>in vivo</i>. Differentiated cell types and stem cells are compared and contrasted for this application, as are natural and synthetic scaffolds. Covers the rationale for employing selected growth factors and examines the methods for incorporating their genes into the scaffolds. Discusses the influence of environmental factors, including mechanical loading and culture conditions. Presents methods for fabricating tissue-engineered products and devices for implantation. Addresses the federal regulatory status of tissue-engineered products, as well as strategies for introducing such products into the clinic. Examples of procedures currently employed clinically are analyzed as case studies. All sessions are webcast to the world and archived for open access review at any time.
<br><I>M. Spector</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.540"></a>
<p><h3>HST.540J Human Physiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m7a.html#7.20">7.20J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Comprehensive subject in human physiology, emphasizing the molecular basis and applied aspects of organ function and regulation in health and disease. Includes a review of cell structure and function, as well as the mechanisms by which the endocrine and nervous systems integrate cellular metabolism. Special emphasis on examining the cardiovascular, pulmonary, gastrointestinal, and renal systems.
<br><I>M. Krieger, D. Sabatini</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.541"></a>
<p><h3>HST.541J Cellular Biophysics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.794">2.794J</A>, <A HREF="m6b.html#6.521">6.521J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.470">20.470J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m2b.html#2.791">2.791J</A>, <A HREF="m6a.html#6.021">6.021J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.370">20.370J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>; <a href="m2a.html#2.005">2.005</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.002">6.002</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.003">6.003</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.071">6.071</a>, <a href="m10a.html#10.301">10.301</a>, <a href="m20a.html#20.110">20.110</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 5-2-5
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Meets with undergraduate subject 6.021J. Requires the completion of more advanced home problems and/or an additional project.
<br><I>D. M. Freeman, J. Han</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.542"></a>
<p><h3>HST.542J Quantitative Systems Physiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.792">2.792J</A>, <A HREF="m6a.html#6.022">6.022J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.371">20.371J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m2b.html#2.796">2.796J</A>, <A HREF="m6b.html#6.522">6.522J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.471">20.471J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-2-6
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/6.022j/www/">http://web.mit.edu/6.022j/www/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-124</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E25">E25-117</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E25">E25-117</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Application of the principles of energy and mass flow to major human organ systems. Mechanisms of regulation and homeostasis. Anatomical, physiological and pathophysiological features of the cardiovascular, respiratory and renal systems. Systems, features and devices that are most illuminated by the methods of physical sciences. Laboratory work includes some animal studies. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>R. G. Mark, C. M. Stultz</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=HST.542');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.543"></a>
<p><h3>HST.543 Cardiac Biophysics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.021">6.021</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>In depth review of contemporary theories in the physics of the heart. Overview of cardiac physiology, including an in depth examination of cardiac excitation and excitation-contraction coupling. Cardiac membrane channels, the action potential (Hodgkin-Huxley and Luo-Rudy models), and action potential propagation (cable and bidomain models). Arrhythmias, drugs, and defibrillation. Relies heavily on the current literature in the field. Follows Harvard FAS schedule.
<br><I>K. K. Parker</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.544"></a>
<p><h3>HST.544J Fields, Forces, and Flows in Biological Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.795">2.795J</A>, <A HREF="m6b.html#6.561">6.561J</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.539">10.539J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.430">20.430J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.013">6.013</a>, <a href="m2a.html#2.005">2.005</a>, <a href="m10a.html#10.302">10.302</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Molecular diffusion, diffusion-reaction, conduction, convection in biological systems; fields in heterogeneous media; electrical double layers; Maxwell stress tensor, electrical forces in physiological systems. Fluid and solid continua: equations of motion useful for porous, hydrated biological tissues. Case studies of membrane transport, electrode interfaces, electrical, mechanical, and chemical transduction in tissues, convective-diffusion/reaction, electrophoretic, electroosmotic flows in tissues/MEMs, and ECG. Electromechanical and physicochemical interactions in cells and biomaterials; musculoskeletal, cardiovascular, and other biological and clinical examples.
<br><I>M. Bathe, A. J. Grodzinsky, R. D. Kamm</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.545"></a>
<p><h3>HST.545 Physiological Systems Analysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A survey of systems theory with applications from bioengineering and physiology. Analysis: differential equations, linear and nonlinear systems, stability, the complementary nature of time and frequency domain methods, feedback, and biological oscillations. Applications: nerve function, muscle dynamics, cardiovascular regulation. Laboratory: neural models, feedback control systems, properties of muscle, cardiovascular function. Follows Harvard FAS calendar.
<br><I>D. M. Merfeld</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.557"></a>
<p><h3>HST.557J Molecular Simulations
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6b.html#6.582">6.582J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6b.html#6.502">6.502J</A>, <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.457">HST.457J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>; <a href="m6a.html#6.041">6.041</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.042">6.042</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the basic concepts underlying dynamical simulations of proteins and nucleic acids. Basic definitions of components that form biological systems used to develop physical models that describe the dynamics of biomolecules. Topics include classical statistical thermodynamics for calculation of macroscopic observables, normal-mode analyses of protein dynamics, and thermodynamic perturbation theory. Emphasizes actual techniques and algorithms used for such calculations. Prior knowledge of biochemistry is not required. Students taking the graduate version complete an additional project.
<br><I>C. M. Stultz</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.560"></a>
<p><h3>HST.560J Radiation Biophysics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m22b.html#22.55">22.55J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m22a.html#22.055">22.055</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=24">24-115</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides a background in sources of radiation with an emphasis on terrestrial and space environments and on industrial production. Discusses experimental approaches to evaluating biological effects resulting from irradiation regimes differing in radiation type, dose and dose-rate.  Effects at the molecular, cellular, organism, and population level are examined.  Literature is reviewed identifying gaps in our understanding of the health effects of radiation, and responses of regulatory bodies to these gaps is discussed. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>Staff</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=HST.560');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.561"></a>
<p><h3>HST.561J Noninvasive Imaging in Biology and Medicine
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m9a.html#9.173">9.173J</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.483">20.483J</A>, <A HREF="m22b.html#22.56">22.56J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>, <a href="m8a.html#8.03">8.03</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Background in the theory and application of noninvasive imaging methods in biology and medicine, with emphasis on neuroimaging. Focuses on the modalities most frequently used in scientific research (x-ray CT, PET/SPECT, MRI, and optical imaging), and includes discussion of molecular imaging approaches used in conjunction with these scanning methods. Lectures are supplemented by in-class discussions of problems in research and demonstrations of imaging systems.
<br><I>A. Jasanoff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.563"></a>
<p><h3>HST.563 Imaging Biophysics and Clinical Applications
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>, <a href="m8a.html#8.03">8.03</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-1-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the connections and distinctions among  various imaging modalities (x-ray, optical, ultrasound, MRI, PET, SPECT, EEG), common goals of biomedical imaging, broadly defined target of biomedical imaging, and the current practical and economic landscape of biomedical imaging research. Emphasis on applications of imaging research.  Final project consists of student groups writing mock grant applications for  biomedical imaging research project, modeled after an exploratory National Institutes of Health (NIH) grant application.
<br><I>C. Catana, A. Kumar, A. Guimaraes</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.565"></a>
<p><h3>HST.565 Molecular Imaging using SPECT and PET-CT
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers the physical, mathematical and instrumentation basics of positron emission tomography / computed tomography (PET-CT), and single photon emission tomography (SPECT). Topics include particles and photon interactions, nuclear counting statistics, gamma cameras, and computed tomography as it pertains to SPECT and PET (including PET-CT, PET-MR, and time-of-flight PET). Discusses the clinical applications of PET in molecular imaging of the brain, the heart, and cancer. Includes a practical demonstration of SPECT and PET-CT imaging at the Massachusetts General Hospital. Considers the ways in which these imaging techniques are rooted in physics, engineering, and mathematics.
<br><I>G. El Fakhri</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.569"></a>
<p><h3>HST.569 Biomedical Optics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Calculus
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to physics and engineering of optical technologies and their applications in medicine and biology. Propagation of light in tissue, bright field, dark field, phase contrast, DIC, fluorescence, Raman, confocal, two-photon, low-coherence, spectral microscopy, and speckle. Current trends in microscopy and optical imaging. Appropriate for upper-level undergraduates and graduate students in life sciences as well as engineering. Includes lectures, seminars, and occasional guest lectures. Grading based on midterm and final report. Report analyzes a specific technological need in medicine or biology and proposes a solution. Opportunity to pursue implementation of the solution as a project in the following term is available.
<br><I>B. Vakoc, B. E. Bouma, G. J. Tearney, S. H. Yun</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.576"></a>
<p><h3>HST.576J Topics in Neural Signal Processing
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m9a.html#9.272">9.272J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img align="bottom" width=16 height=16 alt="Subject Cancelled" title="Subject Cancelled" src="/icns/buttonx.gif"> <i><b>Subject Cancelled</b></i> <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents signal processing and statistical methods used to study neural systems and analyze neurophysiological data. Topics include state-space modeling formulated using the Bayesian Chapman-Kolmogorov system, theory of point processes, EM algorithm, Bayesian and sequential Monte Carlo methods. Applications include dynamic analyses of neural encoding, neural spike train decoding, studies of neural receptive field plasticity, algorithms for neural prosthetic control, EEG and MEG source localization. Students should know introductory probability theory and statistics. Alternate years.
<br><I>E. N. Brown</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.580"></a>
<p><h3>HST.580J Data Acquisition and Image Reconstruction in MRI
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6b.html#6.556">6.556J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.011">6.011</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Applies analysis of signals and noise in linear systems, sampling, and Fourier properties to magnetic resonance (MR) imaging acquisition and reconstruction. Provides adequate foundation for MR physics to enable study of RF excitation design, efficient Fourier sampling, parallel encoding, reconstruction of non-uniformly sampled data, and the impact of hardware imperfections on reconstruction performance. Surveys active areas of MR research. Assignments include Matlab-based work with real data. Includes visit to a scan site for human MR studies.
<br><I>E. Adalsteinsson</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.582"></a>
<p><h3>HST.582J Biomedical Signal and Image Processing
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6b.html#6.555">6.555J</A>, <A HREF="m16a.html#16.456">16.456J</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.003">6.003</a>, <a href="m2a.html#2.004">2.004</a>, <a href="m16a.html#16.004">16.004</a>, or <a href="m18a.html#18.085">18.085</a>
<br>Units: 3-6-3
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/6.555/www/">http://web.mit.edu/6.555/www/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-114</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>W11-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=14">14-0637</a>) or <i>F11-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=14">14-0637</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Fundamentals of digital signal processing with particular emphasis on problems in biomedical research and clinical medicine. Basic principles and algorithms for data acquisition, imaging, filtering, and feature extraction. Laboratory projects provide practical experience in processing physiological data, with examples from cardiology, speech processing, and medical imaging. 6 Engineering Design Points.
<br><I>J. Greenberg, E. Adalsteinsson, W. Wells</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=HST.582');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.583"></a>
<p><h3>HST.583 Functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging: Data Acquisition and Analysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides information relevant to the conduct and interpretation of human brain mapping studies. In-depth coverage of the physics of image formation, mechanisms of image contrast, and the physiological basis for image signals. Parenchymal and cerebrovascular neuroanatomy and application of sophisticated structural analysis algorithms for segmentation and registration of functional data discussed. Additional topics include fMRI experimental design including block design, event related and exploratory data analysis methods, and building and applying statistical models for fMRI data. Human subject issues including informed consent, institutional review board requirements and safety in the high field environment are presented. Twice weekly lectures and weekly laboratory and discussion sessions. Laboratory will include fMRI data acquisition sessions and data analysis workshops. Assignments include reading of both textbook chapters and primary literature as well as fMRI data analysis in the laboratory. Probability, linear algebra, differential equations, and introductory or college-level subjects in neurobiology, physiology, and physics required.
<br><I>R. L. Gollub, L. Wald, B. Dickerson, K. Helmer, R. Banzett, J. R. Melcher, R. Savoy, D. Salat, M. Vangel, D. Greve, A. Yendiki, J. Mandeville</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.584"></a>
<p><h3>HST.584J Magnetic Resonance Analytic, Biochemical, and Imaging Techniques
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="H-Level Grad Credit" title="H-Level Grad Credit" src="/icns/hlevel.gif">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m22b.html#22.561">22.561J</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-12
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W EVE (7-10 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E25">E25-117</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to basic NMR theory. Examples of biochemical data obtained using NMR summarized along with other related experiments. Detailed study of NMR imaging techniques includes discussions of basic cross-sectional image reconstruction, image contrast, flow and real-time imaging, and hardware design considerations. Exposure to laboratory NMR spectroscopic and imaging equipment included.
<br><I>L. Wald, K. Setsompop</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.590"></a>
<p><h3>HST.590 Biomedical Engineering Seminar Series
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 1-0-0 [P/D/F]
<br>URL: <a href="http://hst590.pbworks.com/">http://hst590.pbworks.com/</a>
<br>Select thursdays. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>R EVE (5-7 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E25">E25-117</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminars focused on the development of professional skills. Each term focuses on a different topic, resulting in a repeating cycle that covers medical ethics, responsible conduct of research, written and oral technical communication, and translational issues. Includes guest lectures, case studies, interactive small group discussions, and role-playing simulations.
<br><I>HST Faculty</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.598"></a>
<p><h3>HST.598 Research in Health Sciences and Technology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged
<br>Consult instructor <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>For undergraduates desiring to carry on substantial projects of their own choosing in biomedical sciences or engineering. Work may be of experimental, theoretical, or design nature. A project proposal is required at time of registration.
<br>Consult HST Faculty<br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.599"></a>
<p><h3>HST.599 Research in Health Sciences and Technology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>Consult instructor <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>For students conducting research in HST, in cases where the assigned research is approved for academic credit by the department. Hours arranged with research supervisor.
<br>Consult HST Faculty<br>No textbook information available (IAP 2014); No required or recommended textbooks (Spring 2014)
</p><!--end-->
