<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Special Programs<br>Spring
2014</h1><div id="contentmini"><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>Interphase, Program XL, Terrascope, FASI</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<p><a href="#PIP">Interphase</a><br><a href="#PXL">Seminar XL</a><br><a href="#ISP">Terrascope</a><br><a href="#FASI">Freshman/Alumni Summer Internship Program</a>
<h2><a name="PIP"></a>Interphase: Pre-Freshman Summer Program</h2>
<p><b><a href="http://web.mit.edu/ome/programs-services/interphase/index.html"><i>Interphase Home</i></a></b>
<a name="SP.100"></a>
<p><h3>SP.100 Interphase
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Commitment to register as a freshman in the Fall
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Interphase is a seven-week program designed to enhance the academic success of students entering MIT. The program has a dual focus: it gives students an introduction to the MIT experience by exposing them to the rigors of a full subject load while simultaneously preparing them for academic success beyond MIT. The program includes calculus; chemistry; physical education;  physics; writing, oral presentation and teamwork skills; and supporting academic activities, including small-group learning. Students can earn transcript credit for subjects taken in the program, sometimes resulting in advanced placement in corresponding subjects taken in the Fall. Activities include day trips to area cultural, recreational, and business sites. Students participate in a range of personal and educational development seminars and activities designed to ensure their smooth transition to college life.
<br><I>T. Stevens</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<p><p>&nbsp;</p>
<h2><a name="PXL"></a>Seminar XL</h2>
<p><b><a href="http://web.mit.edu/ome/programs-services/seminar-xl/index.html"><i>Seminar XL Home</i></a></b>
<a name="SP.110"></a>
<p><h3>SP.110 Program XL: You Can Be a Success at MIT
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: First-year undergraduate standing
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>
<a name="SP.120"></a>
<h3>SP.120 Program XL: You Can Be a Success at MIT
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: First-year undergraduate standing
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>An academic enrichment program for first-year students, XL utilizes the innovative and effective small-group learning concept to enhance students' academic performance in calculus and science. Students meet in study groups of five to six participants with facilitators trained in effective classroom techniques and concept focus. The study groups help students to reinforce concepts learned in the regular curriculum, and help them to gain mastery of concepts and problems that are often more challenging than those dealt with during lecture. The small study group format emphasizes the full participation of each student with the facilitator acting as a guide. The regularity of weekly meetings enhances the students' understanding of MIT's academic expectations. After the initial meetings, students are encouraged to take more responsibility and to lead the group in problem-solving sessions, which helps to maximize their own learning. Each study group meets for a minimum of three hours each week. The meeting time is set by the XL facilitator based on students' schedules.
<br><I>S. Mtingwa</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<p><p>&nbsp;</p>
<h2><a name="ISP"></a>Terrascope</h2>
<p><b><a href="http://web.mit.edu/terrascope/www/"><i>Terrascope Home</i></a>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?termId=&departmentId=+ISP&subjectCode=&instructorName=&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a>&nbsp;<a href="http://web.mit.edu/is/cert/"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b>
<p>For descriptions of subjects offered through the Terrascope Program, refer to 12.000 Solving Complex Problems and 1.016 Introduction to Earth System Engineering and Science.
<a name="SP.35UR"></a>
<p><h3>SP.35UR Undergraduate Research in Terrascope
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br><I>Staff</I><br>Textbooks arranged individually
</p><!--end-->
<a name="SP.360"></a>
<p><h3>SP.360 Terrascope Radio
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="m1a.html#1.016">1.016</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-168</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>An exploration of radio as a medium of expression and communication, particularly the communication of complex scientific or technical information to general audiences. Examines the ingredients of effective radio programming, drawing extensively on examples from both commercial and public radio. Student teams produce, assemble, narrate, record and broadcast/webcast radio programs on topics related to the complex environmental issue that is the focus of the year's Terrascope subjects. Includes multiple individual writing assignments that explore the constraints and opportunities in radio as a medium. Limited to 12. Terrascope students only.
<br><I>A. W. Epstein</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="SP.3S50"></a>
<p><h3>SP.3S50 Special Subject: Terrascope
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers areas of study not included in the regular Terrascope curriculum. Preference to students in Terrascope.
<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<p><p>&nbsp;</p>
<h2><a name="FASI"></a>Freshman/Alumni Summer Internship Program</h2>
<p><b><a href="http://web.mit.edu/fasip/www/NewPage/"><i>F/ASIP Home</i></a></b>
<a name="SP.800"></a>
<p><h3>SP.800 Freshman/Alumni Summer Internship Program
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Prepares freshmen for summer internships in various companies. Includes workshops on leadership skill development, interviewing, communications, negotiation, and dynamics in the workplace. Upon acceptance to the program, students have readings, writings, discussion, and role-playing exercises. Attendance at the workshops is mandatory.
<br><I>C. Capozzola</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="SP.801"></a>
<p><h3>SP.801 Freshman/Alumni Summer Internship Program II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mSPa.html#SP.800">SP.800</a>
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students who have completed the subject requirements for SP.800 and worked in an approved internship polish their communication skills further by writing reflection papers and giving a formal presentation about their experiences upon their return in the Fall.
<br><I>A. Steinberg</I><br>
</p><!--end-->

<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Science, Technology, and Society<br>Spring
2014</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://web.mit.edu/sts/"><i>STS Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/courseSTS.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=+STS&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>Undergraduate: STS.001-STS.096 <br>plus STS.ThT and STS.ThU</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="mSTSb.html">Graduate: STS.210-STS.910 <br>plus STS.ThG</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<h2>Undergraduate Subjects</h2>
<h3><br>Tier I Subjects</h3>
<a name="STS.001"></a>
<p><h3>STS.001 Technology in American History
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hass5.gif" alt="HASS-D, Category 5" title="HASS-D, Category 5" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-277</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>R4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-277</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A survey of America's transition from a rural, agrarian, and artisan society to one of the world's leading industrial powers. Treats the emergence of industrial capitalism: the rise of the factory system; new forms of power, transport, and communication; the advent of the large industrial corporation; the social relations of production; and the hallmarks of science-based industry. Views technology as part of the larger culture and reveals innovation as a process consisting of a range of possibilities that are chosen or rejected according to the social criteria of the time.
<br><I>M. R. Smith</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=STS.001');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.003"></a>
<p><h3>STS.003 The Rise of Modern Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hass5.gif" alt="HASS-D, Category 5" title="HASS-D, Category 5" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers the development of major fields in the physical and life sciences, from 18th-century Europe through 20th-century America. Examines ideas, institutions, and the social settings of the sciences, with emphasis on how cultural contexts influence scientific concepts and practices.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.004"></a>
<p><h3>STS.004 Intersections: Science, Technology, and the World
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/sts/academic/subjects/sts004-fa13.html">http://web.mit.edu/sts/academic/subjects/sts004-fa13.html</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces students to multidisciplinary studies in Science, Technology, and Society (STS), using four case studies to illustrate a broad range of approaches to basic principles of STS studies. Case studies vary from year to year, but always include a current MIT event. Other topics are drawn from legal and political conflicts, and arts and communication media. Teaching modes include guest presenters, discussion groups, field activities, visual media, and a practicum style of learning. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>R. H. Williams</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.006"></a>
<p><h3>STS.006J Bioethics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hass2.gif" alt="HASS-D, Category 2" title="HASS-D, Category 2" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m24a.html#24.06">24.06J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-155</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-180</a>) or <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-180</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-180</a>) or <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-167</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-167</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Considers ethical questions that have arisen from the growth of biomedical research and the health-care industry since World War II. Should doctors be allowed to help patients end their lives? If so, when and how? Should embryos be cloned for research and/or reproduction? Should parents be given control over the genetic make-up of their children? What types of living things are appropriate to use as research subjects? How should we distribute scarce and expensive medical resources? Draws on philosophy, history, and anthropology to show how problems in bioethics can be approached from a variety of perspectives.
<br><I>J. Markovits, N. Schull</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.007"></a>
<p><h3>STS.007 Technology in History
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hass5.gif" alt="HASS-D, Category 5" title="HASS-D, Category 5" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers theories of the interactions between historical and technological change; relations between the histories of science and of technology; purported turning points such as the Neolithic, Industrial, and Information Revolutions; case studies from a wide range of times and places; and connections across time and space. Lectures supplemented by student presentations. Frequent writing, rewriting, and small group work. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>C. Mavhunga</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.008"></a>
<p><h3>STS.008 Technology and Experience
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the "inner history" of technology: how it affects intimate aspects of human experience from sociological, psychological and anthropological perspectives.  Topics include how the internet transforms our experience of time, space, privacy, and social engagement; how entertainment media affects attention, emotion, and creativity; how medical technologies alter the experience of illness, reproduction, and mortality; how pharmaceuticals reshape identity, mood, pain, and pleasure. In-class discussion of readings, short written assignments, final project. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.009"></a>
<p><h3>STS.009 Evolution and Society
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hass4.gif" alt="HASS-D, Category 4" title="HASS-D, Category 4" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides a broad conceptual and historical introduction to scientific theories of evolution and their place in the wider culture.  Embraces historical, scientific and anthropological/cultural perspectives grounded in relevant developments in the biological sciences since 1800 that are largely responsible for the development of the modern theory of evolution by natural selection.  Students read key texts, analyze key debates (e.g. Darwinian debates in the 19th century, and the creation controversies in the 20th century) and give class presentations.
<br><I>J. Durant</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.010"></a>
<p><h3>STS.010 Neuroscience and Society
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hass4.gif" alt="HASS-D, Category 4" title="HASS-D, Category 4" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores social relevance of neuroscience, considering how emerging areas of brain research reflect and reshape social attitudes and agendas. Topics include brain imaging and popular media; neuroscience of empathy, trust, and moral reasoning; new fields of neuroeconomics and neuromarketing; ethical implications of neurotechnologies such as cognitive enhancement pharmaceuticals; neuroscience in the courtroom; and neuroscientific recasting of social problems such as addiction and violence. Guest lectures by neuroscientists, class discussion, and weekly readings in neuroscience, popular media, and science studies.
<br><I>N. Schull</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<h3><br>Tier II Subjects</h3>
<a name="STS.023"></a>
<p><h3>STS.023J Science, Caste and Gender in India
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mWGSa.html#WGS.226">WGS.226J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>R1-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-242</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the influence of social and cultural determinants (colonialism, nationalism, caste, class, and gender) on modern science and technology in British colonial and postcolonial India. Discusses the relationship of scientific progress to colonial expansions and nationalist aspirations. Explores the nature of scientific institutions within a social, cultural, and political contexts, and how science and technology have impacted Indian society.
<br><I>A. Sur</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.025"></a>
<p><h3>STS.025J Making the Modern World: The Industrial Revolution in Global Perspective
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Ha.html#21H.285">21H.285J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Global survey of the great transformation in history known as the "Industrial Revolution." Topics include origins of mechanized production, the factory system, steam propulsion, electrification, mass communications, mass production and automation. Emphasis on the transfer of technology and its many adaptations around the world. Countries treated include Great Britain, France, Germany, the US, Sweden, Russia, Japan, China, and India. Includes brief reflection papers and a final paper.
<br><I>M. R. Smith</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.027"></a>
<p><h3>STS.027J The Civil War and the Emergence of Modern America: 1861-1890
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Ha.html#21H.205">21H.205J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mSTSb.html#STS.427">STS.427</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W EVE (7-10 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=14">14N-112</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Using the American Civil War as a baseline, considers what it means to become "modern" by exploring the war's material and manpower needs, associated key technologies, and how both influenced the United States' entrance into the age of "Big Business." Readings include material on steam transportation, telegraphic communications, arms production, naval innovation, food processing, medicine, public health, management methods, and the mass production of everything from underwear to uniforms &ndash; all essential ingredients of modernity. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>M. R. Smith</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=STS.027');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.029"></a>
<p><h3>STS.029J The Civil War and Reconstruction
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Ha.html#21H.204">21H.204J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mSTSb.html#STS.423">STS.423</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Anti-slavery and the intensification of sectionalism in the 1850s; the secession crisis; political and military developments in the Civil War years; key technological innovations (including medicine); why the North won; and the political, economic, and social legacies of the conflict.
<br><I>M. R. Smith</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.032"></a>
<p><h3>STS.032 Energy, Environment, and Society
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines national and global energy debates, namely energy security, climate change, and energy access. Explores technological, market, environmental, cultural and political "fixes" to the energy question, as well as a wide variety of energy forms and stakeholders. Evaluates development, nuclear security, environment ethics, and conflicts between energy and food security. Includes debates, presentations, group projects (in class and in the Cambridge community), grant-writing, and individual written assignments. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>C. Mavhunga</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.034"></a>
<p><h3>STS.034 Science Communication: A Practical Guide
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops students' abilities to communicate science effectively in a variety of real-world contexts. Covers strategies for dealing with complex areas like theoretical physics, genomics and neuroscience, and addresses challenges in communicating about topics such as climate change and evolution. Projects focus on speaking and writing, being an expert witness, preparing briefings for policy-makers, writing blogs, giving live interviews for broadcast, and creating a prospectus for a science exhibit in the MIT Museum. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>J. Durant</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.035"></a>
<p><h3>STS.035 Exhibiting Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: One CI-H/CI-HW subject, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-2-8
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/sts/academic/subjects/sts035-sp14.html">http://web.mit.edu/sts/academic/subjects/sts035-sp14.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=10">10-150</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>W1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=10">10-150</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Project-based seminar covers key topics in museum communication, including science learning in informal settings, the role of artifacts and interactives, and exhibit evaluation. Students work on a term-long project, organized around the design, fabrication, and installation of an original multimedia exhibit about current scientific research at MIT. Culminates with the project's installation in the MIT Museum's Mark Epstein Innovation Gallery. Limited to 20; preference to students who have taken STS.034.
<br><I>J. Durant</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.042"></a>
<p><h3>STS.042J Einstein, Oppenheimer, Feynman: Physics in the 20th Century
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m8a.html#8.225">8.225J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the changing roles of physics and physicists during the 20th century. Topics range from relativity theory and quantum mechanics to high-energy physics and cosmology. Examines the development of modern physics within shifting institutional, cultural, and political contexts, such as physics in Imperial Britain, Nazi Germany, US efforts during World War II, and physicists' roles during the Cold War. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>D. I. Kaiser</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.043"></a>
<p><h3>STS.043 Technology and Self: Science, Technology, and Memoir
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mSTSb.html#STS.443">STS.443</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-7
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/sts/academic/subjects/sts043-sp14.html">http://web.mit.edu/sts/academic/subjects/sts043-sp14.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T9-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-061</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on the memoir as a window onto the relationship of the scientist, engineer, and technologist to his or her work. Studies the subjective side of technology and the social and psychological dimensions of technological change. Students write about specific objects and their role in their lives - memoir fragments. Readings concern child development theory and the role of technology in development. Explores the connection between material culture, identity, cognitive and emotional development. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 15; no listeners.
<br><I>S. Turkle</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=STS.043');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.044"></a>
<p><h3>STS.044 Technology and Self: Things and Thinking
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mSTSb.html#STS.444">STS.444</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-7
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/sts/academic/subjects/sts044-sp14.html">http://web.mit.edu/sts/academic/subjects/sts044-sp14.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-061</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores emotional and intellectual impact of objects. The growing literature on cognition and "things" cuts across anthropology, history, social theory, literature, sociology, and psychology and is of great relevance to science students.  Examines the range of theories, from Mary Douglas in anthropology to D.W. Winnicott in psychoanalytic thinking, that underlies "thing" or "object" analysis. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 15; no listeners.
<br><I>S. Turkle</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=STS.044');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.046"></a>
<p><h3>STS.046J The Science of Race, Sex, and Gender
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Aa.html#21A.103">21A.103J</A>, <A HREF="mWGSa.html#WGS.225">WGS.225J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the role of science and medicine in the origins and evolution of the concepts of race, sex, and gender from the 17th century to the present. Focus on how biological, anthropological, and medical concepts intersect with social, cultural, and political ideas about racial, sexual, and gender difference in the US and globally. Approach is historical and comparative across disciplines emphasizing the different modes of explanation and use of evidence in each field.
<br><I>A. Sur, S. Helmreich</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.048"></a>
<p><h3>STS.048 African Americans in Science, Technology, and Medicine
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A survey of the contributions of African Americans to science, technology, and medicine from colonial times to the present. Explores the impact of concepts, trends, and developments in science, technology, and medicine on the lives of African Americans. Examples include the eugenics movement, the Tuskegee Syphilis Experiment, the debate surrounding racial inheritance, and IQ testing.
<br><I>K. Manning</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.050"></a>
<p><h3>STS.050 The History of MIT
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/sts/academic/subjects/sts050-sp14.html">http://web.mit.edu/sts/academic/subjects/sts050-sp14.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-257</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the history of MIT, from its founding to today, through the lens of the history of science and technology, and vice versa. Topics include William Barton Rogers; educational philosophy; biographies of MIT students and professors; campus, intellectual and organizational development; changing laboratories and practices; and MIT's relationship with Boston, the federal government, and industry. Includes guest lecturers, field trips, and interactive exercises.
<br><I>D. Douglas</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://sisapp.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2014SP&Subject=STS.050');" >Textbooks (Spring 2014)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.056"></a>
<p><h3>STS.056 Science on Screen
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-1-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the linked histories of science, engineering, and documentary film from 1895 to present. In addition to historical study and visual analysis, students produce their own short videos based on archival footage. Provides opportunities to interact with both antiquated and modern technologies of media production and projection. Readings cover topics in film studies, the history of technology, STS, and material culture studies. Includes mandatory weekly screenings and media production assignments, as well as several short writing assignments. Limited to 15.
<br><I>H. R. Shell</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.060"></a>
<p><h3>STS.060J The Anthropology of Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Aa.html#21A.303">21A.303J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Applies the tools of anthropology to examine biology in the age of genomics, biotechnological enterprise, biodiversity conservation, pharmaceutical bioprospecting, and synthetic biology. Examines such social concerns such as bioterrorism, genetic modification, and cloning. Offers an anthropological inquiry into how the substances and explanations of biology &mdash; ecological, organismic, cellular, molecular, genetic, informatic &mdash; are changing. Examines such artifacts as cell lines, biodiversity databases, and artificial life models, and using primary sources in biology, social studies of the life sciences, and literary and cinematic materials, asks how we might answer Erwin Schrodinger's 1944 question, "What Is Life?", today.
<br><I>S. Helmreich</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.062"></a>
<p><h3>STS.062J Drugs, Politics, and Culture
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Aa.html#21A.305">21A.305J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the relationship between drugs, politics, and society in cross-cultural perspective; use of mind-altering and habit-forming substances by "traditional societies"; the development of a global trade in sugar, opium, and cocaine with the rise of capitalism; and the use and abuse of alcohol, LSD, and Prozac in the US. Finishes by looking at the war on drugs, shifting attitudes to tobacco, and by evaluating America's drug laws.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.064"></a>
<p><h3>STS.064J DV Lab: Documenting Science through Video and New Media
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Aa.html#21A.550">21A.550J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-3-12
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introductory exploration of documentary film theory and production, focusing on documentaries about science, engineering, and related fields. Students engage in digital video production as well as social and media analysis of science documentaries. Readings drawn from social studies of science as well as from documentary film theory. Uses documentary video making as a tool to explore the worlds of science and engineering, as well as a tool for thinking analytically about media itself and the social worlds in which science is embedded. Class includes a lab component devoted to digital video production in addition to class time. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>C. Walley, C. Boebel</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.065"></a>
<p><h3>STS.065J The Anthropology of Sound
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Aa.html#21A.505">21A.505J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.407">CMS.407</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the ways humans experience sound and how perceptions and technologies of sound emerge from cultural, economic, and historical worlds. Consider how the sound/noise boundary has been imagined, created, and modeled across sociocultural and scientific contexts. Learn how environmental, linguistic, and musical sounds are construed cross-culturally as well as the rise of telephony, architectural acoustics, sound recording, and the globalized travel of these technologies. Questions of sound ownership, property, authorship, and copyright in the digital age are also addressed.
<br><I>S. Helmreich</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.070"></a>
<p><h3>STS.070J Language and Technology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m24b.html#24.913">24.913J</A>, <A HREF="m21Aa.html#21A.503">21A.503J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines cultural impact of communication technologies, from basic literacy to cell phones, and computer-based social networks on patterns of verbal interaction. Introduces theories and methods of linguistic anthropology pertinent to technologies that make it possible for people to communicate across distances in space and time. Students develop their own research projects exploring the cultural dimensions of technologically enhanced communication. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>G. Jones</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.071"></a>
<p><h3>STS.071J Cross-Cultural Investigations: Technology and Development
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mECa.html#EC.702">EC.702J</A>, <A HREF="m21Aa.html#21A.801">21A.801J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mECa.html#EC.792">EC.792J</A>, <A HREF="m21Aa.html#21A.839">21A.839J</A>, <A HREF="mSTSb.html#STS.481">STS.481J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Enhances cross-cultural understanding through discussion of practical, ethical, and epistemological issues in conducting social science and applied research in foreign countries or unfamiliar communities. Includes research practicum to help students develop interviewing, participant-observation, and other qualitative research skills, as well as critical discussion of case studies. Open to all interested students, but intended particularly for those planning to undertake exploratory research or applied work abroad. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>C. Walley</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.072"></a>
<p><h3>STS.072J Nuclear Forces and Missile Defenses
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m17b.html#17.475">17.475J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m17b.html#17.476">17.476J</A>, <A HREF="mSTSb.html#STS.435">STS.435J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the assessment of strategic nuclear forces. Emphasizes the development of force requirements. Methods for analyzing alternative force postures in terms of missions, effectiveness, and cost. The history of the US-Soviet strategic competition provides the backdrop against which the evolution of nuclear strategy and forces is considered. Students taking the graduate version are expected to complete additional assignments.
<br><I>T. Postol</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.074"></a>
<p><h3>STS.074J Art, Craft, Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Aa.html#21A.501">21A.501J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m21Aa.html#21A.509">21A.509</A>, <A HREF="mSTSb.html#STS.474">STS.474</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines how people learn, practice, and evaluate traditional and contemporary craft techniques. Social science theories of design, embodiment, apprenticeship learning, skill, labor, expertise, and tacit knowledge are used to explore distinctions among art, craft, and science. Also discusses the commoditization of craft into market goods, collectible art, and tourism industries. Ethnographic and historical case studies include textiles, Shaker furniture, glassblowing, quilting, cheesemaking, industrial design, home and professional cooking, factory and laboratory work, CAD/CAM. Demonstrations, optional field trips, and/or hands-on craft projects may be included. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>H. Paxson</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.075"></a>
<p><h3>STS.075J Technology and Culture
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Aa.html#21A.500">21A.500J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-7
<br>URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/anthropology/course_desc/index.html#340">http://web.mit.edu/anthropology/course_desc/index.html#340</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>R10-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-180</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the intersections of technology, culture, and politics in a variety of social and historical settings ranging from 19th-century factories to 21st-century techno dance floors, from Victorian London to anything-goes Las Vegas. Discussions and readings organized around three questions: what cultural effects and risks follow from treating biology as technology; how computers have changed the way we think about ourselves and others; and how politics are built into our infrastructures. Explores the forces behind technological and cultural change; how technological and cultural artifacts are understood and used by different communities; and whether, in what ways, and for whom technology has produced a better world. Limited to 40.
<br><I>S. Helmreich, H. Paxson</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.076"></a>
<p><h3>STS.076J Technology and Policy of Weapons Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m17b.html#17.477">17.477J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines in detail the technology of nuclear weapons systems. Topics include nuclear weapons design, effects, targeting, and delivery; ballistic and air breathing missile propulsion and guidance; communications and early warning techniques and systems; and anti-missile, air, and submarine systems. Combines the discussion of technical materials with the national security policy issues raised by the capabilities of these technologies. Considers security issues from the distinct and often conflicting perspectives of technologists, military planners, and political leaders. Subject fulfills the undergraduate public policy requirement in the Political Science major and minor.
<br><I>T. Postol</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.082"></a>
<p><h3>STS.082J Science, Technology, and Public Policy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" title="Not offered academic year 2014-2015" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m17a.html#17.309">17.309J</A>, <A HREF="mESDa.html#ESD.082">ESD.082J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m17a.html#17.310">17.310</A>, <A HREF="mESDa.html#ESD.103">ESD.103</A>, <A HREF="mSTSb.html#STS.482">STS.482</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analysis of issues at the intersection of science, technology, public policy, and business. Cases drawn from antitrust and intellectual property rights; health and environmental policy; defense procurement and strategy; strategic trade and industrial policy; and R&D funding. Structured around theories of political economy, modified to take into account integration of uncertain technical information into public and private decision-making. Meets with 17.310 when offered concurrently. Limited to 18.
<br><I>K. Oye</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.085"></a>
<p><h3>STS.085J Ethics and the Law on the Electronic Frontier
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6c.html#6.805">6.805J</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6c.html#6.805">6.805</A>, <A HREF="mSTSb.html#STS.487">STS.487</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>URL: <a href="http://www-swiss.ai.mit.edu/6.805/">http://www-swiss.ai.mit.edu/6.805/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies the growth of computer and communications technology and the new legal and ethical challenges that reflect tensions between individual rights and societal needs. Topics: computer crime; intellectual property restrictions on software; encryption, privacy, and national security; academic freedom and free speech. Students meet and question technologists, activists, law enforcement agents, journalists, and legal experts. Extensive use of the web for readings and other materials. Students engage in extensive written and oral communication exercises. STS.085 meets with 6.805 and carries HASS credit. 6.805 may be used as an Engineering Concentration Elective. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>H. Abelson, M. Fischer, D. Weitzner</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.086"></a>
<p><h3>STS.086J Cultures of Computing
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Aa.html#21A.504">21A.504J</A>, <A HREF="mWGSa.html#WGS.276">WGS.276J</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W12.30-3.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-135</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines computers anthropologically, as artifacts revealing the social orders and cultural practices that create them. Students read classic texts in computer science along with cultural analyses of computing history and contemporary configurations. Explores the history of automata, automation and capitalist manufacturing; cybernetics and WWII operations research; artificial intelligence and gendered subjectivity; robots, cyborgs, and artificial life; creation and commoditization of the personal computer; the growth of the Internet as a military, academic, and commercial project; hackers and gamers; technobodies and virtual sociality. Emphasis is placed on how ideas about gender and other social differences shape labor practices, models of cognition, hacking culture, and social media.
<br><I>S. Helmreich</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.087"></a>
<p><h3>STS.087 Biography in Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T EVE (7-10 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-220</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>An examination of biography as a literary genre to be employed in the history of science. The use of biography in different historical periods to illuminate aspects of the development of science. A critical analysis of autobiography, archival sources, and the oral tradition as materials in the construction of biographies of scientists. Published biographies of scientists constitute the major reading, but attention is given to unpublished biographical sources as well. Comparison is drawn between biography as a literary form in the history of science and in other disciplines.
<br><I>K. Manning</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.089"></a>
<p><h3>STS.089 Technology and Innovation in Africa
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> )
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-162</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines development, environment, public health, and politics in Africa, past and present. Studies indigenous innovations, such as plant/animal domestication, fire making, ecology, mining/metallurgy, architecture, textiles, music, medicine, and finance. Explores impact of incoming factors (e.g., slave trade, colonialism, development aid) on indigenous innovation. Discusses the uses Africans assign to incoming technologies (such as guns, cameras, and information and communication technology) and ideas like democracy and human rights.
<br><I>C. Mavhunga</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.091"></a>
<p><h3>STS.091 Critical Issues in STS
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassT.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ( <img src="/icns/hassE.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> ) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: One STS Tier I subject or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-10
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analyzes current events and issues from the perspective of Science, Technology and Society. Students explore a chosen topic and develop their own unique analysis, applying the ideas and concepts of STS. Draws on the recent work of STS faculty, along with the concepts and methods that inspired them. Includes current and classic readings in STS; frequent short writing assignments, oral presentations, and collective discussion; and an independently defined research project. Occasional guest visits by STS faculty and advanced graduate students.
<br><I>N. Schull</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<h3><br>Special Subjects</h3>
<a name="STS.S20"></a><a name="STS.S21"></a>
<p><h3>STS.S20, STS.S21 Special Subject: Science, Technology and Society
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Addresses subject matter in Science, Technology and Society that is not offered in the regular curriculum.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<h3><br>Research</h3>
<a name="STS.095"></a><a name="STS.096"></a>
<p><h3>STS.095, STS.096 Independent Study in Science, Technology, and Society
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" title="Not offered academic year 2013-2014" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br><b>STS.095:</b> TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>For students who wish to pursue special studies or projects with a member of the Program in Science, Technology, and Society. STS.095 is letter-graded; STS.096 is P/D/F.
<br><I>Staff</I><br><b>STS.095:</b> No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.UR"></a>
<p><h3>STS.UR Undergraduate Research
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>No required or recommended textbooks
<a name="STS.URG"></a>
<h3>STS.URG Undergraduate Research
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Undergraduate research opportunities in the STS Program.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>Textbooks arranged individually (IAP 2014); No required or recommended textbooks (Spring 2014)
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.THT"></a>
<p><h3>STS.THT Undergraduate Thesis Tutorial
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 1-0-5
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Definition and early-stage work on thesis project leading to STS.ThU. Taken during first term of student's two-term commitment to thesis project. Student works closely with STS faculty tutor. Required of all candidates for an STS degree.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="STS.THU"></a>
<p><h3>STS.THU Undergraduate Thesis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: STS.ThT
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Completion of work of the senior major thesis under the supervision of a faculty tutor. Includes gathering materials, preparing draft chapters, giving an oral presentation of thesis progress to faculty evaluators early in the term, and writing and revising the final text. Students meet at the end of the term with faculty evaluators to discuss the successes and limitations of the project. Required of all candidates for an STS degree.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>Textbooks arranged individually (IAP 2014); No required or recommended textbooks (Spring 2014)
</p><!--end-->
</td></tr></table>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
